Warsaw Says Priests' Deaths Weren't Politically Provoked
LEAD: The Polish Government said today that there was no evidence indicating that the recent deaths of two pro-Solidarity priests were political provocations.


What's Gorbachev Paid? $30,000 and Perks
LEAD: Venturing into the shadowy area of Kremlin leaders' private lives, a youth newspaper in the Soviet republic of Moldavia has published an interview reporting Mikhail S. Gorbachev's salary and defending his wife's stylish wardrobe.


The Easiest Money
LEAD: Ronald Reagan came out of the White House rested up and raring to go.
During his first week out in the world of free enterprise he signed up to write a memoir, compile a book of his speeches and go on the lecture circuit.

Testimony Opens in Murder Trial of Stock Analyst
LEAD: The first wife of a Wall Street stock analyst accused of killing his second wife testified today that she decided not to tell the police that her former husband had asked her if he could bury the victim in her back yard in Massachusetts.


Greenspan Defends Lifting Rates
LEAD: By raising interest rates substantially in the last 10 months, the Federal Reserve helped extend the nation's long economic expansion, Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, said today.


Alexander Smalley, 79, Retired Executive
LEAD: Alexander Smalley, a retired executive and former labor leader, died Jan. 24 at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a long illness.
He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton, Fla.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
American Cyanamid Co., Wayne, N.J., a chemical research company, said it had sold its Canadian retail fertilizer business to Cargill Ltd. for an undisclosed sum.


Reviews/Music; Carlo Bergonzi's Arias
LEAD: Carlo Bergonzi, who sang at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Sunday afternoon, is now at the career stage that the great tenor Beniamino Gigli had reached in the early 1950's, when Mr.
Bergonzi was starting out.
The voice, aged but not abused, is still recognizably itself; the temperament is authentic, the bond of affection with the public is strong.


BP America Restructures
LEAD: BP America Inc., the United States arm of the British Petroleum Company, said it would unify all of its domestic retail gasoline marketing under the single brand name BP.
The company has also changed the names of most of its American business streams to reinforce the worldwide emphasis on the BP name.

Goody Work Goes to Waring
LEAD: Goody Products, Kearny, N.J., a maker of plastic personal-care products available at the 80,000 or so drug and discount stores around the country, has retained Waring &amp; LaRosa to look after its first major consumer ad campaign.


Mr. Cuomo Cuts, Mr. Koch Bleeds
LEAD: Gov.
Mario Cuomo sent New York City a blunt message in his austere budget proposal: Share the pain.
Now Mayor Edward Koch has come up with an equally blunt response: Pain is one thing; state-inflicted wounds are another.
Who is right?
So far, the Mayor sounds more credible.


Robert Henle, 64, I.B.M. Research Official
LEAD: Robert A. Henle, director of the advanced silicon technology laboratory at the International Business Machines Thomas J. Watson Research Center in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., died of lymphoma Friday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.
He was 64 years old and lived in Clinton Corners, N.Y.

LEAD: Film critics, film makers and film lovers met in this small ski town last week to celebrate the American independent film just when changes in the movie industry are sending an avalanche into the path of such pictures.

EATING WELL
LEAD: WITH minor exceptions, the Federal Government's Recommended Dietary Allowances are the same for people in their 80's as they are for those who in their 40's.
It seems ridiculous on the face of it, but so little work has been done on the nutrient needs of older people that what is available has simply been extrapolated from the work done on adults 50 and under.

Corrections
LEAD: An obituary on Friday about Elizabeth Knowlton, a mountain climber, misstated an accomplishment in her career.
Miss Knowlton climbed peaks in the Himalayas more than 20,000 feet high in 1932, but she was not the first woman to do so; Fanny Bullock Workman of Worcester, Mass., achieved the feat before World War I.

LEAD: Evelyn Lloyd is a single parent living in Manhattan without much money, but she emphasizes, ''I am blessed with a roof over my head and a job to support my two boys.''

W. Paterson Wavers on Namesake
LEAD: Once upon a time, the city of Paterson was so prosperous that two neighboring farming communities longed to be identified with its industrial glory.
And so in 1914 a section of Little Falls seceded and became West Paterson, and in 1916 the residents of Dundee Lake chose the name East Paterson.


U.S. Students Place Low On Math and Science Tests
LEAD: American teen-agers scored last in mathematics and well below the mean in science in an international survey, the Educational Testing Service said yesterday.

Man Charged in Rape of 3 Girls
LEAD: A 52-year-old man who was arrested for exposing himself on a Queens street was charged yesterday with raping three girls at knifepoint in the last month, the police said.


Review/Theater; Two Women as Nearly Anyone Else
LEAD: Kathy Najimy and Mo Gaffney, the authors and stars of ''The Kathy and Mo Show: Parallel Lives,'' are San Diego's amusing answer to Cagney and Lacey, Kate and Allie and other strong-minded pair-bonded women.
Kathy and Mo are not detectives or careerists but playful post-feminist satirists.

Wreck of Argentine Vessel Poses Threat of Oil Spill Off Antarctica
LEAD: An Argentine ship, adrift after running aground off Antarctica, is in danger of spilling more than 250,000 gallons of diesel fuel and causing the continent's first major environmental crisis, officials of the National Science Foundation in Washington reported yesterday.

Don't Be Fooled by South African 'Reforms'; Trouble in Namibia
LEAD: To the Editor:


Europe's Inflation Rises
LEAD: The European Community's inflation rate rose to 4.4 percent in 1988 from 2.6 percent the previous year, the community's statistics office said today.
Last year's rate equaled the United States inflation rate and significantly exceeded Japan's rate of nine-tenths of a percent.
The community's consumer price index rose three-tenths of a percent in December, with Portugal, Greece and Spain posting the largest increases.

LEAD: OUT of the teapot comes more than the soothing or ceremonial cup.
Tea can add subtle flavor and rich color to a variety of foods.


Critic's Notebook; Encore! From Stage to Screen
LEAD: In the decades when there was an active, self-starting Broadway theater, successful musicals and plays -especially those by Tennessee Williams - were almost unfailingly transformed into Hollywood movies.
But in recent years, Broadway and Hollywood have generally regarded each other at a cool, bicoastal distance.


After 229 Years, Irishwoman to Lead Parade
LEAD: For the first time in its 229-year history, the annual St.
Patrick's Day parade up Fifth Avenue will be led by a woman.


Pryor Has Eye Surgery
LEAD: Aaron Pryor, the former junior welterweight champion, had eye surgery yesterday at St.
Mary's Hospital in Rochester.
Pryor, 33,had a cataract removed from his left eye and was checked for a possible detached retina.
A news conference was scheduled for today to announce the results.(AP)

Chicago Country Spot May Fade Into Sunset
LEAD: They're heading for the last roundup at the 40-year-old Bar Double-R Ranch, but the trail bosses hope they can find a new pasture for the only no-cover, no-minimum, country-music basement nightclub in downtown Chicago.
An office skyscraper is planned for the site where the Sundowners trio entertains the crowd, and 30 varieties of chili are served to folks who stroll in off Randolph


Murphy Undergoes Surgery on Knee
LEAD: Dale Murphy, the Atlanta Braves' outfielder who won the National League Most Valuable Player Award in 1982 and 1983, underwent arthroscopic surgery yesterday to repair a slight cartilage tear in his right knee.
Murphy, 32 years old, felt a clicking in the knee while playing with his five sons over the weekend.


Sharansky Is a Favorite For Israeli Post at U.N.
LEAD: The Israeli Government is considering appointing Natan Sharansky as Israel's United Nations representative.
Mr.
Sharansky spent nine years in a Soviet prison before immigrating here in 1986.


City's Chaos Swells an Afghan Diaspora
LEAD: A fresh stream of refugees - most of them women, children and old men - are struggling through the mud, ice and snow of the Nawa Pass and into Pakistan.
They are fleeing harsh fighting around Jalalabad, an Afghan Government strongpoint that seems on the brink of falling to the guerrillas.


Cuomo Drops Insistence on Lilco-Pact Ratification
LEAD: Adopting a conciliatory tone, Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo today dropped his insistence that the State Legislature ratify his accord on closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


The Artful Dodger of the Rangers
LEAD: Tomas Sandstrom, who had slipped checks and eluded opponents all night, did not have a bad night dodging questions, either.
After the game Monday, Sandstrom, his shoulder pads having been replaced by a long black leather coat, sidestepped the issue of whether he ought to shoot more, brushed off the suggestion that he had cleaned his play of its nasty stickwork, and ducked completely around talk about his future with the


India Economic Outlook
LEAD: A senior World Bank official predicted today that India, buoyed by its best grain harvest in its 40 years of independence, would record one of its highest rates of economic growth this year. ''India seems to be on the move,'' said Attila Karaosmanoglu, a vice president of the World Bank.
A report by the Reserve Bank of India estimated that the economy would grow by 9 percent this year.


E.P.A. NOMINEE SAYS HE WILL URGE LAW TO CUT ACID RAIN
LEAD: William K. Reilly, President Bush's choice to head the Environmental Protection Agency, signaled a sharp break with Reagan Administration policies today by saying he would propose legislation to reduce acid rain.


Gondrezick Seeks Help
LEAD: Grant Gondrezick, a reserve guard for the Los Angeles Clippers, told his teammates Monday night before they lost their 15th straight game that he had contacted the National Basketball Association office in New York and requested admission to a substance-abuse treatment center in Van Nuys, Calif.
He then asked permission to suit up for the home game against the Atlanta Hawks, but Coach Don Casey would not permit it.

LEAD: Riverside Church, which conducted a nationwide search to find the right person to carry on the advocacy and eloquence of its prominent pulpit, has picked a man from right across the street to lead the congregation.

Corrections
LEAD: An art show listing in the New Jersey Weekly last Sunday, for Englewood, identified the artist incorrectly and misstated the opening time for his show of oil paintings.
The artist is Kurt Ritta.
The opening will be held today at the Intermission Gallery of the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, N.J., from 5:30 to 9:30 P.M., not 9 A.M.


Brady Sees No Urgency To Put Curbs on Buyouts
LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady told Congress today that there was no urgency in adopting measures to curb debt-financed corporate takeovers, adding that Wall Street's enthusiasm for leveraged buyouts might have peaked.


Wright, in Gesture to Bush, Shelves Bill on Covert Acts
LEAD: President Bush's appeal for bipartisanship in foreign policy bore fruit on Capitol Hill today when the Speaker of the House announced that he was shelving legislation that would have required the White House to notify Congress of any covert operations within 48 hours.

Executive Shuffling Continues at Salomon
LEAD: The executive shuffling continued yesterday at Salomon Brothers Inc., which announced a realignment of responsibilities that are intended to strengthen the firm's efforts in the potentially lucrative area of merchant banking.


Addenda
LEAD: *
Joseph K. Fisher, formerly chairman and chief executive officer of Fisher Jackson Levy Flaxman, has formed Fisher &amp; Co., a marketing consulting firm whose specialty will be corporate and financial communications.


Seoul Ends Inquiry on Chun Government Abuses
LEAD: Prosecutors today announced the end of their investigations into Government corruption and human-rights abuses of the last eight years.


Topics of The Times; South American Revelation
LEAD: No bigger candle is hidden under so vast a bushel as art treasures in the American Museum of Natural History.
That is illustrated afresh by the just-opened Hall of South American Peoples, a huge permanent gallery with 2,300 objects spanning 12,000 years.
The 11,000-square-foot hall not only fills an ethnographic gap; it is a dazzling esthetic revelation composed of beads, threads, clay and gold.


Judge Blocks Random Tests For Drugs at Interior Dept.
LEAD: A Federal district judge has blocked a program of random drug testing at the Interior Department, calling it an example of ''bureaucracy run amok'' that would deprive thousands of people of their right to privacy.


Polaroid Is Sued On Buyback Plan
LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. filed suit to block the Polaroid Corporation's recapitalization plan, which appears intended to foil Shamrock's $3.2 billion hostile bid.
Polaroid last week rejected the $45-a-share bid from Shamrock and Monday announced the recapitalization plan under which it will buy back $1.1 billion of its common stock.


Carlyle Raises Fairchild Offer
LEAD: The Carlyle Group, a Washington-based investment banking concern, has raised its offer to acquire Fairchild Industries to $16.30 a share in cash, or a total of $234 million.

LEAD: Robert F. Daniell, chairman and chief executive of the United Technologies Corporation, continued yesterday to put his mark on the company, naming two executives to senior posts in a realignment of management.


Icahn-Texaco
LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, has raised his stake in Texaco Inc. to 17.3 percent from 16.6 percent.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr.
Icahn said he had bought the shares before he reached an agreement with Texaco that bars him from increasing his Texaco holdings above the 17.3 percent level and making a takeover bid for seven years.

Dollar Rises After Pledge On Inflation
LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, moving close to what many traders and economists believe is the upper limit against the West German mark agreed to by Washington and its economic allies.

LEAD: Hurt by poor results in its mainframe and supercomputer operations, the Control Data Corporation yesterday reported a $12.8 million loss for its fourth quarter, in contrast to a profit of $10.8 million, or 26 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987.

Worse Than We Knew
LEAD: No nuclear weapon has been exploded on an enemy since World War II.
The world knew it had come close to a catastrophe in the 1962 Cuban missile crisis.
But it never knew how close until Soviet disclosure last weekend that 20 nuclear warheads, along with their missiles, had actually been deployed in


About New York; Etymologically, 'The Big Apple' Ages 18 Years
LEAD: David Shulman just received a most welcome letter.
The editor of the Oxford English Dictionary wrote to say the next supplement to the prestigious lexicon would list Big Apple as a synonym for New York City.
Heretofore, Big Apple has been listed only as a dance.


G.M. Agrees to Settle Blacks' Suit
LEAD: In a move to end a six-year legal battle with its black managers, professionals and clerical workers, the General Motors Corporation has agreed to settle a lawsuit covering 10,000 current and former black workers in the Midwest, it was announced today.


Panama Moving to Improve Jails Before Rights Inspection
LEAD: Anticipating a key human rights inspection by international observers, the Panamanian authorities are cleaning up jails and scrambling to eliminate what monitors here say are widespread abuses.


Catharine Deaver Lealtad, 93, Pediatrician
LEAD: Dr.
Catharine Deaver Lealtad, a pediatrician who supervised medical services for displaced children in Germany at the end of World War II, died Monday at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn.
She was 93 years old and had been a patient at the V.A.'s extended care center in St.
Albans, Queens, for nine years.

The U.N. Today
LEAD:  Economic and Social Council


Foster Is Reinjured
LEAD: Greg Foster has broken his left arm again.
Foster, the 1984 Olympic silver medalist in the 110-meter high hurdles, broke his arm last summer, two weeks before the trials for the Seoul Olympics.
He fractured it again Monday night while playing basketball with friends in West Los Angeles.
Bob Kersee, Foster's coach, said the hurdler broke the arm undeneath the metal plate inserted during surgery for the previous injury, which occurred when he tripped over a hurdle.

One Designer's Trademark: Restaurants That Tell Stories
LEAD: PAT KULETO, one of the West Coast's most sought-after restaurant designers, has designed 125 restaurants over the past 20 years.
Ten more of his creations will open this year.
While design is only one element of a restaurant's success, 122 of his restaurants have lasted at least five years, a fact considered remarkable in an industry where restaurateurs say 8 out of 10 ventures fail the first year.


U.S. Agency Broadening Inspections of Boeing Jets
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration today broadened a series of mandatory inspections of passenger jets made by the Boeing Company, ordering airlines to check wiring and fire extinguishers on hundreds of jets produced in the last eight years.

LEAD: Many of the National Football League's biggest stars could become free agents today when the league puts into effect its new contract plan.

Reviews/Music; Music Out of the Holocaust
LEAD: When music of very different kinds is bound into one thematic concert, it is usually in the lives of its composers that a common bond is found.
Saturday night's concert at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, however, remembered not the sharing of lives but of deaths.
Eleven composers represented in this long and arduous evening died between 1942 and 1945 and at such places as Furstengrube, Auschwitz, Wulzburg and Dutmergen.

LEAD: ''Oh, you look very attractive,'' said the handsome young man.


Results Plus
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Canadiens 5, Penguins 1: Mats Naslund and Mike Keane each scored twice, and Patrick Roy stopped 38 shots for Montreal last night at Pittsburgh.
Mario Lemieux was held without a point for only the second time in the last 27 games. (AP)  COLLEGE BASKETBALL/WOMEN  Texas 69, Tennessee 67: Clarissa Davis, who was not expected to play because of a sprained ankle, scored 38 points last night to lead 11th-ranked Texas to the upset at home of second-ranked Tennessee (18-2).


Fighters Are Fined
LEAD: The National Basketball Association fined Bill Laimbeer of the Detroit Pistons and Brad Daugherty of the Cleveland Cavaliers $5,000 each yesterday for fighting during a game last Friday.
The players had received one-game suspensions without pay -costing Daugherty $10,000 and Laimbeer $7,300 - and both missed games on Sunday.


MICROWAVE COOKING
LEAD: THERE is more to fish than simple grilling.
There are many great soups that are hallmarks of the regions where they were developed.
And in any season, a fish soup can introduce a meal or become a whole one.


Harrison M. Davis Jr., 80, Ex-Headmaster
LEAD: Harrison Merrill Davis Jr., headmaster of several preparatory schools during his long career as an educator, died of complications of Parkinson's Disease Monday at the Montgomery (N.Y.) Nursing Home.
He was 80 years old and lived in Cornwall-on-Hudson, N.Y.

Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption and article on Saturday, about a gathering in remembrance of a Brooklyn man killed in a parking dispute, gave his name incorrectly.
He was Stephen Kelly.
The caption, in some copies, misidentified the men shown.
From the right were Stephen Jr., Erik and Stanford, sons of Mr.
Kelly, and Robert Abraham, a family friend.


Mine Workers Call Off Strike Against Pittston Coal Group
LEAD: The United Mine Workers today dropped a strike that had been scheduled for midnight against Pittston Coal Group and said 1,700 miners would continue working without a contract.

LEAD: Eddie LeVeque, the last of the original Keystone Kops, the troupe of slapstick gendarmes whose comic antics endeared them to a generation of silent film fans, died Saturday.
He was 92 years old.

LEAD: Buck Williams's 3-point play with 38 seconds left put New Jersey ahead to stay and the Nets snapped Seattle's 17-game home winning streak with a 118-112 victory tonight.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury and several Federal agencies are investigating whether airplane part suppliers have been buying used or surplus parts from aerospace companies and reselling them with false certification to unknowing aviation companies, a newspaper has reported.

LEAD: A member of the Soviet Politburo has apparently withdrawn from the race for Moscow's at-large seat in the new Soviet congress rather than face a contest against Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and human rights campaigner.

Sutton said that if he resigns or is dismissed when the investigation of 18 allegations of wrongdoing is completed, he would consider coaching at another college or in the N.B.A.

LEAD: With the possible exception of Thomas Jefferson, who instructed his tombstone carver to recall that he was ''father of the University of Virginia'' but not that he was President of the United States, there is little precedent for how to be an ''education President.''


Colombian Jet Hijacking
LEAD: A hijacker who doused a passenger with gasoline and threatened to set a Colombian airliner on fire was arrested today with four accomplices at the airport here, Costa Rican officials said.
The hijacker, a Nicaraguan Miskito Indian, surrendered to the authorities after the Boeing 727 of the ACES airline landed at San Jose's airport.


Grace Pickens Offer Is Enjoined
LEAD: A Federal judge has enjoined the hostile tender offer for the Clemente Global Growth Fund Inc. by Grace Pickens Global Acquisition Partners.
Federal Judge John F. Keenan enjoined the offer because he said it appeared that the Grace Pickens bid had violated a provision of the Investment Company Act of 1940 that prevents one investment firm from acquiring another such firm.


Alfonso de Borbon, 52, of Spain Dies in Colorado Skiing Accident
LEAD: Alfonso de Borbon y de Dampierre, the Duke of Cadiz, was killed Monday in a skiing accident here.
He was 52 years old.


Economic Scene; Costa Rica's Debt Message
LEAD: AS goes Costa Rica's economy, so goes Latin America's?
Fears of setting a precedent for the Latin mega-debtors - Mexico, Brazil, Argentina, Venezuela - have stopped foreign banks from settling accounts on realistic terms with this tiny nation.
But now Costa Rica's sophisticated financial negotiators have turned the tables on their commercial creditors.


Witness Says He Saw 2 Flee Byrne Slaying
LEAD: A man who was being guarded by a police officer when the officer was murdered testified yesterday that he had seen two of the four men accused in the killing fleeing the murder scene in Queens.

LEAD: THE felicitous combination of rosemary and lemon is found often in northern Italian cuisine, most successfully in simple, quick veal dishes.

Commodities Exchange Seeks Advice
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade announced today that it had hired a former assistant United States attorney to advise it and its members on the use of Federal racketeering laws in white-collar crime cases.


Topics of The Times; 'Jan Palach Lives!'
LEAD: Two thousand demonstrators recently crowded the main square of Prague to honor the memory of Jan Palach, a 20-year-old student who immolated himself on Jan. 16, 1969.
Hundreds of them were beaten and scores were jailed, including Czechoslovakia's most renowned playwright, Vaclav Havel.


Review/Piano; Concentration And Finger Power
LEAD: Veda Zuponcic played an uncompromisingly difficult piano program on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall.
Miss Zuponcic, who is the head of the music department at Glassboro (N. J.) State College, is a formidable player, with an unwaveringly strong technique, and clear well-considered ideas about the music she played.


Bass Group Says It Owns 5.6% of Houghton Mifflin
LEAD: In a disclosure that Wall Street took as a signal of a possible takeover battle, the Robert M. Bass Group said yesterday that it owns 5.6 percent of the Houghton Mifflin Company, a textbook publisher based in Boston.


Lisa's Legacy: Awareness of Child Abuse and With It, Alarm
LEAD: Fourteen months after she was beaten to death, 6-year-old Lisa Steinberg seems to have left as her legacy an increased awareness of child abuse - and a new readiness to report cases in which abuse is suspected.


Grain and Meat Prices Rise As Temperatures Get Cold
LEAD: Soybean and grain prices were sharply higher on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.


Texas Eastern
LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a Houston-based natural gas transmission company, said it had met with several banks on Saturday to discuss the financing of a possible restructuring or recapitalization as an alternative to the $42-a-share tender offer from the Coastal Corporation.
The meetings were held one day before Texas Eastern formally rejected the Coastal bid as inadequate.


'Soft' X-rays May Bring Better Computer Chips
LEAD: The race to build computer chips capable of storing thousands of times the information squeezed into today's most complex chips is almost certain to hinge on the development of a device that can generate X-rays that act much like light.
These longer, or ''soft,'' X-rays will still have wavelengths much shorter than visible light, making it possible to etch on silicon wafers circuits far finer than those being made with light and optical lenses.


How to Pay for Honest Government
LEAD: Nobody can be proud of the backhanded way Congress raises its members' salaries.
But experience shows that it's either that way or no way, because few members will risk political oblivion by voting publicly to increase their own pay.

Bridge
LEAD: Longevity and bridge expertise seem to go together.
One piece of evidence for that proposition is the original list of 10 life masters established by the American Contract Bridge League in 1936.

Yankee Food in a Land Where the Crumpet Is King
LEAD: A REUBEN sandwich with white Russian dressing?
Buffalo chicken wings in a Tex-Mex restaurant?
Welcome to London's version of Yankee cooking.
Until five or six years ago American restaurants here mostly served hamburgers and pizzas.
Now a more sophisticated assortment of edible Americana has invaded the English restaurant scene: somewhere between burgers and haute cuisine, it consists of British interpretations of American diners, steakhouses, delicatessens, even fine food stores.

About Education
LEAD: Colleges compete furiously for the same group of top-ranking minority high school graduates.
When everybody tries to recruit from the same pool, the number of black and Hispanic undergraduates does not grow.
In recent years, it has actually shrunk.
The National Center for Education Statistics reports that blacks earned fewer college degrees in 1985 than in 1977.

Nintendo Is Sued by Atari
LEAD: The Atari Corporation has filed a $250 million lawsuit against the Nintendo Company, accusing the Japanese video game maker of monopolizing the market with restrictions on its licensed game creators.


BUSH BACKS PLAN TO ENHANCE ROLE OF SECURITY STAFF
LEAD: President Bush has approved a revamping of the foreign policy machinery under which the White House national security adviser and his staff will be at the center of decision making, Administration officials said today.


Top-Selling Books of 1988: Spy Novel and Physics
LEAD: Tom Clancy's ''Cardinal of the Kremlin,'' a novel about a member of the Central Intelligence Agency who races to rescue an American mole in the Soviet Union, was the biggest selling hard-cover book in the United States last year, according to a survey by The New York Times.
It was published last July and has 1,277,611 copies in print.


House Panel to Hold Hearings on Ships' Anti-Missile System
LEAD: A House committee today ordered hearings on the reliability of weapons designed to protect Navy frigates from cruise missiles after a Congressional report concluded that tests on the weapons were not realistic enough.

LEAD: After six decades in which advertising has been indelibly associated with the East Side of Manhattan, ''Madison Avenue'' is moving west.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. I recently decided to repaint my wood kitchen cabinets.
They are finished with an avocado-colored oil- base enamel.
I painted just one cabinet with a beige latex paint to see how I would like it.
I did not prepare the surface in any way and the one coat did not cover too well.
Also, it seems to be chipping off in places.


Theodore Marshall, 86, Chemical Engineer
LEAD: Theodore Henry Marshall, a retired chemical engineer and retired brigadier general in the Army Reserve, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Island Park, L.I.
He was 86 years old.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, is offering to the public two issues of short-term notes totaling $1 billion with maturities of three and six months.
The offerings are being made through Freddie Mac and an 18-member selling group.
Both issues were priced at par.

Keeping Hot Potatoes Out of the Political Kitchen
LEAD: They've rewritten Harry S. Truman's old maxim, or so it sometimes seems these days.

Report on Clayton
LEAD: Mark Clayton, the Miami Dolphins' wide receiver, is described as a ''big user'' of cocaine in the Feb. 6 issue of Sports Illustrated by an admitted drug dealer.
The player's agent, David Ware, said the article is ''entirely false, shameless yellow journalism.'' The magazine quotes state prosecutor's documents in which a former limousine driver who is charged with cocaine trafficking describes Clayton and the suspended Dolphin wide receiver, Mark Duper, as ''big users'' of cocaine.

LEAD: President Bush plans to meet with banking and savings industry representatives on Thursday to discuss the proposals for rescuing the savings and loan industry, the White House said today.

LEAD: Pirmin Zurbriggen of Switzerland took a hard fall during downhill training yesterday at the world Alpine championships in Beaver Creek, Colo., but managed to ski off the mountain to be examined by team doctors and to have X-rays taken at Vail Valley Medical Center.
Hugo Steinegger, a spokesman for the Swiss team, said Zurbriggern appeared to have a chest bruise.

LEAD: The former chief American diplomat in Kabul spoke today of the possibility of a coup against the Afghan President by Communist hard-liners or guerrilla sympathizers in the Government as the deadline for the Soviet troop pullout nears.

Terms were not disclosed.
Magic Marker, based in Trenton, has been operating under the protection of Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code since April 1986.

LEAD: A 23-year-old black motorcyclist whose fatal shooting by a police officer touched off three nights of violence had traces of cocaine in his system and was carrying a small amount of marijuana, The Miami Herald reported today.

LEAD: The Toronto Blue Jays signed Jimmy Key, the left-handed pitcher, to a four-year contract yesterday.
The first three years are guaranteed.
The fourth year, 1992, is at the club's option, but Key must be notified of the club's decision by Nov. 1, 1990.
Otherwise the contract is not binding and Key may elect to become a free agent.


QUAYLE IN CARACAS TO HAIL NEW CHIEF
LEAD: On his first diplomatic mission abroad, Vice President Dan Quayle today joined other foreign dignitaries, including 22 heads of government, who will be attend the inauguration of Venezuela's new President on Thursday.


G.M. to Shut Its Plant Near Boston
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it would indefinitely shut its assembly plant in Framingham, Mass., by Aug. 1, putting 2,100 employees out of work.

Harry A. McArdle, Runner, 82
LEAD: Harry A. McArdle, a lifelong running enthusiast who was the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior half-mile champion in the early 1930's, died after apparently suffering a heart attack while jogging near his home in Rego Park, Queens, on Jan. 23.
He was 82 years old.

Apollo Computer
LEAD: Apollo Computer Inc. introduced a speedy computer yesterday that specializes in displaying three-dimensional graphic images and starts at $94,900.
Apollo, based in Chelmsford, Mass., said the Series 10000 Visualization System was suited to such high-tech jobs as finite element analysis, fluid dynamics, image processing, electronic design and molecular modeling.

Penney Plans Sale Of Insurance Unit
LEAD: The J. C. Penney Company said that it had put its J. C. Penney Casualty Insurance Company up for sale and that it was holding preliminary talks with several companies.
The giant retailer, based in Plano, Tex., said that it had decided to abandon the in-store insurance business because the expected synergy between the company's retail operations and personal financial services had failed to materialize.

LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Oil and gas companies are continuing to cut spending on exploration in the U.S.
Those plans reflect both the relatively low price of oil and brighter drilling prospects abroad. [ Page A1. ] The index of leading indicators rose 0.6 percent in December, the eighth straight month in which it has reversed direction.

USX Steel Profits Seen at $60 a Ton
LEAD: The USX Corporation's chairman, David M. Roderick, said that the company had corrected problems in the steel division that had caused steel profits to fall below expectations last year.
USX had predicted that its steel profits in 1988 would be about $60 a ton shipped.
But the USS unit, the nation's largest steelmaker, achieved a profit of only about $40 a ton shipped.


Hedda Nussbaum, Hardly a Heroine . . .
LEAD: At lunch one day with a group of women covering the Steinberg trial, a stalwart feminist announced that she, but for a lucky combination of circumstances, could have been Hedda Nussbaum.
Although I had heard similar remarks before, and have heard them since, I was appalled.
I find this particular anguished expression of feminine identification simplistic and alarming.

LEAD: ''I OFTEN get carried away,'' Graham Rust admitted.
He was referring to the 13 years (one week a month) he spent painting sumptuous wall and ceiling decorations for a staircase at Ragley Hall in Warwickshire, England, the home of the Marquess and Marchioness of Hertford. completed in 1983.


Philippine Troops Kill 32 Muslim Insurgents
LEAD: Troops killed at least 32 Muslim rebels in their biggest battle with the insurgents since 1986, the army said today.
The guerrillas had attacked a remote village in the southern Philippines.

LEAD: Elaine de Kooning, a painter, teacher and writer on art, died of lung cancer yesterday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital.
She was 68 years old and lived in East Hampton.

Report Finds Poverty Among Children Is Up
LEAD: Poverty among white children has increased by almost a third during the 1980's, and nearly half of all black children and a third of all Hispanic children in the nation are poor, according to a report released Tuesday that called for spending $4.3 billion to help children.

Cut Loose


Israel Currency Reserves
LEAD: Israel's foreign currency reserves jumped $1.22 billion in January as speculators sold dollars purchased before a turn-of-the-year devaluation of the shekel, the Bank of Israel said today.
The reserves now stand at $4.63 billion, back to the level they had reached before a speculative flight into the dollar drained Israel's currency stock in November and December.

But the suspense is apparently over for at least one officeholder, even if the news is not good.


Care and Cleaning Of Venetian Blinds
LEAD: ''YOU ought to see how long people wait to bring in their Venetian blinds for cleaning,'' Louis Manganiello said. ''I've got to put gloves on to pick them up.''


Conference Is Planned On Retail Ad Strategies
LEAD: The Retail Marketing Society will sponsor a special conference on retail advertising strategies on March 22.
The conference, to be held at the New York Hilton, will include lunch-time remarks by Jerry Della Femina, the irrepressible chairman of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS, who will answer the question, ''Is retail advertising real advertising?


Marcos Condition Is Critical After an Operation in Hawaii
LEAD: Former President Ferdinand Marcos of the Philippines was moved back to intensive care at St.
Francis Medical Center early today and is again in critical condition, a hospital spokeswoman said.


Bank Is Issuing Deposit Notes
LEAD: The Bank of New England is offering $100 million of deposit notes due 1991 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley &amp; Company.


In Re: Columbia Pictures And Puttnam's Orphans
LEAD: Although it is nearly a year and a half since David Puttnam abruptly left his job as chairman of Columbia Pictures, nearly a dozen of his movies are still locked behind the studio gates.
Like orphans in a Hollywood melodrama, they wait, fatherless and forlorn.

Bridge
LEAD: In every war there are unknown heroes who would receive medals if anyone knew about their deeds of valor and reported them.
Sometimes, as when one dead man is found surrounded by fallen foes, we can infer a remarkable feat of arms.


Eugene A. Staley, 82, An Economist, Is Dead
LEAD: Dr.
Eugene Alvah Staley, an educator and international economist, died of lymph cancer Tuesday at the Stanford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif.
He was 82 years old and lived in Palo Alto.

Delta Computer Moving
LEAD: In a move that runs counter to the trend toward offshore assembly, a company that makes personal computers in East Asia has decided to move its operations to Akron.
The Delta Computer Corporation, which will lease space once occupied by the B. F. Goodrich Company, said the move to the United States would help it to control quality and reduce shipping time.


Critics Hope to Eliminate Testing Panel
LEAD: The Board of Examiners, the testing agency that since 1898 has decided who can teach or become a principal in New York City's public schools, is itself being put to a test these days, fighting for its survival against a powerful array of educators and politicians who are pressing for its abolition.

Review/Dance; A Rustic Romance With Swiss Precision
LEAD: The Basel Ballet from Switzerland, which has rightly earned an international reputation under Heinz Spoerli, its director since 1973, made its Manhattan debut on Tuesday night with the American premiere of Mr.
Spoerli's version of ''La Fille Mal Gardee.''


Review/Ballet; A Troupe With a Toe in Two States
LEAD: A dance troupe with two homes, the Pennsylvania and Milwaukee Ballet, opened a week's engagement Tuesday night at the Kennedy Center.
Under the artistic direction of Robert Weiss, who directed the Pennsylvania Ballet of Philadelphia when it merged with the Milwaukee in 1987, the new company regularly performs in both cities.


Close to Home
LEAD: AT Z o'clock in the afternoon, every day but Sunday, three elderly people gather in the kitchen of a white clapboard house.
One of the women mixes herself a vodka martini, using vodka from her bottle.
The other woman makes a vodka and tonic, using vodka from her bottle.
The man, the oldest at 94, is the only Scotch drinker among them, so there is no confusion about which is his bottle.


A Record-Breaker
LEAD: When John O. Marsh Jr. walks into his office in the Pentagon this morning, he will become the longest-serving Secretary of the Army or Secretary of War, as the position was called until the Defense Department was set up in 1947.

LEAD: The Philip H. Dougherty Memorial Committee, an ad hoc advertising group, announced that it had received more than $50,000 in donations toward a memorial being established at Ithaca College in honor of the late advertising columnist of The New York Times.

Intel in Technology Pact With A.T.&amp;T.
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Intel Corporation have formed a product and technology exchange agreement on microelectronic chips for communications use.
Under the five-year accord, the companies will produce and market each other's existing chips and work to develop and manufacture future products.


Lucas Carton Sale
LEAD: A Japanese brewing company has bought the Lucas Carton restaurant, reputed to be among the top dozen in the world, for 43 million francs, or about $7.1 million.
A spokesman for the cognac producer Remy Martin et Cie, the restaurant's owner, said the Paris culinary landmark had been sold to Asahi Breweries Ltd., a unit of the Sumitomo group.


Rosa Parks Is Hospitalized
LEAD: Rosa Parks, the black woman who helped spur the Southern civil rights movement by refusing to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Ala., in 1955, was in fair condition today at Harper Hospital here, where she was taken Wednesday after suffering chest pains.
Mrs.
Parks, who is 75 years old, had a pacemaker inserted last March for an irregular heartbeat.


Talk of Bid Sends Prime Stock Up $1
LEAD: Shares in Prime Computer Inc. rose on rumors that the Ford Motor Company or MAI Basic Four Inc. may top MAI Basic's $1.3 billion offer for the computer maker.
Prime's shares rose $1 each, to $20.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, exceeding MAI Basic's $20-a-share price for the first time since the hostile tender began in November.


Tampa Violence Flares Again On Day After Suspect's Death
LEAD: Demonstrators threw rocks and bottles and set trash bins on fire today in the second night of violence after a suspected drug dealer died in police custody.


Memories Of a Night In Asuncion
LEAD: Just the sight of the Paraguayan players brought it all back for Bob Seguso and Ken Flach: the curses, the coins flying through the air, the threat of knifeplay in the dark Paraguayan night.

Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.
Bouley  ** (Nov. 20, 1987), 165 Duane Street (608-3852) - With Valentine's Day approaching, many couples are seeking restaurants that have not only good food but a romantic ambiance as well.

C. Everett Bacon, Former Athlete, 98
LEAD: C. Everett Bacon, an eight-letter athlete in football, baseball, tennis and golf at Wesleyan University who was selected as an all-America quarterback in 1912, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at Southampton Hospital.
He was 98 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.


Soviet Joins Shootout
LEAD: Rimas Kurtinaitis, the leading scorer in the Soviet Union's 82-76 victory over the United States in the Seoul Olympics last summer, will participate in the Long Distance Shootout on N.B.A.
All-Star Saturday, Feb. 11, at the Summit in Houston.
The 6-foot-5-inch Kurtinaitis had the highest single-round score in a recent Lithuanian 3-point shot contest, an event based on the N.B.A.

Review/Art; With Caricatures, Doings of the French Revolution
LEAD: During the French Revolution, a Parisian could remain informed about the meaning of a recent decree or the significance of the latest beheading by wandering into a print shop or strolling through the garden of the Palais-Royal, where caricatures were sold.
These 18th-century political cartoons were often hastily produced by anonymous artists and sometimes by artists of the first rank like Jacques-Louis

Review/Music; Post-Modern Sounds
LEAD: Scott Johnson is a post-modern rhapsodist.
His compositions peregrinate from idiom to idiom, from Minimalism to progressive rock to electronics to snippets of speech to the sweet-and-sour melodicism of Milhaud or Prokofiev.
But the music balances variety and continuity, as Mr.
Johnson spins out musical ideas in a plausible yet unpredictable succession.


Review/Music; Cecil Taylor, Clearinghouse Of Jazz Ideas
LEAD: Perhaps more than any other jazz artist, the pianist Cecil Taylor's performances have to be seen in concert.
He is a spectacle, and people come to see him flail away at the piano, where he'll cock his arms stiffly for a second, roll the backs of his hands over the keyboards, or drop his elbows across the keys.


Treasury Issues Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed in extremely light trading yesterday as market participants chose to wait for this morning's release of January employment data before establishing new positions.


Suspect Held in W. Virginia After Discovery of 6 Bodies
LEAD: The authorities have discovered the bodies of six people who were shot in the head with a shotgun near a trailer compound, and one of the residents has been charged with two of the deaths.

LEAD: Paul Ereng's experience at the Seoul Olympics last summer proves how much anybody really knows about handicapping a race in track and field.

Review/Dance; Basel Ballet In Parody And Romp
LEAD: The prize for the weirdest of all weird ballets to be seen in New York goes to ''La Belle Vie,'' which purports to deal with a French revolution or two and life under the Second Empire.
It is, in fact, the Basel Ballet's near-wordless and naive equivalent of ''Les Miserables'' - the musical, not the book - and a summer stock version at that.

LEAD: On Sunday, the Corner Store Dance Company will present ''The Day I Had a Cold,'' a modern-dance program of stories, poems, props and songs for preschool and elementary-school children at the Ansche Chesed Synagogue, West End Avenue at 100th Street.
The 2 P.M. performance is a benefit for B.J.'s Kids Day Care Community.

On Stage
LEAD:  A 'Lampoon' for Broadway It's more than a dream, a gleam in the eye and even talk - nevertheless, it's still amorphous.
It's what producers describe as ''in development.'' But by fall, if everything goes according to plan, it should be a show called ''National Lampoon's American Tricentennial'' and, depending on which producer you're talking to, by the end of the year, or spring 1990, after regional tryouts, it should be on Broadway, at the Ritz


Our Towns; Some Neighbors Still Aren't Seen As Neighbors
LEAD: Like a lot of small-town newspapers, the Glen Cove Record-Pilot tries to stress the good.
If there's bad news, it usually gets played down.
For example, last week there was just one paragraph on a Glen Cove man charged with attempted murder.
The story did not name the man or his victim.
Maggie Polk, the editor, says that in sensitive matters it's best not to.

LEAD: Marie Syrkin, an author, editor and teacher who was active in the Zionist cause for many decades, died of cancer Wednesday at St.
John's Hospital in Santa Monica, Calif.
She was 89 years old and lived in Santa Monica.

Cash In on the Homeless
LEAD: The ragged, deranged man shivering on a steam grate symbolizes a costly potential burden for society - but he may also represent something much more positive: thousands of dollars in potential cash benefits from Government programs.
The mentally ill street people, perhaps the most pathetic of the homeless and those who most disrupt the quality of life, may be eligible for especially large payments.

Review/Theater; After Deaths, Wandering Through One's Own Life
LEAD: ''The Cezanne Syndrome,'' the opening play in the SoHo Rep's three-week festival of new French-Canadian drama, is a brief hallucinatory chronicle of a death retold.
A mother and child have died in an automobile accident and the grief-stricken father goes through daily domestic routines while his mind wanders in time and fantasy.

LEAD: Investors continued to take profits in blue-chip stocks yesterday, giving the Dow Jones industrial average its second straight loss.


Repsol to Sell Stake
LEAD: The Spanish national oil company, Repsol Exploration S.A., said it would offer up to 30 percent of its stock to private investors in the country's biggest privatization.
The offering could raise around 165 billion pesetas, or about $1.38 billion, an analyst said.
About a third of the shares will be offered to institutional investors in the United States, Japan, West Germany, France, Britain and Switzerland, Repsol's chairman, Oscar Fanjul, said.

Brazil's Debt Can Save the Amazon
LEAD: Brazil owes the world $115 billion.
The world wants Brazil to stop recklessly destroying the Amazon rain forest, an extraordinary natural wonder.
Those two conditions invite a deal, a grand debt-for-nature swap that would ease Brazil's burden of foreign borrowing and preserve the Amazon forests.
What stands in the way of so compelling a solution?

Knopf Editor Is Named Publisher at Atheneum
LEAD: Lee Goerner, an editor at Alfred A. Knopf, has been named publisher of Atheneum Publishers.

Atheneum is an imprint of Macmillan.

One Mile of Gowanus Expressway Is Closed
LEAD: A one-mile stretch of the southbound Gowanus Expressway in Brooklyn was closed yesterday when a routine inspection for New York State uncovered cracks in the steel structure under the roadway, state and city transportation officials said.


Coastal Says F.T.C. Seeks Data on Bid
LEAD: The Coastal Corporation said the Federal Trade Commission had requested additional information under Federal antitrust laws on its $2.6 billion offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation, an oil and gas producer.
The request extends the waiting period for buying Texas Eastern's shares under a tender offer that was about to expire on Wednesday until 10 days after Coastal complies with the request.

Reviews/Film; Behind the Voices of the Townships
LEAD: The documentary ''Voices of 'Sarafina!' '' makes it easy to understand why the Broadway show's young South African performers have such incandescent energy onstage, and why they seem such a close-knit band.
As to the latter point, they shared the common experience of living at the house of their director, Mbongeni Ngema, for the first several months of their stay in the United States.

Agency to Study and Shift Cases of Troubled Families
LEAD: In the wake of disclosures that a New York City agency had failed to monitor hundreds of troubled families under its care, child-welfare officials said yesterday that they would begin an extensive review of cases and redistribute them to reduce workloads.


Europe-Indonesia Deal
LEAD: The European Community has agreed to allow Indonesia to export 25.5 million knitted garments to the community this year, the largest quota granted to any supplier, a textile trade group said today.
Hong Kong, previously the largest supplier of knitted garments to the 12-nation trading bloc, received a quota of 25.32 million pieces, said Chamrul Djafri, an executive of the Indonesian Textile Association.

LEAD: Malaysia and the Philippines, which produce most of the world's palm and coconut oils, are waging a campaign to persuade Americans -and through them, major food companies - that tropical oils have no ill effects on health.
But the battle already appears to be lost.


Orange Juice Prices Decline As Fear of a Freeze Abates
LEAD: Orange juice futures prices turned lower yesterday, erasing nearly two-thirds of the week's gains, as fears of frost damage to the Florida orange groves faded.

Economic Scene; Social Security And the Budget
LEAD: PRESIDENT BUSH plans to present his revisions of President Reagan's final budget next week.
The Bush changes are likely to include a reduction in the growth of military spending to zero from Mr.
Reagan's 2 percent, adjusted for inflation.
That should shave a few billion dollars from the proposed military outlays of $293.8 billion in 1990.


'Forgotten War'
LEAD: After almost four decades, American veterans of the Korean War will finally have a memorial commemorating their service and the 165,707 killed, wounded and missing from 1950 to 1953 in what has come to be called the ''Forgotten War.''


U. of Chicago Bars Recruiters of Top Firm Because of Slurs
LEAD: The University of Chicago Law School yesterday barred the world's largest law firm from recruiting on campus for a year, a result of a student's complaint of racist, sexist and anti-Semitic slurs by a partner during a job interview.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $18.6 million, to $285.37 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 137 institutional funds decreased by $580.2 million, to $74.42 billion.
The assets of the 226 general-purpose funds were up by $301.9 million, to $90.22 billion.

Shareholder Sues Apple Computer
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said a shareholder's lawsuit had been filed against the company.
The suit maintains that Apple failed to disclose in a timely manner information related to the company's expected financial results for its second quarter.
Apple said last week that its second-quarter earnings would be depressed because of excess inventory of dynamic random access memory chips bought at inflated prices last summer.

Fairchild Rejects A Sweetened Offer
LEAD: Fairchild Industries, a military electronics company, rejected as inadequate a sweetened $16.30-a-share bid from the Carlyle Group, a Washington-based investment firm.
Carlyle controls a partnership that owns 10 percent of Fairchild's stock.
Before making its latest proposal on Tuesday, worth $230 million, it offered $15.50 a share earlier last month.

William Stephenson, British Spy Known as Intrepid, Is Dead at 93
LEAD: Sir William Stephenson, the Canadian-born millionaire industrialist whose adventures as Britain's World War II chief of intelligence in the Western Hemisphere were chronicled in the 1979 bestseller ''A Man Called Intrepid'' died Tuesday in Paget, Bermuda.
He was 93 years old.
Sir William, who had been living in retirement in Bermuda and Jamaica for many years, was given the code name Intrepid by Winston Churchill because long before his cloak-and-dagger days began he had been one of Britain's top fighter pilots in World War


Poll Rates Hazards to Air Travel
LEAD: A majority of Americans support increased anti-terrorist measures on international flights.
Even so, nearly two out of three say inadequate airplane maintenance poses a greater danger to air travelers than terrorism does, according to a Media General-Associated Press survey.

Saudis Seen as Top Mideast Buyer of U.S. Arms
LEAD: The State Department has told Congress that the United States may sell a large volume of new tanks, missiles and warplanes to countries in the Middle East, Administration officials said today.


Bureaucracy and Big Repairs Stall '86 Plan for Drug Centers
LEAD: In 1986, faced with a crack epidemic, Mayor Edward I. Koch promised the state 10 buildings to use as drug treatment centers.
Since then, only one building has been transferred to a drug treatment group, and it will not open for months.
Two burned, five have liens on them, two have been condemned and all are in such serious disrepair that they will not be ready until late this year or next year.

Restaurants
LEAD: One question often posed to a restaurant critic is, ''What is the difference between a three-star and a four-star restaurant?'' Indeed, it is a fine distinction.
A succinct explanation would be: a three-star establishment must excel; a four-star must excel and inspire.
Le Bernardin, the all-seafood restaurant that received four stars in 1986 shortly after it opened, is a paradigm of a restaurant that does both.


Chrysler Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

High-Tech TV Standard Is Affirmed
LEAD: The American National Standards Institute yesterday rejected an appeal by Capital Cities/ABC Inc. and upheld a standard for high-definition television and movies that was favored by CBS Inc., HBO Inc. and the Society of Motion Picture and Television Engineers.

Seat That May Be Filled
LEAD: For two years, Senate and House leaders have been undecided over who should head the Congressional Budget Office, and the agency, one of the most important analytical arms of Congress, has gone without a permanent director.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary by The Associated Press on Wednesday about Alfonso de Borbon y de Dampierre, the Duke of Cadiz, described a court action incorrectly.
After a 1984 car crash in which the Duke's elder son was killed, a Spanish court granted the boy's mother temporary custody of the other son.
But six months later the court ruled that the child could be returned to his father's custody.

Jack Douglas, Writer For TV, Is Dead at 80
LEAD: Jack Douglas, an Emmy Award-winning comedy writer and a frequent guest on Jack Paar's television talk show in the late 1950's and 60's, died Tuesday at West Hills Humana Hospital, where he was admitted four days earlier with pneumonia.
He was 80 years old.


Cadbury Rescues Bassett From Bid
LEAD: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British maker of soft drinks and candy, stepped in to rescue Bassett Foods P.L.C. from a hostile takeover bid by a Swedish food company.
Cadbury Schweppes said Bassett, known for its licorice and chewy candies, had accepted its offer of $:91 million, or about $159 million.


Review/Music; Quick Answers in Conductor's Debut
LEAD: The most promising young American conductor to come along in many years, Hugh Wolff, made his debut on Wednesday evening with the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall.
In previous New York appearances at the head of the New Jersey Symphony, of which he is music director, Mr.
Wolff produced results that raised hopes for his future dangerously high.

Ascap Exhibition
LEAD: Feb. 13 is the 75th anniversary of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, the oldest and largest music licensing organization in the United States.
To mark the event, an exhibition, ''Ascap: The Music of America,'' will feature original music manuscripts, photographs and other memorabilia, beginning today and running through April 1 at the Vincent Astor Gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, 65th Street and Broadway.

Howard W. Siebens, 83, Oilman
LEAD: Harold W. Siebens, an oilman and philanthropist who in 1980 made an anonymous gift of $18 million to Buena Vista College, a small liberal arts institution in Storm Lake, Iowa, died on Sunday at his home on Lyford Cay in the Bahamas.
He was 83 years old.

He was 74 years old and lived in Mount Desert, Me.

Peru's Inflation Rate Up
LEAD: Peru's inflation rate reached 47.3 percent last month, compared with 41.9 percent in December and 12.8 percent in January 1988, the National Statistics Institute said today.
The rate rose to 2,280 percent for the last 12 months.

Electronic Futures Trading Cleared
LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today approved a global computer trading network, called Globex, which will enable the futures and options trading markets to operate electronically after regular trading hours.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about a Connecticut Supreme Court ruling on removal of life support misstated the role of the Society for the Right to Die.
The society joined the case as a friend of the court; the patient's family was represented by the law firm of Wise &amp; Layton.

LEAD: William S. Rubinstein, a real estate financing expert with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., has left to join Smith Barney, Harris Upham &amp; Company as a managing director.

Nissan Purchases
LEAD: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's second-largest car maker, said it planned to increase its purchases of American-made semiconductors.
The products now account for 2 percent of total semiconductor use by Nissan in its cars and trucks, and the company is hoping to increase that share to 10 percent in 1992.


Extradition Is Upheld for Bombing Suspect
LEAD: A Federal judge in Brooklyn ruled yesterday that a naturalized United States citizen accused in a 1986 terrorist attack on a bus in the Israeli-occupied West Bank could be extradited to Israel.
Judge Edward R. Korman overruled a decision by a magistrate who had found the arrest of the man, Mahmoud Abed Atta, 35 years old, was ''impermissible.


Amdahl to Buy Key Computer
LEAD: The Amdahl Corporation agreed to acquire Key Computer Laboratories Inc., a private company based in Fremont, Calif., for Amdahl stock valued at about $30 million.
With 60 employees, Key specializes in computer systems based on Unix, the industry standard operating system developed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, and other mainframe computer technologies.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy Posts Gains
LEAD: The Ogilvy Group reported 1988 revenues of $838.1 million, a 13.5 percent increase over the previous year.
Net income for the year rose 10.7 percent, to $32.9 million, or $2.25 a share, a record for the company.
The revenue growth was stronger than most analysts had expected, said Emma Hill, who follows advertising stocks for Wertheim, Schroder &amp; Company.

Bridgestone Plans 2d Tennessee Plant
LEAD: The Bridgestone Corporation said it would build a radial truck tire manufacturing plant in Tennessee at a cost of $350 million.

Touring Soviet Dancers Left Without Funds in Baltimore
LEAD: Fifty-nine ballet dancers from the Soviet Union who opened a United States tour in Baltimore on Thursday may have to return home because their American producers have lost expected financing. ''We don't even have the money to feed them,'' a spokesman for the producers said yesterday.

South Korean Debt Falls
LEAD: South Korea's foreign debt declined by $4.4 billion during 1988, the Bank of Korea reported today.
The country's foreign debt fell to $31.2 billion in December 1988 from $35.6 billion in December 1987, the bank said.
Bank officials said South Korea registered a record trade surplus of $14.27 billion in its current account in 1988, up 44.8 percent from $9.85 billion in 1987.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  SKIING  Girardelli Captures Gold: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg won the first men's gold medal at the world Alpine championships with a victory in the combined downhill yesterday in Beaver Creek, Colo.
Girardelli, an overwhelming favorite for the combined title after finishing third in the slalom Monday, was one-hundredth of a second behind the pacesetter, Michael Mair of Italy, in the downhill.


Review/Music; Dutoit and the Montrealers In Debussy and Beethoven
LEAD: There is a wide, all but unbridgeable, gap between playing a piece of music and performing it.
Disputes between listeners often involve this distinction, although it is seldom clear from the rhetoric vented that either party recognizes exactly what divides them.
Audiences sometimes seem torn between those listeners, often amateur musicians themselves, who can be tremendously excited by hearing playing that is without technical flaw, and those who require something more of music.

Pseudo-Spring, Real Guilt
LEAD: It was the best of Januaries and the worst of Januaries.
Best because the midday sun felt like late March, the evening air gave hints of April, the snowdrops popped up even earlier than usual.
Worst because of the worry that this was the greenhouse effect, already starting to warm us up.


North Africa Bloc Seen
LEAD: Five heads of state will meet in Marrakesh, Morocco, this month to discuss forming a North African trade union, the Moroccan Foreign Ministry said today.
The trade bloc -to be known as the Arab Maghreb Union - would link the 62 million people of Algeria, Morocco, Tunisia, Libya and Mauritania in a type of common market.

S.A.S. Lifts Stake
LEAD: Scandinavian Airlines System has increased its stake in the Texas Air Corporation to 9.9 percent from 7.9 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, S.A.S. said that on Tuesday and Wednesday it purchased an additional 802,200 Texas Air shares, at an average price of $15.38.
With these purchases, the Stockholm-based airline reached the maximum amount of shares that it can purchase under a recent agreement between the two airlines.

Scientist Says Antarctic Oil Spill Does Significant Harm to Wildlife
LEAD: Looking out at a wrecked Argentine ship, an American biologist in Antarctica yesterday reported the ''depressing'' toll of the leaking oil on the fragile and once unspoiled environment.
He described spreading oil slicks, dying sea life, penguins in peril, and adult birds disappearing and leaving their chicks to predators.

LEAD: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, looking into allegations that have delayed the confirmation of John G. Tower as Secretary of Defense, today interviewed a conservative lobbyist in Florida and the staff of a restaurant in Washington.


Filling Big Skates
LEAD: Mike McPhee of the Montreal Canadiens and Joe Nieuwendyk of the Calgary Flames will play in the National Hockey League All-Star game Tuesday night in Edmonton, Alberta, as substitutes for injured players.
McPhee will replace his teammate Mats Naslund, who is nursing a sprained ankle.
Nieuwendyk will take the place of Denis Savard of the Chicago Blackhawks, who is also suffering from an ankle injury.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Money Market Funds
LEAD:  Money market mutual funds are more popular today than they have been in some time.
Investors pulling back from recent volatility in the stock and bond markets have been using mutual funds as a parking place while they decide which investment route to take.
Individuals are also using the funds as a savings or cash management tool, in addition to other kinds of investments.

LEAD: Moshe Arens, Israel's new Foreign Minister, believes that nothing could be more irrelevant than the Israeli Army's recent finding that Yasir Arafat's arm of the Palestine Liberation Organization has ceased guerrilla attacks against Israel.

LEAD: It may be more blessed to give than to receive, but the national office of Catholic Charities has joined the ranks of those proposing to do both at the same time.
The organization has started to promote its new Caritas Mastercard, christened with the Latin word for charity or love.
Any time Caritas cardholders use their cards, one-half of 1 percent of the sales price will go to Catholic

LEAD: Shamrock Holdings Inc. submitted 14 nominees today to be considered for positions on the board of the Polaroid Corporation at the company's annual meeting May 9.
Shamrock, the Burbank, Calif., investment group that has pursued Polaroid since July, said last month that it would seek control of the board through a proxy fight to advance its $3.2 billion takeover bid, which Polaroid has rejected.

Blacks Start Church in 'Whitest' State
LEAD: Before moving to Vermont from Michigan last year to work at the university here, Rodney S. Patterson asked about the whereabouts of churches ministering to the needs of blacks.
He was disappointed, but not surprised, to find that there were none.
After all, Vermont is the state that Ebony magazine called ''the Whitest state in America.


New Beckett Book Makes a Dramatic Entrance
LEAD: Before presenting the first reading in the United States of Samuel Beckett's most recent work, ''Stirrings Still,'' Barry McGovern offered a disclaimer.
He said the text was prose and not meant to be performed.
But as with late Beckett short plays like ''A Piece of Monologue'' and ''Rockaby,'' it is a brief, dense interior monologue.

Ramage Suspended
LEAD: Rob Ramage, a Calgary Flames defenseman, was suspended for eight games yesterday by the N.H.L. for a stick infraction on Jan. 15 in which he knocked down Doug Bodger of the Buffalo Sabres. ''Although Ramage does not have a previous history of stick fouls, players must understand that there can be no excuse for reckless swinging of their sticks at opponents,'' said Brian O'Neill, the N.H.L.


Bill White a Unanimous Choice to Head National League
LEAD: Bill White's name was not on the first list of candidates to succeed Bart Giamatti as National League president.
But yesterday, when White was officially introduced to the news media at a midtown hotel, it was clear he was the popular choice.
The longtime Yankee broadcaster, who will take office April 1, will become the National League's 13th president.

Now there are plausible signs of substantive changes as well.

LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation donated four buildings at its closed plant in Kenosha, Wis., to local officials for use as a manufacturing site and a human resources and employment center.
The four buildings, including the main general plant offices, have more than 500,000 square feet of office space.

LEAD: New York State's method of awarding merit scholarships to high school students on the basis of their scores on Scholastic Aptitude Tests discriminates against girls, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.
He ordered the state to change its selection process.

LEAD: The mayor of Camden, N.J., fresh from a course in pistol-handling techniques, used his 9-millimeter handgun to hold off a burglar who smashed into his house before dawn Thursday after breaking away from police and leaping, handcuffed, across rooftops and alleys in the southern part of the city.

LEAD: The Stanford String Quartet, founded in 1983, now consists of two veteran players - Andor Toth, the first violinist, and Bernard Zaslav, the violist - and two younger musicians, Zoya Leybin, violinist, and Stephen Harrison, cellist.
The quartet is on a tour of major American cities and London as part of the Stanford University centennial celebrations.

LEAD: The death of a young black man in police custody has prompted complaints by many blacks of police brutality and raised tensions in this historic town, which has long prided itself for being progressive on social issues.

U.S. Links Man With 3 Bombs To a Terror Plot
LEAD: The Federal Government asserted today that a Japanese man convicted of possessing three powerful homemade bombs was part of an Japanese Red Army terrorist plot seeking revenge for the United States air raid against Libya in 1986.


P. I. Prentice, 82, Former Publisher of Time
LEAD: P. I. Prentice, a former publisher of Time magazine and other periodicals, died Thursday at Morton Plant Hospital in Clearwater, Fla. after suffering a series of strokes over the last three years.
He was 89 years old and lived in Belleair, Fla.


PARAGUAY: At a Glance
LEAD:  Government


Special Camp Fair
LEAD: A Special Camp Fair, from noon to 5 P.M. tomorrow at the Jewish Guild for the Blind, is to feature 70 programs for children and teen-agers with disabilities.
The fair is sponsored by Resources for Children with Special Needs, the 92d Street Y and the International Center for the Disabled.
Directors from the 70 programs will be on hand to give advice on day and sleep-away camps, travel, early childhood and remedial education programs and volunteer and job opportunities.


John Cassavetes, Major Director In U.S. Cinema Verite, Dies at 59
LEAD: John Cassavetes, an actor, screenwriter and director who was in the forefront of American cinema verite, died yesterday in Los Angeles.
He was 59 years old.


Swing for Dancing
LEAD: Bill Conway and Swing Express will play swing music for dancing in a program presented by the New York Swing Society, on tomorrow at the Cat Club, 76 East 13th Street (505-0090).
Doors open at 7 P.M., with music beginning at 8; tickets are $8, $4 for the elderly.

LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. said today that he shared President Bush's position that energy resources on public lands should be exploited in ''an environmentally acceptable manner,'' and he called for opening the vast Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in northern Alaska for oil exploration and drilling.

Bush Aides' Plan on Savings Units Is Said to Place Cost on Industry
LEAD: The Treasury plans to submit proposals to President Bush on Saturday that will place much of the burden for dealing with the savings and loan crisis on private industry, Congressional aides and industry experts said today.


Malone's 28 Points Lead Jazz Past Nets
LEAD: Karl Malone scored 28 points and added a career-high 9 assists as the Utah Jazz routed the New Jersey Nets, 129-101, tonight.


Nintendo Amends Atari Games Suit
LEAD: Nintendo has filed another suit in its long dispute with American companies over the $2.3 billion annual video-game market.
Nintendo of America on Thursday filed legal action in United States District Court against Atari Games Inc., charging patent infringement.
Also named was Tengen Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Atari Games.

EMPLOYMENT SURGE REPORTED BY U.S. FOR START OF YEAR
LEAD: A persistently vigorous economy and exceptionally mild weather caused employment to surge last month, creating a record in the proportion of people of working age who have jobs, the Labor Department said today.


Dow Off a 3d Straight Day but Up for Week
LEAD: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average dropped for the third consecutive day.


Jim Moore Photos
LEAD: ''Jim Moore Photographs: A Variety of Performing Artists'' runs through Feb. 25 at the Amsterdam Gallery, 111 Amsterdam Avenue, at 65th Street.
The exhibition, a 15-year retrospective sponsored by the New York Public Library and the Museum of Performing Arts, presents 100 black and white photographs of clowns, magicians, mimes and jugglers, some famous, some not.


Major Soviet Paper Says 20 Million Died As Victims of Stalin
LEAD: A Soviet weekly newspaper today published the most detailed accounting of Stalin's victims yet presented to a mass audience here, indicating that about 20 million died in labor camps, forced collectivization, famine and executions.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Ascom Holding A.G. and Rockaway Corp., Parsippany, N.J., said they had signed a definitive agreement for the previously announced merger of Rockaway into a U.S. subsidiary of Ascom.
The transaction is valued at $112 million.

Huge Soviet Convoy Leaves Kabul
LEAD: A huge Soviet military convoy pulled out of Kabul in a snowstorm during the night.
Soviet officials said no more than 1,500 Soviet troops were left in the besieged Afghan capital.


Much of the U.S. Shivers and Skids
LEAD: An ocean of Arctic air that engulfed much of the nation this week with the year's bitterest cold continued its assault yesterday, sending temperatures plunging to merciless lows from the Pacific Northwest to the Great Lakes and icing the landscape from Texas to New England.


Lockheed Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of the Lockheed Corporation rose on renewed takeover speculation and rumors that the investment bank Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company was working with the aerospace company on a restructuring plan.
Lockheed rose $1, to $48, as the New York Stock Exchange's ninth-most-active issue, after being up more than $2 during the day.

BUSH ETHICS AIDE KEPT OUTSIDE JOB
LEAD: An examination of the finances of the White House counsel, C. Boyden Gray, chosen by President Bush to enforce his call for the highest possible ethical standards, shows that he has been chairman of a $500 million communications company for the last six years while working for Mr.
Bush and lacks familiarity with Government ethics procedures.


Lee Stevens, 58, of Talent Agency
LEAD: Lee Stevens, the president and chief executive officer of the William Morris Agency, died of lymphoma on Thursday at the Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 58 years old.


Illinois Is Urged To Repeal Law For AIDS Tests
LEAD: The first year of mandatory prenuptial AIDS testing in Illinois has turned up few cases of the virus and has caused tens of thousands of people to flee the state to be married and untold others to put off marriage altogether, Illinois health officials say.

Paraguay's Republic of Fear
LEAD: Paraguay is well rid of Gen.
Alfredo Stroessner, deposed in a violent coup early yesterday by one of his own army commanders and ordered into exile.
A canny and cold-blooded tyrant, General Stroessner sustained himself in power for almost 35 years by creating a republic of fear.


NEW GUIDE, LESS SQUINTING
LEAD: Help for the visually impaired shopper is now at hand in the form of a new guide published by Consumer Reports.


Tutu Asks U.S. Jews to Urge Palestinian Pact
LEAD: Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu, the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize winner, asserted this week that he found events in the Israeli-occupied territories similar to those in South Africa.
He urged American Jews to press Israel to reach a settlement with the Palestinians and to repudiate its joint programs with the South African

LEAD: Les Boatwright was going to meet his bookmaker that Monday when he suffered a heart attack, and as swiftly as a score in a game might change, he went to meet his maker instead.

LEAD: Iran and Iraq are showing some movement in their long-stalled peace negotiations, offering small concessions in talks with a United Nations mediator, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar reported today.


Officials Say Tampa Suspect May Have Suffocated
LEAD: A black man whose death in police custody set off two nights of stone- and bottle-throwing may have suffocated while lying tied and handcuffed in a patrol car, medical investigators said today.

LEAD: Curlew, an avant-rock quintet, is to perform at 9 and 11 o'clock tonight at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055).

F.S.L.I.C. Head to Quit; He Defends His Agency
LEAD: The head of the Government agency that insures deposits at the nation's savings and loan associations will resign, effective next Friday, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today.


House of Music Benefit
LEAD: The Bloomingdale House of Music is to celebrate its 25th anniversary with a gala benefit featuring the folk singer Odetta on Monday at the Trinity School, 101 West 91st Street.
The evening will begin with cocktails at 6:30 P.M. and a performance by Odetta at 7:30, followed by dinner.
Tickets are priced from $1,000 to $50.

LEAD: Michael K. Deaver, a former White House aide, today abandoned his appeal of perjury convictions for lying about his lobbying, saying he wanted to ''get on with my life.''
