Ringier Withdraws W.A. Krueger Bid
LEAD: The W. A. Krueger Company, a commercial printing concern based in Scottsdale, said that Ringier A.G. of Zurich had withdrawn its offer of $10 a share, or a total of about $321 million.
But Krueger said that the Swiss concern, which is also a printing company, still remained interested in acquiring


Europe Flight Delays Up
LEAD: Nineteen percent of European airline flights were delayed by at least 15 minutes in 1988, up from 14.9 percent in the previous year, the Association of European Airlines reported today.
It said the delays affected 13 million passengers, up from 9.5 million in 1987.
In its annual report, the group also said its 21 member airlines posted a 6.1 percent growth in passenger traffic in 1988.


A State Senator Is Found Guilty In a Loan Case
LEAD: State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. was found guilty yesterday of filing a false application for a bank loan that was to be used to build a supermarket in his South Bronx district.
He was acquitted of perjury and another charge of making a false application.


How to Un-Veto Federal Ethics
LEAD: Government service, the new President says, is a ''noble calling'' and his Administration will not tolerate even the ''appearance of what is wrong.'' The two ideas, whose declaration from the White House is warmly welcome, reinforce each other.
A strong way to assure the nobility of public service is to make clear that public servants live by high standards.

The 'Challenge' of Bow Hunting
LEAD: I have read Thomas V. Connors's letter (''Ban on Bow Hunting Is Without Logic'' Jan. 22) reacting to mine (''Deer Hunting on Fire Island'' Jan 8) urging a ban not, unrealistically, on hunting per se, but on bow hunting only.
But I found myself distanced from understanding Connors's milieu even further by his reference to such weapons' use as a ''logical extension of hunting practices that outdate all but the cavemen's spear.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL/3-21


Brazil Cardinal's Praise of Castro Stirs Protest
LEAD: The head of Brazil's largest Roman Catholic archdiocese has provoked an outcry in conservative circles here by writing a letter to President Fidel Castro expressing the hope that he will always govern Cuba.


Putting the Best Foot Forward
LEAD: BARRINGTON'S of East Islip does its best.
Whether it's a special occasion or a special diet, it comes through.
This is a restaurant that's warm, willing and welcoming.
When diners call for reservations, they are often asked if a birthday or anniversary is being celebrated.
If so, a cake may appear for dessert.

LEAD: Emily Rebecca Remes, a lawyer for the New York State Commission on Government Integrity, and Craig Andrew Stewart, an assistant United States Attorney, were married yesterday at the Loft in Manhattan.

Modern Trends In Medals
LEAD: MEDALLIC art has changed since the first flattering portraits in metal commissioned by Italian princes and German merchants during the 15th and 16th centuries.
The American Numismatic Society at 155th Street and Broadway is showing modern examples of the art from around the world.
The exhibition will run through April 1.

Add Real Human Suffering to Abortion Debate
LEAD: To the Editor:


Michelle Oaklan to Marry
LEAD: Mrs.
Marie Oaklan and Norman Oaklan, both of Buffalo, have announced April wedding plans for their daughter Michelle Oaklan and John Michael McFaul, a son of John McFaul of Watertown, N.Y., and the late Mary McFaul.
Miss Oaklan, a graduate of the Rochester Institute of Technology, is the director of public relations at Loews Hotels in New York.


Innumeracy
LEAD: To the Editor:


200 Soviet Muslims Protest For More Religious Freedom
LEAD: More than 200 Soviet Muslims marched from a mosque through the Uzbek capital of Tashkent to press the Government to take up their religious demands, Tass reported today.


In a Philippine Town, Child Prostitution, Despite Protests, Is a Way of Life
LEAD: Drive into this green and quiet town 40 miles southeast of Manila and groups of men will run alongside your car, banging on the windows, offering a choice of the local attractions: A boat ride to the scenic waterfall or a child prostitute.


Getting a Direct Line to the State Department
LEAD: FOR 10 years, the Bureau of Consular Affairs in the State Department has been preparing, revising and rescinding informative notices to Americans about travel abroad.
These information sheets, or travel advisories, to give them their official name, are based on reports from State Department people in the field.

The Case of the Purloined Party
LEAD: MARDI GRAS is invariably associated with New Orleans.
However, the event is a regional one and actually started in 1704 in Mobile, Ala., a smaller, more provincial city 150 miles east of New Orleans.
As the celebration has flowered in Louisiana, Mobilians have become truculent and defensive about their party, which seems to have abandoned them like an ungrateful son who ran after a painted woman, settling down happily in the sin and carelessness of New Orleans.

LEAD: The New York City Ballet danced an all-Tchaikovsky program on Friday night at the New York State Theater, thereby honoring one of the ballet world's greatest composers.

Yet Tchaikovsky's orchestral and instrumental music is so rhythmically supple and emotionally expressive that it can easily send dancers whirling.


Sleeping Pills
LEAD: IN THE DIM LIGHT OF MY bathroom, I looked into a vial at a dozen oval, sky-blue sleeping pills.
I was getting desperate.
At 2 A.M., an emergency-room doctor at the hospital had awakened me to get some advice.
Since then, my brain had buzzed without mercy.
I tried all the rituals of the insomniac until 3:30, when I pulled out my rarely used bottle of Halcion with the anxiety of someone hesitant to plunge into the unknown known.

LEAD:  A RUSSIAN IN HARTFORD  A Soviet play with a Soviet director and an American cast will open at the Hartford Stage Company for previews on Saturday, to Feb. 16.
The play, ''The Paper Gramophone,'' will run from Feb. 17 to March 18.
The director, Yuri Yeremin, who has adapted the work from an unproduced screenplay by Alexander Chervinsky, is making his American debut with this production.


The Deficit Melts if Spending Is Fixed
LEAD: The question of how to reduce the chronic Federal Government deficit is on the front burner.
The flexible freeze concept, which I developed in 1978 and presented to George Bush - who was running for President - at a meeting in Kennebunkport, Me., in August of that year.
The freeze appeared then - as it does now - to be the most economically sound and politically feasible approach to reducing the deficit.

When the Law Becomes Big Business
LEAD: The law has become big business.
Today, several firms have more than 1,000 attorneys, with gross revenues of $250 million or more.
Modern ''mega-firms'' emphasize profitability, productivity and business generation in an atmosphere of competitiveness and bureaucracy.
But as these firms grow, some of the values important to the practice of law have been sacrificed.

FICTION
LEAD:  THE BODY POLITIC.
By Victor Gold and Lynne Cheney. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) When art seeks so blatantly to imitate life, one asks, at the minimum, that it be done creatively.
In ''The Body Politic,'' a slim novel annotated with fictitious transcripts and official-looking memorandums that attempts to hook readers with its snapshots of power plays inside the White House and on Capitol Hill, it unfortunately is not.

The Salty Oasis of Cedar Key
LEAD: WE were a half tank out of Orlando, somewhere near Yankeetown, heading north for Cedar Key, when the urge for oysters struck.
With the top down on our rented red Chrysler, unfolding the road map was difficult.
Fortunately, we were cruising through a part of Florida where it's hard to get lost: the Big


RIVER BLINDNESS
LEAD: Erik Eckholm's article on river blindness in West Africa was interesting (''River Blindness: Conquering an Ancient Scourge,'' Jan. 8).
I had the opportunity to travel some years ago in Upper Volta, and saw this devastating illness firsthand.
William C. Campbell and his team, who discovered ivermectin, and Merck &amp; Company, which is providing the drug without charge, are to be commended, along with the international team that is coordinating the dispensing of the drug.


Butter Sculptures
LEAD: For the next month, visitors to the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street, will be able to see eight Tibetan monks from the Gyuto Tantric Monastery create more than 25 pastel-colored butter sculptures.
The sculptures, or the 15 Chupas, which are part of Buddhist ritual, will be on view for two to three weeks after their completion in late February.


Recitals from Vienna and Canada
LEAD: VISITORS from England, Austria and Canada bracket the week at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers, with the pianist Stephen Hough giving a recital there today at 3 P.M. and the violist Thomas Riebl joining the Orford String Quartet at that same hour next Sunday.


Kentucky Accepts Fault
LEAD: The University of Kentucky, in responding to National Collegiate Athletic Association allegations against its basketball program, will accept responsibility for a package of money said to have been sent to the father of a recruit, The Lexington Herald-Leader reported today.


The 60's Reinvented: Only the Beat Goes On
LEAD: When CBS's sitcom heroine Murphy Brown, a star television journalist in her early 40's, first meets her new, 25-year-old executive producer, she doesn't ask him about his news experience or format plans.
She simply demands, ''Do you know who the Shirelles are?''


Columbia-Presbyterian Laying Off 300
LEAD: Beset by continuing financial pressures, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center has laid off 50 employees and plans to cut another 250 from its 6,200-member staff in the next two weeks.

Proposition 42: Debate Goes On
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground.
On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade.
This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil.

LEAD: FOR weeks, the General Assembly and its tag-along army of lobbyists have trudged through the fog of pre-budget uncertainty, straining for a landmark or a sign that could reveal the outlines of the budget Gov.
William A. O'Neill will propose this week.


What Was Lost In Afghanistan
LEAD: IN 1979, as tens of thousands of Soviet troops streamed into Afghanistan, Moscow's strategy seemed straightforward and completely in line with its world view: A bold military strike, reminiscent of moves into Hungary and Czechoslovakia, would prevent insurrection and chaos from toppling a pro-Soviet and Marxist regime.


Exposure and Light How to Overcome the Reciprocity Failure
LEAD: HAVE you ever taken pictures just after sunset and found later that they come out underexposed with an unattractive shade of green?
Have you ever had some of your flash pictures come out darker than they should?
If so, you may have been a victim of what's known as reciprocity failure.

THE REGION: A Warm Economy; New York Is About to Find Out What Happens After a Boom
LEAD: TRUE to predictions, 1988 marked the abrupt end of Wall Street's boom.
But it also showed that the metropolitan region's six-year economic recovery still has some steam, especially outside Manhattan.
Jobs are still being produced, though much more slowly than in the past, and economists expect growth to continue in 1989, though they are not sure for how long.

Ulster Protestants and Catholics Talk Secretly
LEAD: Leading politicians from four Protestant and Catholic parties in Northern Ireland have acknowledged secretly talking to each other since October about resuming a dialogue on ways out of the violence that has killed 2,700 people since 1969.

Crux of Problem: Animal Suffering
LEAD: Continuing the discusions of deer population control, Thomas V. Connors (Letters to the Editor, Jan. 22) pleads that logic should prevail in governmental decisions affecting animal conservation.
However, he completely overlooks the basic crux of the controversy between hunters and animal rights activists -- that is, the pain and agony caused to the innocent deer.

Terminology Tested
LEAD: THERE has always been a trans-Atlantic difficulty, in bridge terms, about the meaning of protection.
In Britain the word describes the act of reopening an auction that would be ended by a pass: The idea is to protect a partner who may have passed with a good hand.

Tal Defeats Timman in an Exhibition Match
LEAD: MIKHAIL TAL of the Soviet Union, who held the world championship in 1960, won the 1988 KRO Exhibition Match on Dec. 23 in Hilversum, the Netherlands, against the Dutch grandmaster Jan Timman.
Tal scored 3 1/2 to 2 1/2 in the six-game contest sponsored by Katholieke Radio Omroep and the Interpolis insurance company.

LEAD: Replies for publication should be no more than 300 words and addressed to Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036.
Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number.
We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

Prospects; The Dow Creeps Up
LEAD: The stock market, which has been climbing since the first of the year, last week rose to its highest level since the October 1987 collapse.
On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,331.25.
The markets in London, Tokyo and Frankfurt have also risen sharply this year.
Financial experts are debating whether this is the beginning of a new, global bull market or just the ''January effect'' - when stock prices rise at the start of a new year.

LEAD: In the beginning was the Astrodome, plopped down in 1965 like a wayward flying saucer in a sweltering pasture south of downtown Houston.


TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
LEAD: Joseph Califano's talk to Democrats was not only tough, but so cynical it will fail to serve his party in any way.
All he explains is how to take some votes away from Republicans.
He does not address the larger problem: how to persuade the other half of the electorate - the half that does not vote at all - to go to the polls.

Braves' Hall Loses
LEAD: When Glenn Wong, the arbitrator, awarded Albert Hall a $250,000 salary yesterday instead of the $310,000 the player had bid for, Hall became the second player and the second Atlanta Brave outfielder to lose in salary arbitration this winter.
Hall had the same salary last year.
Dion James, the other Brave, is the only other player whose case has been decided in arbitration.

They should give third base to Jefferies, second base to Miller and Fernandez's slot in the rotation to West.

That German Accent in American Modern Dance
LEAD: The German strain of contemporary dance as it has manifested itself in the United States is usually overlooked if not unacknowledged.
There is general agreement that modern dance, a 20th-century phenomenon, has been dominated by Americans.
But it is also true that between the World Wars, Germany was a major center in the growth of the free dance, as the creative form outside the ballet tradition was formerly called.

EUROPEAN REPORT: MILAN, LONDON AND MADRID
LEAD: In the short film that accompanied his most recent show of women's fashions, Franco Moschino, Italy's self-appointed gadfly of the runways, publicly tweaked the establishment by declaring fashion ''full of chic.'' Moments earlier, the designer had cheerfully lampooned the existing order, trotting out onto the catwalk such affronts to good taste as a tight-fitting low-cut evening dress festooned with metallicized lampshade fringe.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Jan. 8 about Shiite Muslim terrorist attacks on Saudi diplomats characterized the Hejaz region of Saudi Arabia incorrectly.
It is not part of the eastern province and does not have a large Shiite population.

Switching Channels
LEAD: A high-stakes cast change is coming to prime-time news.
After more than a decade with CBS News, Diane Sawyer is leaving to become a co-anchor on a new prime-time news program on ABC.
Ms.
Sawyer, who has been a correspondent on ''60 Minutes'' since 1984, and Sam Donaldson, the former ABC chief White House correspondent, are to be co-anchors of a program that the network has been planning for several years and is likely to begin by this summer.

Mario M. Cuomo already has a war chest of $4,771,789, according to a report filed with the State Board of Elections by his continuing campaign organization.


Correction
LEAD: An obituary last Sunday about Martin Popper, a New York lawyer who died on Jan. 27, omitted the disposition of a court action involving him.
His conviction in 1961 for contempt of Congress, after he declined to tell a Congressional committee whether he was a Communist, was reversed in 1962 by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia.


To West Germans, The Far Right Isn't Just Another Fringe
LEAD: BY the standards of most functioning democracies, a rise of fever on the far right in times of stress is not a cause for undue alarm, unpleasant as it may be to acknowledge the tenacity of xenophobia and bigotry.
But in West Germany the boundaries of political sentiment are still constrained by history and suspiciousness: While a shift to the left raises allied suspicions of a latent German longing for neutrality, a blip on the far right still touches off the ''neo-Nazi'' alarm.


Keeping the Profits From Your House
LEAD: The runup in real estate prices over the past few years is leaving more and more owners with huge profits when they sell their properties.
The tax bill on those profits will be put off for many of the owners when they file their 1988 returns in coming months and show that they rolled the gains into another house.

A Gust of Competition in Meteorology
LEAD: Temperatures as low as 80 degrees below zero in Alaska over the last 10 days have wreaked untold damage - causing a few planes to crash, pipes to burst, utility wires to snap and industry to come to a virtual halt.
But losses would have been greater, weather experts say, had the state been caught completely off guard.


Doubts on Peary's Polar Feat Tied to Misreading of a Paper
LEAD: Recent charges that Robert E. Peary deliberately faked his assertion that his 1909 expedition was the first to reach the North Pole were based on a ''completely erroneous'' interpretation of a key document, according to navigation experts studying the dispute.


Concerto Premiere
LEAD: Stanislaw Skrowaczewski is to conduct the American Composer's Orchestra in the New York premiere of his own Violin Concerto, and the world premiere of Aaron Jay Kernis's ''Invisible Mosaic III,'' at Carnegie Hall at 3 P.M. today.
Also on the program is the William Schuman Violin Concerto.
Robert McDuffie is to be the soloist in the Skrowaczewski and Schuman works.

ABOUT BOOKS
LEAD: ''PAUL ROBESON'' by Martin Bauml Duberman (Knopf, New York, $24.95) is a passionate, tantalizing book.
Approach its 803 pages carefully; it returns the reader to yesterday's headlines, relentlessly opening and probing old wounds to pursue the larger-than-life story of one of the most significant black figures in American history.

'The Years Go By, The Skin Sags'
LEAD: IT is not just the rich and famous who are having cosmetic surgery these days.
People from all walks of life are now asking surgeons to fix their physical flaws, big and small, said a Waterbury cosmetic surgeon, Paula A. Moynahan.
For some, it means forgoing a vacation or a second car; for others, it is simply a quick dip in the savings or checking account.


POSTINGS: A Tale of 2 Towns; Factory-Built Units Straddle a Border
LEAD: Assembly-line housing is being put up in an unusual condominium project that straddles the Maplewood-Irvington Township border near Newark in Essex County, N.J.
The first apartments in a cluster of 14 two- and three-story buildings are to be ready this month, with all 51 two-bedroom units finished by the end of the year.

THE GUNS OF SLAVADOR
LEAD: STILL HAGGARD AND GAUNT FROM his time in the mountains of El Salvador, the guerrilla official put a recording of a Haydn symphony on the stereo and sat down to talk.
It was his 13th year of fighting to overthrow his country's government.
As Haydn's reassuring tones filled the room, the rebel visibly relaxed, safe now in a nearby country outside El Salvador.

A Letter To Martin
LEAD: MARTIN, the dream has faded and it is now wake-up time.
Twenty-one years have passed and our people are still in the dream state.
Still singing, ''We shall overcome'' and still saying, ''We are living the dream.'' I'm beginning to wonder, whose dream are we living?
It is time to rise from the world of dreams.

THE BROTHERS WOLFF
LEAD: ON THE WALL OF GEOFFREY WOLFF'S JAMESTOWN, R.I., living room is an early American portrait of a Colonial matron whose half-smile suggests, improbably, a flinty New England Mona Lisa.
Wolff refers to the painting as a ''generic ancestor portrait'' whose subject's ''knowing smirk'' has often made him wish that she were in fact a relative.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Our clapboard garage is built on a cement-block foundation and is on sloping ground.
On one side, the bottom row of clapboards is one foot above ground level, but on the other side the bottom row is nine inches below grade.
This is one foot from our neighbor's property line, so it is impossible to regrade the soil.

Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review of John Costello's ''Mask of Treachery'' on Dec. 25 misstated the year in which the spies Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean fled Britain for the Soviet Union.
It was 1951.


TOUGH TALK FOR DEMOCRATS
LEAD: If we Democrats follow Joseph Califano's advice, we will win national elections again.
Our current Presidential nominating process guarantees Democratic defeat.
The process forces candidates to appeal only to narrow segments of the electorate.
A survivor of that undemocratic nominating process forfeits the chance to win the general election.

THE NATION: In Federal Departments; Are Judge and Agency Too Close for Justice?
LEAD: WHEN a corporation or a private citizen disputes a Federal agency's decision - involving, say, a disability pension or an allegation of unfair labor practices - an administrative law judge decides who is right.
But more and more, critics are raising questions about the atmosphere in which these decisions are rendered, given that one party in every case is the agency that employs the judge.


Rodriguez Honored
LEAD: He may not have been the biggest money winner during his 25 years on the PGA Tour, but few golfers of his generation attracted as many devoted followers as Chi Chi Rodriguez.
Now, at the age of 53, Rodriguez has become a big money man on the Senior Tour and has received some high-level recognition, too.


Combat Pay in Gulf May End
LEAD: The general in charge of the United States Central Command has recommended suspension of combat pay for sailors in the Persian Gulf, Pentagon officials say.
The recommendation, under review by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is the strongest indication yet that American defense officials believe the truce between Iran and Iraq may hold.


If Time Flies, It Can Hop, Skip and Jump
LEAD: AND now, fashion watchers, an up-to-the-minute report: at 3:15, a woman in boots and a miniskirt was seen hurrying up Fifth Avenue.
Just 20 minutes earlier, a chic woman in a fur-trimmed leather suit designed by Gianfranco Ferre was hurrying uptown.
Other timely spottings were made at 2:25 and 5:35.


Using Yak Hair to Woo Business
LEAD: Dwarfed by the bedraggled red curtain that covers the faded pink walls of the Hotel Intourist dining room here in the Soviet Far East, a Japanese businessman taps relentlessly through dinner at a shiny laptop computer.
Continuing even after a stern, slow waitress flicks an abacus to tally his check, he is straddling two very different worlds: one breaking out of the late 19th century, another hurtling into the 21st.


POSTINGS: $11 Million Apartment House; A High Riser On 86th Street
LEAD: An 18-story apartment house is rising on the north side of 86th Street near Second Avenue on the site of a cluster of Yorkville row houses, some part of the Rhinelander development of a century ago.
When erected in the 1880's there were six buildings with the addresses 237-247 East 86th Street, but the structures had been modified considerably over the years before their demolition last year.

LEAD: MUCH was made in last year's Presidential campaign about Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis's veto of a Massachusetts law to require public school pupils to recite the Pledge of Allegiance each school day.
What effect did the sound and fury have on school policy in Massachusetts?


Winograd to Return to the Hartford
LEAD: ARTHUR WINOGRAD ended his long tenure as the music director of the Hartford Symphony in April 1985, but on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M. he will return to the podium at Bushnell Hall.
The maestro's son, the violinist Peter Winograd, will make a guest appearance and play the Second Violin Concerto of Prokofiev.

LEAD: 'We came to believe that an illegal underground ''black market'' may exist in New York in the private placement of children for adoption.' - A Manhattan grand jury reporting on its investigation into how Joel B. Steinberg obtained Lisa, the child he was convicted of killing.

And in This Gallery, We See the Ancient Moog
LEAD: My old friend took it very well, I thought, when he read that a Moog synthesizer had been placed in a museum.
No dropping of the jaw in amazement, no forehead slapping, no tiresome jeremiad about the accelerating tempo of modern existence.
But the news did shake him up, I could tell.
After all, the Moog in a museum?

LEAD: Should we be excited that year two of the 92d Sreet Y's Schubertiade is upon us?
Some think it a Quixotic idea - all the Schubert repertory performed over a 10-year span and in the order it was written.
An endurance test?
Spiritual weight-lifting?
An ambition endearing but perhaps a little foolish?

LEAD: THERE is nothing like spicy food to take the chill off a gray winter day.
From Italy, the American Southwest and from China, the following recipes are simple to make - and a little exotic.
They are also light and extremely low in saturated fats.


Bills Renew Debate on Death Penalty
LEAD: CONSERVATIVE legislators are again seeking to strengthen the death-penalty law.
They contend the statute is so difficult to impose that it might as well not exist.


On That Good Montana Powder
LEAD: A SMALL group of skiers had gathered in the Snowgoose Grille at the base of Big Mountain.
It was the end of a full day of powder skiing on the alpine slopes of Whitefish, a small town in northwest Montana.
The halogen lights of nighttime skiing shed an amber glow across the lower reaches of Hibernation, a favorite intermediate run.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH she does not mean to look a gift horse in the mouth, First Selectman Linda Bongiolatti of Litchfield said she did not want her recent 5 percent pay raise.
Miss Bongiolatti told the town to keep the money.

I am a 15-year-old girl who believes that female teen-agers have at least as much technological ability as male teen-agers.

Ms.

Landfill Linked to Cases of Leukemia and Low Birth Weight
LEAD: People living close to the nation's No. 1 Superfund toxic-waste cleanup site, the closed Lipari landfill, were more likely to contract adult leukemia or produce babies with low birth weights than people beyond one kilometer, a state study has concluded.

POSTINGS: What Price Parking?; A 2d Garage Condo
LEAD: Brooklyn is getting its second condominium parking garage, this one in the Cobble Hill neighborhood.
A development group has bought a 50-year-old, three-story factory at 187 Pacific Street between Court and Clinton Streets and converted it into 130 condominium parking spaces priced at $27,500, $30,000 and $40,000, depending upon size - an average of about $262 a square foot.

What the States Are Doing for Industry
LEAD: DOUG ROSS, the director of the Michigan Commerce Department, met recently with his counterparts from other Middle Western states, and proposed a kind of industrial disarmament accord.
If the other states would do likewise, Mr.
Ross proposed, Michigan would stop using local property tax abatements as a lure to entice manufacturers and other businesses to relocate in his state.

THE WORLD: New Rules in Poland; Jaruzelski Tries to Buy Peace With Pluralism
LEAD: POLAND'S leader and his supporters had to threaten to resign in order to persuade the Communist Party Central Committee to talk to Solidarity.
The tactic amounted, a Solidarity strategist said later, to a ''declaration of martial law on the Central Committee.'' But the hard part for Gen.
Wojciech Jaruzelski may be only beginning.


Signs of Strength Raise Some Jitters
LEAD: Statistical signs of strength in the economy heightened anxiety among those worried that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates further to cool the economy and dampen inflation tendencies.
The most startling figure was a 408,000 rise in the number of nonfarm jobs created in January.
An increase of about 300,000, the monthly average gain last year, had been expected.

There is nothing even left to tax.

LEAD: The word was out on Sharon Sweet.
This 37-year-old soprano from Gloversville, N.Y., had been singing professionally for only three seasons, but in those three she had moved to the top of the field about as fast as one can move in the world of opera.
Fans, impresarios and managers from all over the country were lined up in eager expectation to hear her American debut in the Verdi Requiem, with the Collegiate Chorale Saturday night at Carnegie Hall.

LEAD: As taxpayers begin filling out their 1988 returns in the next few weeks, many will be paying at the lowest rates since World War II.
The reason is that 1988 was the first year in which the rate reductions of the Tax Reform Act of 1986 were fully effective.

GLOBAL BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Turkey and a Canadian-led group will sign a $500 million agreement today to build the first nine miles of a rail system in Ankara, a municipal spokesman said.
A fifth of the lines will run underground.
Canada's Urban Transport Development Corporation and its Turkish partners, Gama Endustri and Guris Insaat, were awarded the four-year contract in July.

The Editorial Notebook; Cuba's Quarantine for AIDS
LEAD: Cuba has an unusual AIDS policy.
A third of its population has already been tested for the virus, and the 240 people found to be infected have been put into quarantine.
Since no cure is in sight, their isolation is indefinite.

LEAD: Young &amp; Rubicam has won back the Motorola corporate advertising account that its Chicago office had lost to Lintas: U.S.A. a year ago.
The budget is about $5 million annually.


Diet Determines Color and Shape of a Caterpillar
LEAD: The food eaten by a caterpillar in the Southwest causes bodily changes allowing the insect to mimic the seasonal appearance of its oak tree home, a researcher reports.


Metro Datelines; Death of a Judge Is Ruled a Suicide
LEAD: The state's Chief Medical Examiner ruled yesterday that the death of a Superior Court judge, Richard C. Noren, was a suicide.
The judge killed himself, officials said, days after withdrawing his bid for reappointment while facing Judiciary Committee questions about his drinking.


Tauscher Edges Swiss For Men's Downhill Title
LEAD: The cowbells and drumbeats were briefly silenced today when Hansjoerg Tauscher of West Germany crossed the finish line of the men's downhill race in the world Alpine championships.


Paraguay's Leader Denies Ties to Drug Trafficking
LEAD: Trying to dispel rumors of drug connections, Paraguay's new leader today denied any involvement in narcotics trafficking and pledged to fight what he called ''one of mankind's worst scourges.''

Books of The Times; Stories That Call an Evil by Its Name
LEAD: Most contemporary fiction trades in ambiguities, the grays and pastels of emotion and morality.
In Ron Hansen's beautifully crafted stories, however, wickedness, evil, malice is called by name; and for his people, the snake in the garden never fails to appear.
As one character puts it: ''You pay your bills, you try and live simple, you pray to the Lord for guidance, but Satan can still find a loophole, can't he?


Compaq's Prices
LEAD: The Compaq Computer Corporation cut the suggested retail prices of its Deskpro 386S desktop computers by $200 and its stock price fell.
Compaq lost $1.50 yesterday, to $73, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Traders said the price cuts could hurt the Houston-based personal computer maker's earnings and might signal a weakness in sales of the 386S models.


Israeli Alleges P.L.O. Terror
LEAD: Foreign Minister Moshe Arens lashed out today at the United States and other Western nations, asserting that an attempted guerrilla raid on Sunday proved that the Palestine Liberation Organization had not truly renounced terrorism.


New Challengers on Ice
LEAD: Most of the skaters familiar a year ago are gone.
The best of them, including Brian Boitano and Debi Thomas, are now touring professionals.
In their absence, a new group will compete for titles at the national figure skating championships, which begin here Tuesday.


Lower Net Is Posted at LTV
LEAD: The LTV Corporation, taking a number of one-time charges to complete a restructuring, posted a fourth-quarter net income of $95.3 million, or 77 cents a share, on sales of $1.67 billion.
In the corresponding quarter a year ago, LTV earned $140.6 million, or $1.17 a share, on sales of $1.98 billion.


Business and Health; Long-Term-Care Policies Improve
LEAD: PRODDED by consumer groups, state regulators and Congressional proponents of a new Federal role in long-term care, many insurers have been making long-term-care policies more attractive to the elderly by lowering the barriers to receiving benefits.


Ron Field, a Tony Award Winner For His Choreography, Dies at 55
LEAD: Ron Field, a Tony and Emmy Award-winning choreographer of Broadway musicals, died yesterday morning at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan.
The cause of death was brain lesions and neurological impairments, said Mr.
Field's lawyer, Michael Miller.

LEAD: An immense Antarctic iceberg that may have camps of Admiral Byrd and Roald Amundsen embedded in its core has zigzagged several hundred miles since it broke loose last October.
It is now 177 miles from its starting point, the National Science Foundation reported.
It is 95 miles long and 22 miles wide, almost as large as when it broke off, or calved, from the Ross Ice

U.S. Rig Count Falls
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs dropped last week by 17, to a total of 780, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago, the number of rigs totaled 986.
The count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, and it reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil as of last Friday, not the number of rigs actively producing oil.

LEAD: The Soviet Union marked the final stage of its withdrawal from Afghanistan with a show for the press today in this dusty border city.

LEAD: Bowing to a wave of national outrage, the House of Representatives today abandoned its leadership and forced a vote for Tuesday that is expected to kill a proposed 51 percent Congressional pay increase.

LEAD: An association of the largest customer group of the domestic steel industry called upon the Bush Administration today to make major modifications in steel import quotas when they expire later his year.

Nicaragua Devalues Currency
LEAD: The Sandinista Government devalued the currency and raised prices for petroleum products today for the third time this year.
The devaluation, from 2,300 to 2,700 cordobas to the dollar, is part of economic measures designed to contain inflation that has reached an annual rate of 36,000 percent.

LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade has scheduled a meeting with its members on Thursday to discuss after-hours trading systems.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  HORSE RACING  Socially Informed Triumphs: Socially Informed, ridden by Richard Migliore, raced to a front-running 1 1/2-length victory in the featured race at Aqueduct yesterday.
Make Luck was runner-up in the field of six, 2 1/2 lengths ahead of Dancing Pretense.
Socially Informed, the favorite, covered six furlongs on the fast track in 1:09 4/5 to earn $21,600 for James Riccio with his second victory in three starts this year.

Yugoslavia Inflation Up
LEAD: Yugoslavia's inflation jumped to 290 percent last month, official figures showed today.
The Federal Bureau of Statistics said prices had soared by a monthly record of 39 percentage points from the 251 percent inflation registered at the end of 1988.
Economists said that the January rises were highest in services, farm products and energy and that they reflected the gradual elimination of price controls by the Government of Branko Mikulic, who resigned Dec.

Missing Jogger, 11, Is Found
LEAD: An 11-year-old youth reported missing from his home in Harlem last Friday after he went jogging but never returned was found yesterday by Transit Authority police wandering in Pennsylvania Station.
The boy, Kareen Stembridge of West 148th Street, told the police that he did not go home because he feared he had failed one of his classes at Intermediate School 223.


John Tries To Find Out If Yanks Want Him
LEAD: Memo to the office: Tommy John is willing.


Shevardnadze Ends Pakistan Trip With Little Gain
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, left Pakistan for Moscow today with almost nothing to show for his last-minute attempt to insure a peaceful transition in Afghanistan.


U.S. and Argentina Beginning Cleanup of Antarctic Oil Spill
LEAD: American and Argentine crews are beginning the slow and dirty job of cleaning up the devastating oil spill from the polar supply ship that ran aground and capsized off the Antarctic Peninsula.


Metro Datelines; Gun Bills Released By Assembly Panel
LEAD: An Assembly panel yesterday released two bills that would stiffen the penalties for illegal firearms dealing, while a Senate committee withheld a vote on a bill to ban semi-automatic rifles that look like assault rifles after a large showing by National Rifle Association members.


Foundation Is to Assist Group of Soviet Dancers
LEAD: Members of the Donetsk Ballet from the Soviet Union, whose planned tour is jeopardized because of lack of funds from their United States producers, are to receive living expenses for this week from a benefactor.
The troupe made its United States debut in Baltimore on Thursday.


An Army With Its Spirit in Disarray
LEAD: As Soviet troops return from Afghanistan to flag-waving welcomes at the Soviet border, some of those left behind are giving vent to the frustrations and disillusionment common to an army in retreat.

Slaying Suspect to Get Gene Tests
LEAD: The man accused of raping and killing a doctor at Bellevue Hospital Center last month agreed to submit to genetic testing after pleading not guilty yesterday at his arraignment in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.


High PCB Levels Found In Eskimo Breast Milk
LEAD: The milk of nursing Eskimo women in northern Quebec has a higher level of PCB's than that of women anywhere in the world, according to a new study.


Officer Guilty in Marine Death
LEAD: A court-martial jury today convicted a Marine sergeant of negligence in the death of a Marine who was left behind after a military exercise in the California desert last August.


Abrams Seeks To Restructure Child Societies
LEAD: Most of a group of child-protection societies in New York State abuse their police powers and act as vigilantes or perform no function at all, the state's Attorney General said yesterday.

S.&amp;P. to Drop Nabisco
LEAD: The Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it would remove RJR Nabisco Inc. from the S.&amp;P. 500-stock index at 4:30 P.M. tomorrow.
Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company has made a $24.88 billion tender offer for RJR that is scheduled to expire Thursday morning, and S.&amp;P. said it was possible that RJR Nabisco's removal from the index could be postponed if the Kohlberg offer was extended.

Pennzoil Owns 8% of Burlington Resources
LEAD: The Pennzoil Company confirmed today that it had acquired 8 percent of Burlington Resources Inc., a new energy company with large natural gas reserves.

LEAD: Following is a transcript of President Bush's part of a news conference in Washington yesterday as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:  OPENING STATEMENT

LEAD: Dr.
Samuel Broder, a man of intensity and impatience, believes that the National Cancer Institute is a place where people with ambition, energy and fresh ideas can step forward and take charge.


Study Clouds Suit on Nabisco Bonds
LEAD: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, a bondholder that sued RJR Nabisco Inc. because its bonds lost value after Nabisco's management made a leveraged buyout offer, concluded in a confidential study that covenants with bondholders did not prevent RJR Nabisco from accepting such a bid, court documents filed last night show.

LEAD: *
Bankers Trust Company said Douglas G. Hoffman, a former principal with Tillinghast Management Consultants, would join the banking company as a senior vice president.


Two Budget Tales of Prudence and Pain; Some Cuomo Medicaid Cuts Could Increase Costs
LEAD: Gov.
Mario Cuomo proposes reducing New York's $2 billion budget deficit by squeezing $310 million out of spending on Medicaid health insurance for the poor.
That also squeezes New York City's budget since the city shares costs of the program with Albany and Washington.
For the most part, this is no exercise in budget cruelty.


Facing the S &amp; L's, Not So Squarely
LEAD: President Bush has acted quickly to clean up the savings and loan mess; he's determined, he says, ''to face this problem squarely.'' But his contorted financing scheme needlessly raises the cost.


Subway Fear Varying Little Since Attacks
LEAD: The New York City subway system has been running for months now with a rapist on the loose.
Yet fear seems to be no greater, and no less, than before.


George F. Zahn, Executive, 88
LEAD: George F. Zahn, a retired maritime company executive, died Wednesday of lymphatic cancer at his home in Staten Island.
He was 88 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about the changing face of the AIDS epidemic misstated the rate of new AIDS diagnoses in gay men in recent years.
As figures provided later in the same article indicate, somewhat above 7,000 new cases among gay men have been diagnosed every six months, not every year.


The Man Who Brings Pie in the Sky to Earth
LEAD: Representative Dan Rostenkowski, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, was grumbling about the pie-in-the-sky people, the people who do not know how to compromise.


Warsaw Opens Parley With Solidarity
LEAD: The Government and the banned labor union Solidarity began discussions today on broad political and economic change in Poland.
The Government offered to reinstate the union and give it a share of parliamentary power through ''nonconfrontational elections'' in exchange for Solidarity support of Government economic programs.

Pacific First Accepts Offer
LEAD: The Pacific First Financial Corporation of Tacoma, Wash., the largest savings institution in the Pacific Northwest, agreed to be acquired by Royal Trustco Ltd. of Toronto for $27 a share in cash, or about $212 million.


Slow Rise Seen In Gasoline Use
LEAD: United States gasoline demand is expected to rise by 1 percent to 2 percent in 1989, industry experts say.


Coach Stays, Team Forfeits
LEAD: Florida A&amp;M was awarded a 2-0 forfeit over Morgan State tonight because the Morgan State coach, Nat Frazier, refused to leave the building after he was ejected.


Atlanta Cartoonist Resigns
LEAD: Doug Marlette, the editorial cartoonist who last year brought The Atlanta Constitution its first Pulitzer Prize in 20 years, resigned from the newspaper yesterday to become a cartoonist at Newsday.

RUSSIANS GUARDING AIRPORT AT KABUL
LEAD: The last Soviet military convoys rolled north from Kabul today, Soviet officials said, but hundreds of Soviet soldiers remained behind to guard the Afghan capital's airport, a lifeline for food and fuel made scarce by a blockade imposed by Muslim guerrillas.


Harvard to Meet B.U. For Beanpot Crown
LEAD: Harvard hung on in the final period tonight to beat Boston College, 5-4, in the opening game of the Beanpot Tournament at Boston Garden.
The Crimson could not win a face-off or keep the puck out of their zone in the last 20 minutes.
The Eagles' attack against Chuckie Hughes, the brilliant Harvard goalie, was furious but futile.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column on Thursday about Crazy Eddie Inc. described management changes incorrectly.
Elias Zinn stepped down as president and chief executive but remains a director.
Victor H. Palmieri remains chairman.
Peter A. Martosella, the new president and chief executive, previously served as president and chief executive of the Baldwin-United Corporation on behalf of the Palmieri Company.


Output of U.S. Workers Increased 1.4% in 1988
LEAD: American workers increased their productivity by 1.4 percent last year, an improvement over 1987 that nonetheless revived doubts about the economic projections in President Bush's spending plans.


Talley Is Selling Air Bag Business
LEAD: Talley Industries said it had reached a definitive agreement to sell its automotive air bag business to TRW Inc. of Cleveland for $85 million in cash and other compensation.
Talley, a diversified manufacturer of industrial and consumer products, said it would receive 12 years of royalty payments based on worldwide sales of air bags and also the return of intercompany debt.


BankAmerica Payout: Signal of a Recovery
LEAD: Reaching a significant milestone on its road to recovery, the BankAmerica Corporation announced today that it would pay a dividend on its common stock for the first time in three years.


Moroccan Envoy Back
LEAD: An old Washington hand, Ambassador Ali Bengelloun of Morocco, has returned for his third tour of duty in Washington.
He and his wife, Jackie, were a popular team on their first tour, in the Kennedy and Johnson years, early 1962 until mid-1965.
They returned in 1977 for seven years and made their embassy residence popular with dinner parties at which guests dipped their fingers into a common pot of bastilla (pigeon pie).


Illinois Central
LEAD: The board of the Illinois Central Transportation Company said it would ''investigate alternatives'' to the $20-a-share tender offer from Prospect Group Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Illinois Central board also said it would remain neutral on Prospect's $434 million offer.


Channel 2 Plans New Show at 7 P.M.
LEAD: In another attempt to bolster ratings in its early evening time period, the flagship CBS television station in New York, WCBS or Channel 2, announced yesterday that starting Feb. 27, ''This Evening,'' a new half-hour magazine program, would replace the game show ''Win, Lose or Draw'' at 7 P.M.

Europe Sets Rules on Chips
LEAD: The European Community today introduced strict new rules affecting access to European markets for computer chips in a move that diplomats said could intensify United States and Japanese charges of protectionism.


Chelsea Industries
LEAD: The Kane Miller Corporation offered of $27 a share for Chelsea Industries, a Boston film manufacturer.
Kane Miller's offer represents a 48 percent premium over Chelsea's price today of $18.25, up 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Kane Miller, a Tarrytown, N.Y., food processor, estimated the total price of its offer at $55 million.

New Solution Stretches Organ Transplant Time
LEAD: A new chemical solution can preserve human livers outside the body for up to 34 hours, doctors have reported.
This would more than triple the time surgeons have to get a donated organ into a dying patient.

Treasury Prices Are Off Slightly
LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and notes dipped slightly in listless trading yesterday, as market participants prepared for the start of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions today and watched the Federal Reserve Board for clues about whether the central bank has tightened credit conditions again.

4 Found Dead in Lake Shack
LEAD: A fisherman found four teen-agers dead early Sunday in their shanty on frozen Harpt Lake.
They had been overcome by carbon monoxide from propane heaters and a propane hot plate after taking part in a weekend ice-fishing derby.
Officials said they had not determined if the heaters in the 7-by-6 1/2-foot plywood shanty were malfunctioning or were just poorly vented.


With Cloudy Crystal Balls, Scientists Race to Assess Global Warming
LEAD: SPURRED by the anxiety of a public suddenly alert to the potential dangers of global warming, a small fraternity of scientists is running a high-stakes race against the environmental clock, trying to predict the precise impact of the greenhouse effect in time to take effective countermeasures.


Manville Trust Fund In Trouble
LEAD: The trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos will run out of money later this year if settlements continue at their current rate, trust officials and other lawyers said yesterday.


Mexico Refuses U.S. Loan
LEAD: A United States offer of a $3.5 billion emergency loan remains open, officials said today, even though Mexico has decided not to borrow the money and is trying to renegotiate payments on its crippling foreign debt.


Salvador Offers Solutions, but Will We Listen?

The U.N. Today
LEAD:  Economic and Social Council  STATISTICAL COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.


Police Vehicle Cards Going To Civilians Despite Curbs
LEAD: Despite efforts by the New York City Police Department to reduce civilian use of police vehicle-identification cards, at least 37 civilians, including a teamster official, have continued to receive the treasured credentials.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ad Revenues Up 8.65%
LEAD: Magazine advertising revenues in 1988 increased 8.65 percent, to $5.94 billion, from a year earlier, the Publishers Information Bureau reported.
The increase exceeded the 5.5 percent rise in 1987 and marked the largest annual gain since 1984.
The greatest growth was in cosmetics and toiletries, which increased 21.5 percent, and in automobiles, which rose 17 percent.


William Forrest, Actor, 86
LEAD: William Forrest, a former star athlete who appeared in nearly 200 films and on the television series ''The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin,'' died Jan. 29.
He was 86 years old.
Mr.
Forrest's films included ''The Fighting Seabees,'' ''I'll See You in My Dreams,'' ''Here Comes Mr.
Jordan,'' ''Miracle on 34th Street'' and ''They Died With Their Boots On.

A Top Officer Is Named At Revitalized Rohr
LEAD: Rohr Industries, which has been turned around in the last few years since a decision to concentrate on aircraft and aerospace, said yesterday that it had named Robert H. Goldsmith president and chief operating officer.


Gamesmanship Or Dirty Play?
LEAD: Ask opponents if Bill Laimbeer of the Detroit Pistons gets under their skin, and you won't find much argument.


Elizabeth Chapman Little, Administrator, 77
LEAD: Elizabeth Chapman Little, chairwoman of the board of the Bruce Museum in Greenwich, Conn., from 1983 until last year, died of cancer on Saturday at Greenwich Hospital.
She was 77 years old and lived in Greenwich.


Pretoria Banker Discounts Sanctions
LEAD: The head of South Africa's central bank said today that the nation was surviving the damage of Western economic sanctions despite a reduced annual growth rate and a heavy outflow of capital.


Syracuse Holds Off Seton Hall To Win 20th
LEAD: After building a 16-point lead against Seton Hall tonight, the Syracuse Orangemen almost fouled up.
But Sherman Douglas wouldn't let them.


Isuzu Revamps U.S. Operations
LEAD: The Japanese car maker Isuzu Motors Ltd. said on Sunday that it had reorganized its operations in the United States, placing Isuzu Motors America Inc., with headquarters in Detroit, in charge of its four subsidiaries.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. How much warning could we expect of a comet or asteroid that would strike the Earth?
Could we destroy or divert it?
A.
We would probably get only a few days' warning of a previously unknown object, such as an asteroid, probably not enough time to do anything to fend it off, astronomers believe, but such an object is likely to be fairly small.

LEAD:  Baseball


Market Place; View on Sears: Wait and See
LEAD: SEARS, ROEBUCK &amp; COMPANY, now in the early stages of a restructuring, will report its fourth-quarter results this week, and they are expected to be flat or only slightly better than last year's.


New York Acts To Alter Award Of Scholarships
LEAD: Even before a Federal court found that New York State's method for awarding $40 million in college scholarships discriminated against girls, the State Education Department was prepared to revert to high school grades to determine who will receive awards this year, officials said today.


Rangers Lose Grip On First
LEAD: There wasn't a better description of the state of the Rangers than the dispassionate one offered by Neal Broten of Minnesota as he stood in a tunnel in Madison Square Garden Sunday night and cast an appraising glance in the direction of the funereal Ranger locker room.


Roll-Call Vote From the New York Area
LEAD: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today demanded a vote on a proposed 51 percent raise by rejecting a motion to adjourn.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to adjourn; ''xxx'' denotes those not voting.
CONNECTICUT  Democrats - Gejdenson, no; Kennelly, yes; Morrison, yes.


Turoff and Cab Owner Plead Guilty in Scheme for Extra Medallions
LEAD: The former head of the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission, Jay L. Turoff, and an owner of a large cab fleet, Donald Sherman, each pleaded guilty yesterday to participating in a scheme to misappropriate 23 taxicab medallions and more than $500,000 in taxicab revenues.


Edwards to Run for Governor of New Jersey


Kollmorgen Seeks Alternatives to Bid
LEAD: The Kollmorgen Corporation said it was in talks with third parties to discuss possible alternatives to the $294 million hostile tender offer from the Vernitron Corporation.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Kollmorgen said it had furnished financial information to the parties, but the Stamford, Conn., electrical machinery concern emphasized that it had made no decision to sell the company.

Gay Men Find Sadness Colors Life As They Make the Most of the Days
LEAD: There is a photograph that hangs on the wall in an apartment in the East Village that sums up the impact of AIDS on the lives of gay men.

LEAD: Eliot Feld's two latest ballets are a study in contrast. ''Kore'' is a solo that continues the choreographer's exploration of Minimalist music by Steve Reich. ''Love Song Waltzes,'' danced to Brahms's music of the same title, sets four couples spinning in a neo-romantic mood.

U.S. and Pan Am Assailed
LEAD: Relatives of victims of Pan Am Flight 103 accused the Federal Government and the airline yesterday of negligence before the plane's bombing.
Thirty relatives, some with photographs of their lost relatives pinned to their clothes, demanded an accounting of why the Government had not made public a terrorist threat that such a flight would be bombed.

2 Mailmen Held in Drug Case
LEAD: Two mail deliverers were arrested yesterday on Jessup Avenue in the South Bronx after buying heroin, the police said.
The mailmen, who worked in River Vale, N.J., were identified as Thomas Cascione, 30 years old, and Joseph Gariano, 31.
Mr.
Cascione was wearing his uniform and was on his lunch hour, a police spokesman, Detective Joseph McConville, said.


For Many, Turmoil of Aging Erupts in the 50's, Studies Find
LEAD: WHILE any number of people anguish over their 30th birthday and try to hide their 40th, it is with the 50th that most start to actually see themselves as beginning to be old, researchers are finding.


CONTEST PROMOTES ANTI-DRUG EFFORTS
LEAD: A $26.4 million nationwide competition for programs to combat drug or alcohol abuse through preventive education and treatment was announced yesterday by the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation of Princeton, N.J.


West 49th To the N.H.L. All-Stars
LEAD: rrAround the corner from the litter on Ninth Avenue, people still live in some of the tenements.
But what was once a five-story red-brick building of railroad flats at 416 West 49th Street, is gutted now and all but abandoned.
In this area known as Hell's Kitchen, rusted roll-up metal doors protect the food store on the ground floor that supplies more than two dozen hot-dog and hot-pretzel vendor carts stored there at night.

LEAD: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist called again today for changes in the procedure for appealing death sentences, saying the present system invites delays in executions that extend for years.

SSMC Attracts New Suitors
LEAD: Two separate investment groups emerged today to challenge a friendly $163 million tender offer for SSMC Inc. by a Hong Kong concern.
One group is led by Paul A. Bilzerian, the chairman of the Singer Company, which spun off SSMC as an independent company in 1986.
Singer retained a 27 percent stake in SSMC, which makes Singer sewing machines.


Rules Are Tightened on Deductions
LEAD: Although Federal income tax rates are now at the lowest level of the postwar years, the rules on itemized deductions have been tightened considerably.
And some rules, like those governing the deductibility of interest, are more complex than ever.

Bridge
LEAD: Among the many misfortunes that bridge players encounter at the table, some are mercifully very rare.
Most players will go through a lifetime of bridge without, for example, bidding to a major-suit game with a normal 8-card fit and then taking no trump tricks at all.


Russian Music Series
LEAD: The New York University Chamber Music Society is to give the second concert in its series the Year of Russian Music on Thursday at 8 P.M. at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
Subsequent dates in the series are March 23, April 3 (at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street), April 13 and May 17.

LEAD: Further delays of a vote by the Senate Armed Services Committee could make the nomination of John G. Tower as Defense Secretary politically untenable, Republican committee members said yesterday.

New York and Jersey Told to Cut Water Use
LEAD: A drought warning was issued yesterday by the Delaware River Basin Commission, which supplies New York City with about half its water.
That is the second step in a drought alert process that began three weeks ago with a drought watch.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline on Friday on an obituary of an oilman and philanthropist gave his first name incorrectly.
He was Harold W. Siebens, not Howard W. Siebens.


Ondrej Nepela, Figure Skater, 38
LEAD: Ondrej Nepela, the only Czechoslovak to have won an Olympic gold medal in figure skating, died in West Germany last Thursday, the West German Ice Skating Association announced.
He was 38 years old and had been suffering from throat cancer.

Barbara Tuchman Dead at 77; A Pulitzer-Winning Historian
LEAD: Barbara W. Tuchman, whose skill at writing histories of men at war and on the brink of war won her two Pulitzer Prizes, died of complications of a stroke yesterday afternoon at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.
She was 77 years old and was admitted to the hospital Saturday after suffering the stroke at her home at Cos Cob, Conn.

LEAD: A panel of the National Institutes of Health that has been investigating the accuracy of a notable research paper by a Nobel laureate, Dr.
David Baltimore, says that ''no evidence was found of fraud, misconduct, manipulation of data or serious conceptual errors.''

LEAD: Ing.
C.
Olivetti &amp; C. S.p.A., the Italian business machine group, introduced a line of personal computers that are equipped with microchannel architecture.

LEAD: A national penny-stock brokerage has been temporarily banned from soliciting business in New York State because of suspicions that it has defrauded thousands of investors, the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday.


Ward Recalling Vehicle Cards From Civilians
LEAD: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward, angered by the questionable civilian use of police vehicle-identification cards, ordered the recall yesterday of thousands of the cards.
New York City will replace them with redesigned credentials to be issued solely to people involved with law enforcement.


The Hellinger Theater Is Leased to a Church
LEAD: The Nederlander organization has rented the Mark Hellinger Theater to the Times Square Church for five years for $1 million a year, James M. Nederlander, the organization's chairman, said yesterday.
The Hellinger has long been considered one of the best and most beautiful theaters for presenting Broadway musicals.

House Roll-Call of 380-to-48 Vote Rejecting a $45,000 Raise
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives voted today, 380 to 48, to reject a $45,000 raise for members of Congress, Federal judges and senior officials of the executive branch.
A yes vote was a vote to reject the raise.
Voting yes were 215 Democrats and 165 Republicans.

LEAD: Since man first tossed cucumbers in brine - and savored the sour results - the pickle business has not exactly sparkled with technical innovation.

Some say the development could amount to a small revolution for the $400 million industry.

LEAD: Lee Goode Kingsley, who worked in the New York music world for many years, was killed on Jan. 30 by a hit-and-run motorist at 67th Street and Broadway.
She was 80 years old.

LEAD: The Nicaraguan Foreign Minister said today that Central American countries appear ready to move ahead with their long-stalled regional peace plan.

LEAD: President Bush, seemingly intent on becoming one of the most peripatetic Presidents, is hurtling around Washington to swear in his Cabinet.

LEAD: Edward S. Steitz, who joined the Springfield College athletic department 43 years ago as a graduate assistant and later served 10 seasons as basketball coach, announced yesterday that he was retiring as the school's athletic director after 33 years on the job.

LEAD: In a move that could delay the replacement of the Federal Government's telephone system, the MCI Communications Corporation has protested the General Services Administration's award of a $25 billion contract to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the U S Sprint Communications Corporation.

LEAD: Tommy John, who was apparently discarded by the Yankees at the end of last season, will likely be back with the team this spring, although it is uncertain whether he will hold a job on the pitching staff.


Zagat Restaurant Guides: Whose Voice Is Being Heard?
LEAD: WITHOUT a doubt, Tim and Nina Zagat have made it in the food world.
Their restaurant guides to eight urban areas - with more to come in the spring - are rapidly gaining influence and circulation.
The New York guide, which started as a single-sheet summary 10 years ago, sold nearly 200,000 copies last year, making it the top-selling restaurant book in the city.

Ms.

Bridge
LEAD: If an expert sits down to kibitz someone he does not know, he can usually tell after one deal whether he is watching an experienced player.
But he may receive mixed signals: The bidding and the play may point in opposite directions.
In such cases, the play is a better guide.
An expert may make a bad-looking bid because of some partnership understanding or because he is riding a hunch, but he is very unlikely to make a bad play.

He usually played only one game of racquetball, but he had lost, 21-3, so he played another game.

Jacobs-Shaklee
LEAD: An investment group led by the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs has raised its stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 9.7 percent from 6.4 percent.
In Securities and Exchange Commission filings, Mr.
Jacobs said he had bought 383,900 more Shaklee shares for an average of $31.51 a share.
Mr.
Jacobs gave no reason for his additional stock purchases.


Canada Oil Drilling Up
LEAD: Petroleum drilling activity in western Canada is increasing at a modest rate, an oil industry group reported today.
The Canadian Association of Oilwell Drilling Contractors said the number of rigs working for the week ended today rose to 206, out of 528 available, from 191 the previous week.
The association earlier forecast an average 250 rigs would be active in the first quarter.

LEAD: The Vernitron Corporation said it might raise its hostile $23-a-share tender offer for the Kollmorgen Corporation if Kollmorgen's confidential financial data ''justifies such an increase.'' In a letter Monday to the Kollmorgen board of directors, Stephen W. Bershad, Vernitron's chief executive, also said the company would take legal action, if it was not included in the bidding for the Stamford, Conn., electrical machinery manufacturer.

Strong City Journal; Stampede Is Feared On Range
LEAD: The Z Bar Ranch is a vast stillness of hills, valleys and tree-lined creeks where hardly a sign of human beings intrudes.
A ranch house of native limestone is tucked behind a hill, and on a far rim, a few horses graze, small brown shapes outlined against the sky.

LEAD: Leonard Forman, a former director of planning and chief economist for The New York Times Company, was named executive vice president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau yesterday.
Mr.
Forman was most recently the senior vice president of Telemundo Inc., a Spanish-language television network formed in 1987.

LEAD: The greatest challenge in reducing the spread of AIDS and its future toll, most experts believe, is curbing the spread of the virus among intravenous drug abusers.

LEAD: A random, computer-assisted investigation of wealthy New York State taxpayers claiming to live outside the state has found that the first 12 people audited all were falsely filing as out-of-state residents, officials said today.
That has resulted in the collection of $28 million in back taxes.


Lionel Newman, 73, Winner of an Oscar As a Film Composer
LEAD: Lionel Newman, who composed, conducted or supervised the scores of more than 250 movies, including ''Hello, Dolly!'', for which he won an Academy Award, died of a heart attack Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.
He was 73 years old.
Mr.
Newman's 11 Oscar nominations included those for scoring the music of such films as ''Doctor Doolittle,'' ''Mardi Gras,'' ''Let's Make Love'' and ''The Pleasure Seekers.

As Power Wanes for Kollek, A Dream for Jerusalem Fades
LEAD: Two things seem fairly certain about Jerusalem's municipal elections this month.
First, Mayor Teddy Kollek is likely to win re-election.
But second, he will probably lose control of the City Council - and also lose his 22-year struggle to bring Arab and Jewish Jerusalem closer together.

LEAD: A friend presented Samuel K. Skinner, the new Secretary of Transportation, with a toy aircraft yesterday, greatly pleasing the Secretary, an aviation enthusiast who is a licensed pilot.

LEAD: The Williams Telecommunications Group, a fast-growing digital telecommunications company, said today that it had signed an agreement to acquire Lightnet, another fiber-optics company, for about $365 million.

Conner has the flu and his backup at point guard, John Bagley, was placed on the injured list by the Nets earlier in the day with a severely sprained left ankle.
That meant Conner would get all the playing time he wanted against the Seattle SuperSonics.

A Subgenus of the Sparrow May Have Fallen
LEAD: Reports of the dusky seaside sparrow's extinction may have been greatly exaggerated.
New genetic studies indicate that the small Florida bird may not have been a true subspecies after all, but just another member of the common seaside sparrow flock so numerous along the Atlantic coast.

Winds Ascendant at Merkin
LEAD: Steve Richman's Harmonie Ensemble, which appeared for a delightful program last Wednesday night at Merkin Concert Hall, harks back to the late 18th century, when one of the most popular forms of concert music was the wind band.
For such ensembles, treading the line between cultivated and vernacular before that line was as firmly drawn as it is today, composers wrote superior scores, and arrangers - superior and otherwise - busily transcribed everything from complete grand operas to popular tunes of the day.

Man Freed in Queens Triple Slaying
LEAD: At 8:45 P.M. on June 4, 1987, a lone robber took about $1,000 at a Queens liquor store, forced the two owners and a customer into a tiny bathroom at the rear and killed each one with a bullet in the head.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:  VALENTINE'S DAY  My love stirs in the breeze  Like the paper hearts  Strung along the ceiling  Of the stationery store.
My love's a lacy heart  Packed with neat rows  Of extravagant treats.
Accept my heart - and bite  The crisp exterior  To reach the marshmallow  Beating inside.


Providence Coasts Past Pitt, 88-78
LEAD: Matt Palazzi broke out of a shooting slump with 22 points and Eric Murdock scored 19 of his 21 in the second half tonight to lead Providence to an 88-78 victory over Pitt in the Big East Conference.


J. Henry Neale, 84, a Lawyer and Banker
LEAD: J. Henry Neale, a lawyer and banker, died of a stroke Monday at White Plains Hospital.
He was 84 years old and lived in Scarsdale.


Topics of The Times; Clio's Friend
LEAD: To some academic historians, Barbara Tuchman was flawed.
She lacked a Ph.D., and indeed had not been improved by any graduate education.
Unforgivably, her books - at least six of them - were best sellers.
But she wrote superlatively, with a strong narrative line, and brought ancient controversies and forgotten leaders back to life.


Dow Rises 26.07, to 2,347.14; G.M. a Factor
LEAD: After four days of declines, stock prices rebounded strongly yesterday as blue-chip issues rallied.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 26.07 points, or 1.12 percent, to 2,347.14, another post-crash high.


Flyers' Brown to Oilers
LEAD: The Philadelphia Flyers sent Dave Brown, a right wing, to the Edmonton Oilers yesterday for Keith Acton, a center, and an undetermined future draft pick.


Budapest Journal; The Lasting Pain of '56: Can the Past Be Reburied?
LEAD: Finally, 31 years after they were hanged, Imre Nagy and his closest associates are going to be permitted decent burials.


Injunction Remains Against MAI Basic
LEAD: A Federal judge said he would continue to block MAI Basic Four Inc.'s $1.3 billion offer for Prime Computer Inc. because Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., which is helping to finance the bid, did not provide all the information sought by the court.


Seeing Eye to Eye
LEAD: President Bush may lack a Republican majority in the House and Senate, but a majority of the senior staff members in both bodies are in harmony with his views on major issues, a survey shows.


Soviets Revise Casualty Toll In Violence in Transcaucasus
LEAD: Ethnic violence in Armenia and Azerbaijan killed 91 people and injured 1,650 last year, a Soviet official said today.
The figures are the highest yet offered by officials.


A Sequel to Earth Day Planned in April 1990
LEAD: The first Earth Day, April 22, 1970, hailed as the birthday of modern environmentalism, is going to have a sequel in 1990 that organizers hope will dwarf the original.

LEAD: The dollar finished mixed against major foreign currencies yesterday in trendless trading marked by speculation over interest rates.


Future of Blacks in U.S. Draws 400 to Harvard
LEAD: Michelle Davis, a black sophomore at Harvard University, said some white students believed that academic standards had been lowered to let blacks into prestigious schools.


GTE Income Off 2.4% in Quarter
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter declined 2.4 percent, to $326 million, or 96 cents a share, from $334 million, or 99 cents a share, in the comparable 1987 period.
Revenues rose to $4.3 billion from $4.1 billion a year ago.

LEAD: ''Rorret,'' Fulvio Wetzl's Italian film opening today at Film Forum 1, is terror spelled backward.

Jackson's Focus: Redlining

Jesse Jackson urged Congress today to link the Federal bailout of savings institutions to tougher laws against redlining.
Some lenders have been accused of this practice, which means denying loans for property in poor neighborhoods.

LEAD: Faced with ferocious public opposition, the House yesterday capitulated and voted down the 51 percent raise that was to have lifted Congressional pay to $135,000 a year, starting today.

LEAD: While maintaining that network television is still the pre-eminent advertising medium, the heads of CBS, NBC and ABC agreed yesterday that its share of the viewing audience would continue to decline and one predicted that the networks' share could fall below 60 percent of the prime-time audience.

South African Prison Strike
LEAD: Nearly 200 black detainees, some held without charge for nearly three years, are staging a hunger strike to demand their freedom, parents of the prisoners said today.
All 191 detainess at Diepkloof Prison in Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg, have stopped eating, parents of some detainees told reporters.

LEAD: President Bush became a grandfather for the 11th time today.
The White House announced that Mr.
Bush's son Neil, and his wife, Sharon, became the parents of Ashley Walker Bush, a 7-pound, 2-ounce girl.
Ashley Bush, born at Rose Medical Center in Denver, is the third child of Neil, who is in the petroleum business in Denver.

New Heat Pump Cuts Power Cost
LEAD: The Electric Power Research Institute and an air-conditioner manufacturer have produced a new heat pump for homes that is 30 to 40 percent more efficient than current models.
It uses computer technology and advances in electric motor controls and produces hot water as a byproduct during the summer.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.The top of our new rosewood dining room table has a milky-white stain that was caused by a hot serving dish.
The dish was resting on a wicker server but apparently enough steam heat was transmitted to mar the finish.
We have tried to remove the stain with combinations of linseed oil, turpentine and furniture polish, but none have worked.

Assault Rifles Assault Common Sense
LEAD: Patrick Purdy, the Stockton, Calif., schoolyard killer, might have inspired national soul-searching about violence in American life.
Instead he inspired a bonanza in gun sales.
On learning that Mr.
Purdy had used a $400 Chinese-made military assault rifle to kill five children and wound 30 others, Californians jammed the stores and within days had snapped up the inventory of such weapons.

LEAD: Former Associate Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court, who was hospitalized Monday after suffering from dizziness, has pneumonia and will remain at Baptist Medical Center for several more days, a spokesman for the medical center said today.
Mr.
Powell, who is 81 years old, was being treated with antibiotics and was reported to be in good condition with no respiratory distress.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about alcohol addiction gave an incorrect date for Kitty Dukakis's entry into an alcohol treatment center.
It was Sunday, not Friday.


Speech to Congress to End Honeymoon
LEAD: The speech that President Bush is to deliver to a joint session of Congress on Thursday will mark the end of the honeymoon between the President and Capitol Hill, if in fact that season of unrealistic sweetness and light didn't peter out altogether earlier this week in the partisan battle over Secretary of Defense-designate John G.


Japan to Amnesty 30,000 to Honor Hirohito
LEAD: Japan said today that it will grant amnesty to more than 30,000 suspects and convicts on the day of Emperor Hirohito's funeral this month and ''restore civil rights'' to 11 million others punished for minor infractions.

Death of Arrested Man Is Linked to Drug Use
LEAD: The death of a young man here in police custody was brought on by drug use and not police brutality as some residents have contended, officials said today.


S.E.C. Disclosure Plan Is Opposed by Big Board
LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange has formally opposed the Securities and Exchange Commission's proposal to expand the private placement market and has made some counterproposals of its own.


Bush's Speech on T.V. And Radio at 9 P.M.
LEAD: President Bush's address to Congress at 9 o'clock tonight will be televised by ABC, CBS, NBC, CNN and C-Span.
Some affiliates of PBS, including Channel 13 in the New York area, and of the Spanish-language network Univision, including Channel 41 in New York, will also carry the address.


Maier and Hangl Are First In World Alpine Super G
LEAD: No one has really figured out the super G. It is a cross between the downhill and giant slalom, shorter than one, longer than the other.
When the gates are set, it is very often more of one than the other.

'Trouble in Tahiti'
LEAD: The American Symphony Orchestra is to commemorate Leonard Bernstein's 70th birthday with a performance of his ''Trouble in Tahiti'' at Carnegie Hall, on Feb. 19 at 3 P.M.
The concert, with George Hanson conducting, will also feature Leonidas Kavakos as soloist in Tchaikovsky's Violin Concerto.
Tickets are $25, $20 and $15.


Germans Pledge Curbs on Chemical Plants
LEAD: A West German official today briefed Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on measures planned by Bonn to prevent the export of equipment that could be used to make chemical weapons.


Electronics Co-op in First License Pact
LEAD: The Microelectronics Computer and Technology Corporation, the nation's first cooperative research effort mounted by major competitors in an industry, said today that it had its first licensing agreement.


Soviet Composers Union Readmits Rostropovich
LEAD: The Soviet cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich, stripped of his citizenship in 1978 while in the United States, has been restored to membership in the Soviet Composers Union, the Tass news agency said today.

LEAD: Gordon E. Hyde, an advertising executive for half a century and a former president of the Grand Jury Association of New York County, died of pneumonia on Saturday at his home in North Salem, N.Y.
He was 92 years old.

Athletes Who Overtrain Share Personality Traits
