An Inexact Copy
LEAD: To The Home Section:


Ewing Gets a Scare as Knicks Triumph
LEAD: There is something about Glenn (Doc) Rivers and the Omni.
They spell trouble for Patrick Ewing.
With 9 minutes 57 minutes remaining in the third period tonight and the Knicks trailing, 64-52, Ewing tried to spin to the basket from the left post.
He was poked in the right eye by Rivers, the Atlanta Hawk playmaker, who was double-teaming.


Hardwick to Run for Jersey Governor


Kentucky School, Pressed, Revises Smoking Rules
LEAD: The University of Louisville has scaled back a policy that put restrictions on smoking to satisfy state lawmakers who threatened to cut the school's budget if the policy remained unchanged.


Judge in North Trial Rejects U.S. Effort To Censor Testimony
LEAD: The Federal district judge in the trial of Oliver L. North today rejected a Justice Department effort to censor testimony dealing with national security.
The ruling set up a legal battle that could force a dismissal of some or all of the 12 remaining charges against Mr.
North.


Washington Talk: Briefing; Dukakis Reflects
LEAD: Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts was on Capitol Hill yesterday, but his business was largely local, a contrast to trips he made to Congress last year when he was the Democratic Presidential nominee.


Robert Middlebrook, Executive, Dies at 72
LEAD: Robert W. Middlebrook, formerly president of Squibb International, senior vice president of Richardson-Merrell Inc. and a vice president of Pfizer International, died of a heart attack Saturday at a vacation home in Fort Myers, Fla.
He was 72 years old and lived in Washington, Conn.


IRAN WILL RELEASE CERTAIN PRISONERS FOR ANNIVERSARY
LEAD: Iran announced today that it would release several thousand political prisoners to commemorate the 10th anniversary of the Islamic revolution on Saturday.
But it said about 900 opponents of the Government accused of murder and other serious crimes would not be freed.


Backstage at Savings Rescue: Urgent and Secretive Process
LEAD: On the way to President Bush's bailout plan for hundreds of bankrupt savings institutions, senior Administration officials and Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, decided on Sunday night to pump billions of dollars in emergency loans into the institutions if the plan touched off a run on deposits.


Two More Cooling System Cracks Found in a Nuclear Arms Reactor
LEAD: In another indication of the difficulties officials face in reopening the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant, the Energy Department said today that it had found two more cracks in the cooling system of a reactor that produces a crucial gas used in nuclear weapons.


The Isolation Of a Young Tennis Player
LEAD: rrHenry Merlo's old conduct code was looking better and better last weekend.
Particularly when Andre Agassi put his thumbs in his ears and started wiggling his fingers at the Paraguayan Davis Cup team.


Sanctions Are Sought On Pretoria
LEAD: The foreign ministers of the Commonwealth nations decided today to seek ways to strengthen financial sanctions against South Africa after it was disclosed that a Canadian bank had made a large loan to a South African-controlled company.

Decorating: How Far Can $10,000 Take You?
LEAD: NOT so long ago, it was possible to build an entire house with $10,000.
Today, according to a 1988 survey by the American Society of Interior Designers, the average cost of a residential decorating project is $68,200.
At Blair House in Washington, America's official residence for visiting dignitaries, the decorator Mario Buatta managed to spend $20,000 on a pair of silk curtains - albeit elaborately swagged and draped curtains.


Travel Packages Available for Skiers
LEAD: rrFor most people, going skiing means getting into a car and driving to the mountains.
But in recent years, other ways to travel have become available and are often faster and easier and sometimes no more expensive than driving.


Small Change at the Checkout
LEAD: When New York City and Westchester shoppers pay for their groceries at D'Agostino supermarkets this month, they can also help provide hot meals for the homebound elderly.
A clever innovation at the checkout counter makes it possible.
Customers are asked to ''round up'' their bills to the next dime or dollar.


Penny Stock Rule Offered
LEAD: To crack down on penny-stock fraud and high-pressure sales tactics, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved for public comment a rule that would set tough procedures for brokers trying to sell risky stocks to new customers.


A Leash That May Be More Humane
LEAD: ''It's a miracle,'' said James Drakeford, an assistant department manager at Dean and DeLuca in New York City, after walking a friend's dog with a new device called the Gentle Leader.
Mr.
Drakeford had previously been dragged down the street by his friend's 50-pound mutt. ''With the halter,'' he said, ''the dog simply couldn't pull.


Pretoria Acts On Currency
LEAD: South Africa's central bank announced tighter measures this week to stop abuses of foreign exchange controls after a series of currency scandals.


Coleman Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Derrick Coleman of Syracuse University, who is among the nation's leaders in rebounding and blocked shots, pleaded guilty yesterday in Syracuse City Court to harassment and disorderly conduct charges stemming from a fight and break-in incident on campus last December.
Coleman, a junior, was sentenced by Judge James Tormey to 50 hours of community service and was ordered to make restitution for damages he caused during the Dec.


VERDICT IS MIXED ON BRAIN SURGERY
LEAD: An experimental brain operation to treat Parkinson's disease has produced moderate improvement for some victims but not the ''miracle'' that an earlier report suggested, a researcher said.


Bridge
LEAD: Several groups of players assemble in a private home or club for a weekly game that continues year after year.
One of the most unusual is the Monday night game at the Cavendish Club, 105 East 73d Street.
It has been going for 35 years, with several founding members still playing.
The game is the cut-in team variety, scored by imps.

Jets Make a Change
LEAD: The Jets made their second coaching change of the off season yesterday by naming Rod Humenuik to replace Dan Radakovich as offensive line coach.
Humenuik was dismissed by the Patriots in December after holding the concurrent titles of line coach, assistant head coach and offensive coordinator.
Coach Joe Walton is believed to have wanted a firm commitment from Radakovich on whether he would return next season.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in active trading yesterday as traders reacted defensively after results of a $9.5 billion sale of 10-year notes were announced.

LEAD: L. Janette Richardson, a professor of literature who specialized in Chaucer, died of cancer Jan. 28 at the home of a friend in Piedmont, Calif.

MOLECULE IS SEEN AS AN AIDS FIGHTER
LEAD: Hybrid molecules closely related to CD4, a substance being tested as a promising drug against AIDS, may themselves have value in treating that deadly disease, scientists reported yesterday.


Notre Dame and Georgia Tech Win
LEAD: Iona and Fordham had visions of toppling two college basketball heavyweights in Madison Square Garden last night.
And both for a half looked their opponents squarely in the eyes and matched elbow for elbow and spurt for spurt.


Savings Bailouts Are Put on Hold; Pending Deals Likely to Collapse
LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which is taking control of more than 200 insolvent savings and loan associations, today froze all negotiations for the sale of ailing institutions.
It said any deals involving Government guarantees and other debt obligations would be dropped.


Manson Is Denied Parole
LEAD: A parole board today denied freedom for Charles Manson, leader of the infamous ''family'' that in 1969 murdered the actress Sharon Tate and eight other people.
The board's decision marked the seventh time that Mr.
Manson had been denied parole.
The board considered the latest psychiatric study of Mr.


Working Overtime: A bind for Parents
LEAD: AT about 4 P.M. every day, working parents around the nation start getting nervous.
They pace, tap pencils and take aspirin.
It is an hour away from the moment of truth, when carefully orchestrated child-care arrangements can be thrown into a tailspin by a business meeting that runs long, a last-minute invitation from a superior to ''stop by,'' or by a manager who asks, ''Will you stay to finish this project?


Sara Lee to Acquire Hanson's Hygrade
LEAD: Hanson Industries announced it was selling its Hygrade Food Products Corporation to the Sara Lee Corporation for $140 million.
Hygrade, based in Southfield, Mich., produces frankfurters, luncheon meats, sausage, bacon and hamsunder the Ball Park, Grillmaster, Hygrade's and West Virginia labels.
The price tag includes the assumption of an unspecified amount of debt.


Coe Won't Run
LEAD: Sebastian Coe of Britain abandoned, at least temporarily, his comeback bid by withdrawing yesterday from the 800-meter run at the European indoor championships next week.
British officials said Coe, who still holds the world indoor and outdoor records for the distance, was concerned about a calf injury that caused him to withdraw from a recent meeting in Genoa, Italy.


Charter Jet Crash in Azores Kills 144
LEAD: An American charter jet carrying Italian vacationers to the Caribbean crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain in the Azores today while trying to land and all 144 people on board were believed killed.


Miners' Strike Is a Test for Warsaw and Solidarity
LEAD: Thousands of miners defied the authorities today by continuing a strike at a major coal mine feeding Poland's largest power-generating station.


I.B.M. and Rebels Head for Battle
LEAD: Personal computer users who have been thinking of upgrading to a more sophisticated machine should take note: The war between I.B.M. and the rebel coalition of computer makers is far from over.


4 Members of L.I. Family Stabbed, 2 Fatally
LEAD: Four members of a Long Island family were stabbed, two fatally, in their home in Roosevelt last night, and a fifth member of the family was arrested and charged in the incident, the police said.


Gooden Agrees to 3-Year Pact Making Him Top-Paid Met
LEAD: Dwight Gooden, saying his career with the Mets was ''like a family thing'' that he wanted to preserve, agreed to a three-year contract for $6.7 million yesterday and will become the highest-paid player in the Mets' history and, at least for the time being, the highest-paid player in baseball.


From Designers, Pictures And a Thousand Words
LEAD: NEVER mind that this is the age of facsimile machines, overnight mail and portable telephones; decorators are still sending messages the old-fashioned way - on postcards.
These are not the sort picked up in museum gift shops or airports, but postcards depicting rooms the decorators have done.
Emily Todhunter, who runs Designs by Emily, with offices in Manhattan and London, sends a card with a watercolor of a room she completed this winter for the Royal Oak Designer Show House in New York.


DeLorean Loses Plea
LEAD: John Z. DeLorean, the colorful auto executive who built a futuristic-looking sports car in Northern Ireland, lost a bid in Federal court on Tuesday to block a $53 million legal judgment imposed against him in Britain.


Head of F.A.D.A. to Resign
LEAD: Gerald P. Carmen, who took over the much-criticized Federal Asset Disposition Association last year, said today that he was resigning as president and chief executive of the Government agency, which manages and sells real estate that is acquired when ailing savings and loans are taken over.

LEAD: Family Court in Manhattan is an increasingly frayed conveyor belt of violent tales and misery these days, largely because of crack.


But We Are Going to Pay
LEAD: Not many have noticed the bottom line of President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry.
Over the next 30 years it is going to cost us, the taxpayers, upwards of $100 billion.

LEAD: MARTIN HUTNER was embarking on a one-day job as a decorating consultant.
His clients, Bob and Elizabeth Lunt, had just moved to a 1920's Tudor-style house in Westchester from Manhattan and, he said, ''I don't know anything about them.''

Joe Mullen's Star Rises Among the Best
LEAD: Wayne Gretzky, who had just been awarded a car after being named the most valuable player in the National Hockey League's 40th annual All-Star Game, was asked what he planned to do with his latest prize.
It was the 14th car he had won in his career, Gretzky said, and he planned to give it away.


Malaysian Investor May Bid for SSMC
LEAD: A Malaysian investor, Vincent Tan, said he was prepared to pay more for SSMC Inc. than the offer of $30 a share, a total of $163 million, which the SSMC board has accepted from Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., a Hong Kong-based concern.
In a letter dated today to the SSMC board, Mr.
Tan requested the confidential financial information that SSMC made available to Semi-Tech.


The World Series Of the Caribbean
LEAD: It may seem odd that the Caribbean Series, winter baseball's annual championship, is being played this week on the shores of the Pacific Ocean, but that quirk is very much in keeping with the character of the February Classic.

Georgetown Defeats UConn, 70-58
LEAD: Jaren Jackson scored 8 of his 18 points during the first 7 minutes 52 seconds of the second half as second-ranked Georgetown went on a 20-10 run tonight to defeat Connecticut, 70-58, in a Big East Conference game.


U.S. Sees Signs of Iraqi Unrest
LEAD: The United States has evidence of unrest among Iraqi Army officers in mid-December that led to arrests and unconfirmed reports of executions, State Department officials said today.


British Air to Redo First-Class Service
LEAD: British Airways P.L.C. introduced changes in its first-class service that it said were designed to win a bigger share of the $1 billion market for first-class passengers on long-haul flights.
The airline, recently privatized by the British Government, said it is investing $40 million to upgrade its first-class service, from which it earns nearly $400 million a year.


Epic Healthcare Group Inc. In a $115 Million Offering
LEAD: Epic Healthcare Group Inc., an Irving, Tex., operator of 36 general acute-care hospitals, is offering $115 million of units through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

Excerpts From Remarks by Bush About Tower
LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks here today by President Bush about the nomination of John G. Tower as Defense Secretary, at a photography session with William J. Bennett, the designated director of the National Drug Control Policy.
A transcript was provided by the White House.
The Controversy


BUSH BACKS TOWER AMID NEW CHARGES INVOLVING NOMINEE
LEAD: President Bush strongly defended his choice of John G. Tower as Defense Secretary today, denouncing the ''frenzied speculation'' about Mr.
Tower's character and challenging critics to produce ''hard information'' in support of their doubts about the nominee.


Jefferies Credibility Is Assailed
LEAD: In several dramatic confrontations, defense lawyers yesterday assailed the credibility of Boyd L. Jefferies, the Government's main witness in the GAF Corporation stock manipulation trial and two other major securities cases.


Final Four Candidates
LEAD: Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., is among four arenas that have been invited to bid on the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Final Four for 1994 and 1995, Cedric Dempsey, the chairman of the N.C.A.A.
Basketball Committee, announced yesterday.
Presentations will be made to the committee on July 2 by representatives of Byrne arena, the Charlotte Coliseum in North Carolina, the Seattle Kingdome and the Indianapolis Hoosier Dome.

LEAD: The name Clifton Chenier was emblazoned on the accordion that his son C. J. Chenier played Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s.
Along with the instrument, Mr.
Chenier has inherited most of his late father's Red Hot Louisiana Band and a daunting legacy.


Children's Car Safety Debated
LEAD: The National Transportation Safety Board today urged another agency to change its recommendation on the safest way to put a seat belt on a child.

LEAD: When President Bush addresses the Senate and the House tonight, will he be addressing a joint session or a joint meeting of Congress?


Senate Approves Yeutter
LEAD: The Senate today unanimously approved the nomination of Clayton K. Yeutter as Agriculture Secretary.

LEAD: Ashland Oil Inc. has pleaded no contest to Federal environmental violations in the spill of more than 700,000 gallons of diesel fuel into the Monongahela River last year.

Portraits of a Vanguard: 'I Dream a World'
LEAD: When Brian Lanker mentioned to a friend his idea for a book-length photographic essay on influential American black women, he was asked whether there were enough black women of stature around for such a project.
What he found, he said, was that there were more such women than he had space for.

LEAD: Philip Pratt, chief Federal judge for the Eastern District of Michigan, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.
He was 64 years old.


Mannes College Joins the New School
LEAD: The Mannes College of Music will merge today with the New School for Social Research, the presidents of both institutions said yesterday.


Madeleine Low, 94, Hudson Guild Trustee
LEAD: Madeleine M. Low, a trustee of the Hudson Guild neighborhood house for 55 years, died of heart failure on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 94 years old.

LEAD: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts rose for the week ended yesterday, while yields for money market mutual funds dipped slightly.

CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: AT five in the morning of the day Ted Bundy died a headache woke me.
Headaches often do, but I don't mind my predawn prowls through the house - hunting for the Advil, fumbling for a glass.
In fact I like looking out at the dark windows on the other side of the garden, and knowing that the rest of my small world is still asleep.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article on Feb. 1 about a projection by the Census Bureau -that the United States population will begin to decline in the next century -characterized the novelty incorrectly.
It was not the first of its kind by the bureau; a similar projection was made in 1982.

Jordan Acts on Dinar
LEAD: Jordan forcibly closed offices of moneychangers around the nation today, blaming them for speculating against the weakened dinar.
Police locked and sealed the premises of more than 70 exchanges in Amman, the capital, and elsewhere, including exchanges at borders and airports, witnesses said.


Review/Ballet; Basel's Treatment of Love and Meddling
LEAD: ''La Fille Mal Gardee'' has led a charmed life.
It was first produced in 1789 with choreography by Jean Dauberval - choreography that was forgotten long ago.
But for the last 200 years, other choreographers have been inspired to do their own versions of this ballet, which shows how two young lovers, Lise and Colas, outwit the attempts of Lise's mother to marry her off to Alain, a wealthy nitwit.

Bank of Tokyo
LEAD: A Bank of Tokyo Ltd. unit said it would pay $13 million less than it had planned for the Los Angeles-based Union Bank.
A reason for the lower payment was not disclosed.
Union Bank, a subsidiary of Union Bancorp, was purchased last March from Standard Chartered P.L.C. of London for $750 million and merged in November with the Bank of Tokyo's California First Bank subsidiary in San Francisco.

Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 453 money market mutual funds increased by $2.26 billion, to $287.62 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 137 institutional funds decreased by $171.40 million, to $74.24 billion.
The assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $649.30 million, to $90.87 billion.

Spread of TV Ad Networks Brings Concern About a Glut
LEAD: One of the most popular new ideas in television advertising is the ''unwired network,'' an arrangement that offers companies a national audience for their ads at a lower cost than time on ABC, CBS or NBC.
The operator of an unwired network buys commercial time on a widely scattered group of independent television stations and sells it to a national advertiser.

3 Nights of Singing
LEAD: Irene Reid, a singer, is leading a quartet tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., and there is to be a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow.

Review/Theater; Sloughing Off Scars Of a Bad Childhood
LEAD: If social consciousness were all, the Circle Repertory Company would deserve a brace of humanitarian citations for presenting ''Dalton's Back,'' a play about child abuse.
But at a time when two or more New Yorkers cannot meet for dinner without debating the moral and psychological complexities of Hedda Nussbaum, who needs a bland, earnest drama dedicated to the unsurprising proposition that the wounds of child abuse don't easily heal?


Sasser Treated At Smithers
LEAD: The Mets confirmed reports yesterday that Mackey Sasser, one of their reserve catchers, had been undergoing treatment for the last month at the Smithers Institute in Manhattan.


Restaurants
LEAD: For all the clamorous charms of Chinatown, there are times when one is in the mood for Chinese food served in a more relaxed setting.
A half-dozen or more uptown Chinese restaurants offer food that equals the best found downtown - at uptown prices, of course.
Four-year-old Fu's remains one of the best of this lot.


Astronomers View Creation of a Pulsar Amid Stellar Debris
LEAD: Astronomers report that they have glimpsed the birth of a pulsar, an extremely dense star spinning nearly 2,000 times a second inside the debris of a recent stellar explosion.
The observation appears to provide clinching evidence for a theory about the sequence of events in a supernova, the explosive collapse of a massive star.


Dollar Falls On Doubts About Bush
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday in a flurry of selling prompted in part, traders said, by suddenly lower expectations on the impact of President Bush's budget proposals.


Fight Choreography
LEAD: ''A Night at the Fights,'' a revue of fight choreography and stage combat, is to be presented this weekend by the Midtown Arts Common.
Fists, whips, swords and daggers will be the weapons of choice for the cast, who are also members of ''Fights R Us,'' a stunt group based in New York.
The show is being presented at the Theater of St, Peter's Church, Citicorp Center, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, today and tomorrow at 8 P.M., with an abbreviated show tomorrow at 12:15 P.M.


Hunger Strikes Grow in South Africa Prisons
LEAD: A hunger strike by hundreds of political detainees has developed into a battle of wills over laws providing for indefinite detention without access to a court.

On Barks and Bites, Leases and Leashes
LEAD: If a dog bites the little girl next door after she stomps on its tail, what are the legal consequences?
If the landlord tries to evict a tenant for violating a ''no pets'' clause in a lease, is there any recourse?
When the neighbor demands a new pair of Gucci loafers after the dog fouls his walkway, can he collect in court?

Carl R. Oman, Dentist, 96
LEAD: Dr.
Carl R. Oman, a dentist and retired professor of dentistry at the Columbia University School of Dental and Oral Surgery, died of cardiac arrest Wednesday at North Carolina Memorial Hospital in Chapel Hill.
He was 96 years old and lived in Chapel Hill.

GOVERNMENT MOVE TO DELAY THE TRIAL OF NORTH IS DENIED
LEAD: A Federal appeals court panel today rejected a plea by the Bush Administration that the criminal trial of Oliver L. North be temporarily halted to protect national security secrets.

LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering $250 million of floating-rate notes due 1993 and $150 million of fixed-rate notes due 1993.

Review/Art; Yoko Ono on Her Own, Storming the Barricades
LEAD: Before she became famous as the wife of one of the Beatles, Yoko Ono was familiar to a coterie of performance artists, musicians, poets and film makers as one of their own, a maker of experimental films and an organizer of avant-garde happenings.
Recently, Ms.
Ono decided it was her former self that the public should get to know better, and as it happened, there was one institution only too willing to help.

Bush to Get Order to Tighten Rules on Secrets
LEAD: An order being prepared for President Bush's approval would give Cabinet officers and other agency heads sweeping authority to grant or deny access to secret Government information.
The right to appeal those decisions would be greatly diminished.

Review/Film; 'Cousins,' an Adaptation
LEAD: The wedding scene that opened Jean-Charles Tacchella's blithe 1976 romantic comedy ''Cousin, Cousine'' was a warmly familial affair, and the one that opens the American remake, ''Cousins,'' is also jam-packed with festive relatives.
But beyond this, all similarity ends.
The French party was charmingly chaotic, played lightly but with considerable subtlety and humor.

LEAD: For eight years, President Reagan delivered speeches to Congress that were long on inspiration and relatively short on programs.

Invitation to Bush
LEAD: At Yale University, opposite Davenport College, where George Bush once resided and studied, there stands the St.
Thomas More Catholic Chapel.
Each Wednesday a group of students, faculty, spouses and others run a soup kitchen there for the needy and hungry of downtown New Haven.
It's always crowded, with sometimes as many as 200 people pushing in to escape from the cold and to get warm food.

Harried Madrid Chief Is Said to Consider Quitting
LEAD: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez is passing through the deepest crisis of his six years in power and may resign before Spain's next scheduled general election in early 1990, politicians, journalists and diplomats say.


Ruling on Scholarships Will Not Be Appealed
LEAD: The New York State Education Commissioner said today that he had decided not to appeal a Federal court decision that invalidated the state's method of awarding $40 million in college scholarships.

LEAD: Michael N. Manley, a social democrat who presided over Jamaica for eight tumultuous years in the 1970's, swept to victory tonight in national elections.


Colgate Net Up Sharply
LEAD: The Colgate-Palmolive Company reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings more than tripled, partly because of the big consumer-products company's sale of the Kendall health-care subsidiary.

LEAD: The abrupt decision by Federal regulators to cancel discussions on the likely sale of more than 70 insolvent savings institutions in Texas has angered many prospective investors, say lawyers and industry officials.

Chargers Select Henning as Coach
LEAD: Dan Henning was named coach of the San Diego Chargers yesterday, ending a seven-week search for a successor to Al Saunders, who was dismissed.
Henning, 46 years old, a Washington Redskins assistant and former head coach with the Atlanta Falcons, was signed to a five-year contract and became the eighth head coach in San Diego's 29-year history.

Review/Ballet; Feld Puts Shoe on the Other Foot
LEAD: ''Asia,'' a new work by Eliot Feld, is a winner.
This harem-pants ballet of wit and irony, full of implied commentary on male-female relations, is sensationally performed - by five women acting like a collective Theda Bara and a sole man in an imaginary seraglio.


McDowell, Johnson Will Sign With Mets
LEAD: One day after they agreed to sign Dwight Gooden for three years at $6.7 million, the Mets continued to dispense dollars and avoid arbitration when they reached agreement yesterday with Roger McDowell and Howard Johnson on one-year contracts.

LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  President Bush presented a revised $1.6 trillion version of the Reagan budget that features a one-year freeze in the military budget at the level of inflation and modest spending increases in some domestic programs.
He said the projected revenues for 1990 will be $80 billion more than they are this year.

With Notes From Home, A Pianist Is on a Mission
LEAD: On his first visit to New York in 1984, the Norwegian pianist Kjell Baekkelund all but had to swim the last few hundred yards.
His plane overshot the runway at Kennedy International Airport and landed in Jamaica Bay.
He arrived via rubber raft.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  BOXING  Two Titles to Brown: Glenwood Brown won the World Boxing Association Americas and New York State welterweight titles when he took a unanimous decision from 41-year-old Saoul Mamby in a 12-round bout at Felt Forum last night.
The former World Boxing Association lightweight champion, Edwin Rosario, stopped Jesus Gallardo in the eigth round of a scheduled 12-round bout and welterweight Aaron Davis of the Bronx remained undefeated (22-0) when his opponent, Jose Bezerra De Lima, was disqualified in the fourth round for excessive holding.

LEAD: Robert Reid made a 15-foot jump shot with 10 seconds remaining tonight, lifting the Charlotte Hornets over the Atlanta Hawks, 110-108.

The Cruelty That Isolates Iran
LEAD: Perhaps 10,000 political prisoners - or perhaps only 3,000 - may benefit from an amnesty to take effect tomorrow when Iran observes the 10th anniversary of its revolution.
The uncertainty is typical of a chaotic, revolutionary society in which no one knows who's in charge of what, and in which the closest thing to decisive power is wielded by a joyless, glowering fanatic.

Review/Art; Frank Stella's 1988
LEAD: In his current exhibition at M. Knoedler &amp; Company, Frank Stella presents the first new body of work since his 1987 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.
Unlike the ''Polish Village'' series he unveiled after his 1970 retrospective at the Modern when his work announced his new allegiance to built-up reliefs, these pieces, all made in 1988, do not mark an exciting or surprising shift in direction, at least not in the visual sense.

Pan Am Head Lists Airline's Options
LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation's chairman said he believed the company's international airline operations must be acquired or expanded to survive amid growing overseas competition. ''Pan Am could be acquired by another carrier,'' Thomas G. Plaskett said. ''Pan Am could acquire another carrier, a new investor could acquire both Pan Am and another carrier, or a business combination could take place between Pan Am and a foreign carrier or carriers.


Wright Says He Knew Raise Would Be Lost
LEAD: House Speaker Jim Wright said today that he had known for a month that the public would not accept enactment of a Congressional pay increase without a vote.
But he said he could not convince his colleagues.


Aviation Officials Warn of Delays In Steps to Tighten Flight Security
LEAD: Heightened airport security measures ordered in response to the recent bombing of a Pan American jetliner will take many months or even years to put into effect, Government aviation security officials said today.


Plight of Needy Spurs Donors
LEAD: Every time Jamie Wharton walks in New York City and sees people with no food, no money, no home, he thinks how lucky he is.
Jamie is 11 years old and lives in Armonk, a village in Westchester County, but often comes into the city on weekends.

NEW YORK


DEMOCRATS, WARY, PLEDGE THEIR HELP
LEAD: While pledging to cooperate with President Bush, Democrats on Capitol Hill complained tonight that his idea of bipartisanship seemed to involve making the politically popular decisions himself and dumping the painful ones on Congress.


Azores Flight Recorder Found
LEAD: Investigators today found a flight recorder from an American airliner that crashed in the Azores Wednesday, killing all 144 people on board, and continued their search for clues to the cause of the accident.
The chartered Boeing 707, carrying 137 tourists from the Italian city of Bergamo and 7 American crew members to the Dominican Republic, flew into a mist-shrouded mountaintop as it tried to make a scheduled refueling stop on the mid-Atlantic island.


From Art to Apparel, West Has Come East
LEAD: WHEN the word was passed along, more than a century ago, that young men should go West, wise young New Yorkers stayed put, knowing that the West, like anything else worth seeing, would eventually make its way to town.
A cultural sagebrush of song, cooking and style has been pushing up through Manhattan's concrete mesa, and now a roundup of art from the West lends special bouquet to what has all the earmarks of being a trend.

LEAD: Andreas Bach, a pianist, is to play a recital at the 92d Street Y, on Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8.

Doctor Defends Cocaine Treatments
LEAD: For 50 years, Dr.
Milton Reder, a prominent New York physician, has used cocaine to treat pain.
The practice was recently banned by New York State health officials, but Dr.
Reder has ignored the ban, moving into the forefront of physicians who say the treatments should be allowed until more research has been done.

The Blues, in a Festival at Triplex
LEAD: THE blues has innumerable faces.
It can be a stomping, three-chord exorcism or a sophisticated jazz excursion; it can be dance music or tormented introspection.
It can slip between the lines of a cabaret song or ennoble a rock truism.
The blues binds together American popular music because while its essence is unmistakable, its form is flexible - it respects no pigeonhole.

Review/Art; 'The German Image'
LEAD: First the good news about Thomas Krens's first major statement as director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. ''Refigured Painting: The German Image 1960-88'' - opening tomorrow - is a very ambitious show.
It raises the complex issue of the human figure in postwar German painting.
It places in some kind of artistic context such familiar figures as Georg Baselitz, Anselm Kiefer, Markus Lupertz, A.

LEAD: The Director of Central Intelligence told Congress today that third-world countries were expanding their ability to make ballistic missiles and chemical weapons despite Western efforts to curb the spread of such arms.


Honeywell Rises On Unisys Rumor
LEAD: The shares of Honeywell Inc. climbed today amid rumors that the Unisys Corporation, the computer maker, was interested in buying the Minneapolis-based company.
Honeywell's stock soared $3 a share, to $67, on the New York Stock Exchange, after touching $69.
Analysts said the company might command $4 billion, although they doubted whether a takeover bid would emerge.

Walesa Urges Halt to Strikes
LEAD: Lech Walesa called today for a six-week strike moratorium in Poland, saying there was a plot to stir up labor unrest and undermine Solidarity's talks with the Government.
The Government said four strikes erupted in different parts of Poland.
The Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, called them dangerous because of the difficult economic situation.

Bush, in Ottawa, Now Vows To Pursue Acid Rain Pact
LEAD: President Bush met with Prime Minister Brian Mulroney today and agreed to pursue an international accord with Canada to reduce the acid rain that falls on both sides of the border.


Halt at Ford Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said that it had interrupted production at an assembly plant this week, its first such shutdown in years.
Bert Serre, a spokesman for Ford, said the plant, in Hermosillo, Mexico, would resume production of the Mercury Tracer subcompact on Monday.
The car had been accumulating on dealers' lots, a rare problem for Ford, which for years has produced all the cars it could and sold all that it produced.


Prime Rate Up 1/2 Point, To 11%
LEAD: Large commercial banks increased their prime lending rate by a half percentage point yesterday, to 11 percent, for the fifth consecutive increase over the last 12 months.


Alternative Minimum Tax: A Credit Is Now Helpful
LEAD: More taxpayers than ever are now having to pay the alternative minimum tax, as a result of changes in the income tax laws, professionals say.
And while many will want to restructure their finances to avoid the tax in the future, that is not necessarily the best strategy, given the new A.M.T. credit that is allowed beginning with 1988 returns.

LEAD: Jose Uribe, the San Francisco Giants' shortstop, cannot leave the Dominican Republic until he stands trial on a rape charge, a district attorney there said yesterday.

Dataproducts
LEAD: The Dataproducts Corporation, a manufacturer of computer printers, instructed its investment banking firm, Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company, to seek a buyer for the company.
Dataproducts, which has annual sales of about $345 million, said it had not made a final decision to sell the company but that it believed it could obtain the best value for its shareholders by putting itself up for sale.


Canseco Gets a Ticket
LEAD: Speed and power have brought Jose Canseco all sorts of honors in his three-year career, including the American League's most valuable player award for last season.
Early yesterday morning in Florida, that combination brought him a ticket after the police estimated that his 1989 Jaguar was traveling more than 120 miles an hour along Interstate 95 in northern Dade County.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Gilbert Beats McEnroe: Brad Gilbert upset John McEnroe, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the Volvo Chicago tournament.
Earlier, 16-year-old Michael Chang withdrew with tendinitis in his right leg, putting Horacio de la Pena of Argentina into the semifinals.
Gilbert will face de la Pena in one of today's semfinals.

LEAD: Giorgio Zancanaro, who was to sing the title role in concert performances of Verdi's ''Nabucco'' with the Philadelphia Orchestra in Philadelphia and New York this month, has withdrawn because of a bronchial condition, the orchestra has announced.

Below are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Federal and state offices open, local offices closed.
Post offices: Regular delivery.

LEAD: Emily Kimbrough, an author, lecturer and former radio commentator, died yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

LEAD: Dan Kelly, the broadcaster of St.
Louis Blues games for the last 21 years, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Chesterfield, Mo.
He was 52 years old.


Bank Branches At K Mart to End
LEAD: First Nationwide Bank, a unit of the Ford Motor Company, said it would close its 170 branches in K Mart stores, effective March 10.
The decision represents the end of a bold experiment for First Nationwide, a San Francisco-based savings institution, to grow quickly without having to build new branches.


11 Bases Listed as Sites for Missile Trains
LEAD: The Air Force today issued an environmental statement listing 11 military bases around the country where railroad trains carrying MX missiles might be located if the Bush Administration decided on such a plan to hide the missiles' whereabouts.

Kirk Gets One Year For Tax Evasion
LEAD: Dana Kirk, the former Memphis State basketball coach, was sentenced to one year in prison and fined $20,000 yesterday for income tax evasion and obstruction of justice.
Kirk, 53 years old, declined to comment on the sentence but said he was considering an appeal.
United States District Judge Odell Horton said he agreed with the jury's verdict that Kirk was guilty of cheating on his taxes and trying to intimidate a grand jury witness.


George B. Walsh, Professor, 42
LEAD: George B. Walsh, chairman of the department of classical languages and literature at the University of Chicago, died of cancer Tuesday at Bernard Mitchell Hospital in Chicago.
He was 42 years old and lived in Chicago.


Review/Music; Rosemary Clooney's Apple Pie
LEAD: Rosemary Clooney exudes comfort, coziness and serenity, just as her friend and champion, Bing Crosby, once did.
If her delivery is not as soft as that of a crooner, she also never really raises her voice.
The tone she adopts for both ballads and uptempo songs is warm but matter-of-fact.
Like Crosby's, her technical proficiency is such that her singing seems nearly effortless, though of course it isn't.


Simon Virsaladze, 80, Designer
LEAD: Simon Virsaladze, one of the Soviet Union's leading designers of ballet, film and opera, died of leukemia Thursday in Tbilisi, Georgia.
He was 80 years old.

LEAD: Declaring that the nation's streets are becoming a combat zone, police officials urged Congress today to ban assault rifles like the one used to kill five children last month in a California playground.


Scandals and School Decentralization
LEAD: When New York City's public schools were decentralized in 1969, one goal was to give parents a voice in their children's education.
But parents remain shut out.
Local politicians quickly gobbled up the powers relinquished by the central Board of Education.


Teheran and Baghdad Agree to March Talks
LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of Iran and Iraq have agreed to hold a new round of direct peace talks on the Persian Gulf in March after talks with Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar, the Secretary General announced today.


Tacoma Backs Needle Swap
LEAD: A government role in a program that gives free hypodermic needles to drug addicts when they turn in used ones received final approval Thursday from the Tacoma-Pierce County Health Board.
The program, aimed at fighting the spread of AIDS, was started on a private basis in August by a former drug counselor, Dave Purchase.

LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission's New York regional office held a one-day conference of 45 state, Federal and securities industry enforcement officials on Thursday as part of its effort to combat penny-stock fraud in the New York City area.

LEAD: Although a new law intended to reduce conflicts of interest on New York City's local school boards is only a few months old, some board members are already taking steps to avoid its consequences, election records and political associates indicate.

LEAD: George Balanchine's ballet version of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' loses no time in plunging into its music and dancing.
The plot is not given short shrift but is compressed with cinematic swiftness into a minimum of dramatic posturing.

Adam Mujica, said that Mr.
Clark and other school employees had harrassed him after four students accused him of sexual misconduct over four years.

LEAD: The consumer-products giant Unilever said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Faberge Inc., a leading cosmetics company, for $1.55 billion in cash, raising its investment in the American market in the last two years by almost $5 billion.

More important than his details, he avoids confrontation and invites negotiation.

A Correction: The Budget
LEAD: A table yesterday with a front-page article about President Bush's budget for the fiscal year 1990 misstated differences between some of President Ronald Reagan's proposed spending for the year and President Bush's in the same categories.

He was 69 years old and lived in Carversville, Pa.

BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1989
LEAD:  The Economy


Victims' Errors Blamed in Fire Deaths
LEAD: Windblown flames that roared through an apartment and hallway and killed three people in a high-rise in Queens on Thursday began as a small terrace fire and mushroomed into tragedy because of errors commonly made by fire victims, the authorities said yesterday.


Orange Crop Forecast
LEAD: The nation's orange harvest is estimated at about 215 million boxes for the 1988-89 season, virtually unchanged from the previous forecast a month ago, but 7 percent higher than last season's production, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.


Man Convicted in 14 Killings Jury Votes for Death Penalty
LEAD: A jury found a man guilty of capital murder today in the shooting and strangulation deaths of 14 family members and recommended that he be sentenced to die for the killings.

LEAD: A Federal appeals court today rejected the Bush Administration's third attempt in two days to halt the trial of Oliver L. North to prevent the disclosure of state secrets, and the Administration said it would make a final plea to the Supreme Court Saturday morning.

Cliff Buck, Olympic Official, 88
LEAD: Cliff Buck, president of the United States Olympic Committee from 1969 to 1973, died Wednesday night at the Heritage Park Care Center in Carbondale, Calif.
He was 88 years old.
Mr.
Buck was an administrator in amateur sports for more than 30 years.
He worked for the Rocky Mountain Amateur Athletic Union and the national A.A.U.

He was 77 years old.

It was 1966, not 1962.

Interest Rates Soar in Credit Markets
LEAD: Interest rates jumped in the credit markets yesterday after the report of an unexpectedly sharp rise of 1 percent in the January Producer Price Index, a portent of higher inflation.
The markets also reacted to a half-point increase in banks' prime lending rate, to 11 percent.

Golden Gates
LEAD: French-Japanese, California-Italian, Mediterranean-American, Southwestern-French - defining cuisine today isn't easy.
In restaurants in the United States, ingredients, cooking techniques and presentation styles overlap and blur.
A torte of black beans is as likely to appear on the menu at a French restaurant as creme de cresson.

Kabul Accuses Pakistan of Planning Invasion
LEAD: President Najibullah accused Pakistan today of planning to invade Afghanistan with the intention of annexing the country.


Breaking a Deadlock In Panama
LEAD: On the face of it, there is complete deadlock.
Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's strongman, has withstood U.S. efforts to strong-arm him out of power, and Washington isn't about to back down and accept him.
But there is a whiff of deals being reconsidered.


Valentine Protocol: Children Know Best
LEAD: SATURDAYS at the library are different from other days of the week; a certain lightness fills the air.
Cartoon-pitched children's voices float brightly over the muffled sound of rustled pages emanating from the reading room.
One can feel the staidness lifted; the building swarms with frisky Lilliputians, who might easily erupt in giggles if told reading was for anything but fun.


Pitt Upsets No. 2 Hoyas
LEAD: Jason Matthews scored 24 points and Pitt held No. 2 Georgetown to 8 points in the final 10 minutes to upset the Hoyas, 79-74, today in the Big East Conference.


First Interstate's Turn to Squirm
LEAD: A little more than two years ago, Joseph J. Pinola, chairman and chief executive of the First Interstate Bancorp, made an audacious bid to buy the BankAmerica Corporation.
BankAmerica was more than twice First Interstate's size, but it was in shambles - its stock was depressed, its capital base weak and its management surprised by a series of loan losses and other misfortunes.

Sharpening Chisels and Planes
LEAD: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit.
However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them.
Dull cutting tools are ineffective.
They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.

On Screen, a Kiss Is Still a Kiss
LEAD: With Valentine's Day approaching, this is as good a time as any to point out that Cupid doesn't always shoot straight.
Sometimes he creates star-crossed lovers of the sort that Hollywood adores, lovers who meet under the most inopportune circumstances imaginable.
The couple in the 1963 LOVE WITH THE PROPER STRANGER (Paramount Home Video, $19.95), which is newly available on videocassette, are especially star-crossed, since the salesgirl (Natalie Wood) is already pregnant by the footloose musician (Steve McQueen) when the film begins.

Spinners can buy an unprocessed soft mound of wool freshly sheared from the sheep.

Boxing
LEAD:  Jacquot Wins Title: Rene Jacquot became the first Frenchman in 30 years to win a world boxing championship by scoring a unanimous 12-round decision over Donald Curry of the United States for the World Boxing Council super-welterweight title last night at Grenoble, France.
The scoring by the judges was: Sid Nathan of Britain, 117-113; Justo Vasquez of Spain, 118-115, and Jesus Arias of Mexico, 118-116, all in favor of Jacquot.

LEAD: How cool is coldness?

New Order songs have become standards for college radio stations and rock dance clubs and moved on to more commercial outlets; despite a stage presence best described as efficient, New Order concerts are dependable sellouts.

Fires Leave 15,000 Homeless
LEAD: Three mysterious fires broke out within hours of each other in metropolitan Manila, razing 2,000 houses and leaving up to 15,000 people homeless, police said today.
The first fire broke out Friday afternoon in Tondo, a Manila slum district, destroying about 2,000 houses in a four-block area.
Several people, mostly children, were missing but there were no reports of deaths, police said.

Sharpening Chisels and Planes
LEAD: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit.
However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them.
Dull cutting tools are ineffective.
They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.

WHAT'S DOING IN: Savannah
LEAD: Unlike some other time-worn towns, Savannah doesn't believe in keeping the family treasures in a display case, to be seen but not touched.
House museums, frequent private tours and friendly homeowners offer a hands-on history lesson.
Laid out by Gen.
James Oglethorpe 256 years ago, Savannah has the country's largest urban National Historic Landmark District, which includes free-standing mansions, row houses on Gordon, Jones and Gaston streets and 22 park-like squares.


Compaq Sharpens Its Video Option
LEAD: Computer-aided design and computer-aided engineering, or CAD-CAE, used to be done almost exclusively on powerful work stations costing tens of thousands of dollars.
Today, most CAD work is done on personal computers, especially on machines that are powered by the Intel 80386 processor.
That chip has enough muscle to display and redraw complex graphics and drawings.

But I thought I was entitled to at least try.

LEAD: IF you go to the mall only to shop, chances are you have never seen them.
They are there at dawn, hours before the first cash register rings, often before the first janitorial shift.
Clad in sweat suits and jogging shoes, they come to walk the store-lined corridors, back and forth, over and over.
They are mall walkers, and for them, the suburban shopping mall, with its controlled climate, security guards, level floors and restrooms, is the perfect exercise track.

Impressionism Revisited: Context Is King
LEAD: During the last 15 to 20 years, art historians like Robert L. Herbert have changed art history.
They believe that nothing can be understood apart from its social context and that absolutely everything in art has meaning.
Each splash of color, each odd angle and each straight line is seen as a product of intention and choice.

LEAD: IF ever a coin could be called endearing, the Lincoln cent earns the title hands down.
Celebrating its 80th year, more than a quarter-trillion of the coins have been minted.
Although it is known commonly as the penny that term is an anachronism from British colonial times.

Designing A Jewelry Jungle
LEAD: MIA FONSSAGRIVES-SOLOW, right, was in the fashion business with the designer Vicky Tiel in Paris in the 1960's.
When she returned to the United States she became a sculptor, making larger-than-life-size animals.
Recently she has interpreted animal shapes as jewelry, including walking cats, swinging monkeys, butterflies with folded wings, lions' heads and standing meerkats (African mongooses).

NEW YORKERS, Etc.
LEAD: IT'S difficult to believe, but there are people who don't talk to themselves.
They think the things that many others say aloud, they form sentences and phrases in their minds, and occasionally they go so far as to move their lips - but no sound emerges.
In fact, these people are apt to consider those who do talk to themselves a rather strange lot, next door to street mutterers and just a few degrees away from the men and women who carry on loud and rambling conversations with phantoms on buses and subways.

Question Of the Week; Will Free Agency Work In Football?
LEAD: The free agency will do to football what it did to baseball: It will make millionaires out of mediocre players.
Big-city teams with big-city budgets will become a collection of overpriced underachievers.
Owners will be tried and found guilty of collusion in an effort to stop the bidding madness.
And the fans will enjoy it all from their $500 seats, while waving their $25 programs, eating their $15 hotdogs, and sipping their $5 sodas.

LEAD: What are America's most pressing domestic needs?

Many Americans share these goals.
But there's a problem.
Though the captain's new chart plots a sensible destination, his boat is too small to get there.

Mr.
McMurtry virtually dismissed all of Texas literature, saying Texas writers were unduly fixated on the past and largely because of that had produced almost nothing of lasting value.
He lamented that he had been far too optimistic when he predicted 14 years earlier the demise of literature extolling the rural glories of wide-open spaces and yahoos on horseback.

WHEN OLD IS NEW
LEAD: In this era of eternal youth, speeding up the aging process may seem like a strange idea, but it has become big business in the design world.
It is now possible to get the feeling of perfectly faded fabrics or the rich patina of century-old woods without paying the price of time.
The tricks, to be sure, are theatrical: soaking freshly printed chintzes in vats of tea; smearing mud into shiny surfaces; mixing eggshells, finely ground dust or coffee grinds into paint; beating fabrics with stones.

Adultery Penalty May Change
LEAD: The State House of Representatives has passed a bill repealing a 200-year-old law that makes adultery a crime punishable by a year in jail.
The measure, passed 201 to 149 on Thursday, goes to the Senate, where a similar bill was defeated two years ago.
Supporters of repeal said the law was unenforceable, while their opponents said repeal would lead to a perception that New Hampshire tolerates adultery.

Sharpening Chisels and Planes
LEAD: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit.
However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them.
Dull cutting tools are ineffective.
They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.


A Greece of Forests And Mountain Lakes
LEAD: FOR years, my vision of Greece consisted exclusively of naked, sun-scorched rock and pristine sugar-cube villages rising out of an expanse of blue sea.
Then, gradually, I became drawn to another, more subtle Greece, not Mediterranean but Balkan; an autumnal land of fir forests, stately poplars and dark green mountains grooved with snow, evoking the background of an old master's painting rather than the usual watercolor sketch of sea and stone.

LEAD: Back in 1974 the dam across the Kennebec River here broke in a heavy rainstorm, and a section of the river suddenly looked as it did before the dam was built in 1836.


Why the Garbage Is Never Really Gone
LEAD: ACROSS much of the United States, trash is still disposed of in the old-fashioned way, with bulldozers and open landfills.
But the metropolitan areas of the Northeast were forced by geography to move farther and faster toward large-scale incineration and, more recently, recycling.


Affordable Housing: A Necessity Both for People And for Business
LEAD: THE growing shortage of affordable housing in New Jersey is now a serious concern for tens of thousands of young working people unable to buy a home, for thousands more who cannot afford skyrocketing rents and, of course, for the 25,000 of our citizens who are homeless.


Corrections
LEAD: A map on Jan. 22 with an article about private dining clubs in London located Harry's Bar incorrectly.
The club is on the east side of South Audley Street.


Playing His Songs
LEAD: Some of the most memorable songs on Broadway this season were written by an all but forgotten lyricist, Andy Razaf.
The American-born son of an Malagasy nobleman, Razaf wrote the words to more than 500 tunes, mostly in the 1920's and 30's, before he died in 1973.
Among them are seven songs in the long-running ''Ain't Misbehavin' '' and five in the recently opened ''Black and Blue'' - including the title songs.

LEAD: To the Sports Editor:

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
John M. Wardell of Bay Head, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Dickenson Wardell, to George Dudley Iverson 6th, a son of Ellen B. MacNeille of Chevy Chase, Md., and Mr.
Iverson 5th of Washington.
The couple plan to marry in April.


Born to Travel
LEAD: To the Editor: I agree with Thomas Swick and Waugh (''Born to Travel,'' Nov. 27) that a poor travel book is better to read than a novel.


Outbreak of Road Shootings Plagues Detroit
LEAD: Every year, the police here receive two or three reports of highway shootings.
But ever since Michael K. Warner was shot and killed on Interstate 75 south of Detroit around midnight Nov. 19, the shootings have multiplied and the reports have multiplied even more.
The police say that the shootings seem to be unrelated and that some are imaginary; often stones or debris are the culprits.

LEAD: Additional resources for the International Monetary Fund and a bigger role for Japan in the 151-nation lending agency were projected this week by the chairman of its policy-making Interim Committee, Finance Minister H. Onno Ruding of the Netherlands.

North Trial Issue Goes to Justices
LEAD: The Bush Administration asked the Supreme Court to stay the trial of Oliver L. North or risk ''irreparable injury'' to the national security.


Sharpening Chisels and Planes
LEAD: WOODWORKING chisels and at least one hand plane have a place in almost every household tool kit.
However, if you own such tools, learning how to sharpen them is as important as learning how to use them.
Dull cutting tools are ineffective.
They are also dangerous because they require more effort to use than sharp tools and so are more difficult to control.

Movies Lost in Translation
LEAD: By self-appointment film purveyor to the world, Hollywood, in turn, has always welcomed artists from abroad.
Some great directors, such as Jean Renoir and Max Ophuls, came and went.
F.
W.
Murnau, Billy Wilder and Fritz Lang, among others, stayed, responded to the environment and prospered.
Each in his own way enriched the American movie idiom.


Maria Edgeworth's Names
LEAD: To the Editor:


Question Of the Week; Will Free Agency Work In Football?
LEAD: The N.F.L. has opted to go for a field goal instead of a touchdown in the area of free agency.
By protecting three-quarters of its roster players from being eligible for free agency, it has kept the stars on the sidelines.
About the only players eligible will be expendable members of the kicking teams, plus the aged and the malcontents.

LEAD: Karen Beth Metsky and Robert Cowen 3d are planning a May wedding, the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs.
Marvin Metsky of Livingston, N.J., have announced.
A graduate of the University of Pittsburgh, Miss Metsky is a vice president of Sports Minded, a sports-equipment marketing company in New York.


TARGET: KABUL
LEAD: ROCKET LAUNCHERS ARE STACKED IN A CORNER of the cramped windowless room and Kalashnikov assault rifles hang on hooks along the walls.
Outside, dusk has fallen and the blue-white lights of Kabul off in the horizon outline the skeletal remains of nearby bombed-out houses.
The winter stillness is interrupted at regular intervals by the dull thud of artillery.

LEAD: Books may never be sold there again, but the inside of the Scribner Book Store on Fifth Avenue is likely to become an official New York City landmark, which would be welcomed by its owners.

Once Moldy, Now Worth $1 Million, a Mural Starts a Fight
LEAD: A school tosses out a moldy old mural.
It falls into the hands of an art conservator, who restores the painting.
Sixteen years later, the once-worthless work is appraised at $1.25 million.
Who is the rightful owner?
The school?
Or the conservator?

LEAD: The Venezue lan central bank has approved a plan to seek a $600 million loan based on future gold sales, two leading Caracas newspapers reported Saturday.


Knife Attack on British Train
LEAD: About 15 knife-wielding youths robbed passengers on an inter-city train early today and attacked some who resisted, resulting in some injuries, the transport police said. ''At least 11 people were robbed of cash, jewelry and other valuables, and two people were taken to a hospital with head and neck injuries,'' a police official said.

LEAD: After an almost euphoric reception by Congress last Monday, President Bush's plan to rescue the savings and loan industry is getting somewhat bruised.
Lawmakers are complaining that the proposal is short on money, weak on detail and likely to become a budgetary nightmare down the road.

Squash Rankings Still Go by the Letters
LEAD: THE elegant simplicity of squash rankings used to place a great deal of importance on that first jump up, from level D to C. Level D in those days was, in addition to being the lowest, the broadest and deepest of the four - ''like second gear in a car,'' -said Pat Canavan, head pro at the Lincoln Racquet and Fitness Club in Manhattan.

Spring Training
LEAD: EVERY team sport has its training season, but baseball is the only sport whose pre-season preparation has a special name that conjures up special feelings.
No one speaks expressively about ''summer training'' in pro football.
Everyone, however, talks about ''spring training,'' as in, ''I can't wait 'til spring training starts.

LEAD: ONE of the favorite topics of conversation around Hayward, Wis., these days is about waves, but not the cresting kind.
A wave to a Hayward local is a surge of skiers lined up for the start of the Curel American Birkebeiner.
It is the largest cross-country ski race in North America and tends to attract as many as 6,000 competitors to the start.

Fire at McFarlane Town House
LEAD: A fire broke out Sunday afternoon at the home of Robert C. McFarlane, the former national security adviser, Fire Department officials reported.
They said no one was injured.
Damage to the home, a town house in the Georgetown section, was estimated today at $75,000.
Mr.
McFarlane, who was national security adviser under President Ronald Reagan, pleaded guilty last year to four misdemeanor counts of withholding information from Congress in connection with the Iran-contra affair.

Ralph Black Is Dead; Arts Manager Was 69
LEAD: Ralph Black, a widely known arts manager and advocate, died of cardiac arrest Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md.
He was 69 years old and lived in Bethesda.


Honeywell Venture
LEAD: Honeywell Inc. said Sterch, its joint venture with the Soviet Ministry of Mineral Fertilizer Production, had won three contracts in the Soviet Union worth a total of $8 million.
Honeywell said the contracts cover the supply of process control systems and site services for modernizing ammonia fertilizer units at three chemical plants.


Builder Announces Campaign for Mayor
LEAD: Henry Hewes, who was state chairman of Pat Robertson's Presidential campaign last year, said yesterday that he will run for mayor on the Right to Life Party line.

Grey to Handle Tonka
LEAD: The Tonka Corporation, whose toy trucks have gladdened many a child's heart, brightened the halls of Grey Advertising yesterday by consolidating its $60 million worth of business there.
The company moved the creative and marketing assignments for its Tonka Products division to Grey from Jordan, McGrath, Case &amp; Taylor, which had been Tonka's agency for seven years.


Panel Unaware of Baker Stock
LEAD: Some members of the Senate committee that voted to confirm James A. Baker 3d as Treasury Secretary in 1985 were not aware that he held a large amount of bank stock, a Senate aide said today.


Copper Prices Drop Sharply On Report of High Inventory
LEAD: Copper futures prices dropped steeply yesterday, punctuating a weeks-long decline, following reports that an increase in inventories at the London Mercantile Exchange was two or three times larger than traders had anticipated.

LEAD: Five female employees of an Albany television station who filed sexual discrimination complaints against a station manager will receive $25,000 each under a settlement, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday.

Cow Manure Fuels a California Power Plant
LEAD: A desert power plant fueled by cow manure is generating enough electricity to supply up to 20,000 homes.


Sen. Armstrong of Colorado Says He Will Not Run Again
LEAD: Senator William L. Armstrong, a Colorado Republican who has served in Congress since 1973, said today that two terms were enough and that he would not seek re-election in 1990.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Alexander &amp; Baldwin Inc., Honolulu, said it would report a one-time gain of $101.6 million, or $2.16 a share, in its first quarter because of the sale of its Wailea Development Co. subsidiary to the Swinwa Golf Group for $197.5 million.


Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about the dispute over government secrets at the trial of Oliver L. North misstated the Supreme Court's involvement.
The action the Court had planned, before an agreement between the White House and the independent prosecutor, was consideration of a stay, not judgment on the merits of the arguments.


Lincoln Center Award Named for Beverly Sills
LEAD: Lincoln Center has established a new award for young American singers in honor of Beverly Sills, who is leaving the directorship of the New York City Opera in May.

Frank G. Taormina; Manufacturer, 89
LEAD: Frank G. Taormina, a food importer and manufacturer who was chairman of Progresso Quality Foods when he retired in 1969, died yesterday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 89 years old and lived in Peapack, N.J.


Wyse Technology
LEAD: Wyse Technology, a manufacturer of personal computers and computer terminals, said it expected an operating loss for its fourth fiscal quarter, ending March 31.
Wyse, based in San Jose, Calif., suffered a loss of $26.4 million in the third quarter.
The expected loss in the fourth quarter will put Wyse in violation of certain credit agreements and force it to seek waivers from its lenders or alternative financing, the company said.


Ailing Robot Industry Is Turning to Services
LEAD: The robotics industry, whose sales have been in the doldrums for the last three years, is getting closer to the day when applications in the service sector of the economy will free it from dependence on industrial users.


American Dogwoods Are Unable to Resist Devastating Fungus
LEAD: THE hope that some native American dogwoods might be resistant to a spreading fungal disease that is killing many of the flowering trees has been dashed by a new study.


ARCO Spending
LEAD: ARCO said its board had approved a 30 percent increase in its 1989 capital spending program, to $2.6 billion, from $2 billion last year.
ARCO said that it would increase capital spending in all business segments in 1989 and that worldwide spending for oil exploration and production would rise to $1.5 billion, from $1.1 billion in 1988.


Correction
LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about dividend increases referred incorrectly to the Dow Jones industrial average.
The 30 stocks that make up the average do not include Ford Motor.


No More Pretty Flowers
LEAD: Valentine's Day 1989 finds a new President's honeymoon with Congress nearing its inevitable end somewhat sooner than usual.
Divorce or even separate bed-rooms may not be in order yet, but they're not sending pretty flowers anymore.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. What happens when you crack your knuckles?
Does it cause arthritis?
A.The bones and the series of ligaments that form the knuckles and many other joints have a little elasticity, said Dr.
Robert L. Swezey, director of the Arthritis and Back Pain Center in Santa Monica, Calif.

LEAD: The New England economy, whose rocket-like growth was the envy of the nation for most of the decade, is returning to earth.

LEAD: Many alcoholics can be treated as effectively, and much more cheaply, at outpatient clinics as in hospital treatment wards, researchers have found.

Brown Stock Up
LEAD: Shares of Brown Group Inc. rose today after the St.
Louis-based shoe manufacturer announced plans to restructure its operations.
Brown Group gained 50 cents, to $34.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Late Friday, Brown Group said it would take an $18 million charge against earnings to cover losses on the sale of three specialty retailing businesses.


Bass Group Buys 5.7% Xicor Stake
LEAD: A group led by Sid R. and Lee M. Bass of the wealthy Texas family said it had bought 5.7 percent of the outstanding stock of Xicor Inc.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the Bass group said it had acquired about one million of Xicor's shares for investment purposes.
Xicor is a Milpitas, Calif., maker of semiconductors.

LEAD: In a surprise announcement, Edward A. Horrigan Jr., chairman of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for the last nine years, announced late yesterday that he would leave RJR Nabisco Inc. on March 1.

LEAD: The nuclear-powered attack submarine Pasadena joined the Navy's fleet Saturday.
Thirty-five 35 nuclear weapon opponents conducted a peaceful demonstration outside the commissioning ceremonies.
The 360-foot submarine, which displaces 6,900 tons and will carry a crew of 12 officers and 115 enlisted men, was built at General Dynamic's Electric Boat division shipyard here.

Ruling Favors Player
LEAD: A former Seattle Seahawk wide receiver, Sam McCullum, was illegally discharged by the Seahawks when he was cut before the strike-marred 1982 season, the National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday.
McCullum, then the Seahawks' player representative, must be given back pay, with interest, from the time of his release and a job ''substantially equivalent'' to the job he lost, the N.L.R.B.

LEAD: A STUDY that spanned a decade in the lives of nearly 1,000 people found no statistically significant link between the amount of DDT in their bodies and risk of death by cancer.

Future Is Now at Oklahoma Track
LEAD: Five years ago, when the Edward DeBartolo Corporation purchased an undeveloped 375-acre tract from the Oklahoma City Zoo and began building a race track, company officials wondered how the zoo had been using the empty land.
When a bulldozer unearthed the first set of elephant bones, they realized where the zoo had long been burying its deceased attractions.

LEAD: D. Wayne Lukas and Laz Barrera, a member of the racing Hall of Fame, are among six trainers under investigation for having run horses that had cocaine in their systems.


Uribe Charges Dropped
LEAD: A judge in the Dominican Republic ruled yesterday that there was insufficient evidence to take the San Francisco Giant shortstop Jose Uribe to trial for rape.
Judge Freddy Matos Nina made the decision in Santo Domingo after questioning Uribe for more than two hours.
Uribe, 29, was accused by a woman of threatening her with a gun and raping her.

Rig Count Down Again
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs continued to decline last week, plunging by 34, to a total of 746, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago the count totaled 968.
Baker Hughes's economist, Ike Kerridge, said the count usually falls from late December through late March or early April.
The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity.


Trade Surplus Up in Japan
LEAD: Japan's trade surplus rose in January from a year ago as low oil prices continued to keep down import costs, the Finance Ministry reported today.

Fossil Findings Fan Debate on Human Origins
LEAD: NEW fossil discoveries and genetic evidence have fueled a resounding debate among anthropologists over the timing and circumstances of the last major event in human physical evolution, the emergence of the anatomically modern Homo sapiens.


Drop in Europe Jobless
LEAD: The unemployment rate in the 12-nation European Community fell in December to 10 percent, its lowest level in more than five years, the community reported today.
The jobless rate in November was 10.1 percent.
The community last had an unemployment rate of 10 percent in the summer of 1983.
Unemployment peaked at 11 percent in the fall of 1984.

Correction

LEAD: A proposal to make English the official language of Suffolk County has ignited a bitter debate over the rights of the county's foreign-speaking residents.


At This Retreat, A Cat Becomes His Own Master
LEAD: One day melds quietly into the next here at the Last Post, a lovely 37-acre wooded retreat for elderly cats.
Many of the cats spend entire days lounging in one of the 60-foot-long pine-paneled cat sitting rooms, with the skylights, ceiling fans and large wood beams trucked in from Maine.
Hundreds of happy cats rest on the sitting room armchairs, couches and tables.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Grey Advertising
LEAD: Grey Advertising reported that its 1988 earnings rose 13.6 percent, to $11.7 million, or $8.88 a share.
This figure excludes the one-time earnings lift from the sale of foreign and domestic subsidiaries.
Grey's net income was $10.3 million in 1987.
The company's gross billings in 1988 were $2.48 billion.

LEAD: The chairman of the Coleman Company, known throughout the world for its lanterns and other camping equipment, offered yesterday to buy the company for $450 million.

The agency has been named to invent the marketing for the Converse Performance Brand, the company's new entry in the ''jock'' end of the sneaker market.

LEAD: A gathering of millions of Hindus for a major festival has served as an impressive display of the hold that faith continues to have on the life of this young nation and ancient land.

LEAD: Robert Taylor Scott Keith, a retired Navy vice admiral, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at his home in Falls Church, Va.
He was 83 years old and previously lived in Virginia Beach and Coronado, Calif.


For the Public Schools, A Mixed Report Card
LEAD: A comprehensive educational study released today gives the nation's schools a mixed report card: good marks on teaching of basic skills but poor grades on conveying the kind of advanced abilities needed to succeed in college and in the workplace.

LEAD: When Mayor Henry G. Cisneros of San Antonio said last year that he would leave office this spring, the job offers rolled in.

But he says the position he ended up accepting surprises even him.

LEAD: By CLIFTON BROWN


J. Newton Hill, Educator, 88
LEAD: J. Newton Hill, a former dean of Lincoln University in Oxford, Pa., died of pneumonia Saturday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.


New Director to Be Named For the 1994 World Cup
LEAD: Preparations for the 1994 World Cup, the first to be held in the United States, are barely under way and a change has already been made at the top of the organizing committee.


National Credit Card Securities
LEAD: The National Credit Card Trust 1989 is offering $750 million worth of debt securities backed by Citibank Visa and Mastercard receivables through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

LEAD: ''IT started with Betty Crocker, who didn't exist,'' said George Lois, the chairman and creative director of the Lois/GGK advertising agency in New York, referring to eponymous food products. ''Uncle Ben, Aunt Jemima - they didn't exist,'' he said, but they helped consumers identify with rice and pancakes.


Patents on Equations: Some See a Danger
LEAD: Encouraged by a new attitude in the courts and at the Patent and Trademark Office, universities and corporations are rushing to stake patent claims in a whole new arena of intellectual property: mathematical equations.


Wide Medication Misuse Is Found Among Elderly
LEAD: Misdiagnoses by doctors, faulty prescriptions and improper use of drugs by patients have created widespread problems among the elderly, a new Government study has found.
For example, 51 percent of deaths from drug reactions in this country involve people 60 years of age or older, even though they account for only 17 percent of the population, the report said.


Centaur Partners Lifts Offer for Pennwalt
LEAD: Centaur Partners, a New York investment group, today raised its bid for the Pennwalt Corporation to $110 a share from $100 a share.


Coastal Extends Texas Eastern Bid
LEAD: The Coastal Corporation extended its $2.6 billion cash offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation by 10 days after the deadline for its original offer expired Monday.
Coastal officials extended the $42-a-share offer to next Thursday, a spokesman, Robert Wells, said.
Both companies are based in Houston.
