LEAD: In the face of sharp Congressional criticism over the lack of details in President Bush's budget proposals, top Administration officials promised today to provide more specifics before the end of the week.


Pilots at Eastern Urged To Back Other Unions
LEAD: The governing body of the pilots' union at Eastern Air Lines Inc. issued a strongly worded resolution yesterday recommending that its 3,500 members respect any picket line set up by the airline's other unions.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption in some copies yesterday about negotiations over the Long Island Lighting Company and the Shoreham nuclear power plant misidentified the Federal judge in the case.
He is Judge Jack B. Weinstein; he resigned the post of Chief Judge in the Eastern District of New York in March 1988.


Khomeini Urges Muslims to Kill Author of Novel
LEAD: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran declared today that the author and publishers of a novel deemed offensive to Islam had been ''sentenced to death.'' The novelist, Salman Rushdie, author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' said he was taking the threat seriously.


Corrections
LEAD: An obituary in late editions on Sunday and in all copies on Monday about Rabbi Samarious Gourary, executive director of United Lubavitcher Yeshivoth, gave his residence incorrectly.
He lived in Brooklyn, not Montclair, N.J.


Corrections
LEAD: An article by The Associated Press in some editions on Tuesday about a court ruling on transit service for the disabled misidentified the lawyer who argued before a Federal appeals court.
He was Timothy M. Cook, director of the Washington-based National Disability Action Center.


Drug Charge Jails Oklahoma Star
LEAD: The University of Oklahoma has been jolted again with the jailing of Charles Thompson, who started at quarterback for much of last season, after his arrest by F.B.I. agents on a complaint of selling cocaine to an undercover agent.


Inside New Yorker, a Splash of Color
LEAD: In its 64th anniversary issue, The New Yorker offers its first color art inside the magazine in decades and a redesigned Goings On About Town section.


Little Drop Seen in Property Values
LEAD: The regulator designated by President Bush to oversee about 200 insolvent savings institutions said today that property values in the Southwest would not suffer as a result of quick sales of troubled institutions or portions of the thousands of failed projects they financed.


Review/Music; Pieces by Virtuoso Pianists
LEAD: Voytek Matushevski, a pianist from Poland, devoted his Sunday afternoon Alice Tully Hall recital to music by four composers who were also virtuoso pianists.
Prominent on the program were Ignace Paderewski and Josef Hofmann, who thrived in the twilight of Romantic pianism, and whose works are rarely played today.


No New Tower Findings Seen
LEAD: A senior White House official said today that the renewed investigation into former Senator John G. Tower's background had produced no damaging new findings that would be likely to jeopardize Mr.
Tower's nomination as Defense Secretary.

LEAD: The Tandy Corporation, a consumer electronics manufacturer and retailer, announced today that its new division, the Grid Systems Corporation. would take over marketing the company's computers to corporations and governments.


Sudan Agrees to Discuss Emergency Famine Aid
LEAD: The Sudanese Government has invited representatives of United Nations relief agencies and other humanitarian organizations to Khartoum next month to discuss emergency steps to avert mass famine this spring, officials say.

Fighting Crime Wholesale and Retail
LEAD: What's the best way to prosecute crime?
The standard answer is, one case at a time.
Yet the limits of that approach have long been clear, and some criminal justice authorities are pondering a broader strategy that helps fight crime wholesale rather than retail.
The concept is by now familiar to police.

2 Exhibitions on Women and AIDS
LEAD: Two exhibitions on women with AIDS are to be presented from Feb. 24 to April 16 at the New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street.


If the Shoe Doesn't Fit
LEAD: Nike, the shoe company, has come out with a television commercial for hiking shoes that was shot in Kenya using Samburu tribesmen.
It combines broad shots of brightly clad, dancing men and women, and close-ups of the colorful new boots.
There are no words until the very end.
Then the camera closes in on the one tribesman who speaks, in native Maa.


Afghans and the Soviet Psyche: Military Myths Fade as the Troops Pull Out
LEAD: Soviet troops are leaving Afghanistan, but their escape from nine years of war does not erase their humiliation.


Belgian Rate Up Again
LEAD: Belgium's central bank increased a key interest rate today for the fourth time this month and the sixth time this year.
The bank raised the rate on the three-month Treasury bill by 0.15 percentage point, to 8.10 percent.
The bank also raised the rates on one- and two-month Treasury bills by 0.10 percentage point each, to 7.7 percent and 7.9 percent, respectively, and the rate on four-month certificates by 0.35 point, to 8.10 percent.


Steroid Sentence
LEAD: Dan Duchaine, a former body builder and self-described expert in steroid use, has been sentenced by Judge J. Lawrence Irving of San Diego Federal Court to a maximum of three years in Federal prison for his part in a steroid distribution ring.

LEAD: John Hancock Financial Services announced yesterday that six investment bankers formerly with Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had formed a new Hancock affiliate to specialize in banking services to the alternative energy and independent power industries.

About New York; Picture the Plaza As a Man. That's Fred Cristina.
LEAD: A half century, 50 years, more than 26 million minutes ago.
Most of a man's life.
It has been that long since Fred Cristina reported for his new job as a busboy in the Oak Room of the Plaza Hotel.
Joe Louis was heavyweight champion, Tallulah Bankhead was wowing Broadway, youngsters danced the Big Apple and Hitler was still far, far away.

Review/Theater; The Gumshoe Stomp, Or, Sleuthing to Music
LEAD: ''In a Pig's Valise,'' the ''hard-boiled yarn with music'' at the Second Stage, is an homage to detective fiction by a playwright whose affection for Raymond Chandler and Dashiell Hammett may be second only to his love for the sound of his own voice.
The playwright is Eric Overmyer, the author of the widely produced ''On the Verge,'' a work of such relentless erudition that its icy intricacies of diction linger long after the play's subject and human mouthpieces have evaporated.

Safe From Enemy Eyes
LEAD: When I was very, very young I assisted in creating a club.
It met under a large piece of burlap nailed to an apple tree.
There were three members: a president, a vice president and a doorman.
The doorman's job was to sit outside and keep an eye peeled for enemies while the president and vice president sat inside pretending to smoke candy cigarettes.

Results Plus

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE BHOPAL SETTLEMENT  Union Carbide was ordered to pay $470 million in damages for the December 1984 toxic gas leak in Bhopal, India, ending a legal battle over compensation for victims of the world's deadliest industrial accident.
The Indian Supreme Court's settlement proposal was accepted by Carbide, and all suits against the company and its former chairman, Warren Anderson, were dropped.

He was 58 and lived in Manhattan.


Ethics Panel Votes to Relax Stock Sale Rule
LEAD: President Bush's ethics commission today approved a plan that would allow new Federal appointees to defer capital gains taxes on stock holdings that they sold to avoid potential conflicts of interest.


Mosbacher Pessimistic On Steel Pact
LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today that the domestic steel industry was assured continued trade protection because there was no chance anytime soon of concluding an international agreement that would ban trade-distorting steel subsidies.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Saturday about the removal of State Senator Israel Ruiz of New York after his Federal felony conviction described state law on the removal process incorrectly.
It specifies that the post is vacated when a legislator is convicted of a felony; it does not require that the crime be considered a felony under New York State law.


Third Party Enters Battle for Ransburg
LEAD: A third party entered the battle to acquire the Ransburg Corporation when Eagle Industries offered to buy the industrial equipment maker for $21 a share in cash, or a total of $170 million.
Eagle is a subsidiary of Great American Management and Investment Inc., a manufacturing and financial services concern based in Chicago.


Seoul Journal; Censor's Scissors: No Longer Just Open and Shut
LEAD: The play ''Honeysuckles'' closed recently, on schedule and not because the Government shut it down.


Note and Bond Prices Fall Again
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds continued to slide in light trading yesterday, pushed lower by a retail sales report that was stronger than expected and a drop in the dollar.


Conrail Board May Select Chief Today
LEAD: The board of directors of Conrail may select a successor today to Richard D. Sanborn Jr., the chairman and chief executive who died Sunday after suffering a heart attack.

LEAD: Testing of blood samples from a group of 143 emergency-room patients at a South Bronx hospital has shown that 23 percent of them were infected with the AIDS virus, a finding that health officials call a disturbing sign of the extent of the epidemic.

LEAD: The Suffolk County Legislature refused yesterday to abandon its racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company, saying it would do so only if the utility first promised to ''irrevocably close, shutdown and decommission'' the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

LEAD: Dolph C. Simons, chairman of the board of The Journal-World, a daily newspaper in Lawrence, Kan., and of the World Company, its parent company, died in his sleep yesterday morning at his winter home in Scottsdale, Ariz.
He was 84 years old and lived in Lawrence.

Coffee machines.

LEAD: A researcher at the National Cancer Institute has been ordered by Federal officials to stop raising funds for a foundation he established, the scientist's lawyer said today.

The event is a benefit for the Poetry Society of America.

Information: 254-9628.


Gibson Still Hurting
LEAD: Kirk Gibson of the Los Angeles Dodgers, the National League's Most Valuable Player last season, continues to be bothered by a sore right knee but does not need surgery, the team said yesterday.
After examining Gibson, Dr.
Frank Jobe, the Dodgers' team physician, said the outfielder has tendinitis of the adductor tendons in his right knee but the ailment does not require an operation.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that the profit margins on its computer hardware, an important gauge of financial strength, rose in 1988 for the second straight year.

Report Says Bomber Had Fire Before Crash
LEAD: The Air Force said today that investigators had been unable to determine the exact cause of a B-1 bomber crash in Texas in November but that a fire on board had been fed by a fuel leak and had destroyed control lines.

LEAD: An Australian mining and investment company said Monday that it had secured rights to mine for gold and chromite in Vietnam.
Convictory Investment said it hoped to complete feasibility studies within six months on the Bong Mieu gold mine in southern Vietnam and the Thanh Hoa chromite mine in the north.

William Garbe Dead; Watercolorist Was 41
LEAD: William Garbe, an artist known for his large-scale watercolors of birds, flowers and seashore life, died last Thursday on the way to St.
Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Dr. Helane S. Rosenberg of Rutgers And Dr. Yakov M. Epstein Are Wed
LEAD: Dr.
Helane Susan Rosenberg and Dr.
Yakov Michael Epstein, both faculty members at Rutgers University, were married last evening at the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue in New York.
Cantor Philip Sherman performed the ceremony.


EATING WELL
LEAD: THE ancient Greeks said eating figs caused the teeth to rot.
Twentieth-century parents say the culprit is candy.
Both are right, but only partially.

Angelos E. Papatestas, Surgeon, 50
LEAD: Dr.
Angelos E. Papatestas, a professor of surgery at the Mount Sinai Medical Center, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 50 years old.

Kobe Steel to Buy 50% of USX Plant
LEAD: Kobe Steel Ltd. of Japan the last of Japan's big integrated steelmakers to enter a joint venture with a United States producer, will buy half of the USX Corporation's plant in Lorain, Ohio.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed.


Charles S. Gage, Executive, 85
LEAD: Charles S. Gage, a retired treasurer of Yale University, died Sunday at Yale-New Haven Hospital.
He was 85 years old and lived in Hamden, Conn.


Roslyn Journal; Where Have All the Forests Gone?
LEAD: Looking up at the shaved hillsides outside this frontier mountain town, Marianne Gordon sees her old nature trails turned to stubble and her husband's hunting grounds denuded of trees.


White House Delays Making Choice on Modernizing Missiles
LEAD: The White House announced today that it would not meet a Congressional deadline of Wednesday for deciding how to modernize the nation's land-based nuclear missiles, a choice that has been debated for a decade.

2 Trading Practices Could Bring Prosecution
LEAD: A former United States Attorney hired to advise the Chicago Board of Trade on the criminal inquiry into commodity trading activities today identified two types of illegal trading practices that could be prosecuted under the Federal racketeering law.


Rushdie Is Still Planning to Visit U.S. Next Week
LEAD: A death sentence by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini and other protests have not altered the plans of the novelist Salman Rushdie to come to the United States next week to promote ''The Satanic Verses,'' his American literary agent said yesterday.


Sales of Cars and Light Trucks Fall 15.1 %
LEAD: Sales of domestic light vehicles fell 15.1 percent in the first 10 days of February, prompting analysts to predict today that deeper price discounts and production cuts are inevitable.


Breaking Taboo, Soviets Report Big Jump in Crime
LEAD: In the first disclosure of detailed crime statistics in 56 years, a Soviet official said today that per capita crime in the Soviet Union rose by 17.8 percent last year, with especially sharp increases in violent crimes.

Rake's Progress
LEAD: ''Womanize'' is an unattractive verb, evoking rubberize, galvanize, oxidize, personalize and also stigmatize.
Its derivative, ''womanizer,'' is unattractive too, since it conveys nothing of what may attract men to women beyond the utilitarian.

Bhopal Tragedy: The Key Events
LEAD:  Dec. 3, 1984: Methyl isocyanate gas leaks from pesticides plant of Union Carbide India Ltd. in Bhopal, India.
Final death toll is estimated at more than 3,500.
Dec. 7: Warren Anderson, chairman of Union Carbide, and Keshub Mahindra, chairman of Union Carbide India, are arrested on charges of negligence and corporate liability.


Review/Art; Britain's Heritage, a Rich Attic, on View
LEAD: One of the best things that has happened to Britain since the end of World War II was the establishment in 1980 of the National Heritage Memorial Fund.
An act of Parliament stood behind it, but as is often the way in Britain, the trustees of the fund had no precise mandate. ''Heritage'' was nowhere defined in the act in question.

LEAD: The Grodnik Matheson Company, a Los Angeles investor group, said it had tried unsuccessfully to buy a 10 percent stake in National Lampoon Inc. from the company's chairman, Matty Simmons.
Reached at his office in Los Angeles, Mr.
Simmons said he would not comment on the proposal.
Mr.
Simmons said he holds between 10 percent and 11 percent of National

Ann-Margret, the film actress, is the spokeswoman in a public service ad campaign created by the Venet Companies, a subsidiary of GMI Group Inc., for the Myasthenia Gravis Foundation.
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular disease.

LEAD: Stanley Benn, a lawyer, died of a heart attack Saturday at Community Hospital in Boca Raton, Fla., while on vacation.
He was 49 years old and lived in West Deal, N.J.

LEAD: When fire damaged the house of Robert C. McFarlane on Sunday, the former national security adviser to President Ronald Reagan became temporarily homeless.

About Education
LEAD: More than 100 bills dealing with the needs of children and families were introduced in the 100th Congress.
None passed.
Sociologists and educators generally agree that children, and particularly poor children, need a new deal.
But lawmakers still have not agreed on policies to enhance early child care and education.

LEAD: ''It's like a laboratory, my house, for the creation of character,'' Tony Lo Bianco was saying. ''When I'm working, I'm like a mad scientist.
One day my wife came home from shopping, and she heard this voice and she thought it was somebody else in the house.
That was when I knew I could play La Guardia.

THE POP LIFE
LEAD:  'Mystery' Music When Roy Orbison died of a heart attack last December, he was on the brink of one of the most remarkable comebacks in pop history.
This week, the singer - whose posthumously released album, ''Mystery Girl'' (Virgin) makes its debut on Billboard's pop-album chart at No. 55 - has more records on the chart than any other artist.


Bryn Smith Arrested
LEAD: The front office of the Montreal Expos refused comment yesterday about the arrest of the pitcher Bryn Smith in a prostitution sweep last week in which six police officers in West Palm Becah, Fla., posed as prostitutes along a busy street.
Smith, 33 years old, was among 116 people charged with solicitation.


Bauer Starts 2d Magazine For Women
LEAD: THE Bauer Group, a West German publishing company, clearly believes that once is not enough.
Having already started Woman's World, a weekly magazine, Bauer has added a monthly, First for Women, to its American magazines.

Tokyo Market at a High
LEAD: A stable yen and impetus from Wall Street's gains pushed the Tokyo stock market's Nikkei index to a record high in trading here this morning.
It ended the morning session up 197.78 points, or 0.62 percent, at 32,347.26.
Earlier, it had reached a trading high of 32,354.75.
The previous high of 32,270.48 was set Feb.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Tuesday about ambassadorial appointments for longtime supporters of George Bush described political contributions by two of them incorrectly.
The appointees, Joseph Zappala, who has been selected as Ambassador to Spain, and Melvin F. Sembler, the choice as Ambassador to Australia, contributed $100,000 each to the Republican Party, not to the Bush campaign.


Oil Imports in January Topped Output in U.S.
LEAD: For the first time in a decade, the United States imported more oil in January than it produced, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

Mario M. Cuomo said today that leaders from New York State, the Federal Government and New York City - including Mayor Edward I. Koch and his rivals in this year's mayoral campaign -should get together ''in partnership, in family, in synergism'' to form a commission to resolve the city's problems.


Battle Erupts for Texas Deposits, Making Savings Plan More Costly
LEAD: A bidding war for savings deposits has broken out in Texas, just days after the Bush Administration announced its proposal to rescue the savings and loan industry.
That proposal was intended, in part, to shut down insolvent institutions that were forcing up deposit rates for the rest of the industry.

Los Angeles Delays Ban on Assault Rifle Pending Court Case
LEAD: The city agreed today to a one-week delay in its ban on the possession of assault rifles while a Federal judge decides if he has jurisdiction in a lawsuit filed by Colt Industries Inc. challenging the new law.


Escaped Inmate Is Captured
LEAD: One of two inmates from a Staten Island prison who rode a garbage truck to freedom Tuesday was peacefully recaptured in the Bronx yesterday, a Correction Department spokesman said.
John Santiago, 34 years old, was arrested at a girlfriend's home at 2170 Bathgate Avenue in the Tremont section at 3:30 P.M., the spokesman said.

LEAD: Lawyers for John A. Mulheren Jr. and the United States said yesterday that a magistrate had granted a 30-day extension that gives them more time to resolve the case and possibly avoid an indictment.

LEAD: Norway said this week that Anglo-Dutch Shell had made the first oil find in the Barents Sea but said further tests would be needed to see if the deposit was worth exploiting.

LEAD: Lenny Dykstra, sometimes benched and frequently angry over sharing center field with Mookie Wilson, won some comfort and a major raise yesterday when a labor arbitrator ruled in his favor and against the Mets and awarded him $575,000 in salary.

Salvadoran Union Bombed
LEAD: The offices of El Salvador's largest anti-Government union, the National Union of Salvadoran Workers, were bombed early today, wounding one person and causing serious damage.
The Maximilano Hernandez death squad took responsibility for the bombing.
It left behind a statement saying that a new unit, the People's Counterrevolutionary Army, carried out the attack.

LEAD: Local governments are increasingly demanding that real estate developers pay for everything from road improvements to day-care centers, a practice that is driving prices of new homes higher in some regions and intensifying the debate over whether such charges amount to an unfair tax on new residents.

'Legs Diamond' to Close
LEAD: ''Legs Diamond,'' a musical with book by Harvey Fierstein and Charles Suppon and music and lyrics by Peter Allen, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Mark Hellinger Theater.
The play, directed by Robert Allan Ackerman and starring Mr.
Allen, will have run for 64 regular performances and 72 previews.

THE BAKER FAMILY HOLDINGS
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said Tuesday that he would sell his personal stock holdings and those of his wife and a minor child to avoid any appearance of a conflict of interest.
Questions have been raised about his substantial holdings in the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York.
When he was Treasury Secretary, Chemical had large investments in loans to third-world countries that were being pressured by the Treasury to repay their loans, and as Secretary of State, he may have to consider issues involving third-world finances.


Presidential Snacks
LEAD: A debate is under way among close associates of George Bush over the favorite snack of the President.
Mr.
Bush has long shown a fondness for pork rinds, so much so that Congressional leaders recently brought him some as a good-will gift.
But some longtime Bush friends, such as Don Rhodes and Vic Gold, insist that his true love is popcorn.

LEAD: A group of American doctors and nurses left for Vietnam today on a mission known as Operation Smile.
Their objective is to perform plastic surgery on about 100 children whose deformities prevent them from smiling.

Mavericks Send Aguirre To Pistons for Dantley
LEAD: Mark Aguirre, a high-scoring but temperamentally unpredictable forward for the Dallas Mavericks for all eight of his National Basketball Association seasons, was traded yesterday to the Detroit Pistons for Adrian Dantley.
Included in the trade for Dantley, the N.B.A.'s 10th-leading career scorer, was the Pistons' first-round draft choice in 1991.

LEAD: A jury awarded $14.5 million to the former lover of Rock Hudson today, saying the actor's conduct in concealing his AIDS from his sex partner was ''outrageous.''

Oh, Say Can You Hear. . .?
LEAD: A giant American flag may fly over Long Beach, but only if it does so quietly.
The Long Beach City Council voted Tuesday night to allow Thomas Demski to fly the flag from his 125-foot flagpole, a local landmark, as long as it does not violate the city's antinoise ordinance.
Neighbors had complained that the flapping of the flag on windy nights kept them awake.

Close to Home
LEAD: ''BLACK coffee and a cinnamon doughnut,'' I said to the man behind the counter. ''No sugar, right?'' he replied.
When, a minute or so later, I left the store, a half-stifled smile was curling up the corners of my mouth.
Recognized!
Acknowledged!
A regular at Al's coffee shop at last!
All I could think of was the day a little girl I used to escort around town ushered me up to the newsstand where she bought her comic books and said grandly, ''They know me here.

Corrections
LEAD: An illustration and a caption in Science Times on Tuesday about threats to Antartica's wildlife mislabeled a penguin species and incorrectly described the diets of two species.
The illustration showed a Chinstrap penguin, not an Emperor; both the Chinstrap and the Adelie penguin, also pictured, eat mainly krill, not fish and squid.

Passages From Rushdie Book
LEAD: The passages in ''The Satanic Verses'' that Muslim critics have condemned as blasphemous refer to a figure named Mahound, whom they regard as a thinly and perversely disguised representation of the Prophet Mohammed.
Mahound appears in the novel only as a character in another character's dreams.
This character, Gibreel Farishta, suffers from the delusion that he is really the archangel Gabriel, and he later concedes that he is mentally ill.

Microsoft Stake In Unix Maker
LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation said today that it would make a minority investment in the Santa Cruz Operation Inc., a privately held company that produces Unix system software.


John H. Batten Dies; Manufacturer Was 77
LEAD: John H. Batten, former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of Twin Disc Inc., a manufacturer of power transmission equipment, died of cancer Tuesday at St.
Luke's Memorial Hospital in Racine, Wis.
He was 77 years old and lived in Racine.


Experts Disagree if Baker's Stocks Posed Conflict With Treasury Post
LEAD: The decision by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d this week to sell his holdings in a banking company has left experts divided on whether it was proper for him to own that stock as Treasury Secretary and whether the bank benefited from his policies.

11,000 Buyers Look Forward to School
LEAD: For young people on vacation, the annual blitz of back-to-school sales is a rude reminder that the endless summer always ends too soon.
But the hubbub of 1,000 merchants at a recent trade show reflected another reality - that the back-to-school market thrives year round.


Sony's Profits Up 44.4%
LEAD: The Sony Corporation said today that its earnings rose 44.4 percent in its third quarter on healthy sales gains.
The company's profits in the period ended Dec. 31 totaled 28.9 billion yen, or $229 million, up from 20 billion yen a year earlier.
Sales totaled 613.8 billion yen, or $4.87 billion, an increase of 36.8 percent from 448.7 billion yen.


Catching the Spirit
LEAD: Ronald H. Brown, the new chairman of the Democratic National Committee, accepted victory last week with praise for such Democratic Governors as Bill Clinton of Arkansas, Ray Mabus of Mississippi and Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont.

'Out of Africa' Chair Right Out of Africa
LEAD: WHEN the producers of ''Out of Africa'' were combing Kenya for period pieces that would give the movie the right look, they stumbled across some unpacked boxes in an antiques store not far from the home of Karen Blixen, who under her pen name, Isak Dinesen, wrote the book on which the movie was based.

Chrysler to Export Axles to China
LEAD: Acustar Inc., the wholly owned auto parts subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, said it had agreed to export up to 80,000 axles a year to the Beijing Jeep Corporation of China.
Acustar said in a statement that it would begin exporting the axles for rear-wheel-drive applications with a 1,000-axle shipment scheduled for March.


U.S. and Britain Call for Stricter Aviation Security
LEAD: The United States and Britain proposed a worldwide tightening of aviation security rules today at a special meeting of the United Nations aviation organization.


Green a Bit Wary, but Confident
LEAD: On the first day of his first year as the Yankee manager, Dallas Green met with reporters and a dozen or so of his players, sat in his office taking copious notes and later strolled the back field at Fort Lauderdale Stadium - his arms folded, a ball in his right hand, a Yankee cap pulled tightly over his brow - in near silence.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Science Times on Tuesday about steps to reduce research fraud referred to the Institute of Medicine incorrectly.
It is a branch of the National Academy of Sciences, not the National Institutes of Health.

Health Foods Introduced By Heart-Attack Victim
LEAD: Charles M. Harper, a strapping 6-foot-6 chief executive, suffered a heart attack three years ago and from that experience, he said, came a yearning for tasty food that was also low in cholesterol, fat and salt.


Youth Sought in Jersey Killing Is Seized in New Mexico
LEAD: A 19-year-old man wanted in the slaying of one high-school student here and the kidnapping of a second ended his three-day, 1,800-mile flight in the New Mexico desert Tuesday night when he ran a roadblock and a shower of police bullets before being forced off the road by New Mexico state troopers.


Judge Blocks Parole For Drunken Driver
LEAD: A man who was imprisoned for killing two people on Long Island in a drunken driving accident and who has served less than eight months was temporarily blocked from parole by a state judge yesterday.


Israeli Inflation Up 4.7%
LEAD: Israel's consumer price index rose 4.7 percent in January, the highest monthly inflation in three years, after an economic austerity plan was put into effect, the Central Bureau of Statistics said today.
A spokesman said the rise, compared with an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in December and 1.6 percent in January 1988, was caused by price increases in all consumer goods.


Gorbachev Aide Says U.S. Should Lift Trade Barriers
LEAD: A top Moscow economist predicted here today that if the United States abolished trade barriers with the Soviet Union, commerce between the countries would expand ''by a factor of 5 to 10 times'' in five years.


'Gorby Fever' and Mr. Baker
LEAD: ''Trust, but verify'' was Ronald Reagan's constant advice for dealing with the Soviet Union of his new friend Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
The Bush Administration should take it to heart.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d would find the Reagan formula the best remedy for ''Gorby fever'' - the ill-concealed admiration for the Soviet leader that he reportedly has found sweeping through the bodies politic of our allies.


Making A Duplex: No Place to Go But Down
LEAD: ILENE HOCHBERG, author of the magazine parodies Dogue, Catmopolitan and Vanity Fur, in which pets play the parts of people, takes at least one thing seriously: her apartment. ''I live in a little jewel box,'' she said.

In Storm Over Winnie Mandela, Body Is Identified as Soweto Boy's
LEAD: A storm over Winnie Mandela that has embarrassed the country's anti-apartheid movement took an ominous turn today.
The police identified a decomposing body as that of a missing 14-year-old whom Mrs.
Mandela's bodyguards are accused of having abducted.


LATIN AGREEMENT RAISES EYEBROWS AT WHITE HOUSE
LEAD: The Bush Administration was caught off guard by the agreement by five Central American countries to disarm the Nicaraguan guerrillas, American officials said today, even though Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d met with the Foreign Ministers of Costa Rica and Honduras just last week.


In Texas, Farewell to Old Post Office
LEAD: After 142 years, the post office here has finally outgrown T. C. Lindsey's general store.
The post office is among the nation's oldest in an original site and has been used in movies because of its old-fashioned look.


Review/Music; A 15th-Century Rarity
LEAD: Jacob Obrecht was born in Holland sometime within hailing distance of 1450, entered the priesthood, spent his life neglecting administrative duties and composing wonderful, imaginative music, and died of the plague in Ferrara in 1505.
It is hard to know just how much he wrote and when, since biographical information is sparse; he did not achieve the fame and influence of his near-contemporary Josquin Desprez.


MAN IN THE NEWS: Boris V. Gromov; Afghanistan: Last Man Out
LEAD: Soviet officials had repeatedly vowed that their men would not leave Afghanistan in disarray, like the last Americans clambering onto helicopters from the roof of their embassy as Saigon fell around them.


Freni Recital Canceled
LEAD: The soprano Mirella Freni has canceled, because of illness, the recital she was to give at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.
Information: 247-7800.


Preserve Your 'Piffiab'
LEAD: ''Ford's D.C.I. is pulling the seacock on Piffiab.''


Review/Music; Beethoven, Vehemently
LEAD: The New Hampshire ensemble known as the Apple Hill Chamber Players carries off the prize for most wholesome-sounding musical appellation, but its merits do not stop there.
The group's concerts are distinguished by not only high professionalism but also an unspoiled enthusiasm for music.
Such eagerness to search for the expressive heart of a score can lift a performance out of the bog of routine concert-giving, reminding one of the playing of the better class of amateurs - a word that in its uncorrupted sense merely meant a lover.


Nets Erase Big Deficit But They Still Lose
LEAD: The Nets deserved a better ending tonight.


Virus That May Cause Leukemia Is Spreading Among Drug Addicts
LEAD: A troubling virus that was thought to be very rare is now spreading widely among groups of intravenous drug users in this country, according to new surveys that have not yet been published.

LEAD:  John Dollar  By Marianne Wiggins  214 pages. Harper &amp; Row. $17.95.

LEAD: ''There is not a single Soviet soldier or officer left behind me.
Our nine-year stay ends with this.''  - Lieut.
Gen.
Boris V. Gromov, the commander of the Soviet forces in Afghanistan.  [ A1:6. ]


Malaysian Coal Deposits
LEAD: A West German team has found two coal deposits with about 93 million tons of coal worth an estimated $2.56 billion, it was reported Tuesday.
The two deposits were found in the Tebulan and Merit South areas of the Malaysian state of Sarawak, The New Straits Times reported, quoting S. P. Chen, director of Sarawak's Geological Survey Department.


Bridge
LEAD: Defenders face most of their problems early in the play, when there are few clues and many options.
The reverse is true in the end-game, and the defender can usually relax.
But that is not always true.
As the diagramed example shows, a player who is not alert can easily fall into a little trap.


Next Arts Festival Is Put Off Until 1991
LEAD: The Second New York International Festival of the Arts will be staged in June 1991 rather than in 1990 as originally planned, and will be the showcase for foreign arts companies who have never before performed in New York or who have infrequently appeared here.


United States v. North
LEAD: The prosecution of Oliver North ran into many frustrations before the agreement by the independent counsel and the Attorney General that lets the trial go forward.
But that should not be a reason for surprise.
The case is a hard test of three weighty and sometimes conflicting interests: national security, justice and accountability.

John P. Coakley, Executive, 70
LEAD: John P. Coakley, a retired president of the United Tanker Corporation, a shipping company, died Monday at Marcus Lawrence Hospital in Cottonwood, Ariz.
He was 70 years old and lived in Sedona, Ariz.


For Allergy Tests, Experts Suggest A More Conservative Approach
LEAD: Some doctors frequently misuse allergy tests, subjecting patients to unnecessary procedures and treatment, false diagnoses and needless expense, allergy experts say.


Human Rights Panel Falls Short of its Goals
LEAD: A year after Mayor Edward I. Koch pledged a sweeping reorganization of the New York City Human Rights Commission to better handle complaints of discrimination, the agency remains plagued by problems and has fallen far short of its own goals for finishing investigations.


Review/Dance; Rioja's Spanish Idiom
LEAD: Pilar Rioja is a superb concert dancer whose choreography is drawn from a variety of Spanish idioms.
Not for her the conventional format of the ebullient Spanish dance program.
Purity and seriousness are her trademarks.
To appreciate her is to understand her first and foremost as a creative artist.


Afghan Turmoil: Wars and Coups of 2 Centuries
LEAD:  1839-42 British Indian forces, fearing a Russian thrust into India, occupy Afghanistan.
Guerrilla wars break out and eventually prompt a British retreat.
Guerrillas turn the retreat into a massacre.  1878-80 Second British-Afghan war erupts, again because of British worries about Russian intentions.


Deficit Cited by Northrop
LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it lost $86.1 million in the fourth quarter after setting aside $150 million for possible losses on several classified military research and development projects.


FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
LEAD: Amid a heavy volume of new tax issues, New Jersey yesterday priced a $350 million competitive issue of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by the BT Securities Corporation.


Dollar Closes Down Slightly After Early Selling Pressure
LEAD: The dollar closed with minor losses against most key foreign currencies yesterday, after moving erratically all day.


An Industry Revamped By Disaster
LEAD: Chemical industry leaders in the United States said yesterday that the Bhopal disaster had led to profound changes in the way they handle their safety procedures.


Sallie Mae Offers Fixed-Rate Notes
LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, also known as Sallie Mae, is offering $200 million of fixed-rate notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.


Maloney Studies Racial Strife
LEAD: The Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn has begun an investigation into accusations that Hasidic Jews have intimidated and in some cases have beaten black residents of the Williamsburg section, the United States Attorney said yesterday.


Clemens and Red Sox Agree On 3-Year, $7.5 Million Deal
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox and Roger Clemens, their two-time Cy Young Award winner, escalated baseball's salary scale another major notch yesterday, agreeing to a three-year, $7.5 million contract.
Then they stepped back and waited to see if the Los Angeles Dodgers and Orel Hershiser would escalate it even further before their scheduled salary arbitration hearing today.

40 Die, 90 Are Hurt as Christians Battle in Lebanon
LEAD: Lebanese Army troops and Christian militiamen fought a fierce battle today for control of Christian areas of the country, and the police said 40 people were killed and 90 wounded.


Behrens Cancels Date With Orchestre de Paris
LEAD: Hildegard Behrens has canceled her appearance in the performance tomorrow night of Beethoven's Missa Solemnis with the Orchestre de Paris at Avery Fisher Hall, because of a problem that prevented her from taking part in the rehearsals in Paris.
Alison Hargan, a British soprano, will take her place.


Brazil Drops Charges Against Two Indians
LEAD: Brazil's court of appeals has dropped charges against two Indians who lobbied abroad against construction of dams on their land and an American scientist who served as their interpreter, a court official said today.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a Hindu festival in India, and its map caption, gave an incorrect date in some copies for the ritual bath in which 15 million pilgrims joined.
The date, described as the most auspicious for such a bath, was Feb. 6.


More Fertilizer Use Seen
LEAD: Fertilizer use by American farmers is expected to rise by 9 percent this year because of larger crop plantings and higher crop prices, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.
The greater demand will also drive up fertilizer prices by about 7 percent, the department's Economic Research Service said in a report.

LEAD: It violates minimal comity among nations for the leader of one state to clamor for the murder of citizens of another.
Ayatollah Khomeini goes further.

LEAD: Bradford W. Stone, a retired automotive executive, died of heart failure Tuesday at Alexandria (Va.) Hospital.

LEAD: The decline of the biggest land mammal of us all is the subject of tonight's ''National Geographic Special.'' With humans encroaching on its native grounds in Asia and Africa, with poachers after its tusks, the elephant is under siege.
The qualities and predicament of the species are on display at 9 P.M.

LEAD: Morgan Stanley &amp; Company, the Wall Street firm that spurred four of its competitors to suspend program trading for their own accounts last year, said yesterday that it was resuming the controversial practice.


Soybeans Advance a Bit As Cattle and Pork Retreat
LEAD: Soybean futures advanced modestly yesterday after rising strongly on Tuesday, while cattle and pork futures were off slightly.

IRANIANS PROTEST OVER BANNED BOOK
LEAD: Thousands of people reportedly threw stones and waved pictures of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini outside the British Embassy in Teheran today in protest against a book that has been deemed offensive to Islam.


Bolivian Planning to Sell 8 Paintings at Auction
LEAD: Eight paintings by Gauguin, Cezanne, Renoir, Monet, Pissarro, Fantin-Latour and Boudin - most of them acquired in the 1980's by Jaime Ortiz-Patino of Geneva, an heir to a Bolivian tin fortune - are to be auctioned on May 9 in New York.
David J. Nash, who heads Sotheby's fine art sales, said yesterday that the paintings are expected to sell for more than $50 million.


News Corp. Reports Net Is Up Sharply
LEAD: The News Corporation yesterday reported a sharp increase in earnings for its second fiscal quarter and for the first half of its financial year.
The company, which is controlled by Rupert Murdoch, also reported the first profit for its Fox Television network.

Why Stroke the Rich?
LEAD: The 1986 Federal tax reform became fully effective just six weeks ago, and already President Bush wants to start tearing it apart.
Violating both the promise and the fairness of that landmark law, he seeks to revive favorable tax treatment for capital gains.
That might spur investment, a little.
More certainly it would benefit the rich, a lot.

Israelis Study Devices In Blasts in West Bank
LEAD: The Israeli Army, Air Force and national police began an investigation today to identify mysterious exploding devices that have killed and wounded several West Bank Palestinian children in the last two weeks, the army said.


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. Our living room ceiling, which was painted about nine years ago, is showing dark streaks where each of the overhead beams in the attic crosses.
These streaks don't wash off easily.
We have a humidifier on the furnace and the attic above this ceiling is unheated.
We plan to repaint, but want to avoid this happening again.


Lasting Costs for Child Found From a Mother's Early Drinks
LEAD: Even moderate drinking by women in the first month or two of pregnancy, often before they realize they are pregnant, can impair the child's intellectual ability upon reaching school age, a new study indicates.

Fisher-Price Report
LEAD: Quaker Oats Company stock fell after the president of its Fisher-Price unit said the division's contribution to this year's earnings would be flat.
The share price dropped 75 cents today, to $51, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Fisher-Price's president, R. Bruce Sampsell, said at the New York Toy Fair that the unit's operating results for the year ending in June would be about even with the $106 million earned in the 1988 fiscal year.

LEAD: Regulators of the savings and loan industry allowed a Republican organization in Florida to use office space without paying rent, Representative James J. Florio of New Jersey said today.

U.S. Notes and Bonds Inch Higher
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds inched higher in light trading yesterday on the expectation that West Germany might be about to raise interest rates and that the Federal Reserve Board would follow suit.


Accusations Filed
LEAD: The California Horse Racing Board will file accusations against two trainers, Laz Barrera and D. Wayne Lukas, for running horses that tested positive for cocaine, the board said yesterday.
Leonard Foote, executive secretary of the board, said he expected to find even more horses with cocaine in their urine samples as the testing continues.


With Soviet Forces Out, the Afghans Look Ahead
LEAD: ''Some people may think it was the Geneva agreement that paved the way - or external pressures,'' an Afghan guerrilla leader, Abdul Rasul Sayyaf, said today, after hearing that Soviet troops were finally out of Afghanistan.


Cease-Fire Fails in Beirut's Christian Sector
LEAD: Sporadic clashes between Lebanese Army troops and the Lebanese Forces Christian militia continued all day today, despite a cease-fire that was reached late Wednesday in Lebanon's worst fighting among Christians in almost 14 years of civil war.


Recent Works
LEAD: Composers Concordance is to present a concert of recent works by Patrick Hardish, Wendy Chambers, Awilda Villarini, Joseph Pehrson, Beth Anderson, Louis Karchin and James T. Anderson at 8 tonight at CAMI Hall, 165 West 57th Street.
The performers are to include Rolf Schulte, a violinist; Alicia O;Malley, a guitarist; Douglas Schultz, a pianist, and Annabel Gordon, a cellist.


E.P.A. Restricts Fungicide's Use On 42 Products
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency today barred the application of the widely used fungicide captan on a broad range of fruits and vegetables, 42 in all, saying it posed a significant risk of cancer.

Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Option to close.

6th Officer Indicted in Tompkins Sq. Melee
LEAD: A New York City police sergeant was indicted yesterday for assault, making him the sixth officer to be charged with misconduct and assault arising from the disturbance in Tompkins Square Park in August, the Manhattan District Attorney said.


The Great Outdoors, Within City Limits
LEAD: UNTIL spring, most New Yorkers would probably prefer to forget that there even is an outdoors, a place where chill winds nip mercilessly at bundled-up strollers.
But for hardy urban explorers, New York is more than just an agglomeration of warm buildings.
About one-seventh of the city's 303.7 square miles is parkland, and in it one can hike and ice-skate, savor the stark beauty of wintertime nature or just listen to the quiet.

LEAD: ''The Art Show,'' at the Seventh Regiment Armory, is a consistently engaging and discreetly provocative affair.
It serves a very good cause -that of the Henry Street Settlement -and, with the lightest possible touch, it makes history.

Tours of Brooklyn
LEAD: Singer's Brooklyn is to give minibus tours of of Brooklyn tomorrow and on subsequent Saturdays through the end of March.
Each tour is to emphasize a different aspect of the borough.
On Sundays the group gives tours of Manhattan.
Each tour is from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. and leaves from a midtown Manhattan location.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Birthday Present: John McEnroe, seeded third, celebrated his 30th birthday yesterday with a 6-2, 6-3 victory over Michiel Schapers of the Netherlands and reached the quarterfinals of the $492,500 Stella Artois indoor championships in Milan, Italy.
McEnroe received applause from the crowd and a cake with 30 candles from the organizers.

W. H. Baumer, 79, Industrialist; Helped Plan Normandy Invasion
LEAD: William H. Baumer, an industrial executive and a retired United States Army officer who helped plan the invasion of Normandy in World War II, died of heart failure Tuesday while aboard an airplane flying to Los Angeles from Washington.
He was 79 years old and lived in La Jolla, Calif.

LEAD: The Dutch Foreign Minister called on Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today to undertake a Middle East peace mission as early as possible, a senior American official said.

Baker responded that the conditions in the area were not yet ripe for an initiative.

British Aerospace
LEAD: British Aerospace P.L.C. said its Dynamics Ltd. subsidiary will cut 2,500 jobs by the end of 1990 and reduce its significant sites to four from six.
The unit's chairman, Richard Evans, said the move came after a review of the company's operations.
The unit has about 16,000 employees and is primarily involved in British Aerospace's missile programs, including the Rapier system.

LEAD: Elliot Kahn, a building contractor who was a past president of the Subcontractors Trade Association of New York, died of stomach cancer Wednesday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y.
He was 68 years old.
Mr.
Kahn was founder and president of the Arrow Louver and Damper Corporation, a heating, ventilation and air-conditioning contracting concern.

LEAD: The Ford Motor Company reported today that its fourth-quarter profit soared 24.5 percent, to $1.16 billion, giving the No. 2 auto maker a third consecutive year of record profits.


Emerson String Quartet
LEAD: The Emerson String Quartet -Philip Setzer and Eugene Drucker, violinists; Lawrence Dutton, violist, and David Finckel, cellist - is to play Prokofiev's Quartet No. 1, Haydn's Quartet in E flat major (Op. 33, No. 2) and Brahms's Quartet No. 2 at 3 P.M.
Sunday at Alice Tully Hall.
Tickets are $17.50.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 454 money market mutual funds increased by $1.46 billion, to $289.01 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
Those of the 137 institutional funds decreased by $851.20 million, to $73.39 billion.
The assets of the 224 general-purpose funds were up by $1.42 billion, to $92.30 billion.


Coleman Holders Sue to Block Offer
LEAD: A group of shareholders of the Coleman Company has filed a lawsuit seeking to block the Coleman family from acquiring the public corporation.
In the action, filed on Wednesday in Sedgwick County District Court in Wichita, the stockholders said the $64-a-share offer was inadequate.
Coleman closed today at $70.625, down 37.5 cents, on the New York Stock


No Rate Rise In Germany
LEAD: West Germany's central bank, the Bundesbank, left its leading interest rates unchanged today despite strong market expectation of an increase.

Officers Waiting Longer in Courthouses, Union Says
LEAD: Police officers are spending longer hours waiting in courthouses because of a sharp rise in drug-related arrests in New York City and limited space in prosecutors' offices, officials said yesterday.
The problems have slowed the early processing of all kinds of criminal cases.

LEAD: The Treasury, revising a Customs Service ruling that touched off an outcry from foreign automobile makers early this year, ruled today that most imported vans and sport-utility vehicles would continue to be classified as cars, not trucks, thus avoiding an almost tenfold increase in their tariffs.

Review/Film; Exploring A World In a Mind
LEAD: Films about the unconscious ought to make more sense than films about more sensible things.
They need an internal logic to take the place of the external logic that's missing.

LEAD: The British Government protested today to Iran in the ''strongest terms'' over Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death threat against the novelist Salman Rushdie and announced that recent moves toward establishing closer relations with Iran would be shelved.


Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, 76, of Indonesia
LEAD: Sjafruddin Prawiranegara, who was Indonesia's Prime Minister in 1948-49 and later rebelled against Sukarno, the nation's first President, has died.
He was 76 years old.


Genentech Drive To Lift TPA Sales
LEAD: To spur sales of its heart attack drug, tissue plasminogen activator, Genentech Inc. has enlisted the help of the American sales force of Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc. of Ridgefield, Conn.
The 400-member staff will spend about a fifth of its time promoting TPA to physicians who operate in offices and are not cardiologists.

LEAD: The Nynex Corporation, one of the most profitable of the companies that became independent after the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, said yesterday that William C. Ferguson had been named to its top posts.

Review/Art; Abstraction That Opens a Window on the Psyche
LEAD: In his third exhibition of paintings in Manhattan, Carroll Dunham continues to develop his singular brand of abstraction, one that is as psychologically revealing as it is formally self-conscious.
Each work features one shape rendered in one bright color on a rectangular surface composed of one or more 40-by-60-inch sheets of paper mounted on panels.

Pop/Jazz; A Sampling of Music That Sings the News As Well as the Blues
LEAD: BEFORE television, before newspapers, even before alphabets, news was spread and history recorded by song.
Melodies and rhythms turned raw data into art; rhymes, verse structures and repetitions (like Homer's ''wine-dark sea'' and ''rosy-fingered dawn'') were aids to memory.
While modern telecommunications and general literacy have challenged music's monopoly on carrying information, they haven't eliminated that role.

Australia Trade Deficit
LEAD: Australia's current account deficit, the broadest measure of trade, jumped 65 percent, to $1.54 billion (Australian), or $1.31 billion (United States), in January from the previous month, the Government said today.
It was the worst January deficit on record and was sharply higher than the shortfall of $543 million (Australian) a year earlier.


Chase Adds 'Poison Pill'
LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company, said Wednesday that it had adopted a shareholder rights plan, or ''poison pill,'' to protect it from unwanted takeovers.
The bank's plan allows stockholders to buy Chase common stock for half price when an unwanted holder acquires 20 percent or more of Chase common shares or starts a tender or exchange offer resulting in ownership of 25 percent or more of the shares.

Book Counterfeiter Sentenced
LEAD: A dealer in rare Hebrew books who sold counterfeit copies of the first printed Passover Haggadah was sentenced yesterday to a year and a day in prison and ordered to pay $72,000 in restitution.
The defendant, Raphael Podde, 46 years old, of Woodmere, L.I., was also ordered by Judge Charles P. Sifton of Federal District Court in Brooklyn to pay the Government $6,350 for the cost of prosecution.

LEAD: Bowing to protest from the White House and from House members of both parties, Speaker Jim Wright today postponed a vote he planned for next week on legislation that would require foreigners to disclose most major investments in the United States.

LEAD: Stephen Aaron, a guitarist, is to give the New York premieres of works by David Bernstein and Walter Burle Marx at 8 P.M. tomorrow in a recital at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street.
The program is also to include works by J.S.
Bach, Nikita Koshkin, Jose Broca, Agustin Barrios and Giulio Regondi.

LEAD: Harvard University is expected to name Robert C. Clark, a profesor on its law faculty, as the new law school dean, according to The Harvard Crimson, the student newspaper, and several students at the law school.
The announcement by Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok, could come as early as Friday.

Palmer on TV Team
LEAD: Jim Palmer, who won 268 games for the Baltimore Orioles from 1965 to 1984, has signed to broadcast play-by-play descriptions on the club's telecasts over a local Baltimore station this summer.
Palmer will be teamed with an ex-teammate, Brooks Robinson, the former third baseman, who will serve as an analyst.


Ex-Official Defends Role on Eastern
LEAD: Former Transportation Secretary Jim Burnley said Wednesday that an ethics official allowed him to rule in a case involving Eastern Airlines even though he was negotiating at the time for jobs with law firms linked to the company.


British Jobless Rate Dips
LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 7 percent of the work force in January from 7.2 percent in December, bringing the number of jobless to its lowest level in eight years, the Government said today.

Review/Film; 60's Ideals Gone Awry, In Taut 'True Believer'
LEAD: A long, graying ponytail and a fondness for marijuana are all that remain of Eddie Dodd's 1960's idealism - these, and a reflexive tendency to stick up for the underdog, no matter how disreputable the underdog might be.
So Eddie, who once had the reputation of a brilliant and courageous lawyer and is still thought of as a very clever one, makes it his business to defend the constitutional rights of drug dealers - drug dealers who are apt to drive away from the courthouse in their sports cars, smiling.

Cecilia Lester Sarasohn, Guidance Director, 79
LEAD: Cecilia Lester Sarasohn, a former deputy director of guidance for the New York City Board of Education who directed college preparatory programs, died of complications from leukemia on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 79 years old.


The Dollar Rises in Europe But Settles Lower in U.S.
LEAD: After a strong showing in Europe early yesterday, the dollar turned weaker in later trading in New York.
The early strength in the dollar developed after the West German central bank decided not to increase interest rates.
The decision also strengthened the British pound.


Kerr to Be Deputy Director Of Intelligence Organization
LEAD: Robert Kerr, a career intelligence officer, has been named deputy director of Central Intelligence, the White House said Wednesday.

The reading is today at 6 P.M. at the center, 553 West 51st Street.

Oppenheimer Files On Ausimont Bid
LEAD: The New York brokerage Oppenheimer &amp; Company said it could block completion of a $282 million takeover of Ausimont N.V. by the Italian chemical concern Montedison S.p.A.
Montedison already controls 73 percent of Ausimont and has begun an offer to purchase the remaining shares at $35 each.
But analysts have said that the price is too low and a special committee of Ausimont's board has determined likewise.

Bilzerian Rebuffed In Semi-Tech Bid
LEAD: Semi-Tech Microelectronics (Far East) Ltd., the Hong Kong-based company that has agreed to acquire SSMC Inc., said it had rejected an offer from Paul A. Bilzerian to acquire certain SSMC assets for his support of the $163 million agreement.
SSMC is the sewing machine unit spun off by the Singer Company in 1986.


2 Groups Interested In G. C. Murphy
LEAD: Four years after it acquired the G. C. Murphy Company for $200 million, Ames Department Stores Inc. is considering offers to sell the discount store chain.
Ames's spokeswoman, Catherine Leonard, said the Connecticut-based retailer was entertaining offers from a Murphy management group and the McCrory Corporation.

LEAD: The United States Air Force canceled all its air shows in West Germany for 1989, six months after the Ramstein Air Base crash that killed 70 people and injured hundreds, a military spokesman said today.

2 Killed in Crash After Chase
LEAD: A 30-mile police pursuit of a stolen car ended when the vehicle hit a parked van, flipped over and burst into flames, killing two teen-agers and seriously injuring three others, the authorities said yesterday.
The North Haven police spotted the stolen vehicle shortly before 11 P.M.
Thursday, and two cruisers chased the car from North Haven through New Haven and into Naugatuck before the crash on Route 63, Naugatuck Police Chief William Long said.

About New York; Creating Beauty Out of Suffering As Life Fades
LEAD: A hospice is a place where people with incurable diseases go to slide out of earthly existence with as much comfort and dignity as possible.
It is a place where a pretty hairdo or a good shave, small talk and a helping hand take on vital importance.
The lesson one learns from such a place is at once life's most basic and elusive: You live until you die.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Money Market Mutuals
LEAD:  Uncertainty in the stock market has caused some investors to increase their cash holdings or to invest in a cash equivalent like a money market mutual fund.
Last year, investors earned maximum market yields on funds that were easily accessible without penalties for early withdrawals.
Among the funds in the general-purpose category that yielded the most last year were the Alger Money Market Portfolio with an average yield of 7.81 percent and a bank-sponsored fund, NCC Funds Money Market Portfolio, with an average yield of 7.84 percent.

LEAD: At least a dozen employees of the United States Embassy in Lebanon were evacuated today and taken by helicopter to Cyprus so they would not be endangered by intense new fighting in Beirut, Administration officials said.


Chrysler May Build Mini-Van Overseas
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation is thinking about building its popular mini-van overseas but is not sure whether it wants to do so alone or with a partner, the auto maker's head of international operations said.
Michael Hammes, Chrysler vice president, also said in an interview that the company expects its revenues from sales of cars and trucks outside the United States to double to $2 billion in 1989, its first full year of selling autos abroad.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A brief article yesterday about the visit of Prince Charles to the United States misidentified a member of a group that was to meet with him in Washington.
The member was Arthur Ochs Sulzberger Jr., deputy publisher of The New York Times, not Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, the publisher.
A report about the luncheon meeting appears today on page 1.


Resuscitating Potted Bulbs
LEAD: Flowers of the hardy bulbs are beautiful at this time of year.
Tulips, crocuses, hyacinths, daffodils and Dutch irises that have been forced into bloom provide elegant previews of spring.
Display these pots in a cool bright place and water lightly so the soil is moist.
Enjoy the flowers while they last.

LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation said a United States appeals court had denied the Eastman Kodak Company's motion to have the original trial judge's orders vacated in its patent infringement case.
A trial on damages has been set for April 17.
Kodak had sought to have all orders of Federal Judge Rya Zobel vacated because Judge Zobel inherited 2,250 Kodak shares when her mother-in-law died last year.


Market Holiday
LEAD: Stock, bond and futures markets will be closed Monday in observance of Presidents' Day.


Beef Compromise Seen In U.S.-Europe Dispute
LEAD: A trade compromise being negotiated here this weekend is expected to call for the United States to ship some beef certified as hormone-free to the European Community and for the Atlantic partners to submit their dispute over the use of hormones to a panel of experts, American and European officials said.

'Fantastic Food'
LEAD: The Fantastic Food Festival begins today at the New York Hall of Science, 47-01 111th Street in Corona, Queens.
Exploring the science of flavors, the festival includes scientific demonstrations of food tastes, food preparation techniques and taste testings.
Today is Bread Day, and bread-making skills will be shown throughout the day.

BRIDGE
LEAD: Advice on the subject of opening leads against small slams in a suit can be confusing: Lead an ace or don't lead an ace.
Don't lead a singleton unless your partner might have an ace.
Make an attacking lead.
Make a passive lead.
Don't lead a singleton trump, except when it's right.

Soviet Teacher in Fatal Plunge
LEAD: A Soviet ballet instructor smashed his head through a glass window and jumped to his death from an apartment building a day after his arrival in the United States, the police here said today.
Boris Sinitsyn, 55 years old, apparently committed suicide Thursday morning by jumping from the 35th story of the Galaxy Towers complex, where he and his wife, Mina, 69, also a ballet instructor, had been visiting relatives, the police said.

Louisiana Bank Fails
LEAD: The Louisiana Bank and Trust Company of Shreveport, La., was closed and its deposits transferred to the Hibernia National Bank of New Orleans, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said on Thursday.
The failed bank had $272 million in assets, and the F.D.I.C. said it had advanced $99.6 million to facilitate the transaction.

Takeovers By F.D.I.C.
LEAD: Following is a list, by state, of the 25 savings and loan institutions in 14 states put under the control today of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, along with their total assets as of last Sept. 30:  ALABAMA: Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association, Birmingham, $414 million.


Mattel-Corolle Tie
LEAD: Mattel Inc. said it had agreed in principle to buy 51 percent of Corolle S.A. of France, a privately held doll manufacturer.
Corolle, which makes collector-quality dolls in Langeais, France, will continue to operate as an autonomous unit under its chairman, Jacques Refabert.
The unit will become part of the Mattel's new Timeless Creations division.


Furor Over 'Satanic Verses' Rises As 2 More Book Chains Halt Sales
LEAD: The furor surrounding Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses'' spread yesterday as the B. Dalton and Barnes &amp; Noble chains, which have more than 1,250 stores in the United States, said they would no longer sell the book.


GAF Reschedules Annual Meeting
LEAD: The GAF Corporation rescheduled its annual meeting to March 2 to give shareholders time to review proxy materials, which include revised financing for a proposed management-led buyout of the company.
The meeting was originally set for next Wednesday.


Terrell Loses Ruling
LEAD: An arbitrator ruled in favor of the San Diego Padres yesterday in the arbitration case involving Walt Terrell.
Terrell, a pitcher who was acquired during the off season from the Detroit Tigers, will earn $775,000 this year rather than the $941,000 he requested.
He made $665,000 in 1988.
With three decisions to go, the players and teams are tied, 5-5, in this winter's arbitration results.(

LEAD: Dr.
Joseph Jordan Eller, a dermatologist and skin-cancer specialist, died Monday at the West Palm Beach (Fla.) Hospice.
He was 92 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the resignation of Frank Hodsoll as chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts misidentified Dr.
Mary Schmidt Campbell, who was among those mentioned as candidates to replace him.
She is New York City's Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, not consumer affairs.

Review/Music; From Paris, Barenboim And Complete 'Faust'
LEAD: Everything appeared to be in place at Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening for a memorable performance of ''La Damnation de Faust.'' The Orchestre de Paris and its music director of 14 years, Daniel Barenboim, could be expected to have the idiom of Berlioz's ''dramatic legend'' in their bones.
This was, furthermore, not the usual collection of orchestral excerpts, but the complete score, with the orchestra's own 163-member chorus imported for the occasion.

Tempest in a Wealthy Alpine Teapot
LEAD: Liechtenstein has been plunged into what it considers a political crisis.
But since the Alpine principality has the highest per capita income in Europe, no unemployment and a coalition Government that has lasted for five decades, the turmoil will probably not shake its sturdy foundations.


Midwest Voters Give Bush Support But Disagree Over Nation's Priorities
LEAD: Some Washington insiders may have turned against President Bush since his budget speech to Congress, accusing him of vagueness and a lack of vision, but here in the Midwest most people still seem prepared to give him the benefit of the doubt.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An obituary last Saturday about Joseph J. Enright, a Christian Brother who was a retired teacher, misidentified his order.
He was a member of the Congregation of Christian Brothers, not the Brothers of the Christian Schools.


Hugh Wolff Contract
LEAD: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has extended the contract of its music director, Hugh Wolff, for three years.
Mr.
Wolff, who is 35 years old, was appointed music director of the orchestra in September 1985.


Transactions
LEAD:  Baseball


Reviews/Music; Onward With Schubert: 27 Works
LEAD: Last season the 92d Street Y set itself the Promethean task of presenting all of Franz Schubert's music, an output of nearly 1,000 works composed between 1810 and 1828.
Its Schubertiade project would explore this music chronologically and would last a decade, ending in 1997, on the bicentennial of the composer's birth.


Don't Imagine Brazil Wants to Burn Its Future
LEAD: To the Editor:


How the Storming of the Bastille Liberated the Printing Press, Too
LEAD: Among the most common images of the French Revolution are those of frenzied bloodshed, the Terror, the Committee of Public Safety and a confusing alternation in power among cliques and factions.
But underlying the event was something less conspicuous and, in the end, more important.
It was the word - sudden free speech - or what the organizers of an exhibition opening today at the New York Public Library are calling ''Revolution in Print.

Fewer Cattle on Feedlots
LEAD: Cattle being fed for the slaughter market in the seven leading beef-producing states totaled 7.7 million head as of Feb. 1, down 2 percent from a year ago but up 5 percent from inventories of two years ago, the Agriculture Department said Thursday.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  Graf Gains Semifinal: Steffi Graf, continuing her methodical devastation of the field in the Virginia Slims of Washington tournament in Fairfax, Va., blasted seven aces yesterday in a 6-0, 6-1 victory over Helen Kelesi that put her in the semifinals.
Graf will face Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, who won the final nine games in a 6-2, 6-0 victory over Leila Meskhi, also of the Soviet Union.

Reviews/Dance; Irving Penn Photos Brought to Life
LEAD: In ''12 Most Famous Fashion Models of 1952,'' Matthew Nash has his dancers portray the figures in two well-known photographs by Irving Penn.
Both photos are on display in the piece, which had its premiere Thursday night at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater (219 West 19th Street).


U.S. Trade Deficit Shrinks to $11.9 Billion
LEAD: The United States trade deficit narrowed modestly to $11.9 billion in December, capping the year with the first annual decline since 1980, the Commerce Department reported today.


Review/Dance; Students Have Their Night on Stage With the Feld Ballet
LEAD: The children of the New Ballet School performed Wednesday night at the Joyce Theater in one of the most charming and eloquent dance events of the year.
The choreography, by teachers at the school, offered the children an uncondescending chance to shine at a variety of simple and difficult steps and to gobble up the stage space with buoyant well-trained dancing.


6 Die in Detroit Hotel Fire
LEAD: Six people were killed in a fire that gutted a residential hotel in Detroit's Cass Corridor district early this morning.
The fire, which destroyed the four-story Billinghurst Hotel, also injured 52 residents, three of them critically, as well as four policemen who were involved in rescue efforts.

Officer Arrested in Sex Abuse
LEAD: A Transit Authority police officer was arrested yesterday on charges of sexually abusing a teen-age girl, the police said.
The suspect, Officer John Pirrello, 25 years old, of 70-17 Penelope Avenue in Middle Village, Queens, was charged with sexual abuse and endangering the welfare of a child in connection with incidents from March 1986 to July 1988.


Harris Planning Employee Cuts
LEAD: The Harris Corporation said its semiconductor sector was reducing its worldwide work force by about 270 employees as part of a restructuring after the acquisition of GE Solid State in November.
Harris said these cuts follow a voluntary layoff program completed last month in which more than 500 employees participated, including 280 in the United States.


Herbert Sadkin, 72, Former L.I. Developer
LEAD: Herbert Sadkin, a former Long Island builder and developer, died of cancer Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla.
He was 72 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale.

Tuesday at Carnegie Hall.

Withdrawal Rise Tied to Bush Plan
LEAD: The much-publicized step by President Bush to place insolvent savings institutions under the direct authority of bank regulators has led to an increase in deposit withdrawals in the Southwest since he announced the plan on Feb. 6, industry experts and regulators say.


Review/Film; Skateboards, Vietnamese And Intrigue
LEAD: Hollywood has been slow to recognize skateboarding as a great movie subject, and so ''Gleaming the Cube,'' the skateboard drama that opened yesterday at the Criterion Center and other theaters, is about other things as well.
It centers on the death of a young Vietnamese boy, Vinh Kelly (Art Chudabala), which occurs in a motel room with a view of an elevated railroad train.


Boyd Accepts Contract
LEAD: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd of the Boston Red Sox avoided salary arbitration yesterday by agreeing to a one-year contract for $550,000, the same salary he has received the last two seasons.
He can earn $200,000 more in performance bonuses Boyd, 29, had asked for $700,000 in arbitration, with the club countering with a $525,000 proposal.

LEAD: Suspected mistakes by pilots and controllers and lack of clarity in radio exchanges have become the focus of the inquiry into the crash of an American-operated jet airliner in the Azores last week, safety experts close to the investigation say.

Lilco Gaining Through Compromise
LEAD: A week ago the Long Island Lighting Company won a major victory when a Federal judge dismissed a lawsuit charging it with lying to obtain rate increases.
Damages from the suit could have been bankrupting.
A few days later the utility agreed to forgo $400 million in future rate increases to block any possibility that the judge's decision would be appealed.

Refugees, or Gate-Crashers?
LEAD: Who is a refugee?
That's the tormenting question raised on the Mexican border as immigration officials struggle to stem the flow of undocumented Central American aliens.
Many may be legitimate refugees, victims of political persecution.
But many are not, and the officials seek to deter false claims by denying all the right to work and travel while their cases are pending.

Remembering The Sixties
LEAD: To the Editor:


Where the Mushroom Is King
LEAD: MUSHROOMS have always been the stuff of fairy tales but in Kennett Square, Pa., the noble fungus is a way of life.
The town is the heart of Chester County, which calls itself the world's mushroom capital.
According to the Federal Department of Agriculture, two-thirds of the country's annual crop of nearly 400 million pounds is produced in the county by 160 growers, the largest concentration anywhere.

Not All the Boys of Summer Were Out on the Playing Field
LEAD: To the Editor:


Tea in London
LEAD: To the Editor: The article said that at the Empire Tearoom, High Tea is available and then described it as consisting of sandwiches, scones and jam, cake, etc.
This is Afternoon Tea.
High Tea is a larger meal eaten later in the afternoon or evening, is often a cooked meal and nowadays is more likely to be the family supper.


U.S. Panel Warns of Transport Ship Shortage
LEAD: A Presidential commission has warned that the country is dangerously short of the transport ships it would need in a major war and has proposed a 10-year, $13 billion construction program to start filling the gap.


An Open Letter to My Two Mothers
LEAD: I HAVE always known that I was adopted.
It is a constant in my life, like being left-handed, an accident of fate over which I had no control at all.
I don't know what it feels like to have Aunt Jessie's smile, Uncle Jack's mean temper or Grandma's legs: my smile, temper and legs are mine alone and although I am aware that somewhere out there the matching set exists I am not constantly reminded of them.

LEAD: About a month ago, Andy MacPhail wanted to talk to Craig Fenech about Frank Viola. ''There are a couple of shoes to drop,'' Fenech, Viola's agent, told the Minnesota general manager. ''I think I'll wait.''


Delegations To Congress Select Deans
LEAD: There is fresh leadership in Washington - and not just the names that immediately spring to mind.
The New York and New Jersey delegations in the House of Representatives have elected new deans.


Of Blasphemy, Belief and Fury
LEAD: THE gap in understanding between a resurgent, faith-filled Islam and a secular, pluralist West became a yawning chasm last week when accusations that a novel called ''The Satanic Verses'' was blasphemous led to riots and deaths in Pakistan and India, huge demonstrations in Iran and a death sentence pronounced on its author, Salman


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations.
The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests.
There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air.
Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations.
The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests.
There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air.
Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?


Rights Group Says Hungarians Suffer in Rumania
LEAD: A human rights monitoring group says Rumania's two million Hungarian-speaking citizens are the victims of a Government campaign to destroy their separate cultural identity.


Fighting-Trim Tyson Hunkers Down to Business
LEAD: On Jan. 10, six and a half weeks before he was to fight Frank Bruno, Mike Tyson skipped his regular workout at Johnny Tocco's Ringside Gym in Las Vegas, Nev.


Inside the 'Black Box'
LEAD: These are some of the hundreds of items in the ''black box,'' a group of domestic programs on which President Bush proposes to spend no more in all of fiscal 1990 than in fiscal 1989, $136 billion.
