NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Palm Springs, Calif.; A $100 Million Resort Hotel
LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is proceeding on a $100 million resort hotel that is part of the evolution here from a community with dozens of small poolside bungalow hotels to one that serves convention-goers as well as tourists.


Israeli Troops Prove Newcomers to Riot Control
LEAD: Many Israeli Army officers feel that the Palestinian uprising in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip is subsiding, and they say that their soldiers can cope with any major new outbreak of violence.


Shell Fanciers Back the Eastern Oyster
LEAD: A BILL designating ostrea virginicus, better known as the Eastern oyster, the state shell was described as exciting and a great idea at a hearing last week.


Nuclear Evacuation: Much Misinformation
LEAD: It is positively amazing to consider the misinformation spread regarding what might happen if there was an accident at the Shoreham nuclear plant.
The latest is the article which appeared on the Opinion page Jan. 29 under the title ''Shoreham Evacuation: Like the Blizzard of '86?''


Model for Rockwell Retires
LEAD: A small-town doctor who was the model for a well-known illustration by Norman Rockwell retired today on his 83d birthday.

Edelson raises the possibility that Long Islanders will behave in an irrational manner if there is a nuclear accident at the Shoreham nuclear power plant.

Deaths Force Rethinking of Sea Lion Plan
LEAD: A program to capture sea lions in Puget Sound and move them down the coast is being re-evaluated after two of the first four animals died.

LEAD: Bertha Hope, a pianist who brought a quartet to Birdland on Thursday night, has a terrific rhythmic sense.
Working with the be-bop vocabulary, she smacks a series of syncopated notes, throws in descending series of chords, and lets her left hand rumble.

FRANK BERTE  West Paterson, N.J.


Council of Veterans Refuses Membership to Jewish Group
LEAD: The local Veterans Council has sparked cries of anti-Semitism and the possibility of legal action by refusing to amend its charter to admit a local Jewish veterans group.


Ticket Lottery For Rangers
LEAD: The Rangers, who missed the playoffs last season but may be headed that way this spring, have announced a lottery to allocate tickets for the first three playoff rounds.


At Last, the Battle of the Century Ends
LEAD: ONE of the longest, bitterest conversion fights in Manhattan apartment house history has ended with the imposing Century Apartments at 25 Central Park West becoming a condominium, huge profits for both the sponsors and residents and the payment of millions of dollars in legal fees.

Lease Renewal
LEAD: To the Editor:


Former Mexican Soldier Describes Executions of Political Prisoners
LEAD: In the first public acknowledgement of death squad activity in Mexico, a former Mexican Army soldier is maintaining that he was part of a secret military unit that executed at least 60 political prisoners here in the late 1970's and early 1980's.


WEEK IN BUSINESS;
LEAD: Union Carbide will pay $470 million in damages for the 1984 gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, that killed more than 3,500 people and injured 200,000.
The payments were ordered by the Indian Supreme Court, and Robert D. Kennedy, Union Carbide's chairman, said the company would accept the order.
The Indian Government also accepted the settlement, even though it had sought $3.3 billion for 500,000 claimants.


Tiny Miracles Become Huge Public Health Problem
LEAD: A newborn boy, a mere patch of flesh with a tangerine-sized head and limbs like splinters, lay tethered to a thicket of tubes on a heated table in a special ward for premature infants at New York Hospital.


Ordeal on I-80
LEAD: WE'RE GOING TO hit,'' I called out to my two sons and my wife, Ann, once it became apparent that control of our station wagon was no longer in my hands but was governed instead by the transparent sheet of ice that had formed on Interstate 80 two miles from our exit.
It would turn out to be our good fortune that we slammed into the concrete wall of the bridge on which we came to a rest rather than being in the left lane, where I had tried to maneuver the car as it slid a good 10 to 12 car lengths.


The No Generation: A Modern Glossary
LEAD: WHEN the Me Generation came along, I knew instinctively that it would affect primarily Them, and when the Now Generation was announced, I was still working on the day before yesterday.
With the onset of the No Generation, I am hopelessly out of touch.
It appears we are living in a society whose parameters are defined by negatives, bringing out the worst in us all.


Regan Fees Paid by Campaign and State
LEAD: New York's State Comptroller, Edward V. Regan, is spending up to $400,000 in state funds and campaign money for lawyers as a result of investigations of his campaign financing practices by the State Commission on Government Integrity and Federal and state prosecutors.


Times Square: Lurching Toward a Terrible Mistake?
LEAD: The news these days is full of references to Times Square, and a lot of them seem contradictory.
There are reports that the massive city-state renewal project at the corner of 42d Street and Broadway - a project that was announced in 1981 but which after eight years has yet to begin construction - is about to get a major boost with the decision of one of the city's biggest banks to relocate its headquarters in the project.


Atomic Plant in Pennsylvania Wins Good Marks From U.S.
LEAD: The Philadelphia Electric Company's long-idled Peach Bottom nuclear power plant in central Pennsylvania could be restarted in April if no more serious problems are uncovered, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday.


Salvador At a Crossroads
LEAD: One thing Marxist rebels and the far right in El Salvador agree on is that U.S. policy in Central America is a resounding failure.
Of course they have opposite reasons.


Light on the Subject
LEAD: ORDINARILY, this is the time of year when I would be writing about how to adjust your exposure when photographing snow or how to carry your camera while cross-country skiing.
But the weather has conspired against these topics.


SMALL TOTS, BIG BIZ
LEAD: I never cease to be amazed at my generation (''Small Tots, Big Biz,'' by Tamar Lewin, Jan. 29).
The same parents who will pursue any avenue during pregnancy to assure a ''perfect'' baby will readily institutionalize that same baby during its most vulnerable developmental period.


3d in Row for St. Peter's
LEAD: Willie Haynes hit a 16-foot jumper with 11 seconds to play tonight to give St.
Peter's a 50-49 victory over Fordham in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference game.
The victory was the third straight for St.
Peter's (19-6, 11-2) and its 11th in 12 games.


Lyme Disease Bills in Congress
LEAD: SPURRED by growing concern over the spread of Lyme disease, Northeastern legislators, led by Representative George J. Hochbrueckner of Long Island, have introduced companion measures to channel $10.5 million into fighting the tick-borne infection.


Knicks' Streak Now 18 At Home
LEAD: Individually, the night belonged to Gerald Wilkins.
Collectively, it was another home victory for the Knicks as they easily defeated the injury-riddled Nets, 125-115, to run their Madison Square Garden winning streak to 18 in a row.


A Question of Whether to Go to Work? Let It Snow, Let It Snow, Let It Snow
LEAD: THESE questionable winter mornings are for the birds.
The world outside looks black and white but whether or not to venture out is anything but.


Review/Dance; A Soloist of Many Moods Astonishes Even Herself
LEAD: What's she doing now?
Whatever will she do next?
Ellen Cornfield raised such questions in two quirky solos she presented as part of a program of dances and video works on Thursday night at the Dia Art Foundation.


No Headline
LEAD: It is only poetic justice that Nina Wolff (''Sneezing Beauty in a Raccoon Coat,'' Jan. 29) should have to suffer physical discomfort from wearing her new garment.
After all, many innocent animals had to suffer the tortures of the damned to satisfy her desire for glamour and status.


Trail Blazers Dismiss Coach
LEAD: The Portland Trail Blazers dismissed Coach Mike Schuler today and replaced him on an interim basis with an assistant coach, Rick Adelman.
Schuler, 48 years old, was named the National Basketball Association's coach of the year in his first season at Portland, in 1986-87, when the Blazers had a 49-33 record.


THE REGION: The Polls Agree; As Koch Talks Like An Underdog, Dinkins Takes Him Up On It
LEAD: RE-ELECTED by the largest margin in New York City history the last time his job was at stake, Mayor Edward I. Koch now says he regards himself as an underdog.
Is the Mayor being honest, or merely modest?
Can David N. Dinkins thwart Mr.
Koch's attempt to secure an unprecedented fourth term, and in the process become the city's first black mayor?


This Collection Is Entirely Possible
LEAD: AN entire collection of United States ''entires'' probably does not exist.
But this certainly does not prevent a hobbyist from trying to build - who knows - what might become the first such collection.


COUTURE REPORT: SEXY CHIC
LEAD: Word has been wafting through the perfumed Paris air that Yves Saint Laurent is up to something big.
Now, here it is, show time on the next-to-last day of the spring 1989 Paris couture collections.
In the ornate velvet and red gilded ballroom that Saint Laurent traditionally uses to present his season's oeuvres, a runway stretches beneath the low-hanging chandeliers from a stage smothered with red and purple bougainvillea.


POP/JAZZ
LEAD:  Tone Loc: 'Wild Thing'  Delicious Vinyl/Island, 12-inch single.
A massive dance club hit, ''Wild Thing,'' which has a silly rap about seduction, mixes the glittering, silvery sound of club music, a little grinding rock-and-roll and hip-hop.
Tone Loc (Tony Smith) is part of a blossoming Los Angeles hip-hop scene, and his rap has a nice sort of amble to it.


Correction
LEAD: Because of a distributor's change, an article on page 17 of Arts and Leisure today about the film ''Rachel River'' misidentifies the theater.
It is at the Gemini.


GUERRILLAS CHOOSE AN INTERIM REGIME FOR AFGHANISTAN
LEAD: Afghan guerrilla leaders nominated a moderate as president and a fundamentalist as prime minister today in what was viewed as a compromise on who will lead Afghanistan if its Soviet-backed Government falls.


Votive Figures for Collectors
LEAD: JUST 50 years ago, almost every Catholic church in Italy had an area set aside on one of its interior walls for displaying ex votos, small flat silver figures giving visible testimony of the initiation or fulfillment of a believer's vow (voto).


HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
LEAD: Ten years ago, I received a Ph.D. in Engineering, and have been working in industry, primarily because there have been few faculty openings available.
Demographics show that we will have a shortage of faculty in the 1990's; however, I believe there is a relatively simple solution to the problem.

Miss Cabot Is Engaged
LEAD: Stephanie Mariette Cabot, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Powell M. Cabot of Greenwich, Conn., is engaged to Marcus Lovell-Smith, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Anthony Lovell-Smith of Taunton, Somerset, England, the future bride's parents have announced.
The couple plan to marry in June.


Computers Are Starting to Seem More Like Living Things
LEAD: IN her recent book ''AIDS and Its Metaphors,'' Susan Sontag reflects on how the sudden emergence of computer viruses evokes many of modern society's most primal fears.
Just as AIDS has unnerved people by conjuring up earlier visions of human plagues, she suggests, the advent of the computer virus is undermining the public's faith in the information revolution and changing the way people think about computers, as organisms rather than machines.

CONNECTICUT GUIDE
LEAD:  DEAF THEATER COMEDY  The National Theater of the Deaf will give two performances of Philip de Broca's ''King of Hearts,'' based on the French film of the same name.
A romantic comedy originally released in the 1960's, the movie has become a cult classic.


POSTINGS: Theater Conversion; Chico, Harpo, Groucho, Condo
LEAD: The 80-year-old RKO Keith's Prospect Theater in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn, where many actors and vaudevillians started their careers, is itself taking on a new role.
The 500-seat theater, which once featured the Marx Brothers, the Three Stooges, Burns and Allen and other stars of pre-electronic entertainment, is being converted with an existing supermarket into the 19-unit Park Plaza Condominium.


Life as a Program on a Cosmic Machine
LEAD: AT the same time that computer scientists are thinking of their machines as organisms, biologists are thinking of organisms as though they were computers.
In fact, some physicists have come to believe that the universe itself is a kind of giant calculating machine.

Core Curriculum: Other Opinions
LEAD: The article on Fairleigh Dickinson's core curriculum that appeared Jan. 22 suggests that Dr.
Robert Donaldson, the president of the university, believes that undergraduates ''should be exposed to the world beyond themselves.'' Therefore, as the article illustrates, those whose vocational goals might be science or engineering are required to take a program of liberal arts.


Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: It would be a pity if the negative comments about Spanish paradors were to cause anyone to pass up one of the great travel experiences of Europe.
In more than 80 locations in all parts of Spain, these inns offer an opportunity to relive history amid charming and often spectacular settings.

Wastebaskekt Ball, Anyone?
LEAD: EVER since I read that five or six games - Ping-Pong for one - had been added to the long list of sporting events included at the Summer Olympics in Seoul, I've been wondering how I could promote one of the most popular but least recognized games for inclusion in the 1992 games in Barcelona.
That sport is wastebasket ball, the game we all play in the home, at work, in the classroom or wherever there is a wastebasket.

LEAD: The engagement of Alison Ramona Wylegala to Stephen Joseph Lewis, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Nathan Lewis of Honesdale, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs.
Raymond V. Wylegala of Buffalo.

Paying the Price
LEAD: Britain's track and field team did not do very well at the 1988 Summer Olympics, and the poor showing is going to be costly.
Partly as a result of the Olympic disappointment, the British Amateur Athletic Board announced that it was cutting its budget for payments to athletes by more than 25 percent to $700,000.


Guard Scores 65 For Evansville
LEAD: Scott Haffner scored 65 points - tied for sixth-most in a Division I game -and led Evansville past Dayton, 109-83, in a Midwestern Collegiate Conference game today.


Madrid
LEAD: To the Editor: As a frequent business traveler to Spain, not successful or pretentious enough to stay at the Ritz, I can attest in response to R. Pujol's letter (''Madrid,'' Travel, Jan. 8) that I have never been robbed in a hotel in Madrid.
I have stayed at the Miguel Angel, the Emperatriz and the Palace.

Review/Music; Wringing Melody From Percussive Sound
LEAD: Chunk, the three-man band that played its debut set Tuesday at the Knitting Factory, could only exist in the 1980's, when almost any sound imaginable is just a digital formula away.
Samm Bennett, David Simons and Kent Spelios of Chunk are all percussionists, but by using electronic percussion consoles that produced various sounds, a few visible instruments (rattles, cymbals, steel guitar, jew's-harp), prerecorded rhythms and Mr.


FICTION
LEAD:  SERIOUS LIVING.
By Tom Lorenz. (Viking, $17.95.) Tom Lorenz, the author of the highly praised 1980 novel ''Guys Like Us,'' has returned to print with a rewarding coming-of-age story set in Chicago. ''Serious Living'' is the comic but also poignant tale of 21-year-old Ritchie Kohler, high school graduate and truly ordinary guy.


HIGHER EDUCATION-THE REAL CRISIS
LEAD: In his article ''Higher Education - The Real Crisis,'' (Jan. 22), Michael I. Sovern mentions the coming retirement (in the 1990's) of many great teachers and also the so-called ''lost generation'' of scholars, of whom I (Ph.D. in English, Princeton University, 1976) am one.
I have never found university work.


Unique Instrumental Trio Challenges Composers
LEAD: WHEN the musical trio Fidelio formed two years ago in Hartford, its members had a problem. ''There's almost no existing music for our combination,'' said Harry Clark, the group's cellist.


Aluminum Becomes Prime Target of Thieves
LEAD: Richard Arregui parked his car at an art gallery in Miami one day late last year and noticed something different.
An 8-foot aluminum outdoor sculpture was now only 4 feet high.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  WRITERS ON ARTISTS.
Edited by Daniel Halpern. (North Point Press, $25.) Proust on Chardin, Sartre on Tintoretto, Huxley on El Greco, Hemingway on Miro - writers discussing painters hold the irresistible promise of insight beyond formal analysis, interpretation beyond conventional art history.
But writers commenting on painting is tricky business: they risk turning visual images into words, replacing the art under study with their own.


Good Reading On Plants and Design
LEAD: LAST call to go over seed and nursery catalogues and mail orders for woody plants, perennials, groundcovers and seeds.
Prune mature grapevines, fruit trees, large shade trees, overgrown shrubs and hedges.
Start indoors seed of impatiens, celosias, snapdragons, begonias, geraniums, petunias and coleus.


New Careers For Defense Workers


Customs
LEAD: To the Editor: I read with interest the lament of Sandra Maury (Letters, Nov. 13) about the lack of knowledge among customs agents regarding duty exemptions.
My experience was similar to hers.
I came through customs on Oct. 18, 1988, in San Francisco.
I, too, bought items that were handmade works of art that I fully believed to be (and previously were) exempt from duty.

LEAD: On a recent morning near the airport here, Cuban soldiers filed into a military medical center, rolled up their sleeves and gave blood for tests for the AIDS virus.

Images of Coney Island Coming to the Whitney
LEAD: ''Coney Island of the Mind: Images of Coney Island in Art and Popular Culture 1890-1960'' will be at the Whitney Museum of American Art, downtown, at Federal Reserve Plaza, from Wednesday through April 21.
The work of painters and photographers like Joseph Stella, Margaret Bourke-White and Diane Arbus is to be included among the approximately 90 paintings, drawings, prints and photographs.


Political Memo; Seeking Reasons Besides Dukakis, Democrats Mull Last Fall's Defeat
LEAD: While most Americans have happily forgotten about the 1988 election campaign, Democrats are quietly fighting the war of interpretations.
Since election results, like scripture, can be cited to many purposes, Democrats sifting through the returns are coming up with some very different views about what ails the party.


TALKING: Inspectors; Checking A Home For Flaws
LEAD: EVALUATING the qualifications of a home inspector has never been easy.
And it may become even more difficult in the coming months as professional and trade groups battle over who is more competent to make inspections.


THE 'WALKURE' FACEOFF
LEAD: Like Deutsche Grammophon, EMI has begun its new digitally recorded ''Ring des Nibelungen'' with ''Die Walkure.'' The EMI version, conducted by Bernard Haitink, features Eva Marton, Cheryl Studer, James Morris, Reiner Goldberg, Matti Salminen, Waltraud Meier and the Bavarian Radio Symphony (EMI CDS 7 49534; four CD's and LP's three cassettes).

You're Going on Vacation'' by John Brannon Albright (Practical Traveler, Jan. 15) reminded me of some of the ways my husband and I relieve our travel jitters.

LEAD: As a product of the West Hartford and Fairfield school systems, a current university student and a prospective teacher, I found Jacqueline Weaver's interview with Gail Mellow, director of the Connecticut Project for Equal Education Rights, to be interesting and pertinent (Connecticut Q&amp;A, Jan. 1).


Tofu Innovator Dreams of New Creations
LEAD: AT black-tie dinners, on a beach in Florida, even in his sleep, David Mintz is thinking tofu - that spongy white substance with an origin no one seems quite sure of.


Agency Protests Flights Over Adirondack Park
LEAD: The Adirondack Park Agency, a New York State regulatory body, criticized the United States Air Force Friday for scheduling low-level flights over the park.


New York's Confusing War on AIDS
LEAD: DESPITE the need for a united front against the AIDS epidemic, fragmentation and feuding among city and state leaders have so far prevented concerted action in New York, which has a fourth of the nation's caseload.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations.
The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests.
There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air.
Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?


New Jersey Q &amp; A: Carol Botwin; Trying to Cope With Male Infidelity
LEAD: CAROL BOTWIN, a co-founder and co-director of the Westfield-based Better Relationship Training Institute, is the author of ''Men Who Can't Be Faithful.'' In the book - as in her earlier works like ''Is There Sex After Marriage?'' - she writes about relationships between men and women.


DEVISL LOSE A 3-1 LEAD
LEAD: Vince Damphousse's two third-period goals rallied Toronto and Mark Osborne scored the winner on a power play as the Maple Leafs defeated the New Jersey Devils, 5-3, tonight.


In the Heart ofIstanbul
LEAD: IF you order tea in one of the Ramada Istanbul's several spacious restaurants, you will notice pink tulips on the cups and saucers - for the handsome new cream hotel, combining modern atriums with beautiful Turkish design, is at the center of the Laleli district, and lale is Turkish for tulip.
As with tulips (said to have arrived in the Netherlands from Turkey), life in Laleli is always a treat for the eye.


Colt Drops Suit Against Los Angeles Weapon Ban
LEAD: Colt Industries has dropped its Federal lawsuit against the city's new ordinance banning possession and sale of semiautomatic assault weapons, the city attorney said Friday.


Bleak, Stubborn Life of the Marsh
LEAD: THERE is plenty of ocean south of Long Island, but there are closer, more intimate seas in our marshes; seas of reeds, penetrated by tidal creeks whose vistas coil through acres of spartina grass and giant phragmites in paths hidden from casual observers, but open to explorers in canoe, johnboat or sneak box.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  Tennis  Becker Beats McEnroe: Top-seeded Boris Becker of West Germany defeated third-seeded John McEnroe, 6-2, 6-3, yesterday in the semifinals of the Stella Artois indoor tournament in Milan, Italy.
In the final today, Becker will meet Aleksandr Volkov of the Soviet Union, who defeated Eric Jelen of West Germany by 6-2, 2-6, 7-6.


Past as Prologue
LEAD: ''This gives me chills.'' says Joseph Abboud, the New York men's-wear designer, who has been leafing through a volume of Norman Rockwell illustrations.
He finds what he is after, a 1940's Saturday Evening Post cover, whose subject, he admits, never fails to stir him.
Rockwell's depiction of a war veteran turned scholar is abrim with nostalgic detail.


Curtains Down
LEAD: Adela Holzer, a Broadway producer, has put on one act too many, according to the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau.
Ms.
Holzer, who was the toast of Broadway two decades ago as the producer of the rock musical ''Hair'' and other theatrical hits, was arrested last week on charges that she swindled investors out of $280,000 while posing as David Rockefeller's ''secret'' wife.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. My wife and I recently bought a 63-year-old house and we are planning a number of renovations.
The heating system is covered with asbestos, so we have done some air quality tests.
There are no dangerous levels of asbestos in the air.
Should we put removing the asbestos at the top of our priority list?


Guidry Is Hoping Arm Will Hold Up
LEAD: There is a part of him that yearns to finally become a gentleman farmer, to leave baseball behind and to spend his days mending fences and his nights in front of a warm fire with his family.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Taos
LEAD: Anchored by the massive adobe landmarks of St.
Francis de Assisi church on the south and by Taos Indian Pueblo on the north, Taos seems comfortably settled into winter.
Cozy interiors are a specialty here in New Mexico's high desert country, with beehive-shaped kiva fireplaces, Indian rugs, wooden beams overhead - and the sprinkling of hot tubs to be expected in a ski town.


Old Stones Surface, in Patios
LEAD: Ancient paving stones that were removed and stored during restoration of Florence's historic Piazza della Signoria have turned up in paths and patios at luxury villas, judicial officials said today.
They said magistrates were investigating four council employees and six homeowners in connection with the discovery.

Lucky Number?
LEAD: He has won 73 Winston Cup races, but none at Daytona International Speedway.
So Darrell Waltrip is hoping the matching numbers are a favorable omen for today's Daytona 500, when No. 17 will make his 17th attempt to finish first. ''If I win, I'm gonna spike my helmet in the winner's circle, and then I'm gonna do the Ickey Shuffle,'' Waltrip said yesterday.


The Underdog's Moment of Glory
LEAD: ONE of the fascinating facets of chess is the chance it offers the underdog to produce an incredible combination, a magnificent upset, a creation that would be worthy of a brilliancy prize.

LEAD: John H. Jackson, a retired vice president and copy chief of Geer, DuBois Inc., an advertising agency, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in White Plains.
He was 73 years old.

FICTION
LEAD:  RUMORS.
By Catherine Mann. (Delacorte, $18.95.) Hollywood is so replete with real-life caricatures that it would seem superfluous to create a mannerist portrait of them.
Yet Catherine Mann, herself a one-time Hollywood reporter, has done exactly that. ''Rumors'' has all the hallmarks of a perfunctory nod to the literary form en route to the big payoff: the television mini-series.

FICTION
LEAD:  LONGING.
By Paul Reed. (Celestial Arts, $14.95.) A crucial test of a good writer is whether he or she can take a basically trite story and turn it into something memorable.
In his second novel, Paul Reed passes that test.
If ''Longing'' were the sort of teen-age saga that's devoured by 10-year-old girls, its plot would go like this: A girl moves to a new city, looking for love.

Take Me Out to the Ski Lift
LEAD: BASEBALL season doesn't start until April, but from all appearances baseball-cap season is a year-round affair.
A Yankee cap, for instance, is a perfect midwinter match for a full-length fur coat, and it doesn't look too bad with something more casual, like a windbreaker and turtleneck.
For men, the recommended attire is pin stripes or a bomber jacket, or both.

LEAD:  AT WASHINGTON'S HQ  George Washington's birthday will be celebrated in 18th-century style at the general's headquarters in North White Plains today.

LEAD: In 1982, when I was playing with the St.

Spain
LEAD: To the Editor: Regarding Paul Delaney's article (Travel, Jan. 1) on the national inns of Spain, the system is no longer government owned and has not been for several years.
The system is now independent, although like all of Spain's hotels the paradors are subject to strict regulation as to quality and prices.

Safaris
LEAD: To the Editor: Safaris in Kenya and Tanzania are often very expensive, as you highlighted on Dec. 4.
Many of your readers might, therefore, be interested to learn that South Africa offers the same safari experience for a substantially lower price.
For example, the cost of a night in Kruger National Park ranges from approximately $20 to $40 a person a night.

Reviews/Music; Rock Riffs, Fireworks And Poison
LEAD: Poison's sold-out concert at the Meadowlands on Tuesday night started with flashing red and blue lights, an explosion and a roar of disheveled guitar sound.
An hour and a half later, things hadn't calmed down: a set of timbales had been lowered from the ceiling, guitars were changed every song or so, fireworks had gone off and confetti had been sprayed over the audience.

IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Marble Hill
LEAD: EVER since Marble Hill was severed from the rest of Manhattan by the construction of the Harlem Ship Canal nearly a century ago, the 52-acre enclave has led an isolated existence.

Cassavetes, A Model Of Defiance
LEAD: John Cassavetes, who died two weeks ago, will be as appreciatively remembered for what he didn't do as for what he did.
In conceiving, writing, directing, financing and sometimes distributing his own films, Mr.
Cassavetes most definitely did not play ball.
He did not get along with either conventional Hollywood or the New York avant-garde, and he did not set much stock in an acting career of which others would have been proud.

Why Growth Stocks Could Soon Surge
LEAD: President Bush's proposal to cut the tax rate for capital gains faces an uphill battle in Congress.
But investment experts say if such a cut were enacted the big winners would be the stocks of young companies whose earnings are growing rapidly but which pay out very little in dividends.
Even without a tax cut, however, many Wall Street professionals believe that such stocks currently represent some of the best bargains around.

Sniffing Through History
LEAD: Two thousand years ago, in a cave near the Dead Sea, somebody buried a small clay jug of the oil used to anoint Israeli kings.
Last summer, an archeologist unearthed it.
The jug is still whole and the oil is still fluid, but the fragrance is gone forever - as is the ancient persimmon plant from which it was extracted.

From the townships to the large cities, the remote villages to the white suburbs, Ms.
Karodia, a South African writer who now lives in Canada, depicts a land deformed by rage and random violence.

Review/Concert; Barenboim Conducts the 'Missa Solemnis'
LEAD: The Beethoven of the early 1820's, the time of the Missa Solemnis, presents one of the unforgettable portraits in artistic history.
Here is the old master, deaf, unkempt, bewildered, buffeted by life, poring over the old masters of sacred music, pressing relentlessly inward and outward the frontiers of his own creative realm, composing a mass for the ages (''singing, howling, stamping'' it, in one famous account), while he slides recklessly into debt and negotiates duplicitously with half a dozen publishers for rights to (and advances on) the work.


Manager-Broker Tie No Longer Binds
LEAD: FOR many years, a real estate brokerage's path to commissions on the sales of cooperative apartments was built on contracts to manage the buildings.
That insider's edge led many firms to serve as managing agents for New York apartment houses at little or no profit, or even at a loss, as long as fat brokerage fees were coming in.


Why Are Film Tastes So Parochial?
LEAD: As I read the interesting article, ''Chinese Films Offer New Perspective'' (Jan. 22), I pondered the question of why we Long Islanders accept some foreign products eagerly while avoiding others.
We clasp alien cars, television sets and home appliances eagerly, while avoiding others.
When it comes to entertainment, though, we seem convinced that nothing on our screens is worthy of attention unless it is of domestic origin.

Prospects; Pushing Up Pay
LEAD: The Commerce Department's report early this month on January employment was seen by some economists as one more sign that wage increases are about to accelerate, adding to inflationary pressures.
Hourly wages, for example, rose at an annual rate of more than 7.6 percent.
Also noteworthy was the addition of 408,000 to the nation's payrolls in January, an unexpectedly sharp increase that was only partly explained by unseasonably mild weather.

The jury convicted him of assault and acquitted him on the rape charge.

Reverse Mortgages: An Assessment
LEAD: The article ''Elderly Are Offered Reverse Mortages''  [ Jan. 29 ]  is misleading.
The mortgages described are home-equity loans that place a second or possibly first mortgage on a house based on the house's value without regard to income and must be repaid in full with interest at the end of 10 years.


BURN THE BUILDINGS, HANG THE PROFESSORS
LEAD:  PROFSCAM  Professors and the Demise of Higher Education.
By Charles J. Sykes.  304 pp.
Washington: Regnery Gateway. $18.95.


Now on View, New Work by Freelance Curators
LEAD: Art curators, once as anonymous as starving artists, have stepped into the spotlight of contemporary art.
With them comes a new definition of the job.
While curators of tradition are academically trained art historians who work in museums behind doors that say ''No Admittance,'' many of the new curators are young, often fashionable, art-world operators who are more a part of the scene than an establishment.


Gulf Coast's Rewards For Bird Watchers
LEAD: IT was a brilliant morning on a two-lane farm road about 50 miles southeast of Houston, not far inland from the Gulf of Mexico.
The big Texas sky was bright and blue, the air still except for the occasional passing of a clanky pickup truck.
We had stopped our car along the side of the road to show out-of-state guests a spectacle worthy of a cowboy's boast.

Rustic Italian, With Sophistication
LEAD: SMITHTOWN'S Casa Rustica is a champion among Italian restaurants on an island loaded with contenders.
Some of the also-rans may be ritzier or have snappier service, but a look at the menu and a taste of the food separate Casa Rustica from the pack.

LEAD: Five people have been charged with conspiring to steal millions of dollars from the Bank of America with automatic teller cards forged on the accounts of more than 7,000 customers.

Sports of The Times; Pop Gates Earned His Grits
LEAD: At age 71, he's as lean as the backboard pole in the playground below his fifth-floor Harlem apartment.
But arthritis had Pop Gates sitting on pillows on the long curved couch in his living room.
Asked if he would rather move to a favorite chair, he smiled.


POSTINGS: Canadians in Connecticut; Armed to Fit
LEAD: A major Canadian pharmaceutical house is going to build a $70 million headquarters in Ridgefield, Conn., for two of its American subsidiaries in an innovative structure that will accommodate 700 employees.
The company, Pharma-Investment Ltd. of Toronto, will erect the 266,000-square-foot building for the administrative staffs of its wholly owned subsidiaries, the Boehringer Ingelheim Corporation and Boehringer Ingelheim Pharmaceuticals Inc.

Henry Kloss's Mail-Order Speakers
LEAD: A basic rule for picking a loudspeaker is to allow plenty of time for listening comparisons.
In fact, willingness to let customers become amply acquainted with a variety of loudspeakers under appropriately unhurried conditions is the touchstone that separates reliable and conscientious audio dealers from the rest.

Friendly Hunan in West Haven
LEAD: A RESTAURANT writer could keep busy reviewing Connecticut's Chinese restaurants alone.
It is not just the reviewing, but the need for re-reviewing, as nothing in the food service industry seems to change faster than the personnel in a Chinese restaurant kitchen. ''Very good'' today can turn into a mere ''satisfactory'' in a matter of weeks; such is the speed of the chef's revolving door.


Talk Shows: Morbid Curiosity
LEAD: I agree with Geraldine M. Fox  [ Topics, ''Abuse on TV,'' Jan. 29 ] .
Afternoon and evening expose and talk shows are not in the business of educating the public.
They are in business, period.
Dollar signs dance before them as they probe open wounds before the eyes of the morbidly curious.

We Must Act Locally for Housing
LEAD: WHEN I was my daughter's age, I used to enjoy sketching room plans for my house-to-be. (I think this followed hot on the heels of fashion layouts and bridal dress.) Usually the rooms were spacious and numerous, with no regard for such construction details as plumbing, insulation and electricity.
The houses had conservatories and morning rooms, and money was no object.


Warsaw Begins to Tell Its Own History
LEAD: THE report that appeared in an official Polish publication last week attesting that Soviet troops were responsible for the wartime executions of 4,443 Polish officers in the Katyn forest was hardly a revelation.
The entire Polish nation has known this for decades.
It was a fact of life that grandmothers routinely told grandchildren.

LEAD: ON most days, residents of Shady Lake Park do not have far to travel to pick up their mail: there are 14 mailbox clusters in this lakeside community at the foot of the Ramapo Mountains.
But in winter, they say, the hilly, winding roads coated with snow and ice sometimes become impassable and dangerous.

Bass to Bass
LEAD: It is always comforting when things come full circle.
Ashes to ashes, dust to dust, bass to bass.
This thought is prompted by news that a stretch of Manhattan's deteriorated West Side Highway is about to assume a new identity - as an ocean reef for sea bass and other marine life.

Galveston's Sense Of Delight and Danger
LEAD: WHEN I first moved to Galveston in the summer of 1984, it was less than a year after Hurricane Alicia and the building boom that insurance money had brought to the island.
The people I met would invariably steer conversations to the aftermath of Alicia: the swimming pool lifted six inches out of the ground by a spin-off tornado, the water marks on the den paneling.

LEAD:  George Washington's birthday, actually Feb. 22, will be observed on Monday.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Closed.
Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.
Banks: Option to close.
Parking: Alternate-side rules suspended.


Needed: A Camp to Train Adults as Parents
LEAD: THERE is a war in the news these days and the wounded are almost all women and children.
This is not a war on foreign shores fought between fanatical factions.
It is going on right around us between women and the judicial system, and the object of the war is the children, who are the victims.

LEAD: FOR an easy inexpensive meal, you can't beat chicken.

When Exercise Isn't Enough
LEAD: EVER wonder how many calories a cookie contains?
One typical cookie contains around 80 calories, meaning that an innocent snack of six chocolate-chip cookies and a glass of milk probably has at least 600 calories, depending on how full of chocolate and nuts the cookies are.
A middle-aged male who is 6 feet and 180 pounds probably needs between 2,500 calories a day to meet his nutritional needs without gaining weight.

LEAD: Steel imports declined 16 percent in December from a year earlier, to 1.42 million tons, but imports for all of 1988 rose 4.9 percent, to 20.89 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Friday.

LEAD: Mayor Koch chose well in appointing David Todd to head New York's Landmarks Preservation Commission.
He is an experienced architect who combines sense with sensibility.
Further, he has the ability to distinguish landmarks from dross without abusing the city's architectural heritage or giving in to obstructionism.


Laws Shift, Theft Persists
LEAD: Operation Sludge began in 1983 as a major drive by Federal and New York State law-enforcement agencies to stop gasoline-tax evaders.

LEAD: Four top officers from two of Mexico's biggest brokerage firms were indicted Saturday on charges of illegal trading and criminal fraud.

LEAD: ''We will start shooting the children on the St.
Magdalen schoolyard real soon,'' the letter began. ''Thought you should be there.''


Review/Pop; A Bluesman Plumbs The Depths
LEAD: Mighty Sam McClain, the opener on a soul-blues double bill at the Village Gate, delivered the show's real blues power in Saturday's early set.
Mr.
McClain, who recorded soul music around Louisiana during the 1960's and was rediscovered in the early 80's, plunged immediately into songs of pain-wracked romance and distant hope, pleading for release and redemption with the dramatic timing of classic blues.

Baltimore Symphony Ends Its Strike
LEAD: Members of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra ratified a contract late Saturday night that assures a minimum $1,040 a week in the 1991-92 season and ends a 22-week strike, the longest in American symphony history.

Boys and Girls defeated Grady, 79-73, in the other game at Canarsie High School with a little help from an unearned point.

Slow and Steady
LEAD: Forgetting speed for the moment, Alfredo Rego realized his goal at the world Alpine ski championships in Vail, Colo.
He entered the combined slalom, the super G, the giant slalom and the special slalom, and he finished each race.
Last, to be sure, but Rego finished.

Reporter's Notebook; At Persepolis, Shadows of Two Pasts
LEAD: There is no sound-and-light show in Persepolis anymore.
Tourist buses no longer crowd the entrance to these magnificent ruins.
Those palaces and temples built 2,500 years ago by the descendants of Cyrus the Great to glorify their Persian empire stand serene, surrounded by the majesty of the Zagros mountains.

LEAD: Holden Caulfield, the disaffected teen-ager of ''The Catcher in the Rye'' who fretted about where the ducks in Central Park go for the winter, need not have worried this year.
They didn't go anywhere.

Alcohol and Muscles
LEAD: The amount of alcohol consumed over a lifetime contributes to heart and muscle weakness, according to a study conducted by Spanish and American researchers.
The study involved 50 chronic alcoholics and 50 healthy men of similar age.
Nearly half of the alcoholics suffered weakness of their shoulder and pelvic muscles and a third had damaged heart muscles.

Mario M. Cuomo to appoint a special prosecutor.

LEAD: The Giants, who had been looking for a defensive backfield coach, ended their search yesterday in an unusual way.

Len Fontes, who coached the Giants' secondary for six years, resigned after last season.

Sooners Cancel Reunion
LEAD: The 1949 Oklahoma football team announced yesterday that it has canceled its April reunion to express embarrassment over recent problems plaguing the university's football program.
In a letter, James D. Owens, co-captain of the 1949 team, said he did not plan to take part in any reunions on campus ''until a drastic change in leadership takes place.

Lebanese Army Gains Ground in Christian Areas
LEAD: The Lebanese Army appears to have gained the upper hand after a week of violent clashes with militia fighters for control of Christian areas of Lebanon.

Amer Group to Acquire Wilson Sporting Goods
LEAD: Amer Group Ltd., a diversified company based in Finland, said yesterday that it would acquire the Wilson Sporting Goods Company, the largest sporting goods maker in the United States.


4 Young Children Burn to Death in Brooklyn Fire
LEAD: Four young children in two families, apparently playing with matches in a bedroom whose door was blocked with a mattress, were fatally burned in an apartment fire in Brooklyn yesterday as their mothers cried hysterically from the street.


Drug Agents Arrest 12 People In 3 Heroin Raids in Queens
LEAD: Twelve people were arrested and 100 pounds of heroin was seized during raids on three homes in College Point, Queens, last night, the police said.

LEAD: Like the bamboo shoots that emerge everywhere after a spring rain, to use a Chinese simile, democracy is sprouting again in China.

LEAD: Librarians are protesting a proposal that would take the Government out of the business of interpreting and organizing some of its computerized information.

LEAD: Even before William J. Bennett takes office to lead the Federal effort against illegal drugs, key officials who championed the new post are skeptical that he will acquire sufficient influence to succeed in what many regard as a kind of Mission Impossible.


Fax Machines and Modems: Who Needs Which?
LEAD: FAX modems and fax boards are valuable tools for certain specialized applications on personal computers.
These tools are widely misunderstood, though, and under no circumstances should they be considered a substitute for a stand-alone fax machine.


Chicago Board Discussing Trading Link With London
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade has begun talks with the London International Financial Futures Exchange about the possibility of hooking up their similar electronic trading systems, an exchange official said.

LEAD: Significant progress has been made toward settlement of a wide variety of civil charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission against Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people involved in the talks said yesterday.

Phone-Fraud Prey to Get Refunds
LEAD: The New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday that refunds will be available for consumers who gave in to a telephone sales pitch and made a two-minute phone call that cost $50.20.


Reviews/Dance; Cartoonlike Movement
LEAD: The brief dances that Sara Pearson and Patrik Widrig presented Sunday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center resembled cartoons.
Not animated cartoons or comic strips, which can develop narratives at length, but newspaper or magazine cartoons: isolated drawings that are funny in themselves.


Mattingly Has No Predictions for 1989
LEAD: Except for a few players and some coaches, the clubhouse was virtually empty when Don Mattingly arrived in camp this afternoon, changed his clothes and began to lift weights.
He had been in town since last Thursday, but he was here now, ready to work under the warm Florida sun, although unwilling to offer the predictions of the past.

LEAD: Arena Football will suspend operations this year while attempting to restructure, the general manager of the Detroit Drive said today.

LEAD: The marriage of Hillary Fabian, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Kenneth Fabian of Forest Hills, Queens, to John Senise, the son of Adeline Senise of Little Neck, Queens, took place last evening at the 5 and 10 No Exaggeration restaurant in SoHo.
Rabbi Milton Goodman officiated.


Cubans Are Curious to See U.S. TV
LEAD: From President Fidel Castro to the most anonymous of students, Cubans are awaiting an American television station that is expected to bring them news, sports, music videos and soap operas whether they like it or not.


Sutter Out 5 Games
LEAD: Duane Sutter of the Chicago Blackhawks was suspended for five games yesterday by the National Hockey League for a stick incident involving Neil Sheehy of the Washington Capitals.
With five seconds left in the game Feb. 15, Sutter struck the Capital defenseman with his stick.
He was assessed a high-sticking major and a match penalty, and the foul prompted a videotape review by Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League executive vice president who handles discipline.


Our Towns; A Mind Erodes, A Wife Goes On, But With Dignity
LEAD: rrThe other day, W. H. Ferry was making his quarterly visit to his longtime acquaintances, the Mumfords, when the subject turned to suicide.
Writing had been everything to Lewis Mumford, the great architectural critic and urban historian who is now 93 years old.
He wrote 29 books, the last when he was in his mid-80's.


Man Returns Two Money Bags, Unopened
LEAD: A man said he was not at all tempted to find out what was in two locked canvas bags he discovered on a street over the weekend, but his interest was piqued when he learned what was inside.

Dinah Halpern, Actress, 79
LEAD: Dinah Halpern, a Yiddish actress who appeared in New York, Chicago and Europe, died of cancer on Saturday at St.
Joseph's Hospital in Chicago.
She was 79 years old and lived in Chicago.


100 More Rare Ferns Found
LEAD: The known population of one of the rarest plants in North America has been increased more than tenfold by the discovery of about 100 more.
Before the discovery of the additional Aleutian-Shield ferns, biologists thought only six of the plants remained.
The fern is unique to two of the Aleutian Islands.


Secret Fat
LEAD: Federal dietary guidelines urge Americans to ''choose lean meat'' to avoid heart disease.
Yet current labeling rules leave consumers confused about ground beef - which contributes the most fat to the American diet.


John H. Blair, Lobbyist, 44
LEAD: John H. Blair, the chief spokesman and lobbyist for Connecticut's insurance industry who was previously an aide to Gov.
Ella T. Grasso, died of a heart attack today at John Dempsey Hospital here.
He was 44 years old and lived in Farmington.


REPORT ON TOWER IS SAID TO SATISFY THE WHITE HOUSE
LEAD: President Bush reviewed the latest F.B.I. report on John G. Tower today and concluded that there was nothing in it to prevent the former Texas Senator's confirmation as Secretary of Defense, the White House said.


Turtle Safety Device Cuts Shrimp Catch
LEAD: Trap doors on shrimp nets save the lives of sea turtles, but they significantly reduce the shrimpers' catch, researchers have found.

LEAD: The Texas Eastern Corporation, a major pipeline company that transports natural gas to the Northeast from the Gulf Coast, has accepted a friendly takeover offer valued at $3.2 billion from the Panhandle Eastern Corporation, the companies said today.

LEAD: rrWith his usual bluster, George Steinbrenner has offended the purists who think the Olympic ideal still exists.

Shevardnadze Claims New Arab Support for Peace Bid
LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister claimed new Arab support today for Moscow's latest Middle East proposals in Egypt, but he faced little prospect of Israeli assent in discussions here later in the week.


Frederick Weitzen, 77, Bookstore Founder
LEAD: Frederick Weitzen, a bookseller who pioneered in mail-order techniques and who was a founder of the Marboro Books retail chain, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 77 years old.
Mr.
Weitzen, with Frank Bang and Henry Exstein, started Marboro in 1946 as a mail-order enterprise, advertising extensively to promote sales of popular books at low prices.


Want a Happy Marriage? Learn to Fight a Good Fight
LEAD: WHAT'S the difference between a marriage that gets happier as time goes on and one that grows more miserable?
In many cases it is fights, according to a new study that pinpoints exactly which kinds of arguments help a couple grow closer and which split them apart.

LEAD: The criminal trial of Oliver L. North begins Tuesday morning in Federal District Court here, promising more political and legal drama than insights into the scandal that gave birth to the case about 28 months ago.

LEAD: A West German company suspected of playing a key role in building a poison-gas factory in Libya said today that it produced and shipped an illegal drug known as Ecstasy to the United States.

Museum on Kennedy Opens in Dallas
LEAD: The sixth floor of the former Texas School Book Depository, the place from which Lee Harvey Oswald shot President John F. Kennedy, was opened to the public today for the first time since the assassination 25 years ago.
It has been made into a Kennedy museum with an emphasis on the events surrounding the assassination.

The rapport between the state's present Lieutenant, Stan Lundine, and Gov.
Mario Cuomo has spared Mr.
Lundine such isolation.
It also underscores the importance of a governor choosing his own running mate.

LEAD: Polisario Front guerrillas will hold a new round of peace talks with King Hassan II of Morocco next week, the Polisario Front's secretary general, Mohammed Abdelaziz, said today. ''I received information yesterday that a second meeting will be held next week,'' said Mr.
Abdelaziz, who is here on a three-day visit.

LEAD: Ernest Hemingway might have worn a Swatch Watch, if the company's new ad campaign is any indication of the type of person who owns the trendy timepiece.
While the ads do not feature bullfighting, they depict some of the more dangerous leisure activities in the world, including paraponting over thousand-foot waterfalls.

LEAD: While the Indiana Pacers altered their chemistry yesterday with one trade, Donnie Walsh, their general manager, said he was still hoping to get Kiki Vandeweghe before the trading deadline Thursday.
The Knicks have been pursuing the Portland Trail Blazer forward for more than six months.

LEAD: Archbishop John F. Whealon, urging Roman Catholics not to become ''paralyzed by fear and hopelessness,'' has established an office of AIDS ministry in the Archdiocese of Hartford, church officials said today.


Review/Television; Evolution vs. Creation
LEAD: Although clashes between evolutionists and creationists continue to generate heat around the United States, they do not set off intellectual sparks these days.
As ''God, Darwin and Dinosaurs'' reports, the nation's scientific community dismisses the belief that man was created in more or less his present form as based on faith in the Bible rather than in the findings of laboratory or field.

LEAD: The Interpublic Group of Companies said its 1988 earnings increased 21.9 percent, to $60.1 million, or $2.72 a share, from 49.3 million, or $2.25 a share.
Interpublic - a holding company comprising McCann-Erickson Worldwide, Lintas: Worldwide, Dailey &amp; Associates and other agencies - said its gross billings in 1988 were a record $1.19 billion, a 22.6 percent increase over 1987 revenues of $970.7 million.

LEAD: A court-appointed mediator in talks to settle a racketeering suit against the Long Island Lighting Company yesterday proposed an accord he said would end the court action and be ''an important first step'' toward closing the Shoreham nuclear power plant.


Crackdown on Latin Refugees Has a Shaky Start
LEAD: The Federal Government's crackdown on Central American refugees began slowly today as officials working in makeshift facilities were only able to process a handful of the aliens seeking political asylum.


Can't Afford the Wine? Try a Slice of the Company
LEAD: IF buying a bottle of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild is a bit beyond your means at the moment, you might consider another tack: investing in the Domaines Barons de Rothschild, which runs the place.
Here's how you do it: Tell your broker to buy some shares for you in Chalone Inc., which closed yesterday at $12.25 in over-the-counter trading.

POLICE TRANSFERS STUDIED IN CAPITAL
LEAD: Officials today prepared a plan that would permit the deployment of several hundred Washington police officers from desk jobs to at least part-time duty on streets where homicides are running at a record rate.


What David Duke Owes Willie Horton
LEAD: Credit Lee Atwater, the Republican National Chairman, for responding quickly and unequivocally to the victory of a former Ku Klux Klansman, David Duke, in a Louisiana state legislative election.
He called Mr.
Duke, who ran as a Republican, a ''charlatan'' and urged the party's national executive committee to censure him.


Reviews/Opera; 'Salome,' the Biblical Headhunting Tale
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera's new ''Salome'' is a schizoid affair.
In this Nikolaus Lehnhoff production, the musical and theatrical elements of Strauss's biblical horror story lead parallel lives, never really making contact.
Fortunately for those who care about such things, the score's exhausting musical challenges were met triumphantly on Monday evening, particularly by Eva Marton in the grueling title part.

LEAD: Harold Christensen, a dancer, a teacher and for 33 years the director of the San Francisco Ballet school, died of prostate cancer on Monday at his home in San Anselmo, Calif.
He was 84 years old.

Topics of The Times; Mud Crocuses
LEAD: It is not too late, a New Yorker muses, for the wind to change direction and begin howling from the north.
For the sky to cease sending down rain and replace it with sleet, even snow.
For skiing, skating, sledding and snowballs.
For frostbite, chilblains, windburn and a runny nose.
For the purple down coat.

China Sets Import Curb
LEAD: China has banned cigarette and liquor imports this year to save foreign currency and end abuses in its foreign trade system, official reports said today.
The China Daily quoted the Foreign Economic Relations and Trade Minister, Zheng Tuobin, as also announcing tighter controls on imports of all products that can be made in China and a ban on the reselling of export licenses.

Bridge
LEAD: Deals that call for guessing the location of a queen or a jack are common.
Guesses for a king are rarer, and guesses for an ace, with no other honor involved, are very uncommon indeed.
When they happen, as the diagramed example shows, the need for the guess may not be obvious.

LEAD: The board of directors of the Pennwalt Corporation said it had unanimously rejected the sweetened offer of $110 a share, or a total of about $850 million, from Centaur Partners, a New York investment firm.
Pennwalt, a diversified chemical company based in Philadelphia, said it regarded Centaur's proposed price as inadequate.

Likely Result On Pepperell
LEAD: The winning bidder for West Point-Pepperell Inc., the big textile producer, may be announced as early as today, executives close to the deal said yesterday.
But Pepperell's stock fell 87.5 cents yesterday, to $56.25, on the New York Stock Exchange after traders concluded that the response to Pepperell's invitation to bid for the company might have been less successful than expected.


Prague Jails a Major Playwright For Inciting Protests Last Month
LEAD: A Czechoslovak court today convicted the playwright and dissident author Vaclav Havel of inciting illegal protests and obstructing the police and sentenced him to nine months in prison.


Hewlett-Packard Net Rises
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company today reported a 7.8 percent increase in its first-quarter earnings, but the results fell short of Wall Street's expectations.
Hewlett-Packard's shares closed today at $59.25, down 75 cents each, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Young Hosts Discover The 50's Dinner Party
LEAD: MELISSA PALEOLOGOS is tired of going to nightclubs and restaurants crammed with couches, rugs and other accouterments of an imagined home.
For the last year, she and her husband have been seeing friends and sharing pastas, pastries and chardonnay in a real home - their home.

Kirk to Appeal
LEAD: The former Memphis State basketball coach, Dana Kirk, has notified the United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit that he plans to appeal his one-year prison sentence for tax evasion and obstruction of justice.
The one-sentence notice of appeal was filed by Kirk on his own behalf and did not include any grounds for the appeal.(

Student Articles Hostile to Israel Divide Campus at U. of Michigan
LEAD: A university campus that has struggled with racial tensions now finds itself embroiled in a controversy over anti-Israel editorials in the student newspaper.


Toxic Spill Hurts 3; 100 Are Evacuated
LEAD: A highly toxic chemical spilled from a 30-gallon drum in a warehouse near Linden Airport yesterday, injuring at least three workers and forcing the evacuation of about 100 others, officials said.


Man Whose Killings Led to Tougher Law Is Convicted Again
LEAD: Willie Bosket Jr., whose five-year sentence for two subway murders led New York State to toughen its penalties for juvenile violence, was found guilty today of attempted murder in the 1988 stabbing of a prison guard.


Le Reve Winery on L.I. Says It Isn't in Trouble
LEAD: Le Reve, a major Long Island winery, is reportedly in financial trouble.
But the owner, Alan Barr, said it was not in danger even though a bank has taken steps to foreclose on a loan that he characterized as ''slightly more than $6 million.''

Setback for Nilan
LEAD: Michel Bergeron, the coach of the Rangers, said Chris Nilan, the forward and one of the team's emotional leaders, had suffered a setback in his recovery from an injury to ligaments in his pelvic area.
Nilan was tentatively scheduled to play Monday afternoon against the Devils, but was scratched before the game after he aggravated the injury.

Review/Music; Of Tibet's New Year
LEAD: Because the first full moon after the Tibetan new year occurred Monday night, the eight Tibetan monks from the Drepung-Loseling monastery who are now touring the United States gave the first performances in the West of excerpts from Mon-lam Chen-mo, the Great Prayer Festival.
In Lhasa, the ceremonies would last for three weeks and reach a peak at the full moon.


Review/Music; Young Talent on Display
LEAD: Sunday's American Symphony Orchestra concert at Carnegie Hall had a lot to do with being young.
George Hanson, the winner of the 1989 Leopold Stokowski Conducting Competition and a talented young man, conducted this afternoon affair.
Leonidas Kavakos, the 22-year-old Greek violinist who won last year's Naumburg award and who is quite gifted, played the Tchaikovsky Concerto.


Reviews/Opera; Riccardo Muti's Hand In a Fiery Verdi Work
LEAD: Riccardo Muti's latest opera-in-concert presentation at Carnegie Hall was ''Nabucco'' Monday night, the fiery opera that established Verdi's career at La Scala and inaugurated Mr.
Muti's directorate of the same theater.


Ninth-Grade Bronx Teacher Arrested in Heroin Purchase
LEAD: A high school teacher at a Roman Catholic preparatory school in the Bronx was arrested with a companion for possession of heroin yesterday by officers from the New York City Police Department's special anti-drug unit, the police said.

LEAD: After more than 11 months of delays and pretrial maneuvering, Oliver L. North went on trial in Federal District Court today, accused of a dozen crimes stemming from his role in diverting profits from the secret sale of arms to Iran to the Nicaraguan rebels.

Drexel Makes Key Changes
LEAD: The director of compliance at Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. is being reassigned and the general counsel of the firm left earlier this month after requests were made for the changes by the Securities and Exchange Commission, people at Drexel said yesterday.


Hanover Cuts Its Net After Bond Trades
LEAD: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation said yesterday that it will restate its fourth-quarter earnings, reducing them by $14 million to reflect unauthorized bond trading by an employee.


Mavericks Trade Schrempf for Williams
LEAD: The Dallas Mavericks, still waiting for Adrian Dantley to end his holdout, traded the 6-foot-10-inch forward Detlef Schrempf to the Indiana Pacers yesterday for the 6-11 forward Herb Williams and a second-round draft pick in either 1990 or 1991.
The 31-year-old Williams, a first-round draft pick in 1981, was averaging 12 points and 8 rebounds a game.

Lefty Swing May Set Things Right
LEAD: Mac O'Grady, who has always been a refreshing difference on the PGA Tour, may become the first man in PGA Tour history to play one or more rounds of competitive tournament golf from the opposite side of the ball to which he normally plays.
In his case, he may tee off Thursday in the Ryder Doral Open by playing left-handed instead of right-handed.

Teachers College Is Living in the Present
LEAD: To the Editor:


As Ranks Grow, Indians at Dartmouth Grapple With Adjusting
LEAD: When Eleazar Wheelock founded Dartmouth College here in 1769, he wrote in the school's charter that the primary objective was to educate Indians.


Topics of The Times; Slimmer Campaign Pickings?
LEAD: It's too soon to say whether New York City's new system of public campaign financing will reduce candidates' reliance on wealthy favor-seekers.
But the latest filings are encouraging.
The voluntary plan provides public matching funds for all municipal candidates who agree to strict disclosure rules and reasonable limits on spending and private contributions.


Court Says Patent Law Limits Action by States
LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that states may not go beyond the scope of Federal patent law to protect unpatented products or manufacturing processes against duplication.


Dollar Mixed as Greenspan Fails to Signal Policy Shift
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board's chairman, Alan Greenspan, failed to signal a dramatic shift in the nation's monetary policy in testimony to Congress.


Transactions
LEAD:  Baseball  BOSTON (AL) - Agreed to terms with Mike Greenwell, outfielder, on a two-year contract, and Luis Rivera, infielder, on a one-year contract.
Signed Bill Laskey, pitcher, to a minor league contract and invited him to spring training.
CALIFORNIA (AL) - Purchased the contract of Gary Buckels, pitcher, from Midland of the Texas League.

Santana Eager to Show His Stuff
LEAD: There were two new gloves sitting in his locker, both of them still in the large plastic bag in which they had arrived.
Rafael Santana took one out, slid it over his left hand and pounded his fist loudly into the palm.
He did the same with the other glove.
It was one of the sounds of spring, and Santana seemed eager to begin again.

Polaroid Sets Stock Tender
LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation began a cash tender offer today for 16 million of its shares at $50 a share and announced that it had designated $325 million for privately negotiated share purchases.

Seitzer Signs
LEAD: Kevin Seitzer, a third baseman who hit .304 last season for the Kansas City Royals, has signed a one-year contract for $340,000, a raise of $165,000.
Seitzer, 27 years old, is entering his third season with the Royals.
He had 5 homers and 60 runs batted in last year.(AP)

Europe Air System Plan
LEAD: The Association of European Airlines said today that it would study the costs and savings of a single air traffic control system for Western Europe.
The 21-airline group said such a consolidation might help reduce delays and it called on the European Community for help.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation announced improvements to its Application System-400 line of mid-size computers.
I.B.M. announced expansion features for the smallest models of the AS-400 line - the B10 and B20 - and a new B70 that extends the range of the line.
They will be available in June.

Reviews/Opera; Barenboim Conducts Concert Version of 'Tristan'
LEAD: Monday night offered the New York opera lover some glamorous choices.
But those who opted for the concert performance of the second act of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' by the Orchestre de Paris at Avery Fisher Hall picked wrong.
Even with some first-rate singing, this was a most disappointing 75 minutes of music making.

LEAD: After an initial period of sputter and stall, the public indignation of writers, librarians and civil libertarians grew yesterday in response to the death threats against the author Salman Rushdie and the removal of his novel from many bookstores.

A Walking Disaster
LEAD: To The Living Section:


Streak Comes to Ends
LEAD: Valerie Kepner, a junior at Baldwin-Wallace in Berea, Ohio, ended her streak of successful free throws at 69 Monday night, 9 short of Calvin Murphy's National Basketball Association record of 78.
In a game in which Baldwin-Wallace defeated Mount Union, 70-58, Kepner made her first attempt but missed her second one.


Vernon Crudge, 76, Aerospace Consultant
LEAD: Vernon Grant Crudge, an aerospace industry consultant, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 76 years old.

Stray Buffalo Killed in Red Harvest on the Snow
LEAD: At dawn the buffalo moving north along the Yellowstone River are covered with fresh snow, their enormous heads wearing crowns of white.

LEAD: Federal agents and the New York City police seized more than 800 pounds of heroin in Queens late Monday and early yesterday, confiscated $3 million and arrested 19 people linked to a major Southeast Asian heroin network in what the city and Federal authorities said was the largest drug seizure ever in the United


Unwelcome Windshield Washers Are Targets
LEAD: Saying that residents and tourist were being frightened, the Dade County Commission voted today to allow the jailing of anyone who approaches a stopped car to offer to wash its windshield in exchange for money.


Homeless Stir Aid to Neediest
LEAD: The past holiday season was especially troublesome to Herbert and Mercedes Hill of Brooklyn.
Never had they seen so many people in need - sleeping in subways, begging in the streets, living in cardboard boxes behind Macy's.

Catherine M. Conroy, Feminist, 69
LEAD: Catherine M. Conroy, who helped to organize the National Organization for Women, died of cancer Saturday.
She was 69 years old.


Dole and A.F.L.-C.I.O Are Off to a Friendly Start
LEAD: Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the new Labor Secretary, and leaders of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. had the type of cordial meeting here today that they hope will set the tone for their relationship.


New York Landlords Will Get a New Trial
LEAD: Two Manhattan landlords convicted of conspiring to force tenants out of rent-controlled buildings will get a new trial because of a judge's mistake, the Court of Appeals ruled today.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs increased last week by 20, to a total of 766, after plunging the previous week by 34, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago, the count totaled 978.
The rig count is a widely watched industry index of drilling activity and reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.


A Comedy Club Magazine
LEAD: The publishers of a new magazine for the thriving comedy industry know that getting laughs has become a serious business.
Their publication, Laughtrack, aims to capitalize on the tremendous growth of stand-up comedy in recent years - from a handful of dimly lit clubs in Los Angeles and New York to hundreds of clubs and cable television screens across the country.


Tucker Is Looking for a Comeback
LEAD: Not long ago, Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, said that his toughest fight had been against Tony Tucker.


Fewer Students Seek Admission to Top Colleges
LEAD: After several years of record and near-record numbers, freshman applications for next fall's class have declined as much as 18 percent at some Ivy League and other highly selective colleges and universities.
But admissions officers at the next tier of slightly less selective colleges say they are holding their own or reporting increases.


Awards Curbed for Unconscious Patients
LEAD: In two decisions that are likely to have far-reaching effects on personal-injury and malpractice awards, New York State's highest court ruled today that victims cannot be compensated separately for the ''loss of enjoyment of life.''

Corrections
LEAD: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about the Chicago commodities exchanges reversed the average prices of seats.
A seat on the Chicago Board of Trade sells for $405,000, while a seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange sells for $490,000.
The chart also misstated the Board of Trade's average daily volume in 1988.


Birth Control Industry Is Being Transformed
LEAD: The birth control industry has changed radically in recent years.
Research spending is down and the number of companies offering contraceptive products has fallen off sharply, but the field has been lucrative for those that remain.

LEAD: A new park bench made of sturdy plastic sits in the hallway of a research office at Rutgers University here, an ornamental testament to a useful second life for the plastic-foam cup and hamburger box.


Treasury Prices Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed in slow trading yesterday, as market participants shrugged off the dollar's weakness and Congressional testimony by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan.


Claudio Arrau Cancels
LEAD: The pianist Claudio Arrau has canceled his performances with the New York Philharmonic tonight, tomorrow and Friday because of illness.
He is to be replaced by Elisabeth Leonskaja, who is also scheduled to appear with the orchestra in concerts on Saturday and Tuesday.
The program for these concerts remains unchanged.

LEAD: In a surprisingly critical review, the Federal regulator of commodity exchanges said today that the Chicago Board of Trade had done a poor job of detecting fraud and other violations on its trading floor.

LEAD: H. Lyman Stebbins, a retired stockbroker and a prominent Roman Catholic layman, died of emphysema Sunday at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y.
He was 77 years old.

LEAD: George Wojtasik, who has been the producing director of Equity Library Theater for 22 years, announced yesterday that he would leave his position Friday.
He will be succeeded by Jeffrey R. Costello, assistant general manager of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

China Sets Import Curb
LEAD: China has banned cigarette and liquor imports this year to save foreign currency and end abuses in its foreign trade system, official reports said today.
The China Daily quoted the Foreign Economic Relations and Trade Minister, Zheng Tuobin, as also announcing tighter controls on imports of all products that can be made in China and a ban on the reselling of export licenses.

INSIDE
LEAD:  Greenspan Firm on Inflation  Before the Senate Banking Committee, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, suggested that he would keep pushing interest rates up until inflation eased.
Page D1.
Ruling in Obscenity Case  The Supreme Court ruled that First Amendment guarantees bar officials from seizing the inventory of adult bookstores before publications have been found obscene at trial.


Building a Better Mouse
LEAD: If the old saw about building a better mousetrap is true, what happens if you build a better mouse?
Jack S. Hawley, a Berkeley, Calif., inventor, believes he has built just such a device.
In computer jargon, a mouse is a pointing device used with a personal computer.
By sliding the mouse across a desktop, the user controls a cursor on the screen to make selections and issue commands.


SALVADOR REBELS OFFER TO DISARM IF ARMY IS CURBED
LEAD: Salvadoran guerrilla leaders said today that they would lay down their arms permanently and ''incorporate ourselves into the nation's political life'' if the Salvadoran Government made fundamental changes in the military apparatus.


Ernest F. Easterbrook, Retired General, 80
LEAD: Ernest Fred Easterbrook, a retired Army major general who was the son-in-law of Gen.
Joseph Stilwell, died Sunday.
He was 80 years old.
General Easterbrook served in World War II as an infantry instructor of Chinese troops under General Stilwell, the commander of United States forces in China, Burma and India.

On Second Thought, Courage
LEAD: Finally, the tide has turned in the fearful Salman Rushdie affair.
It started out plenty ugly when Ayatollah Khomeini put a price on the head of Mr.
Rushdie, the author.
The initial response to this vengeful lawlessness added the stench of cowardice.
Governments hemmed and hawed.
Booksellers hastened to yank ''The Satanic Verses'' from their shelves.

LEAD: Worlds of Wonder Inc., the toy maker known for its talking Teddy Ruxpin bear, said today that it had agreed to sell operating control of the company to Eli Jacobs, a New York investor, after the bankruptcy court approves its reorganization plan.


New FM System Is Challenged
LEAD: A new method of broadcasting on FM radio that is intended to improve the quality of stereo reception and increase a station's service area is beginning to come into use.
About 50 stations are using a technology called FMX to broadcast their signals and another 50 are committed to altering their transmitters for it.

LEAD: The chief administrative law judge in the New York State division of human rights, who heads the unit reviewing discrimination complaints, was appointed to the job without the divison's knowing he had been charged with ridiculing a homosexual supervisor in a previous job with the Labor Department, state officials said yesterday.

Student Held on Gun Charge
LEAD: A Brooklyn high school student was arrested yesterday after she was found carrying a loaded .32-caliber handgun, the police said.
Shondella Mercer, 17 years old, of 735 Lincoln Avenue, was charged with criminal possession of a weapon, the police said.
She was arrested shortly after 1 P.M. at Paul Robeson High School at 150 Albany Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section.

60-Minute Gourmet
LEAD: IN French cuisine there is a mode of preparing chicken or seafood that is called a la king, although I confess ignorance of which, if any, monarch had a role in popularizing it.
Many believe it to be an American invention that found its way to France, as in chicken or turkey a la king.


S. Carolina Gets Coach
LEAD: Sparky Woods, the football coach at Appalachian State University for the last five years, was named the new head coach at South Carolina yesterday, concluding a search that began about two weeks ago after the sudden death of Joe Morrison.
Woods, 35 years old, had a 38-19-2 record at Appalachian State.


Passengers on Airliine Shuttle Fly High on Calories and Fats
LEAD: SEVERAL years ago when complaints about airline food were at their peak, many suggestions were made on ways to improve its quality.
A simple snack was most often suggested as the alternative to gummy, overcooked, tepid, tasteless food.
What most people envisioned was a sandwich and a piece of fruit or crackers and cheese.

LEAD: Lines were omitted from a letter Feb. 12 by Ethel Dunn on the Russian peasant's diet.

I guess Mr.
Zaychenko doesn't read Jane Brody, who recommends meat servings of three ounces, much less dietary fat and sugar, and emphasis on vegetables, fruits and grains.

LEAD: Tom Flores, former coach of the Los Angeles Raiders, yesterday succeeded Mike McCormack, who was dismissed last month, as the president and general manager of the Seattle Seahawks.

HEALTH: Treatment Advances; Studies Cite Benefits of Chemotherapy in Early Breast Cancer
LEAD: Even breast cancer patients whose cancer has not spread to the lymph nodes could benefit from chemotherapy, four new studies have shown.
The therapy somewhat improves their chances of remaining free of cancer in the years immediately after surgery, although there is no evidence that they ultimately live any longer.

LEAD: INEVITABLY, anyone who meets Scott Strasser, a 34-year-old Dallas designer, tends to gaze quizzically at his hair. ''There's not a hair of the same length,'' Mr.
Strasser explained. ''And it seems to do it all on its own.''

LEAD: In a Manhattan so distant that it cannot be remembered, two players put their markers away after one last round of nine men's morris.
What they left behind, to baffle modern custodians and visitors in the 18th-century Dyckman House, was a mysterious grid - square within square within square - carved into a granite outcropping in the cellar.

LEAD: Exasperated by what they consider inadequate salaries, bureaucratic inertia and outdated equipment, Moscow's air-traffic controllers have resorted to a novel form of strike: instead of refusing to work, they have spent the last two months refusing to collect their pay.
