THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; TV Sports Ads Up 67%
LEAD: Advertising on network television sports broadcasts last year jumped 67 percent over 1987, to a total of nearly $2.7 billion, the Television Bureau of Advertising reported yesterday.
That represented an increase of $1 billion over 1987, and $500 million more than in 1984, the last Olympic year.
The top three network sports advertisers were General Motors, Anheuser-Busch and Philip Morris, the bureau said.

LEAD: Yesterday's editorial ''On Second Thought, Courage,'' about the reaction to Salman Rushdie's novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' referred to an advertisement elsewhere in The Times.
The ad was placed in most but not all editions, however, so the reference mystified some readers.
It was signed by the national associations of publishers, booksellers and librarians, to support the book on the occasion of its formal publication date ''in the spirit of America's commitment to free expression.

Chicago Suburb Bans Pistols
LEAD: Wilmette has become the fourth Chicago suburb to ban the private possession of pistols.
Proponents of the ban said a shooting last year at an elementary school in neighboring Winnetka that left one child dead and five wounded helped bring about the ban.
The suburbs of Oak Park, Morton Grove and Evanston have enacted similar bans.

In Winter Grasses, a Rough Bouquet of Copper and Beige
LEAD: ONLY now, after several months of magnificence, are the tall ornamental grasses in my garden becoming a sorry sight.
It is their season of collapse and meltdown.


Chemical Stock Sale Threat
LEAD: New York City's pension fund is threatening to sell its stock in the Chemical Banking Corporation if the bank helps finance a South African-controlled company's hostile bid for Britain's Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C.


Pretoria to Lift Key Rate
LEAD: The South African central bank said today that it would raise a key interest rate to counter the impact of weak gold prices and a surging money supply.
The Reserve Bank will increase its discount rates, which set the cost of loans to the commercial banks, by one percentage point, to a floor of 16 percent after Thursday.


PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: ''I WANTED to strangle the kid!'' said Walter Simmons, a marriage and family therapist in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., recalling the behavior of a guest at his daughter's sixth birthday party.
Although Mr.
Simmons did not yield to the temptation, his anger and frustration highlight the difficulties that arise when parents consider disciplining other people's children.


Wheat Stockpile Low
LEAD: The United States wheat stockpile is expected to be whittled this spring to one of the smallest since the end of World War II, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
By June 1, the beginning of the 1989-90 wheat marketing year, the inventory may be about 534 million bushels, the smallest since the mid-1970's, the department's Economic Research Service said.


Dow Falls 42.50 in Biggest Drop in 3 Months
LEAD: Stock prices plunged yesterday, for the biggest decline in three months, as the report of a sharp rise in consumer prices added to concern about inflation and interest rates.

Reviews/Music; An Homage, In 18 Minutes, By Bolcom
LEAD: The novelty on Tuesday evening's Philharmonia Virtuosi program at Town Hall was an 18-minute homage to the French suite, by William Bolcom.
It was called ''Orphee Serenade,'' and consisted of six short movements whose titles give, in acrostic, the French name of the mythical singer: Ouverture, Romance, Pas des Bacchantes, Hurluberlu, Elegie, Energique.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, ruling in a child abuse case it described as ''undeniably tragic,'' declared today that the Constitution does not obligate state and local governments to protect their citizens against harm from private individuals.

Kemp Plans Close Encounter With Homelessness
LEAD: In the rain at 1 o'clock this morning the 11 homeless men and women huddled together on the concrete steps of the Federal Reserve Bank here.
They were talking about what they would say to Jack F. Kemp, the new Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, if he stopped there Thursday night on his two-city tour to get a firsthand look at homelessness.


Corrections
LEAD: A caption yesterday, with an article about Salvadoran rebels' conditional offer to disarm, described the picture incorrectly in some copies.
It showed members of Salvador's political parties, not rebel leaders.


Federal Farm Credit Offering
LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Funding Corporation is offering three-month, six-month and one-year bonds totaling $2.849 billion through the corporation itself and through various securities dealers.
All the bonds are priced at par.

LEAD: Gov.
Thomas H. Kean announced today the first major change in his proposals for next year's budget, joining leaders of the Democratic-controlled Senate in a plan to ease the burden of rising property taxes and increase aid to public schools.


HEALTH: Childhood Illness; In Ear Infections, Bacteria Gain on Penicillin
LEAD: Bacteria that cause ear infections in children are becoming increasingly resistant to penicillin, new studies have found.
Although the resistant bacteria respond to other antibiotics, the alternative drugs are much more expensive.

LEAD: More than seven million healthy Americans have spouses who are chronically ill.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time Inc. Workers Call A Fortune Ad Sexist
LEAD: An advertisement for Fortune magazine has touched off a furor among employees of its publisher, Time Inc., who said it was sexist and demeaning toward women.
Employees took issue with the ad, which appeared in The New York Times and The Wall Street Journal on Friday and promoted the cover article in this week's issue of Fortune about tough corporate managers.

LEAD: Cox Enterprises Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell its independent television station here to Better Communications Inc. for an undisclosed sum.

Review/Television; Jonathan Miller's Mafia 'Rigoletto'
LEAD: Jonathan Miller first produced and directed ''Rigoletto'' in 1975.
Instead of placing the action in 16th-century Mantua, as tradition would have it, he moved it up to the 19th century, which he felt would be more compatible with Verdi's score.
Then in 1982, Mr.
Miller went further, transferring the opera to Little Italy in New York City in the 1950's, the world of the godfather and the Mafia.

Padres Name Smith

Blasphemy: Islam's View
LEAD: In Islam, the term blasphemy covers a multitude of sins, including any kind of public insult to the faith, to its founder or to its practices.
Blasphemy is not distinguished from heresy: it has been used to condemn both learned intellectual challenges to Islamic doctrine as well as dramatic statements that outrage the devout.

The Once and Future Kitchenless House
LEAD: TO Charlotte Perkins Gilman, anatomy wasn't destiny.
Space was.
The late-19th-century author and lecturer found the odes to home-sweet-home a bogus morality for not-so-sweet housekeeping.
The private doll's house must fall, she preached.
Neighborhoods must be designed to serve domestic life.
Architecture was the means.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q.The roof over our carport also serves as a deck.
To keep water from dripping through onto the car below, we had the deck covered with tar paper, then a layer of plywood.
The plywood was primed and painted with an oil-based deck paint.
We would now like to cover it with outdoor carpet, but are worried about this causing the plywood to rot.

Court Restudies Issue of Government-Sponsored Christmas Displays
LEAD: The Supreme Court, hearing arguments in a case from Pittsburgh, returned today to the troublesome question of what type of Christmas holiday display the Constitution permits government to sponsor.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Prospering by Selling to the Prosperous
LEAD: THE arrival today of Robin Raj, the award-winning Chiat/Day copywriter, at Doyle Graf Mabley will mean a change of name for the five-year-old New York agency but not a shift in specialty - marketing to the wealthy and the would-be wealthy.


Europe Inflation Threat
LEAD: Rising inflation is threatening the European Community's brisk economic growth, the 12-nation bloc's Executive Commission said today.
The community's economy is expected to grow by about 3 percent a year over the next two years, but the trend is at risk because of several factors, notably higher inflation, the commission said.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Keyes Martin Gaby
LEAD: Keyes Martin Gaby Linett has broken the Jersey barrier - the barrier that has generally prevented New Jersey ad agencies from landing Atlantic City casino accounts.
The shop, based in Springfield, N.J., has become the full-service agency of record for Caesars Atlantic City Hotel/Casino, formerly the province of Wunderman Worldwide.


Met Opera Announces New Season
LEAD: The Metropolitan Opera announced yesterday that it would present five new productions during its 1989-90 season, and three more complete cycles of Wagner's ''Ring des Nibelungen'' at the end of the season.


SUNY Tuition Rise Is Backed
LEAD: Tuition should be increased this year for New Yorkers at the State University if the Legislature adopts Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, the SUNY board chairman, Donald M. Blinken, said today.
Most students could afford a modest increase, he said.
He would not specify the size of the increase, adding that it should be ''as little as possible.


F.B.I. Investigating Threats to Rushdie Publisher and Stores
LEAD: Federal agents are analyzing scores of threats against both the American publisher and some retailers of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' but nothing so far suggests the threats are organized or directed by Iran, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.


Review/Theater; You-Know-What Conquers All Again
LEAD: The freshness of Gerald Freedman's production of ''Love's Labor's Lost'' at the Public Theater extends from John Ezell's verdant setting to the cast, which is filled with talented newcomers.
It is Don Adriano de Armado, the fantastical Spaniard, who suggests that green is ''the color of lovers,'' and by green he means the innocence that accompanies immaturity.


Dow Jones Fills Post
LEAD: Dow Jones &amp; Company announced yesterday that Karen Elliott House, foreign editor of The Wall Street Journal, had been named vice president of the Dow Jones International Group.
The appointment will take effect March 1.
In her new post, Ms.
House, 41 years old, will direct all editors and publishers of The Wall Street Journal/Europe, The Asian Wall Street Journal, The Far Eastern Economic Review, The Asian Wall Street Journal Weekly.


Viacom Cut its Loss in '88
LEAD: Viacom Inc., a communications and entertainment company, said yesterday that domestic syndication of ''The Cosby Show'' increased its revenues in the fourth quarter and helped cut losses sharply.


Cells in the Nose May Offer Clues to Alzheimer's
LEAD: Researchers who studied nine Alzheimer's patients have identified changes in cells in the lining of the nose that they said might eventually lead to a diagnostic test for the disease.

LEAD: James D. Watkins, the Energy Secretary-designate, said today that he was ''aghast'' at the mismanagement and deterioration of the nation's nuclear weapon industry.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: FACING or veneer bricks, which are thinner than ordinary bricks made for structural use, are often applied to walls to achieve the appearance of masonry at a fraction of the cost and effort.
But as with structural brick, working with conventional facing brick is time-consuming and often requires the skills of an experienced mason.

Review/Theater; A Mix of 3 Latin Strands
LEAD: ''Suenos,'' the new Ruth Maleczech-Herschel Garfein musical, draws inspiration from the murals by Eduardo Carrillo that decorate the stage at the Triplex Theater.
The sweeping canvases have a somber, impressionistic quality until we look closely at the figures in the setting.
In one painting, a pack of emaciated dogs stares hollow-eyed - the hounds of war about to destroy their victims.

LEAD: The Cincinnati Reds's owner, Marge Schott, is looking into reports that Pete Rose had been summoned to Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's office apparently because of Rose's gambling.

Redskins Sign Elam
LEAD: The Washington Redskins yesterday signed Onzy Elam, a free-agent linebacker who had been left unprotected by the Jets.
The 6-foot-2-inch, 230-pound Elam, who has been in the National Football League for two seasons, has played primarily on special teams.
He played only two games last season before the Jets put him on their inactive list because of an intestinal virus.

MCI Loses Appeal On U.S. Contract
LEAD: A Government appeals board yesterday dismissed a protest by the MCI Communications Corporation over a multibillion-dollar contract awarded to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to build part of a new Federal telephone system.
The General Services Administration's Board of Contract Appeals ruled that MCI did not have a right to file the protest because it was not a primary bidder.

Trinova Unit Sale
LEAD: The Trinova Corporation, based in Maumee, Ohio, agreed to sell its laminated products unit to Pioneer Plastics Holdings Inc., a company formed by the Raebarn Corporation, a merchant banking concern in Los Angeles.
Terms were not disclosed.
The unit, which serves the furniture, building and construction markets, had sales of $137.3 million in 1988.

LEAD: John Guare, the author of ''The House of Blue Leaves'' and ''Landscape of the Body,'' was not born to write neat plays.
So the good news from the Yale Repertory Theater is that Mr.
Guare has abandoned the sober classical style he lavished on his ''Lydie Breeze'' trilogy during much of this decade and has instead brought forth a completely uninhibited comic mess.

Sponsored by the publisher Four Walls Eight Windows, the event celebrates the publication of the anthology ''And We Sold the Rain: Contemporary Fiction From Central America,'' edited by Rosario Santos.


Pardy to Coach Marist
LEAD: Rick Pardy, an assistant coach at Hamilton College, has been named football coach at Marist College, officials at the Division III school announced yesterday.
Pardy, 27 years old, was also coordinator of recruiting at Hamilton.
Pardy succeeded Mike Malet, who resigned to become assistant athletic director after the 1988 season.


Our Towns; Public Planners: You See Them And Then, Poof!
LEAD: This is a lovely time in history to work for government.
Members of Congress and Federal judges are paid about the same as 25-year-old corporate lawyers, and when a commission recommends a pay increase, the public revolts.
Ronald Reagan started the 1980's chopping away at government, and succeeded in less than a decade at getting even liberal governors to join in.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The Federal Reserve said it stands ready to provide cash to any insolvent savings institution that runs short because of big withdrawals.
The statement, issued by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and M. Danny Wall, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board was intended to calm depositors' fears.


Plain Talk on Planes for Japan
LEAD: During his visit to Tokyo Mr.
Bush has the chance to address an irritation in American-Japanese relations - Japan's decision to develop a fighter plane largely of its own design instead of buying an American plane off the shelf.


Not-So-Ugly Ducks
LEAD: The muscovy duck is no beauty, not with a large crest, red wattles and a wheeze in place of a quack.
It's obese, too, and its feathers have no sheen.
Furthermore, the name that hints of a romantic Russian origin is a snare and a delusion.
The muscovy is so called because of the musk glands in its rump.


Now, Enter The 'Media Adviser,' A New Line Of Defense For The Sophisticated Legal Firm
LEAD: The primers tell lawyers how to deal with the wiliest of adversaries: how to anticipate their strategems, exploit their weaknesses, protect their clients and themselves.
But the enemy they are speaking of is not opposing counsel.
It's the press.


Testing Urged for Airliner Safety Device
LEAD: The technical research agency of Congress took an important step yesterday on a prime aviation safety issue, proposing legislation to require sweeping new in-service tests of anticollision devices before equipping the nation's entire airline fleet with them.

Clae Rosengarten, 89; Founder of Orchestras
LEAD: Clae Rosengarten, a founder of one of the first professional symphony orchestras on Long Island and of the New York Youth Orchestra in Manhattan, died of colon cancer Wednesday at her home.
She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.


General Sees Lack of Panama Policy
LEAD: The commander of American forces in Latin America has charged that the Bush Administration is not prepared to deal with Panama's political crisis because of a policy vacuum in Washington.

LEAD: The National Basketball Association trading deadline passed today without the Nets making a deal.


On Stage
LEAD:  Reno's Fast-Paced Angst


Belgium's Diamonds
LEAD: Belgium consolidated its status as the leading trading center of polished and rough diamonds last year, taking more than half the world's business, the industry said today.
Belgian sales rose 27 percent, to $12.5 billion, in 1988, the Diamond High Council said in its annual report.
Mark Van den Abeelen, the council's director general, said diamond imports had risen 30 percent, to $6.29 billion, and exports, 25 percent, to $6.23 billion.


SKIPPER CONVICTED OVER BOAT PEOPLE
LEAD: A United States Navy court-martial today found Capt.
Alexander G. Balian guilty of dereliction of duty for failing to provide adequate assistance to a group of Vietnamese boat people adrift in the South China Sea last June.


SENATE PANEL VOTES TO DENY RECOMMENDATION OF TOWER AS BUSH'S DEFENSE SECRETARY
LEAD: The Senate Armed Services Committee tonight recommended rejection of John G. Tower's nomination as Secretary of Defense, dealing a stern blow to President Bush and raising serious doubts about whether Mr.
Tower can win confirmation by the full Senate.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Education page on Wednesday about applications for college freshman classes misstated the percentage of early admissions for the incoming class at Reed, in Portland, Ore.
One-third (not two-thirds) of the class of 300 freshmen has already been admitted.

LEAD: Although there have been painters and photographers - Nicholas Nixon, Rosalind Solomon and the group General Idea among those who have exhibited in Manhattan - taking on AIDS as a subject, few artists have concerned themselves with the disease.
Apart from the commercial considerations that no doubt have dissuaded many, some may be unsure how to approach the subject.

John Zorn Takes Over The Town
LEAD: After five months of relaxation in Tokyo, the composer and saxophonist John Zorn has returned to New York.
When he's here, Mr.
Zorn, the most prominent musician to come out of the downtown scene, is ubiquitous.
A performance guerrilla, he hits small clubs and spaces all across the city, improvising with visiting Soviet musicians, playing with his fellow downtown improvisers, working with a repertory group dedicated to the compositions of the jazz pianist Sonny Clark, or with another dedicated to the tunes of Ornette Coleman.


Bally Cancels Plan For Casino Spinoff
LEAD: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation has canceled a proposed restructuring because of opposition by New Jersey gaming officials to a spinoff of its casino-hotel operations.
Bally had announced a plan in October to make its four casinos - two in Atlantic City and two in Nevada - a separate publicly owned company.

Danish Stock Exchange
LEAD: The Copenhagen Stock Exchange held its last ''open outcry'' bond trading session today before giving way to an electronic system.
The new system will make the trading floor redundant by enabling stock and bond dealers to trade through screens and keyboards linked to a central computer without leaving their office.


Fannie Mae Unit To Be Phased Out
LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, will phase out the operations of its Software Systems division, which provides software and hardware to small and medium-sized mortgage lenders, over the next 18 months.
As a result, Fannie Mae said it would take a charge of less than $10 million before taxes against its first-quarter results.

Gluck Opera Rarity In American Premiere
LEAD: ''Telemacco,'' an opera by Christoph Willibald Gluck, will be given its American premiere this weekend by the Pro Arte Chorale.
The work, written to celebrate the second marriage, in 1765, of Joseph II of Austria, is based on the adventures of Ulysses and his son Telemachus and their escape from Circe, the enchantress.

LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe in Quarterfinals: John McEnroe, seeded second, breezed into the quarterfinals of the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament in France yesterday with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Christian Bergstrom of Sweden.
Top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland rallied to defeat Erik Winogradsky of France, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3.


Congress Study Sees Deficit Rising if Gains Tax Is Cut
LEAD: Congressional experts estimated tonight that President Bush's proposal to cut taxes on capital gains would sharply increase the Federal budget deficit instead of reducing it as the Administration asserts.


TV Weekend; Embroidering Chicago in the 1930's
LEAD: This being a ratings sweeps period, the networks are predictably rushing toward the obvious.
Sex is all over the screen, from last week's ''Swimsuit'' (the ads promised: ''When it comes to helping a girl win a swimsuit contest, everyone is willing to pull a few strings'') to this week's ''Naked Lie'' starring Victoria Principal as an assistant district attorney (''In the courtroom, she knows him as a judge; in the bedroom, she knows him as a lover'').

LEAD: The full United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia said today that it would not hear a challenge to the merger of the business operations of Detroit's two daily newspapers.

For Want Of a Thumbtack . . .
LEAD: President Bush's difficulties in filling many of the key positions in his Administration remind me of a far less consequential experience I had when I first started out in politics.


Sandor Weores, a Poet, Dies at 75 in Budapest
LEAD: Sandor Weores, Hungary's leading poet, who had been nominated several times for the Nobel Prize for Literature, died in Budapest on Jan. 22.
He was 75 years old.

Henderson Arrives, Makes Peace
LEAD: At about 9:15 this morning, under a bright sun that was unable to break the daylong chill, Rickey Henderson finally bounced into camp.
He wore sunglasses and a smile, sang to himself as he walked through the parking lot and dressed for his first full day of work with the Yankees.
Late?
He insisted he was early.


Browns Sign Banker
LEAD: The Cleveland Browns announced yesterday that they had signed Ted Banker, a 6-foot-2-inch, 275-pound offensive lineman who started in eight games last season for the Jets, then was left on their unprotected list of free agents.

LEAD: A winter storm warning was announced, alternate-side parking rules were suspended and forecasters assured everyone who would listen that it would be the big one of the season.
But as of 10:30 P.M., no snow had fallen in New York City yesterday.

LEAD: After years of squabbling and foot dragging, the Philadelphia 76ers announced yesterday that Andrew Toney, a two-time Eastern Conference All-Star selection with an average of 15.9 points and 4.2 assists for his eight-season career, had retired.

Review/Music; Beethoven As Heard Back in 1797
LEAD: Beethoven's first four piano sonatas look backward to Haydn's formality and containment and ahead to the symphonic keyboard style of the Romantics.
The performer is caught in between.
Playing these pieces at the Metropolitan Museum of Art last Saturday night, John O'Conor, an Irish pianist, leaned heavily toward this music's past and present, more or less ignoring what its future would be.

Salvador Army Tied to 10 Killings
LEAD: Despite stiff warnings from the United States to respect human rights, elite Salvadoran Army troops raided a guerrilla field hospital and killed five medical workers and five wounded rebels, the Roman Catholic Church said today.

LEAD: An Israeli paratrooper was killed today when he was struck in the head by a concrete block thrown from a building in Nablus, in the West Bank, the army said.

LEAD: The Victoria and Albert Museum, widely viewed as the world's pre-eminent decorative-arts institution, has begun to make basic changes in its management and organization, setting off an uproar in the museum world.

LEAD: President Bush concluded his visit to Tokyo this morning, meeting with other leaders on East-West relations and regional tensions and offering an upbeat assessment of relations with the Far East as he prepared to leave for China.


Your Money; Insurance Benefit: Low-Cost Loans
LEAD: When unexpected bills start to pile up, many financial advisers recommend that hard-pressed families take out a low-cost loan on their life insurance.
Policyholders can borrow against 75 percent to 90 percent of the cash value of a life insurance policy and can even forgo repaying the loan and interest if they are willing to reduce insurance benefits.

Mr.

LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it had given up trying to sell its closed Fairfield auto-parts stamping plant as a continuing business and instead would sell it as a piece of real estate.

Muncie Is Sentenced
LEAD: On Tuesday in San Diego, Chuck Muncie received a two-and-a-half-year Federal prison term for perjury and selling cocaine to an undercover agent.
On Thursday in San Diego, there was an instant replay of sorts for Muncie, a former Charger running back, as he was sentenced to one year in jail for violating probation in connection with his failure to file a 1983 California income tax return after pleading guilty to the charge in 1987.

New York's Needle Exchange Runs Smoothly
LEAD: To the Editor:


Correction
LEAD: Because of an editing error, the meaning of a sentence in an article Feb. 18 by Howard H. Hiatt and Cyrus Levinthal was altered.
The sentence, about when life begins, should have read: ''Since the question of when that occurs cannot now be answered by science or, under our Constitution, by religion, we believe that for abortion decisions in the latter part of pregnancy, the courts should give the states leeway to set guidelines.


Bernard Wiess, Lawyer and Ex-Judge, 85
LEAD: Bernard Wiess, a Sullivan County lawyer for 50 years, died Tuesday at Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y., after a long illness.
He was 85 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

A letter last week from Representative John D. Dingell, chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations of the House Committee on Energy and


Recouple the Long Island Rail Road
LEAD: Having allowed itself to become uncoupled from the rest of New York's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the Long Island Rail Road is fumbling its efforts to build a modern rail car repair shop adjacent to its main line in Hollis, Queens.
The Federal Government, which is paying half the final cost, sternly warns that it may refuse to finance future L.I.R.R.


Devils Lose 5 Straight
LEAD: Desperation is near, if not here, for the Devils.
Their playoff chances suffered a severe setback tonight in a 6-2 loss to the Flyers.


U.S.-Canada Trade Talks Set
LEAD: Canada and the United States are about to begin new trade negotiations after receiving requests from American and Canadian companies to accelerate tariff reductions on more than 50 goods, trade officials say.


If You Own Something, You Should Get a Will
LEAD: Even in today's complex world, many people postpone or neglect making a will because of superstition, lethargy, cost - or because they believe they simply do not have enough property or money to warrant one.


Jacobs Increases Stake in Shaklee
LEAD: Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, raised his stake in the Shaklee Corporation to 14.19 percent.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr.
Jacobs said his group purchased 189,400 additional Shaklee shares Thursday for prices ranging from $35.125 to $35.50 a share.
Shaklee's shares closed today at $35.125, down 12.5 cents.


Teknowledge Sets Cimflex Merger
LEAD: Teknowledge Inc. of Palo Alto, Calif., a pioneering company in artificial intelligence and expert systems, said its merger with the American Cimflex Corporation of Pittsburgh had been approved.
Cimflex is a privately held company specializing in computer-integrated manufacturing and flexible assembly systems.


Review/Theater; A Rising Nazi's Fall As Bad Parades as Good
LEAD: William James once wrote that the difference between a good man and a bad one is the choice of a cause.
John Halder, a mild-mannered professor of German literature, takes up the National Socialist Party.


Bush Urged To Intervene At Eastern
LEAD: In a move that could avert a strike next week, the National Mediation Board has recommended that President Bush appoint an emergency panel to look into a labor dispute at Eastern Airlines, an aide to the President said yesterday.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Bargains in Ski Gear
LEAD:  Sales of ski equipment are early because of meager snow in many areas.
Shops are advertising 20 to 50 percent off.
Shoppers need to be knowledgeable, and also cautious about bargains they don't need or that are not suitable.
Here are some pointers:  Boots  Bring the socks or orthotics that you use while skiing.


9 Lost, 23 Injured as Jet's Skin Rips Over Pacific
LEAD: Part of the outer fuselage of a United Airlines jumbo jet ripped away shortly after takeoff early this morning, sucking out passengers to the darkness of the Pacific Ocean below.


Sponges Luring Divers To Undersea Gold Rush
LEAD: The work is dangerous, and Doru Bogatescu knows nothing about it.
Still, fresh from Manhattan, he paces along the pier, asking anyone who passes to help him become a sponge diver.


A Hole-in-19
LEAD: In an exhibition of ineptitude that would give many an understanding duffer a thrill of recognition, an Australian golf pro, Robert Edmond, took 19 strokes to complete the par-5 first hole in the second round at the Australian Tournament Players Championship at Sydney yesterday and thereby wrote his name into the record book.

Patents; Space Station Structure
LEAD: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration won patent approval this week for part of the structural skeleton of a space station.
The skeleton, which consists of struts connected in a latticework of squares and tetrahedrons, would be outside the station's pressurized housing and would be used to mount monitoring instruments and other equipment.

Health Risks of Used Batteries Prompt Action on Disposal
LEAD: Every year Americans throw away several billion household batteries, sending hundreds of tons of toxic compounds into landfills, incinerators and, ultimately, the environment.
The health risk has not been measured, but pressure is building to force manufacturers to recycle the batteries or to collect them and dispose of them safely.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the Doral Ryder Open golf tournament misstated the rule on changing clubs during a round, as Mac O'Grady planned to do.


Norris Cotton, 88, Former New Hampshire Senator
LEAD: Norris Cotton, who represented his native New Hampshire for 20 years in the United States Senate as one of its staunchest Republicans, died yesterday at his home in Lebanon, N.H.
He was 88 years old.


Boeing Faces Questions on Quality
LEAD: Cases of misrouted wiring and plumbing, along with production delays, have raised concerns among airline officials and aviation analysts about manufacturing problems at the Boeing Company, which has long enjoyed a reputation for superlative quality.

Suitors Are Given Data on Formica
LEAD: The Formica Corporation, which has agreed to be acquired for $18 a share, or $430 million, said that its financial adviser, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., which is a unit of the American Express Company, had given confidential financial information to seven potential bidders.
It added that ''a number of others'' had indicated an interest in signing confidentiality agreements to receive the data.

Virginia Tightening Gun Law
LEAD: The General Assembly passed a bill Thursday that would make Virginia the first state to require instant checkups on buyers of pistols with barrels shorter than 5 inches or assault rifles with ammunition clips of more than 20 rounds.
Gov.
Gerald L. Baliles has said he would sign the bill.
The state police told legislators that a computerized search for records of felony convictions of Virginia residents could be made in the course of a telephone call.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  TENNIS  McEnroe Advances: Second-seeded John McEnroe beat Carl Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2, yesterday to gain the semifinals of the $291,000 Lyon Grand Prix tournament in France.
McEnroe will meet Jonas Svensson, who beat a fellow Swede, Magnus Gustafsson, 6-2, 6-0.
In another quarterfinal, top-seeded Jakob Hlasek of Switzerland defeated Patrick Kuhnen of West Germany, 6-3, 7-6.(AP)

LEAD: Steven Berkoff came into some prominence recently after directing ''Coriolanus'' at Joseph Papp's Public Theater.
But it is not as if Mr.
Berkoff has not been around for a while doing consistently good and often provocative work.
As an actor he offered a shrewd portrait of Hitler on the mini-series ''War and Remembrance.

LEAD: Intensifying its drive to halt rising inflation, the Federal Reserve Board today raised an important lending rate by a half-point, to 7 percent.

Texaco Dividend
LEAD: Texaco Inc. said its board had decided that the first of two special $4 dividends it announced earlier in the year would be paid in cash.
In late January, the company announced that the dividend, which is scheduled to be paid in late June, would be paid in notes.
Texaco said the special dividends are subject to shareholder approval at its annual meeting in May.

Fredrik Schiotz, 87, Lutheran Leader, Dies
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Fredrik Axel Schiotz, a retired president of the American Lutheran Church, died of the effects of a stroke yesterday at Martin Luther Manor in Minneapolis, where he lived.
He was 87 years old.
In 1954, he was elected president of the church, now known as the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, based in Chicago.

How to Take The Curse Off Convention Centers
LEAD: Surely no building type is as disdainful of urban values as the convention center.
Everything about a convention center flies in the face of what cities ought to be.
To make a good one, you need vast amounts of horizontal space, far more than can fit on a single city block.
So most convention centers end up stretching on for block after block, riding roughshod over any streets that are unlucky enough to fall in their path.

LEAD: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.


Do-It-Yourself Customized Software
LEAD: Computer-aided software engineering, or CASE, is a process that is supposed to simplify the creation and maintenance of computer software.
It is just the type of help that is desperately needed by the many large businesses where the problem of maintaining, updating and fixing aging software has reached crisis proportions.


Doorbell Problems
LEAD: WHEN a doorbell malfunctions, the problem is usually easy to diagnose and correct.
Most systems consist of only three main parts and the wiring that links them.
Here is how an ordinary doorbell works: At one or more doors, pushbuttons are attached.
Each of these has a pair of thin wires connected to them.


WEEKENDS: REAL-LIFE FASHION
LEAD: Before the first crocus or daffodil even blooms, city dwellers show their colors in casual clothes based on down-to-earth comfort.
It is a style that at first may appear downright messy, with a mix of tattered old pieces and possibly a new oversize sweater.
But don't be fooled by the frequently disheveled look.


The Sweet and Sour Sounds of South African Jazz
LEAD: The tune ''Black Lightning'' opens ''Voice of Africa, The African Recordings'' (Kaz 101: record and CD, available from NMDS, 500 Broadway, New York, N.Y. 10012), the first of a four-album, eight-record set of South African jazz by the pianist and composer Abdullah Ibrahim (Dollar Brand).
All the elements of South African Township jazz are there: the rolling ostinatos; the traditional African melodies; the gospel-inflected, sweet and sour tinged harmonies; the cotton-soft horn riffs and the relaxed dance beat implying that the world is, for the moment, without problems.


NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Old Orchard Beach, Me.; Fitting the Last Puzzle Piece
LEAD: IN an effort to change the honky-tonk image of this once-vibrant southern Maine seaside community, town leaders, developers and private citizens are planning an ambitious revitalization to attract businesses and residents to the downtown area.


Young New Yorkers Turn Party-Giving Into Parties That Give
LEAD: At some point this winter, maybe while she was striding past a homeless woman asleep on a subway platform, or watching a shivering panhandler near a cash machine, or listening, a bit skeptically, to a clown-costumed fund-raiser on the street, Melissa Mack decided it was time to have a party.


Trends in Taste Come and Go, but There's No Place Like Home
LEAD: A GREAT deal of attention is being paid these days to what is called nostalgia food.
The homey staples of childhood have become chic.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Jan. 1 about Hispanic residents seeking a larger role in government in Perth Amboy described the namesake of MacWilliam Stadium incorrectly.
Joseph Lockwood MacWilliam was an Army lieutenant at the time of his death in 1936, not a World War I hero.


House Calls to Help New York's Elderly Chinese
LEAD: Ka-Lam Pang's world has shrunk to a single narrow room, barely wide enough to accommodate his bed.
Bars set in the wall allow him to swing himself along in his wheelchair to reach the stove or sink when he is alone during the long shifts his wife works in a garment factory.


FOCUS: Enterprise Zones; Turning a Town From Gloom to Boom
LEAD: EVERYONE here remembers September 1984.
They call it ''Black September'' because that was the month that two factories closed, another laid off half its employees and unemployment in this town of 2,100 soared to 18 percent.


Sudan Leader Seeks to End Guerrilla War
LEAD: Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi, apparently yielding ground to the Sudanese military, said today that he wanted to broaden the political base of his Government and seek ''an acceptable peace formula'' to end a war with guerrillas in the south.


The Parks' Wildlife Issue, Again, Is Whether to Interfere
LEAD: AS hungry bison leave the sanctuary of Yellowstone National Park to be slaughtered by hunters in the largest buffalo kill of the century, conservationists are left once again to contemplate the difficulties of maintaining wildlife in a landscape that is, for the most part, no longer wild.


College Prospects Deserve Chance
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:


Bright Outlook For Casinos In 2d Decade
LEAD: THE casino industry here is moving into its second decade with a torrent of revenues and slowly improving profitability.


Nancy Dickerson Is Married
LEAD: Nancy Dickerson, a commentator for Fox Television in Washington, and John C. Whitehead, chairman of AEA Investors Inc., an investment concern in New York, were married yesterday at the bride's home in Washington.
Judge Abner J. Mikva of the United States Court of Appeals in Washington officiated.


Sports of The Times; A Surprise for Boxing's Wild Goose
LEAD: For a boxing promoter, Mickey Duff was trying to be honest.
Upstairs in the Las Vegas Hilton, Frank Bruno was waiting to challenge Mike Tyson last night, but now, in the lobby, the British co-promoter realistically assessed Bruno's opportunity to be the first British boxer to win the world heavyweight championship since Bob Fitzsimmons more than century ago.


LONG ISLAND GUIDE
LEAD:  MARDI GRAS GALA  For about six weeks now, the Long Island State Park Region has been holding a Winter Arts Festival at Bethpage State Park, an event that ends today with what is called a Mardi Gras Gala.


Bridge
LEAD: Computers can play backgammon well enough to beat a world champion and chess well enough to beat everyone except the greatest.
But in bridge they have trouble advancing beyond the beginner stage.
Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star, has offered a million dollars to a computer that can beat him at bridge.

But We Are Free?
LEAD: Salman Rushdie can see no end to the terror called up by the Ayatollah Khomeini.
For the rest of us in the Western world, there is an answer to intolerance and fanaticism.
That is to understand our own values, and accept the responsibility of defending them.


FACE VALUE
LEAD: IN THE COSMETICS industry, a business built on image, simple products are often wrapped in elaborate packaging, given snappy names and big price tags and photographed next to alluring faces.
Implicit in these advertisements is a promise that the product is at least partially responsible for the face, and that the face is something to strive for.


Joan Hirschhorn And David Bright To Marry in June
LEAD: Mr. and Mrs.
Fred Hirschhorn Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Joan Morgenthau Hirschhorn to David Evan Bright, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Alfred S. Bright of Scarsdale, N.Y.
A June wedding is planned.


Arena: Down an Alley Filled With Illusions
LEAD: FROM the beginning of ''Down an Alley Filled With Cats,'' it is clear that the characters are not who they appear to be.


Prospects; As Interest Rates Climb
LEAD: On Thursday, the nation's major banks raised their prime rates to 11.5 percent - the highest level in nearly five years.
Then, on Friday, the Federal Reserve Board raised the discount rate to 7 percent, the highest level since May 1986.
Four experts discuss how higher interest rates affect the economy.


Polish Police Fight Protesters As Solidarity and Regime Talk
LEAD: While the Communist leadership is negotiating with Solidarity, the police cracked down over the weekend on demonstrations and meetings in Cracow and other cities staged by small, independent groups that support the banned union but reject the negotiations.


THE NATION: Life Without Reagan; Conservatives Like Bush, but They're Watching Him
LEAD: WITH President Bush trafficking liberally in liberal oratory about the good things government can do, one might wonder whether conservatives are feeling a bit uneasy.
Certainly Mr.
Bush sometimes seems to mix his signals.
While Vice President Quayle reassured the faithful this weekend that Reagan-era policies were being carried forward, advocates for the homeless, for example, were being promised a change from the last eight years.


'Red Star Over China'
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Curtain Rises On Kelp Lasagna And Chopped Liver
LEAD: Although the current theatrical season has not yet provided much food for thought, it has given considerable thought to food.
On stages all over New York, breakfast, lunch and dinner are being served along with beer, wine, schnapps, tea in a glass and blue tropical drinks with or without tiny umbrellas.


Global-Warming Panel Urges Gas Tax in West
LEAD: Delegates at a conference on global warming have recommended steps to deal with the problem that emphasize the responsibilities of poor as well as rich nations.


THE REGION: A Bill in Suffolk; As the Suburbs Speak More Spanish, English Becomes a Cause
LEAD: AS Latin American immigrants settle in suburbs across the metropolitan area, state and local efforts to help them are coming under attack.
The immediate target is the use of Spanish by public workers and in official forms and pamphlets.
But the underlying issues are far larger.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD:  SPENCE + LILA, by Bobbie Ann Mason. (Perennial/ Harper &amp; Row, $6.95.) In a novel by the author of ''In Country,'' a farmer helps his wife survive a bout with breast cancer.
Bobbie Ann Mason is ''very good at eliciting the special poignancy of people who don't really understand what is happening to them,'' Frank Conroy said here last year.


Miss Steinbreder Wed in Southport To M. A. Luciani
LEAD: At Trinity Episcopal Church in Southport, Conn., Susan Gay Steinbreder, a daughter of Mrs.
Harry J. Steinbreder Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Mr.
Steinbreder, was married yesterday to Michael Angelo Luciani, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Victor A. Luciani of Fairfield.
The Rev.
Francis X. Cheney performed the ceremony.


Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. I am having a constant problem with the sliding wooden doors on my closet.
The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb.
Mine seem to have come off the track, so it is almost impossible to move the doors unless I pick them up.


Tyson Stops Bruno In Fifth
LEAD: Mike Tyson is back - with a vengeance.
Tyson, who had not fought for eight months, was brutally efficient tonight as he took apart Frank Bruno and stopped him at 2 minutes 55 seconds of the fifth round of a scheduled 12-round heavyweight championship bout.


Review/Music; Jerry Hadley in Song Recital
LEAD: Jerry Hadley's tenor sounded in reasonably good health at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night.
We know it mainly as an operatic instrument, but here Mr.
Hadley - an American singer with a substantial international stage career - divided a recital of songs among Brahms, Vaughan Williams, Britten and Rachmaninoff.


AN AMERICAN BOY IN GANGLAND
LEAD:  BILLY BATHGATE  By E. L. Doctorow.  323 pp. New York: Random House. $19.95.


Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West; Create a Devil
LEAD: To the Editor:


Aguirre Leads Piston Victory
LEAD: Mark Aguirre's accomplishments have always been accompanied by controversy.
He spent eight and a half seasons with the Dallas Mavericks, excelling as one of the top small forwards in the National Basketball Association.
He also endured tempestuous relationships with two head coaches.
He was criticized for lack of effort.


With Tears, Griffith Joyner Bows Out
LEAD: For the third time in a week yesterday, Florence Griffith Joyner cried in public.
In all likelihood, it will not happen again for quite a while.


Italy Feels The Pangs Of Drought
LEAD: It dawned gray and dank today, as it often has in the last few months, the skies seeming to promise badly needed rain but whispering fresh disappointment instead.


A Bedroom Farce
LEAD: ONCE again, I was in bed with the Asian flu.
For two weeks, my husband brought me a lovely white Victorian bed tray and served Saltines and cups of soup.
And for a while afterward on weekends, even when I wasn't sick, he would bring coffee up to the bedroom.


PRESIDENT BACKS SOVIET OVERTURES ON TIES TO CHINA
LEAD: President Bush said Saturday that improved relations between Moscow and Beijing could enhance the prospects for peace in Cambodia.


Many Clergymen Quiet in Rushdie Case
LEAD: Few American religious leaders have made their voices heard in the controversy over Salman Rushdie's book ''The Satanic Verses,'' although the debate has raised important issues of religious sensitivity, freedom of conscience and the power of religious authority.

Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about funds to study and clean Long Island Sound misstated Gov.
William A. O'Neill's proposal for the state's Clean Water Fund for the next fiscal year.
Mr.
O'Neill recommended an appropriation of $75 million, not an elimination of $40 million.


Reviews/Music; The Yma Sumac Mystique
LEAD: Yma Sumac, the Peruvian vocal phenomenon, has always fearlessly straddled the line between the sublime and the ridiculous.
In 1950, when ''Voice of the Xtabay,'' her first album of multi-octave mystical warblings, created a sensation, Miss Sumac was already regarded as something of a camp oddity, albeit one who possessed singular gifts.

LEAD: The article, ''The Tough Job of Teaching Ethics'' (Jan. 22), prompted an unusually strong response from readers.
Some of their comments follow.

A LOT HE DIDN'T KNOW ABOUT JAMIE
LEAD:  FATHER AND SON  By Peter Maas.  316 pp. New York:  Simon &amp; Schuster. $18.95.


Pollution Parable
LEAD: ACCORDING TO TOM J. THORDARSON, when the developers of Big Bang Schtroumpfs, the $85 million theme park set to open on May 9 in Metz, France, approached him to create a theatrical extravaganza as an attraction for the new park, they gave him a few parameters.
The show was to be nonverbal, so as to be accessible to all international visitors.


IMAGINE THIS
LEAD: Passers-by, intrigued by the distressed steel facade with ''One Off'' etched in a strange scribble, can look through a peephole for a fisheye glimpse of the architect Ron Arad's gallery and office.
What they see will make them even more curious.
The former storage space is now totally clad in an envelope of metal, with tiny pinpoints of light directed at an array of whimsical metal furniture.


State Workers Center of Labor Talks
LEAD: NEGOTIATORS are preparing for what may become the year of the state government contract.
The state employs more than one-fourth, or 12,400, of the 52,780 unionized employees facing contract negotiations this year in Connecticut.


DEMOCRATS SPENT MOST ON ELECTION
LEAD: Democratic candidates raised more money and spent more than Republicans last year in campaigns for the 101st Congress.


Pirates Hang On to Top Friars
LEAD: With 10 minutes remaining in the first half at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today, Andrew Gaze had 17 points and Providence College 14.
Since Gaze's Seton Hall teammates had supported him with 10 additional points, the situation was grim for the Friars.

LEAD: The Gold Cup Automobile Company is China's pride: a behemoth corporation that embodies China's hopes of transforming its state-owned factories into efficient, market-oriented enterprises.

Such thinking may account in part for the popularity of such ski resorts as Hunter Mountain in the Catskills or Mount Snow in Vermont.
The proximity brings with it bigger crowds, longer lift lines and higher prices.

WHEN SEX WAS ALL THAT MATTERED
LEAD:  EIGHTY-SIXED  By David B. Feinberg.  326 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.


Building Anew in the Yucatan
LEAD: IT is a cruel and sardonic god, the Mayan rain diety Chaac, who rules over the Yucatan Peninsula of Mexico.
Five months ago he unleashed his fury in the form of Hurricane Gilbert, wreaking devastation on the glorious white beaches, coral reefs and hotels and restaurants that have long lured visitors to the resorts of Cancun and the nearby island of Cozumel.


Speaking of the Unspeakable
LEAD: IN 1981, ON THE LAST day of my freshman year in college, I was raped in a park near my dorm.
In this country, nearly three out of every four women could be the victim of a violent crime during their lifetime.
What is unusual in my case is that the rapist is now serving a maximum sentence of 25 years in prison.


State Preparing to Act on Full Landfills
LEAD: THE East Haven landfill was filled to capacity more than two years ago, but the town continues to use it. ''We're in the same boat as a lot of other towns at this point,'' Mayor Robert M. Norman said.


Tufts to Divest All Its South Africa Holdings
LEAD: Tufts University will divest itself of all its holdings in businesses operating in South Africa, university officials announced late today.


3 Women Found Shot, 2 Fatally, in the Bronx
LEAD: A bank clerk and two other women were each found handcuffed and shot in the head in the clerk's Bronx apartment Friday in what the police said yesterday may have been a retaliation killing over drug trafficking.


AT DARTMOUTH THE CLASH OF '89
LEAD: TWO DAYS INTO THIS YEAR, ON JAN. 3, A NEW Hampshire judge ordered Dartmouth College to reinstate two suspended students.
Chris Baldwin, former editor in chief of The Dartmouth Review, and John Sutter, executive editor, were suspended last spring for disorderly conduct, harassment and invasion of privacy.


THE STEINBERG TRIAL
LEAD: In her article ''The Steinberg Trial: Scenes From a Tragedy'' (Jan. 15), Patricia Volk got my quote all wrong.
I said (unaware that it was for attribution) that Hedda Nussbaum was becoming media savvy, dressing smarter, watching her words, trying not to appear despicable.
This came out, ''She's despicable,'' a far cry from the original thought.


Indoor Pollution: Other Views
LEAD: New Jersey doesn't have enough real problems for legislators to address!
We don't need to fix the auto insurance mess.
We don't need to stop the sexual transmission of AIDS.
We don't need to force an independent audit of waste in autonomous authorities.
We don't need real progress in the fight against drugs.


Assembling Brooklyn's Hispanic History
LEAD: The Brooklyn Historical Society, which adopted its new name and changed its focus to emphasize the people who live in the borough now rather than those who originally peopled it, has embarked on an ambitious project to present the first full picture of Brooklynites with Latin roots.


STEVENSON BEATS J.F.K.
LEAD: The Public Schools Athletic League has been having its basketball playoffs for the last two weeks, but the defending champion, Adlai Stevenson of the Bronx, did not play its first game until yesterday at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan.


What to Do When the Taj Mahal Is for Sale for Half the Price
LEAD: BY the time I sell my house, an efficiency apartment will be plenty big enough.
I've been so obsessive and obnoxious, no one is going to want to live with me anyway.
I'm convinced that selling your house is divine retribution for the mortal sin of trading up.

LEAD: THE attention of residents here is focused on a gasoline spill and a separate hazardous-waste spill that are passing through the wells of about two dozen homeowners and businesses.

THE WORLD: Washington Is a Battlefield Again; So Far, El Salvador's Negotiators Are Not Interrupting Their War
LEAD: WHILE Salvadoran political leaders and guerrilla commanders were discussing a rebel peace proposal in Mexico last week, there was a sharp surge in the violence that has once again come to characterize the civil war here.
It demonstrated anew that El Salvador has turned on its head Clausewitz's dictum that war is a continuation of politics by other means.


CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
LEAD: The thrust of Judith Wallerstein's article is that divorce per se is harmful to children.
I am concerned that this focus will distract attention from the more significant issues, which are that dysfunctional families and parents are harmful to children, regardless of marital status.
Ms.
Wallerstein briefly acknowledges that divorce may be a more satisfactory solution to problems than continuing a harmful marriage.


Other Aspects Of Hague's Career
LEAD: I would like to comment on the well-written article on Jan. 8 about Frank Hague, who was Mayor of Jersey City from 1917 to 1947.


Money Becomes More Expensive
LEAD: The cost of money rose last week when the Federal Reserve increased its discount rate to 7 percent, from 6.5 percent, and banks lifted prime lending rates by a half point, to 11.5 percent.
The Fed, which has been nudging short-term rates upward for some time, said it took the action ''in light of inflationary pressures.

Daddy's Little Girl, Up to Date
LEAD: FOR some of us who emerged from college in the 60's and married young, the meaning of fatherhood has shifted dramatically as the women's movement and changing family structures led to new opportunities and new challenges.


Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
LEAD: Yes, he called his shot, though the Babe himself reportedly denied it.
But this legend has a twist.
Rather than guaranteeing the monstrous trajectory over the right-center-field wall of his next four-bagger off Charlie Root in the third inning of Game 3 of the 1932 World Series at Wrigley Field, Ruth might just as plausibly have been pointing to the downtown saloon where he would be celebrating the day's 7-5 victory.


Time for a Public Broadcasting Overhaul
LEAD: Public broadcasting is broke, and it ought to be fixed.
Viewers and listeners have been saying that for years - they want more and better programs for their money.
Yet, this important institution lumbers on, unable to rise to its full potential because of the way it was set up in the first place.
The question is, how do you fix it?


Magic Returns
LEAD: The two-time defending N.B.A. champion Los Angeles Lakers got their Magic back Friday night after he was sidelined for five games by a partially torn hamstring.
The Lakers went 3-2 without him, but they dominated the Sacramento Kings, 115-103.


It's Farce - So Please Do Slam the Door
LEAD: To hear the director Jerry Zaks tell it, farce is the most dangerous, treacherous, dead-earnest business there is.
If you don't have a door to hide behind, you're a goner.


And Now Pitching for Cuba: Castro; Batting for Reds: Rose
LEAD: After finishing second for four successive seasons, Pete Rose would like to finish first this year.
But after his team finishes first, he has another desire.
If he fulfills that one, it would result in a meeting of the managers of the two largest contingents of Reds in the Westen Hemisphere.


About Cars; A Fan and Vintage Wheels
LEAD: It is late at night, and I have been talking to friends.
As happens, the conversation turned to automobiles, and I started to hold forth on the cars I have always wanted and never had.
They are a strange mix, and they say something of who I am - which is one of the important things that cars are supposed to do.

But not irreparable.

The plastic wheels are supposed to slide along in a metal track fastened to the top of the door jamb.

Cowboys' Buyer Hires a New Coach
LEAD: Tom Landry's career as the only coach the Dallas Cowboys had in 29 years ended tonight when an Arkansas oilman bought the team and made the University of Miami's Jimmy Johnson the coach.


Switzerland
LEAD: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's article ''In Switzerland Train Stations Are for Eating'' (Travel, Jan. 8) brought back memories.
On our annual trip to our summer house at Les Avants, we left Berlin on the 4 P.M. train and arrived in Basel at 7 A.M.
A change of trains left us one hour, and our first stop was the station restaurant, for breakfast.

LEAD: Lack of progress in the dialogue between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization, which started in December, is causing disappointment among guerrilla leaders and contributing to a widening rift among them.

Chess
LEAD: What is the right time limit for international chess?

Doorbell Problems
LEAD: WHEN a doorbell malfunctions, the problem is usually easy to diagnose and correct.
Most systems consist of only three main parts and the wiring that links them.
Here is how an ordinary doorbell works: At one or more doors, pushbuttons are attached.
Each of these has a pair of thin wires connected to them.

Every inch of the Academy's stately spaces is filled.
Even the doorways have been redesigned in a handsome, if slightly authoritarian, manner.
The Academy's exemplary retail outlet for art books and artists' materials has been mated with an Italianate cornucopia in which Italian herbs, Italian cookies and Italian olive oil all have their place.

LEAD: The teachings of Vajradhatu, a branch of Tibetan Buddhism with 3,500 to 5,000 followers in the United States, Canada and Europe, do not prohibit homosexuality or sex with more than one partner.
But the religious group has been shaken over accusations that its leader, Osel Tendzin, regent of the Vajradhatu International Buddhist Church, knew he had AIDS and transmitted it to his sexual partners.

Changes Loom for Home Equity Loans
LEAD: Because of the changes brought by tax revision, the home equity loan has been one of the hottest banking products for the last couple of years.
Now, new changes in Federal law are likely to reshape the market for these loans.
While many of the changes are designed to bolster legal protections for borrowers, they are also likely to make the loans less readily available and more costly, banking experts say.


Newsletters That Point the Way in Different Ways
LEAD: TRAVEL newsletters are a growth business, not surprising considering that the tourism industry, now the No. 3 industry in the country (after food and autos), is predicted by the Commerce Department to be in first place by the turn of the century.
Add to that the reality that a home computer enables almost anyone who can type a letter to be a publisher, and you have a decade in which newsletters have popped up with regularity, although they have often dropped off within months.

Election's Weight
LEAD: Special elections to fill vacancies in state legislatures seldom turn heads, but the one last weekend in an affluent, nearly all-white suburb of New Orleans had heads shaking across the country.
With a huge turnout of 78 percent of the electorate, David Duke, a former grand wizard of the Ku Klux Klan running under the Republican banner, won the legislative seat in Metairie by 234 votes out of the 16,688 cast.

Praised most recently for his biography of Tolstoy, he now deserves applause for this witty and tender, delightfully written and perceptive novel.
Its hero is the orphaned Julian Ramsay, brought up, cared for if not absolutely loved, by his aunt and uncle in an English vicarage.

In Borneo's Wilds, Legend Takes Root
LEAD: ''I'm a romantic,'' says John Milius.
He is standing on a cliff in Sarawak, above the Borneo jungle, fitting a stone to a slingshot that the Malays call ''pana'' and his Iban extras call ''la stika.'' The black-bearded writer-director of ''Farewell to the King,'' which opens on Friday at Loews Astor Plaza and 84th Street Six, is competing with his star, Nick Nolte, in trying to hit the tallest tree jutting up through a cloak of jungle fog whose milky opacity will keep Mr.


Mergers Raise Fear for Angel Network
LEAD: FEARS about the consequences of corporate mergers and buyouts extend beyond the business community.
Priscilla H. Blum and Jay N. Weinberg, for example, who founded the Corporate Angel Network, worry about the consolidation of corporate fleets.
Their nonprofit organization relies on those aircraft to transport about 60 cancer patients a month to major cancer centers across the nation.

LEAD: President Bush and John G. Tower began a public relations effort today to salvage Mr.
Tower's nomination as Defense Secretary.
Meanwhile, White House aides hastily drafted a summary of a dozen findings by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in an attempt to show that allegations about Mr.
Tower's drinking and personal life were unfounded.


'Jerry's Girls,' Revue, in East Windsor
LEAD: AS new musicals fade and newly available ones fail, ''Jerry's Girls'' is just the sort of melange to keep a dinner theater going.


Fake Art
LEAD: To the Editor: William Warren's article ''In Thailand, Faking Art Is an Art in Itself'' (Travel, Dec. 12) well reported on the buyer-beware situation in Thailand.
My wife and I spent five years in Thailand (1982-87) with the American Embassy and, since she was both an artist and an inveterate collector, antique shops became well known to us.

And when he was done, the 31-year-old pitcher said, ''I've answered the question in my mind.

New Jersey Q &amp; A: Dennis Foy; Testing the Limits of Traditional Cuisine
LEAD: FROM the time he was 14 years old, Dennis Foy knew he wanted to be a chef.
A native of Philadelphia, he went from busing tables in a small northern Italian restaurant there to an apprenticeship in a restaurant that was owned by his brother, John.
Dennis Foy moved to Summit in 1974, where he still lives.


Aboard Flight 811: Passengers' Routine Dissolves Into Terror
LEAD: Laura Falci of Chicago was already asleep in seat 24A when United Airlines Flight 811 took off for New Zealand early Friday, her hair falling over her black double-breasted jacket.
Like most airline passengers, she never paid much attention when the flight attendants went through all those instructions about how to adjust oxygen masks in an emergency.

CHILDREN AFTER DIVORCE
LEAD: I am from a small town in central Vermont.
My parents divorced when I was 10 or 11.
One sunny spring afternoon, my brother and I were sitting atop a hill near our home.
We were waiting for my best friend to walk from his house to ours.
He was to stay in our house for an entire week, while his parents were on vacation.

As Viewers Wander, the Networks Scurry After
LEAD: The first thing you notice in Lee Currlin's office at NBC's New York headquarters is the huge magnetic board that overwhelms one corner of the room.
Thin colored strips with the titles of television shows are stuck to it alongside numbers signifying different time slots.
At the far left side of the big board are clusters of strips in jagged disarray, as if they are captured pieces in a chess game.

Around The Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Keep up with seed planting, especially flowers such as impatiens, begonias, petunias and blue salvia, which need a head start indoors; wait a few weeks to plant indoors seed of vegetables such as peppers, eggplants and tomatoes.
Tubers of begonias and caladiums can be started indoors, too, to form roots; use a mixture rich with peat moss so it retains moisture.


Officer Convicted in Marine's Death
LEAD: The only officer charged as a result of the death of a Marine corporal abandoned in the Mojave Desert last August has been found guilty of dereliction of duty and sentenced to discharge and four months in jail.

Donors to Neediest Cases Fund Celebrate Their Good Fortune
LEAD: ''This year we are celebrating life,'' Denise Tredwell of Brewster, N.Y., wrote in a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
A year ago her 8-year-old son was suffering from a paralysis that had been diagnosed as a symptom of a terminal form of cancer.
Now he is regaining his strength and spirit and using a walker, she wrote, sending a donation of $100 ''to brighten the life of a small child.

Question Of the Week; Did Babe Ruth Call His Shot?
LEAD: Of course Babe Ruth called his shot.
And the bat he used was carved from a log which was part of the log cabin Abe Lincoln was born in.
And that log came from a tree chopped down many years before by George Washington.
RICHARD T. POTTER, Jr.
Ridgewood, N.J.

Canadian Program Could Help Sick Americans Obtain Experimental Drugs
LEAD: The Canadian Government has sent out notices to every doctor in Canada that it will allow patients with life-threatening diseases to obtain any drugs companies are willing to sell, even if no country has approved the drugs for marketing.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Palm Beach
LEAD: Palm Beach, the jewel of the American Riviera since the end of the 19th century, is valiantly resisting the coming of the 21st.
The Old World sophistication that made the island distinctive is threatened by a booming mainland population.


The Shout From Central America; Here: Migrants and the Need for Safe Haven
LEAD: The long lines of undocumented aliens applying for political asylum at an immigration office on the border in south Texas attest to the reverberating effect of United States policies in Central America.
So many Central American aliens have applied for asylum in recent months that immigration officials have finally felt compelled to devise a get-tough policy to deter other migrants, trying to escape poverty, not persecution.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Feb. 12 about efforts to negotiate a chemical weapons treaty referred incorrectly to a guilty plea by Alcolac International, a Baltimore chemical company.
In a case resulting from its sale of thiodiglycol to a German company, Alcolac acknowledged that it had ''knowledge or reason to know'' that Singapore, the destination listed on the shipper's export declaration, was not the ultimate one.


Iran Election Set for August; Test Between Factions Seen
LEAD: Iran will hold presidential elections in August, the Islamic Republic News Agency reported today.


Rushdie Novel Stirs Passions East and West
LEAD: To the Editor:


America's Backyard Is Rich With Oil
LEAD: In the aftermath of the 1973 oil embargo, the Federal Energy Administration published its Project Independence report.
Energy self-sufficiency for the United States was ruled out as an impractical goal.
Instead, the report adopted the more modest objective of reducing our vulnerability to oil import disruptions.


Numismatics
LEAD: Of the 637 Spanish silver pieces from the salvaged ship H.M.S.
Feversham in the recent auction at Christie's, 319 were from the mint at Potosi in Bolivia.
The auction coins ranged from the one real to the eight real ''piece of eight.'' Millions were minted and they were the standard coin of trade in the American colonies.


Brazil Indians Meet on Protecting Amazon
LEAD: Environmentalists are hailing a Brazilian Indian meeting that united former enemy tribes as a landmark event in the campaign to save the Amazon rain forests.


PERSPECTIVES: Business Parks; 'Master Developer' Sought for a Frontier
LEAD: IF New York City can be said to have an unsettled frontier, it surely is in the flat outer reaches of western Staten Island, inland from the Arthur Kill, the waterway between Staten Island and New Jersey.

Heinz Goes It Alone in Zimbabwe
LEAD: When the H. J. Heinz Company signed a deal in 1982 for a majority holding in a successful family-owned oil and soap business here, it was the first major American company to invest in the post-independence era.
At the time the Zimbabwe Government said it hoped the deal would act as a magnet for other foreign investment.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Big Hit for Boggs in Court
LEAD: An appeals court has thrown out a key portion of a $12 million lawsuit against Wade Boggs, ruling the former girlfriend of Boston Red Sox slugger cannot sue him for emotional distress, Boggs's attorney, Jennifer King, said today.


Koor Granted Delay on Debt
LEAD: Koor Industries, Israel's biggest company, has won a seven-week reprieve from an American bank that had threatened to break up the company for failure to repay a $20 million loan.
Koor's chief executive, Benny Gaon, said Bankers Trust had agreed to withdraw its liquidation suit while Koor, the Israeli Government, Israeli banks and the Histadrut trade federation, which owns the company, work out a recovery program.


Finance Shift For Britain
LEAD: The British Department of Trade and Industry today dismissed as speculation news reports that it was about to issue new amendments to Britain's Financial Services Act.

Packers Sign Ard to a 2-Year Contract
LEAD: Since the middle of his rookie season in 1981, Billy Ard has started at offensive guard for the Giants.
Yesterday, he left the Giants and signed a two-year, $800,000 free-agent contract with the Green Bay Packers.

LEAD: Roy Eldridge, the jazz trumpeter who was the connecting link in the line that went from the pioneering Louis Armstrong to the modernist innovator Dizzy Gillespie, played with a crackling intensity that set him apart from all his contemporaries.

U.S. Progress in Energy Efficiency Is Halting
LEAD: Energy efficiency in the United States has stopped growing, Government statistics show, ending a powerful trend dating from the energy crisis of the early 1970's.

LEAD: Mik Kilgore, a freshman, made seven 3-pointers in scoring 33 points as Temple beat No. 11 West Virginia by 74-56 tonight, ending the longest major-college basketball winning streak at 22 games.

LEAD: After growing into a $20 billion industry by capitalizing on dreams of instant wealth, state lotteries trying to improve business have turned to another popular American fantasy: competing on television game shows.

LEAD: In a harsh rebuke to the growing enthusiasm here for more democracy, China on Sunday prevented the country's best-known dissident, Fang Lizhi, from attending a banquet to which he had been invited by President Bush.

Bridge
LEAD: In club duplicate games, there is a tendency for the better players to win regularly, a discouraging fact for those not in that category.
One solution that should be adopted more often is to handicap the players, as is customary in golf.

Review/Music; A Blues Guitarist Takes Off
LEAD: Greenwich House, where the young Chicago-based blues guitarist Melvin Taylor performed to a full house on Saturday night at a concert produced by Jazztrack, takes some work to be transformed into a roadhouse.
Mr.
Taylor did it in a few minutes at most; standing still most of the time and looking a bit like an off-duty accountant, he turned the audience into a shouting crowd who'd cheer his every solo and give him a standing ovation when he deserved it.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; JWT Wins Eyelab
LEAD: J. Walter Thompson, New York, has been awarded the advertising and direct marketing account for Eyelab, a chain of optical stores.
The account is valued at $12 million, said Mary Churchill, a spokeswoman for JWT, and will include print and television ads.
JWT won the account after a four-month review process involving seven agencies, including Liggett-Stashower, a Cleveland agency that had held the account.

LEAD: On Friday, the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service detention center on Varick Street in lower Manhattan housed 180 aliens.
None have been held there longer than Lyonel Dor.

Skateboarding On Snow
LEAD: The snowboard has come closest to duplicating the sensation of skateboarding.
But now Sno-Tek, a company based in Costa Mesa, Calif., has come up with a board for snow that more closely resembles a skateboard.
Marketed as the Snowster, the board is mounted on dual sleds instead of wheels.
The sleds, each 12 inches wide, are attached to the 2-foot board by heavy-guage aluminum truck assemblies.

Bad Economics, Worse Politics
LEAD: Inflation indicators point upward.
The Federal Reserve responds by raising interest rates.
The stock market goes down, among other unfavorable economic signs.
Yet the Bush Administration continues to act as though the economy will hold and even grow, as it did during the Reagan years.
President Bush cannot count on that kind of luck, and wishful thinking is no way to shape policy for an uncertain economy.

LEAD: Dr.
Wilhelm Z. Stern, director of radiology at North Central Bronx Hospital, died of cancer Saturday at Montefiore Hospital.

Argentina Seeking Aid
LEAD: Argentina will ask the International Monetary Fund for a $300 million credit to help it meet arrears in service payments on its $60 billion foreign debt, Economy Ministry sources said today.
Creditors have threatened to raise Argentina's financial risk level because of the arrears, which are estimated at $2.5 billion.

LEAD: An off-duty correction officer who shot and killed a grocery store owner in the Bronx Saturday night remained on active duty yesterday after a preliminary investigation found he apparently acted in self-defense, a spokeswoman for the New York City Department of Correction said.

French Inflation Rises
LEAD: French inflation accelerated to a 3.3 percent annual rate in January, fueled by higher prices for energy, rents and television licenses, the statistics office said today.
The office said consumer prices in January rose four-tenths of 1 percent, pushing the rate for the last 12 months to 3.3 percent, from 3.1 percent in December.

Vital Gas for Nuclear Weapons Lies Untapped at Reactor Sites
LEAD: THE Federal Government has a large supply of the perishable gas tritium that it cannot use because it decided years ago not to build a separation plant to extract it.
The amount, worth $56 million, is enough to replenish thousands of nuclear weapons now that traditional supplies of the vital weapons fuel are growing scarce.


For Landry, Unkindest Cut of All
LEAD: In pro football, the cut hangs over everybody's helmet or headset like a guillotine.
Even adequate players know that sooner or later they will be cut from the roster.
Sometimes great players are told to retire to avert the embarrassment of being released, but they know they've been cut.
And coaches, good and bad, are let go depending on their won-lost record or a club owner's whim.

Ewing Is Honored
LEAD: Patrick Ewing, who averaged 29.8 points, 7.8 rebounds and 4.50 blocked shots in leading the Knicks to three victories in four games, has been selected the National Basketball Association player for the week for the period ending Sunday.
Ewing had a career-high 45 points last Friday night. ''I hope this paves the way for most valuable player consideration,'' Ewing said.


Seaver Joining Broadcast Teams
LEAD: Tom Seaver, who took two years off to tend his garden and learn what raising a family was like, has returned to baseball at the age of 44.
The 300-game winner will double up this coming season, working for NBC on its network games and being one of two replacements for Bill White as a Yankee broadcaster over WPIX (Channel 11) in New York.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors are considering new charges, including perjury and obstruction of justice, against Norby Walters, the former sports agent accused of signing college athletes and then threatening them if they backed out of agreements, District Attorney Anton Valukas said in Chicago yesterday.
Walters and Lloyd Bloom are facing racketeering, wire fraud, mail fraud and extortion charges in a trial scheduled to start Wednesday in Chicago.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Q. There seem to be no pigeons in the countryside, only in cities.
Why?
A.
Pigeons, or rock doves, are actually fairly common in agricultural areas.
There they find niches in barns and lofts that resemble the rocky ledges that are their natural nesting sites as well as plentiful supplies of their favorite food, small grains.


Columbia-Presbyterian Celebrates Opening of New Building
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about a party celebrating a new Presbyterian Hospital building identified the people shown in an incorrect order in some copies.
From the left were Charles D. Peebler Jr., Jean Clark, Toni Peebler, Howard Clark, Jackie Morris and Dr.
Thomas Q. Morris.

Fed Names Top Lawyer
LEAD: The Federal Reserve said today that James V. Mattingly Jr. had been appointed general counsel.
The 44-year-old Mr.
Mattingly, currently deputy general counsel, has been on the Fed's staff since 1974.
He replaces Michael Bradfield, who resigned to return to private law practice.


Sudan Chief Rides Out Storm
LEAD: The Prime Minister of the Sudan appeared today to have won another reprieve for his leadership by stalling on demands by the military that he broaden his Government and end the civil war.

LEAD: Ben Johnson's track coach will tell a crowded hearing room Tuesday his version of what was behind one of the most sensational scandals in sports history.
