LEAD: To the Editor:


U.S. Team Selected
LEAD: Four defending champions were among the 23 men and 16 women named yesterday to represent the United States in the world indoor track and field championships Friday through Sunday in Budapest.
The Americans who will defend titles won in 1987 are Antonio McKay in the 400-meter dash, Tonie Campbell in the 60-meter hurdles, Larry Myricks in the long jump and Mike Conley in the triple jump.


Novel Theory Challenges The Big Bang
LEAD: THE Big Bang theory, generally regarded as the best explanation for the origin, expansion and ultimate fate of the universe, is facing the first serious challenge to its validity in more than two decades.


Addict Guilty in Crack Rampage Killing
LEAD: A jury in Manhattan quickly convicted an 18-year-old man of two counts of second-degree murder yesterday for the slaying of an East Harlem bodega owner in what the police said was a cocaine-inspired rampage that left five people dead and six others wounded last year.

Milton W. Hamilton, 87, Colonial Historian
LEAD: Milton Wheaton Hamilton, an authority on New York Colonial history, died Sunday at the home of his daughter, Gwendolyn Stevens of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., after a brief illness.
He was 87 years old and lived with his daughter.

General Dynamics Contract to Smiths
LEAD: Smiths Industries said it had been chosen by the General Dynamics Corporation to provide the navigation system for use on the United States Army's main battle tank, the Abrams M1A2.
Smiths said production of its POS/NAV navigation system for this and other uses is expected to generate orders worth about $200 million in the next five years.

LEAD: A 14-year-old boy suffered second-degree burns on his neck, face and hands yesterday afternoon when a 55-gallon drum resting atop burning leaves in a Harlem park exploded.

LEAD: Lane Kirkland, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., protests that an editorial on Friday wrongly characterized his position on the labor dispute at Eastern Airlines.
The editorial, drawing from published news reports, said he had warned, if there should be a strike against Eastern, of widespread disruption in the transportation industry, including moves against railroads.

Pacific Bell Settlement
LEAD: Pacific Bell, the California telephone operating company, said today that it had agreed to settle a $700 million rate reduction proposed by the California Public Utilities Commission's Division of Ratepayer Advocates in August 1988.
The proposed settlement, which came as a result of the division's audit of Pacific Bell's investment practices, calls for Pacific Bell to reduce future rates by $144 million over four years.


After 8 Years, a Dip in Families in Shelters
LEAD: The number of homeless families sheltered by New York City decreased by 500 last year to 4,637, social service officials said yesterday.


Rig Count Dips in Week
LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs fell last week by nine, to a total of 757, Baker Hughes Inc. reported.
A year ago, the count was 983, the company said.

LEAD: President Bush had an embarrassingly conspicuous front-row seat here Sunday to a spectacle that may have been inspired by a new theory that has come to be known as ''new authoritarianism.''

LEAD: The head trader of a major West Coast brokerage testified yesterday in the GAF Corporation's stock manipulation trial that he executed a series of stock purchases in the fall of 1986 to inflate the price of Union Carbide stock.


Israeli Stabbed in West Bank
LEAD: An Israeli policeman was stabbed by a Palestinian teen-ager today during a patrol in the West Bank, the army said.
It was the third attack on an Israeli in 10 days.
Also today, a group called the Palestinian Arab Army said it had seized a soldier who has been missing for 12 days.

LEAD: A particularly virulent strain of meningitis has reached epidemic proportions in Ethiopia, killing as many as 10,000 people in one region, aid workers in Addis Ababa said today.

ABC Names Producer Of a News Program
LEAD: ABC News announced yesterday that Phyllis McGrady has been appointed executive producer of its new prime-time news program to be anchored by Diane Sawyer and Sam Donaldson.
Ms.
McGrady, who had been executive producer of the ''Barbara Walters Specials'' at ABC, is to oversee development and production.


When an Exotic Virus Strikes: A Deadly Case of Lassa Fever
LEAD: A RESIDENT of a Chicago suburb died two weeks ago from a rare African viral disease that he caught after flying to the funerals of his parents in Nigeria.
It was the first case of Lassa fever in the United States in more than a decade and only the third since the dramatic discovery of the deadly virus that causes it in 1969.

LEAD: Hungary accused Rumania today of violating the rights of its Hungarian minority and urged a United Nations investigation.

Fleet/Norstar
LEAD: Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. tapped the debt market yesterday with a $100 million issue of 10 1/4 percent notes due 1992 at a price of 99.875, to yield 10.30 percent, through Salomon Brothers Inc.
At pricing the notes were yielding about 78 basis points more than the three-year Treasury note.

LEAD: Responding to a flood of consumer complaints, the Federal Communications Commission set new guidelines yesterday for five telephone companies that have been shown to charge very high rates to consumers for long-distance calls made from hotels, hospitals, universities and some pay telephones.

LEAD: Vietnam has rewritten the preamble of its Constitution to remove all accusations of aggression and imperialism by the United States, China, France and Japan.


Sun Microsystems Shares to A.T.&amp;T.
LEAD: Sun Microsystems Inc. said it would issue about 3.2 million more shares of its common stock to the American Telephone and Telegraph Company for about $79.1 million.
The sale comes under the terms of a January 1988 agreement under which Sun can sell to A.T.&amp;T., at Sun's option, newly issued shares equal to 15 percent of its total outstanding common shares.

U.S. Bill Rates Set 4-Year High
LEAD: Treasury bill rates soared yesterday to their highest level in four years, reflecting recent moves by the Federal Reserve to push up the cost of borrowing.
By tightening credit, the Fed hopes to arrest what it perceives to be accelerating inflation.

LEAD: The nation's economy is expected to slow significantly this year, but the chances of a recession in the next two years have eased slightly, according to a poll of economists issued today.


Delay by Enserch
LEAD: The Enserch Corporation, based in Dallas, said it was delaying its previously announced shareholder-rights offering of its Pool Energy Service Company subsidiary to allow for talks with a potential buyer.
The price of the offering was to have been set today.
Under the tentative arrangements being discussed, Enserch said, the company would eliminate several contingent financial commitments required under the proposed public offering.

Cayton Asks Action Against King
LEAD: Bill Cayton, the embattled manager of Mike Tyson, asked the New York State Athletic Commission today to take action against the promoter Don King for interfering with Cayton's contractual relationship with the heavyweight champion.


Woman Gets Term in Raiders' Fatal Shooting
LEAD: A 23-year-old woman was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison on a gun charge stemming from a drug raid at her apartment in Manhattan in which a police officer shot and killed another officer.


Reviews/Television; Relearning Fatherhood, In 'Coach'
LEAD: Proceeding on the not unreasonable assumption that plot logic is hardly a priority among sitcom fans, ABC is launching its new series ''Coach'' almost brazenly out of sequence.
Tonight's ''preview,'' at 9:30, shows a college football coach, Hayden Fox (Craig T. Nelson), desperately trying to become a good father when his daughter, Kelly (Clare Carey), newly enrolled at the college, announces she has a date with an older member of the faculty.

LEAD:  International A3-15


Reviews/Television; Lower Life Among the Cutthroats
LEAD: ''Harry's Kingdom,'' produced by Richard Broke for the BBC, enters the competitive world of salesmen and decimates it.
Written by Ron Pearson and directed by Robert Young, the film can be seen on cable tonight at 9 and tomorrow morning at 1 A.M. on the Arts &amp; Entertainment Network.


BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  COMPANIES  An investigation of industrial espionage culminated in a Geneva parking lot when four people were arrested after they attempted to extort $10 million from Du Pont, law-enforcement and company officials said.
The case involved some of Du Pont's most important secrets for the production of Lycra, the company's brand of spandex fiber.

LEAD: John G. Tower apparently failed to win new supporters among Senate Democrats today with his pledge not to drink if confirmed as Defense Secretary, and his Republican backers conceded that renewed concerns about his financial ties to military contractors raised an additional threat to the nomination.


Japan and U.S. to Change Part of Chip Agreement
LEAD: The United States and Japan today signaled for the first time that they would alter a component of their 30-month computer chip agreement to try to make it conform to international trade rules.

Washington Talk: Senate; Bradley's Covert Effort To Become Panel Chief
LEAD: After four years of serving on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence and hearing about the Government's most confidential operations, Senator Bill Bradley began a covert action of his own late last year: He tried to wrest the committee chairmanship from Senator David L. Boren.


One More Event
LEAD: Marty Stern, the women's track coach at Villanova, wanted the Penn Relays to add a women's 6,000-meter relay because he thought his team could run the fastest time ever.
Tim Baker, the meet director, said he did not want a one-sided race.
So Stern persuaded such women's track powers as Oregon, Oklahoma State and Wisconsin to enter the April 27-29 meet in Philadelphia and run against Villanova in the 3,200-meter and 6,000-meter relays and the distance medley.


N.Y.R.A. Sets Higher Purses
LEAD: Purses at New York Racing Association tracks will be increased by 15 percent, effective with racing tomorrow, the association announced yesterday.





Gamma Ray Bursts
LEAD: Orbiting astronomical satellites occasionally detect puzzling bursts of gamma rays from points in the sky.
The several hundred bursts observed during the past decade have ranged in duration from less than one-hundredth of a second to about 18 minutes, and most have been seen only once.


Arvin Industries Sues Indonesian Executive
LEAD: Arvin Industries, a leading automobile parts producer and military contractor, has sued an Indonesian industrialist, accusing him of manipulating the market for Arvin stock by making ''misleading, false and incomplete disclosures'' of his plans and purposes.


Open Positions on Short Sales Are Up by 1.6% on Nasdaq
LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 1.6 percent monthly increase in short interest for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.


Diamond Coatings Grown on Silicon Chips
LEAD: A TEAM of American and Israeli scientists has discovered a way to grow diamond coatings on silicon wafers, a process they said may lead to a powerful new generation of computer chips.


No Coastal Bid
LEAD: The Coastal Corporation said it would not raise its $42-a-share cash tender offer for the Texas Eastern Corporation in the face of a $53-a-share offer from the Panhandle Eastern Corporation.
The Houston-based energy company also said it might sell some or all of its stake of almost 2.5 million shares in Texas Eastern.

Washington Talk: Briefing; A Revision in Jargon
LEAD: Representative Ronald V. Dellums, a California Democrat, has long been bothered by the Pentagon's term for secret programs, budgets and operations.
They are called ''black programs'' or ''black budgets'' and Pentagon people often talk of ''operations in the black world.''

LEAD: The Energy Department, the Environmental Protection Agency and Washington State said today that they had reached an agreement to clean up radioactive and toxic wastes at the Hanford Reservation, the most contaminated of the nation's nuclear weapons plants.


Biaggi Loses Bid to Avoid Prison Term
LEAD: Former Representative Mario Biaggi's long struggle to avoid prison was lost yesterday when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear his appeal of a 1987 conviction for accepting an unlawful gratuity and obstructing justice.


Harcourt Brace in the Red Amid Its Recapitalization
LEAD: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc., the publishing company, yesterday reported a fourth-quarter loss of $53.9 million, in contrast to a profit of $95.1 million, or $1.36 a share, a year earlier.
Revenues rose to $392.8 million from $329.7 million.


Wasserstein Wins Award
LEAD: Wendy Wasserstein was awarded the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize yesterday for her play ''The Heidi Chronicles.'' She was presented the $5,000 prize by the actess Jessica Tandy during a ceremony last night at the Century Association in New York.


Housing Starts Are Off 1%
LEAD: Housing starts fell by 1 percent in the fourth quarter from the same period in 1987, and the apartment market remained especially weak, according to a private report released yesterday.

LEAD: Japan's vehicle exports in January rose 1.9 percent from a year earlier, to a total of 534,633, according to Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association statistics published today.

Skippy Peanut Butter Chooses BBDO for Ads
LEAD: After a three-month review, Best Foods has chosen BBDO New York to create advertising for Skippy peanut butter.
The company, a division of CPC International, looked initially at eight agencies before giving BBDO; Jordan, McGrath, Case &amp; Taylor; and the incumbent, Saatchi &amp; Saatchi, fees to do speculative creative work.


More Wheat to China
LEAD: China has been authorized to buy two million more metric tons of American wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department said today.
Richard W. Goldberg, the Acting Under Secretary, said the wheat would be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program.
Under the program, private exporters can sell American commodities at reduced prices to meet foreign competition in selected overseas markets and then collect free Government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses.

LEAD: Picking up its review of obscenity regulations where it left off last week, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide the constitutionality of a Dallas law barring those convicted of certain offenses from operating sexually oriented bookstores and movie theaters.

Xerox Credit Notes
LEAD: The Xerox Credit Corporation is offering $175 million of notes due 1992 through Salomon Brothers Inc.
Underwriters gave the notes a 10 1/8 percent coupon and offered them at a price of 99.90, to yield 10.165 percent, or 68 basis points more than Treasury securities with a similar maturity.
Noncallable for two years, the notes are rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A+ by the Standard &amp; Poor's Corporation.


Bush Returns from a 'Productive and Rewarding' Asian Trip


RIGHTISTS REJECT DUARTE PEACE BID
LEAD: A proposal by President Jose Napoleon Duarte to postpone elections, begin a cease-fire and meet leftist guerrillas was rejected today by a key right-wing party and by the rebels' political allies.
